text: The Palladium Pike is a Hardmode spear. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Cobalt Naginata.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Spiked Ice Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns in the Ice biome. The Spiked Ice Slime fires Ice Spikes at the player, and the Ice Spikes and the slime itself always inflict the Chilled debuff, and also have a smaller chance to inflict the Frozen debuff.

In Classic Mode, the Spiked Ice Slime only fires one Ice Spike at a time, approximately every 1.5 seconds. In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), however, it shoots 6-8 Ice Spikes around itself in a short range.
Like most other slimes, the Spiked Ice Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.

The Flesh Cloning Vat is a Hardmode crafting station used to craft Flesh furniture (Crimson -themed furniture) out of Flesh Blocks. The Flesh Cloning Vat can be purchased from the Steampunker for 10 GC, but only appears for sale in worlds that are generated with the Crimson. It can also be crafted from the Decay Chamber, its Corruption counterpart.
Flesh Blocks are crafted using a Meat Grinder, so the Flesh Cloning Vat is of little use without one.

A crafting station allows players to craft various items. Entering the inventory screen displays the "crafting window" in the lower-left, and when the player is standing near one or more crafting stations and possesses the right crafting ingredients, the bar is expanded with additional item choices.
Nearly all crafting stations are furniture. There are 44 crafting stations in total.

Wire is a unique item generally used to connect mechanisms to triggers, like a Pressure Plate, Timer, Switch, or Lever. Wires are placed using Wrenches (or their upgrades), and are retrieved using the Wire Cutter (or its upgrades), both of which can only be obtained from the Mechanic. Wire placed by differently colored Wrenches will be of different colors, which allows independent wire paths to overlap without interfering with each other.

While Wire is available for purchase from the Mechanic for 5 SC each, it can also be obtained from naturally-occurring mechanisms, which exist sparsely in the Caverns and more frequently in the Dungeon and Jungle Temple, such as in traps and Chain Lantern /Switch arrangements.

Wires occupy their own dedicated placement layer, and so can occupy the same tile space as blocks, walls, furniture, plants, and liquids. Wires can be placed in midair, without the need for support. Explosions have no effect on placed Wires.

By default, placed Wires are invisible unless the player holds a mechanism-related item as the tool in hand, (e.g., a Pressure Plate, Wrench, or even a stack of Wire itself). However, if the player is carrying a Mechanical Lens (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (or its upgrade, The Grand Design (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) they can not only see Wires at will, but can control the visibility of individual Wire colors.

With Wrenches and Wire Cutters, the player's Wire placing and cutting reach is roughly 25 tiles horizontally and vertically. With The Grand Design, the player can place or cut Wire anywhere on the screen.

Wires are considered "connected" to triggers and mechanisms when they are placed in the same tile space as those items. Usually, this is indicated by the Wire and the item visually "touching", though not all items fully occupy their tile space (e.g. certain statues).
Wire is considered " ammunition " for Wrenches, and can therefore be placed in the ammo slots of a player's inventory.

The Lead Hammer is a hammer. It is one tier below Silver, but it is one tier above Tin. Like all hammers, it is used to remove background walls and create sloped tiles and half tiles. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Iron Hammer.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

Angler armor is an armor set consisting of the Angler Hat, Angler Vest, and Angler Pants. Each piece of the set provides to increase Fishing Power by 5 and can be received as a reward for completing fishing quests given by the Angler. Although its effects on fishing are useful throughout the game, it only rewards a total of 4 defense.
On the Desktop version, Console version, Mobile version, and Nintendo 3DS version, The hat is given at 10 quests completed, the vest piece at 15, and the pants at 20.
On the Old-gen console version, The hat is given at 20 quests completed, the vest piece at 30, and the pants at 40.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Wearing the full set provides a set bonus which reduces enemy spawn rates by 23% and the maximum number of enemies by 30%.
Ancient Cloth is an uncommon Hardmode crafting material which has a 1/10 (10%) chance of dropping from all types of Ghouls. Its sole purpose is to craft the Ancient set.
The Gold Seahorse is a harmless critter. It is a golden recolor of the ordinary Seahorse, with a 1/400 (0.25%) chance of spawning in place of the ordinary version.
The Gold Seahorse has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Gold Seahorse can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Gold Seahorse Cage). Once crafted, the Gold Seahorse cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Gold Seahorse itself or the crafted furniture can be sold for 10 GC.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.
Meteorite furniture are furniture items crafted from Meteorite Bricks, which in turn are crafted from Meteorite and Stone Blocks at a Furnace. There are 20 different Meteorite furniture items.
Burning Hades Dye is a Hardmode dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. When applied, it turns the item orange and adds fire effects.

Luminite Chainsaws are tools which are currently unobtainable. All of the chainsaws share the same stats. The four types are the Solar Flare Chainsaw, Vortex Chainsaw, Nebula Chainsaw, and the Stardust Chainsaw, each themed after different Celestial Pillars. They are all unable to be crafted, and instead the player must craft the Luminite Hamaxes.
Like all axes and chainsaws, they are used to cut down Trees, Cacti, and Giant Glowing Mushrooms, so the best possible modifier is Godly.

With current methods, it is impossible to hack these items into a character's inventory using external editors, as they will disappear from that character's inventory as soon as they load into a world.

The Golden Lock Box is a grab bag item that is always obtained from Dungeon or Stockade Crates. It always contains one rare item normally found in locked Gold Chests in the Dungeon. It requires one Golden Key to open, which can be obtained from any Dungeon enemy, generally a Dungeon Slime.

Due to the fact players will likely have several remaining keys even after unlocking every single locked chest in the Dungeon, the Lock Box can prove useful for obtaining more loot, especially if there was a Dungeon-exclusive item that did not spawn in a player's world.

The Sroller is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Solar Pillar during the Lunar Events. It can curl into a ball, start spinning and hurls itself at the player, gaining increased defense and dealing high contact damage, similarly to a Giant Tortoise or Ice Tortoise. The Sroller can also create explosions on impact with blocks, dealing even higher area of effect damage.

Cogs are Hardmode crafting materials and placeable blocks that are purchased from the Steampunker for 7 SC each. They are used to make High Velocity Bullets, Liquid Sensors and the Steampunk furniture set.

When Cogs are placed together they will display animated machinery. Corners, lines, and junctions will never be animated, though blocks inside the group of Cogs and the left border will always be animated and other borders are sometimes animated with a 2/3 (66.67%) chance.
Crafting all Steampunk furniture will require 159 (Desktop version) / 153 (Old-gen console version, Mobile version) / 33 (Nintendo 3DS version) Cogs.
Flounders are a type of fish which are found plentifully by fishing in the Desert biome. Their sole use is to craft Sashimi.

The War Axe of the Night is an axe crafted from Demonite Bars. It is stronger than the Gold and Platinum Axes, but weaker than the Meteor Hamaxe. It has a Crimtane counterpart, the Blood Lust Cluster. Like all axes, it is used to cut down Trees, Cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Money Trough is a portable storage item that temporarily summons a flying pet -like version of the Piggy Bank. The Money Trough enables players to access the contents of their Piggy Bank without having to manually place the Piggy Bank or any furniture for it to rest on. The floating Piggy Bank despawns after 3 minutes, but can be re-summoned repeatedly at no cost. The Flying Piggy Bank does not follow the player like pets or minions would, instead it hovers stationarily at the point summoned. Once summoned, other players may use it as well to access their own Piggy Bank.

The Money Trough has a 1/200 (0.5%) / 1/100 (1%) chance of being dropped by Blood Zombies and Dripplers during a Blood Moon, or with a much lower (1/4000 (0.03%) / 1/2000 (0.05%)) chance from their statue -spawned versions (regardless of whether a Blood Moon is occurring). It also has a 1/15 (6.67%) chance of being dropped by Wandering Eye Fish and Zombie Mermen, which can be fished up during a Blood Moon.

The Shadewood Sword is an alternate version of the Wooden Sword made using Shadewood from the Crimson biome. It is functionally identical to its Corruption counterpart, the Ebonwood Sword. Both deal slightly more damage and have a slightly increased speed compared to the Wooden Sword and its variants. With it being stronger than the other wooden swords, it can be useful early on, though one should proceed with caution, as the Crimson is a very dangerous place for players early on.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Butcher is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event. It slowly builds up speed over time, similarly to an Antlion Charger, and wields a bloodied chainsaw that deals heavy damage to players on contact.

The Uzi is a Hardmode gun that fires bullets at high velocity, with a high rate of fire, and with high damage output. Musket Balls and Tungsten Bullets (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (as well as Silver Bullets on Old-gen console and 3DS) shot from this weapon are converted into High Velocity Bullets. They gain the increased speed, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) ability to pierce targets (along with the damage reduction on subsequent hits), and visual appearance of High Velocity Bullets, but retain their original damage. The Uzi has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/100 (1%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/200 (0.5%) chance of being dropped by Angry Trappers.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Peddler's Hat is a vanity item that always drops from the Traveling Merchant if he is killed. It appears identical to the hat that the Traveling Merchant wears.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) When dropped into Shimmer, it turns into a Peddler's Satchel.
Dazed is a debuff that reduces the afflicted player's movement speed and jump height. It is not inflicted by anything during normal gameplay.
This unused debuff works similarly to the Oozed debuff from the Ogre.

The Toy Sled is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that spawns a Baby Snowman pet to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Baby Snowman will ride a toy sled to catch up to them. The Toy Sled has a 1/20 (5%) chance of being dropped by Ice Mimics.
Necro armor is a post- Skeletron armor set consisting of the Necro Helmet, Necro Breastplate, and Necro Greaves. Crafting a full set requires a total of 135 Cobwebs and 150 Bones.

The Ancient Necro Helmet is a rare drop from Angry Bones and Dark Casters in the Dungeon, with a 1/450 (0.22%) chance of dropping. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it is functionally identical to the Necro Helmet and the two helmets are interchangeable with no bonus loss.

A full set grants a total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 19 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 16 defense and (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10% critical strike chance / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 20% chance not to consume ammo. In addition, each piece increases ranged damage by 5%, increasing ranged damage by a total of 15%. It is one of only two ranged-specific pre-Hardmode armor sets on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, the other being Fossil armor. This set provides the highest offensive bonuses for the class prior to Hardmode. On Old-gen console and 3DS, it is the only ranged armor set available in pre-Hardmode.

If the full set is worn, the player leaves an afterimage while running just like full Shadow armor. In addition, the sound the player makes when taking certain types of damage will be the same as for a Skeleton https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:NPC_Hit_2.wav.
The Gold Ladybug is a harmless critter. It is a golden recolor of the ordinary Ladybug, with a 1/400 (0.25%) chance of spawning in place of the ordinary version.
The Gold Ladybug has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Gold Ladybug can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Gold Ladybug Cage). Once crafted, the Gold Ladybug cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Gold Ladybug itself or the crafted furniture can be sold for 10 GC.
The Gold Ladybug can be used as bait for fishing, with 50% bait power.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.
Argon Moss Brick Wall is a brick background wall that glows in the dark like Argon Moss and the Argon Moss Brick it is made from.
The Celestial Emblem is a Hardmode accessory that offers 15% increased magic damage and a 18.75-tile increased pickup range for Stars (21.375 tile total range).
The Amethyst Robe is an armor item that can be worn in the shirt slot. It is part of the Wizard set and is the weakest type of gem robe.

Wearing the Wizard Hat alongside the Amethyst Robe provides a set bonus of +10% magic critical strike chance, whereas wearing a Magic Hat alongside it provides a set bonus of +60 mana. Any leg-slot equipment can be worn with these set bonuses remaining intact.

The Terraprisma is a Hardmode, post- Plantera summon weapon that spawns a detached copy of itself, a Terraprisma minion, that rapidly attacks nearby enemies by performing an extremely quick stab before constantly attacking with a spinning motion, similar to the Zenith, until the target is dead. This pattern will repeat each time the sword changes targets. The Terraprisma is a guaranteed drop from the Empress of Light when all damage dealt to the boss occurs during the day.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Terraprisma has over a Ruthless one is knockback.
The Format:C is a Hardmode yoyo that can be purchased from the Skeleton Merchant for 20 GC during moon phases 5-8.
It has a spin duration of 8 seconds and can reach up to 14.5 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Architect Gizmo Pack is an accessory which increases block and wall placement speed and reach and automatically paints placed objects, essentially granting all of the effects of the accessories used to craft it. All four items required to create the Architect Gizmo Pack are sold by the Traveling Merchant for 40 GC in total.

The Weather Radio is an informational accessory that displays the current weather and wind speed on the Surface, even if the player is in the Underground, Cavern, or Underworld layers. The Weather Radio can be recieved from the Angler NPC as a 1/34 (2.94%) chance reward for completing a Fishing quest for the Angler NPC, depending on the number of completed quests and other factors (for details, see Angler).

The Angler will not give the player a Weather Radio as a reward if they already have one in their inventory or in any of their portable storage items or loadouts. However, if the player has all of the Angler's fishing and informational accessories (or their upgrades like the Angler Tackle Bag and Fish Finder) in their inventories, this rule will be ignored.

The Weather Radio is one of the three parts necessary to make the Fish Finder, with the others being the Sextant and the Fisherman's Pocket Guide, and as such is a required ingredient in crafting the Shellphone.

The Sky Fracture is a Hardmode magic weapon that summons three energy swords per use in quick succession from behind the player, aiming at the cursor's location. Each projectile can hit one enemy or block before it disappears. Unlike the Magic Missile from which it is crafted, the energy blades cannot be controlled. The Sky Fracture has a base 24% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Palladium armor is a Hardmode armor set crafted from Palladium Bars and is the alternative to Cobalt armor.

The set consists of the Palladium Breastplate and Palladium Leggings, as well as three different headpiece variants: the Palladium Mask, Palladium Helmet, and Palladium Headgear, geared towards melee, ranged, and magic damage respectively.

With the full set equipped, hitting an enemy grants the Rapid Healing buff, which heals (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 2 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 3 health per second. This lasts for 5 seconds, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen. Further attacks will refresh the duration. The buff is not canceled if the armor is removed.
Crafting a one-headpiece set requires 54 Palladium Bars, or 162 Palladium Ore. Crafting all five pieces requires 78 Palladium Bars, or 234 Palladium Ore.

The Palladium Pickaxe is a Hardmode pickaxe, and is the pickaxe alternative to the Palladium Drill, having a slower mining speed but longer range and benefiting from mining speed bonuses. Its alternate ore version, the Cobalt Pickaxe, is slightly weaker than the Palladium Pickaxe.

It can mine any block except Adamantite Ore, Titanium Ore, Chlorophyte Ore, and Lihzahrd Bricks. On the Nintendo 3DS version, however, it can still mine Titanium Ore and Adamantite Ore, providing significant help in progressing through the game at an early stage.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Deactivated Probe is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that spawns a small version of The Destroyer named Destroyer-Lite as a pet that follows the player around. The Deactivated Probe has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped from The Destroyer in Master Mode.
The Tsunami in a Bottle is an accessory which can be found in Wooden, Iron, Pearlwood (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Mythril Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Similar to the Cloud in a Bottle, it allows the player to double-jump. Instead of a cloud beneath the player's feet, it creates burst of water when jumping. The Tsunami jump goes 7 tiles into the air, totalling 13 tiles when put together with the first jump.

Grandfather Clocks are furniture items which provide information about the in-game time. If a player is nearby a Grandfather Clock (about 80 tiles horizontally and 50 tiles vertically), the time is displayed on the right side of the screen, underneath the minimap. The time is rounded to the last hour, similar to Tin and Copper Watches, but pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on it will show precise time in minutes as a status message on the bottom left corner.

There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 36 / (Old-gen console version) 21 / 5 craftable versions and (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 5 / (Old-gen console version) 2 noncraftable (but still lootable) versions. The regular Grandfather Clock can rarely be found in Underground Cabins. All are functionally identical, and differ only in their appearance.

Thrown Powders are consumable items that can be used to convert blocks and walls between their Crimson, Corrupt, or (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Hallowed forms. When thrown, they release a cloud of sparkling powder with a very short range, comparable to that of a broadsword, and produce a fair amount of light. Thrown Powder comes in three variants:

Purification Powder is able to revert any Corrupted or Crimson Blocks, but not walls, back into their pure form, such as reverting Ebonstone into Stone or Crimsand into Sand. It is purchased solely from the Dryad for 75 CC each, while a Blood Moon is not active.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Purification Powder can also be used on a Tortured Soul in order to transform him into the Tax Collector NPC, as well as on a Mystic Frog to transform it into the Mystic Slime town pet.
Unlike Holy Water and Blue Solution, Purification Powder cannot spread or purify the Hallow.

Vile Powder is able to convert blocks and walls, including the Crimson and the Hallowed ones, into their (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Corrupted form / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) pure form, such as converting Pearlstone into (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Ebonstone / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Stone. If thrown at a Bunny, Penguin, or Goldfish, it will turn into its Corrupted variants: the Corrupt Bunny, Corrupt Penguin, and Corrupt Goldfish, respectively. It can be crafted from Vile Mushrooms or purchased from the Dryad for 1 SC each during a Blood Moon in a Corrupt world.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Vile Powder can be used to spread the Corruption onto convertible tiles.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Unlike Unholy Water and Purple Solution, Vile Powder cannot spread the Corruption.

Vicious Powder (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is functionally identical to its counterpart, Vile Powder, to where it can convert blocks and walls, including the Corrupted and the Hallowed ones, into their Crimson form. If thrown at a Bunny, Penguin, or Goldfish, it will turn into its Crimson variants: the Vicious Bunny, Vicious Penguin, and Vicious Goldfish, respectively. It can be crafted from Vicious Mushrooms or purchased from the Dryad for 1 SC each during a Blood Moon in a Crimson world.
Vicious Powder can be used to spread the Crimson onto convertible tiles.

The Boreal Wood Bow is a type of bow crafted from Boreal Wood. It is similar to the Wooden Bow, but it deals 2 more damage and has a higher velocity. Because Snow biomes are usually not too far from the initial spawn point, a Boreal Wood Bow can be a superior alternative to its standard counterpart.

Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console version) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.
Bee Wax is a crafting material dropped by the Queen Bee. It cannot be crafted or placed. It takes 44 to craft a set of Bee armor and the Hornet Staff, which amounts to killing Queen Bee 2-3 times.
Poo Wall is a type of background wall crafted using Poo.

The Sawtooth Shark is a type of chainsaw that can be found when fishing in an Ocean biome. It can be caught at a rate of 1/100 (1%) with 50% Fishing Power and 1/50 (2%) with 100% Fishing Power. In terms of axe power, it is equal to the Cobalt Chainsaw.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Titanium Crate is the highest tier of standard Crate in Hardmode. It offers the most valuable rewards and sells for the most coins when sold to an NPC of the three standard crates. Like other crates, it is obtained by fishing. Its pre-Hardmode counterpart is the Golden Crate.

Confused is a debuff which causes the player's controls to reverse. When applied to a player, ◀ Left acts as ▲ Up and ▶ Right ; ▶ Right acts as ◀ Left ; ▲ Up acts as ▼ Down, and ▼ Down has no effect. See Notes for more detailed control behavior. When applied to enemies, a question mark appears above them, and causes them to move away from the player rather than towards them. Enemies with ranged attacks will be unable to use those attacks. The debuff can be prevented with the Trifold Map (and by extension, anything crafted from it), which is dropped by most enemies that cause the debuff.
About 70% of enemies and the entirety of bosses in Terraria are immune to the Confused debuff. Many of the vulnerable enemies include slimes, bats, and most fighters.

The Princess is a Hardmode, post- Plantera NPC vendor who sells royal-themed vanity items and furniture, and is typically the final town NPC that the player encounters. She will move in once the following criteria have been met:

There is an available vacant house. All other town NPCs (not including Santa Claus or town pets) are present, meaning that she can only move in after defeating Plantera, which is also the condition for the Cyborg to move in.
These requirements only apply to the initial spawning. If the Princess is killed, she will automatically respawn after some time.
The Princess will attack nearby enemies with the Resonance Scepter, for which she has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of dropping upon death if the current world is in Hardmode.
The Clothier is an NPC vendor who mainly sells vanity items. He will move in once the following criteria have been met:
There is an available vacant house. Skeletron has been defeated.

He is the same character as the Old Man who guards the Dungeon before Skeletron is defeated. After defeating Skeletron, the Old Man is freed from his curse, and he disappears from the Dungeon's entrance. His clothes are no longer tattered, his eyes have turned blue (from red), and he is wearing a Red Hat. Equipping the Clothier Voodoo Doll allows the player to attack and kill the Clothier (similar to the Guide Voodoo Doll) with any damage-inflicting item. Doing so at night re-summons Skeletron, but killing the Clothier without the Clothier Voodoo Doll equipped (such as by using the Flymeal (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) on its own) will not summon the boss.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Clothier fires shadowflame skull projectiles to defend himself from enemies. They inflict enemies with the Shadowflame debuff for 5-10 seconds and deal 16 / 24 / 28 damage at the start of the game, but as the player progresses, the Clothier will gain various stat increases.

The Mystic Robe (Gypsy Robe on Old-gen console) is an armor item that can be worn in the shirt slot. It provides minimal defense (2) but a 6% damage and critical strike boost to magic weapons, along with a 10% reduction in mana use. It is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 3 GC 50 SC (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 2 GC (Old-gen console version).

Wearing the Wizard Hat alongside the robe provides a set bonus of +10% magic critical strike chance, while wearing a Magic Hat alongside it provides a set bonus of +60 Mana. Any leg-slot equipment can be worn with these set bonuses intact.
Obsidian armor is an armor set that consists of the Obsidian Outlaw Hat, Obsidian Longcoat, and the Obsidian Pants.
A full set of Obsidian armor provides the following benefits:
+15 defense +31% summon damage +1 minion slot +15% whip speed +30% whip range
Crafting a full set requires a total of 60 Obsidian, 30 Silk, and 20 Shadow Scales or Tissue Samples.
Shadow Scales are a crafting material dropped from the Eater of Worlds. They can be used in conjunction with Demonite Bars to create Demonite tools and the Shadow armor set.
A total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 121 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 56 Shadow Scales are required to craft one of each item.

The Sandstone Brick Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Pyramids. It drops as an item when destroyed, and can also be obtained via crafting. It is always considered a safe wall.
Crimtane Bars are pre-Hardmode bars crafted using Crimtane Ore at a Furnace. They are used to make Crimson tier items. Crimtane Bars are the Crimson equivalent of The Corruption 's Demonite Bars.
Crafting all Crimson equipment requires (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 140 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 128 Crimtane Bars and 61 Tissue Samples.

The Cream Soda is a food item that grants the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 16 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The Cream Soda has a 1/70 (1.43%) chance of being dropped by Cursed Skulls, and a 1/35 (2.86%) chance of being dropped by Giant Cursed Skulls.
Like all other food items, the Cream Soda can be placed on a Plate :

Chinese New Year was an unimplemented Mobile -exclusive seasonal event. For unknown reasons, it never took place, existing only in the form of assets that could not be encountered during normal gameplay. It was later removed alongside all other Mobile-exclusive seasonal events when the version updated to 1.3.

Jungle Grass Seeds are a type of seed that can be planted in Mud Blocks to grow Jungle grass, potentially creating an artificial Jungle or Underground Jungle (depending on depth) if enough Jungle grass and plants are created. Jungle Grass Seeds can be found by cutting down plants growing on Jungle grass using virtually any tool or weapon.
A Lens is a common crafting material that has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to drop from Demon Eyes and Wandering Eyes.

Midnight Confetti Walls are a type of background wall made from Midnight Confetti Blocks. They depict falling confetti.They are one of only a few animated background walls. Confetti Walls are a transparent version of them.
Martian furniture are furniture items crafted from Martian Conduit Plating, which are dropped by enemies during the Martian Madness event. There are 20 different Martian furniture items.

Meteorite is a type of ore mined from Meteorite crash sites. Crash sites are not generated upon world creation, but instead generated throughout the game based on certain conditions. Mining Meteorite requires a Tungsten Pickaxe or better. Additionally, Meteor Heads also have a 1/50 (2%) chance to drop a single piece of Meteorite, though only in pre-Hardmode.
Crash sites can occur anywhere, accompanied by a status message " A meteorite has landed! ". Meteorite is required to craft Meteorite Bars.

Contact with Meteorite blocks causes the player to be inflicted with the Burning debuff, unless the player has the Obsidian Skull accessory (or its upgrades) equipped, or is using an Obsidian Skin Potion. Meteorite can be mined without these defenses, and the ore is safe to collect once mined.

Any area with at least (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 75 / (Old-gen console version) 50 / (3DS version) 23 Meteorite blocks in close proximity (e.g. a natural crash site) becomes a Meteorite biome, which will spawn Meteor Heads.
Reef Walls are a type of background wall. They are crafted with Reef Blocks at a Work Bench.

The Bunny is a town pet. It arrives at dawn (4:30 AM) the day after the player uses the Bunny License, which is purchased from the Zoologist for 5 GC. The Bunny does not count towards the NPCs ' "crowded" limit and hence will not affect NPC happiness, although it does count as a regular town NPC for the purpose of the Pylon network. There are six breeds of Bunny, with one randomly being chosen when it arrives.

The only requirements for the Bunny to appear is the use of a Bunny License and the presence of a valid house. The Bunny's house can be changed, as with any other NPC, however the Bunny can share the same house as another NPC. Like other NPCs, the Bunny also require a valid standing point in the house (a home tile). It may not be able to share a house with another NPC if the house is too small.

The Bunny can be talked to with the ⚷ Open / Activate button, like any other town NPC. It will offer a " Pet " option, which places the player directly in front of the Bunny when selected, and displays an animation of them petting the Bunny, an effect that is a purely visual. It only works if there are at least two flat tiles on the same level as the Bunny in front of it. Using any item, taking damage, or closing the dialogue window terminates the animation.
Like the Angler and the Princess, the status message displayed when the Bunny is killed is " <name of Bunny> has left! ". It will respawn within the next days, and may respawn as a different breed.

The Tomb Crawler is a pre-Hardmode worm enemy found in the Underground Desert. Following the same AI pattern as Giant Worms, it moves through solid blocks to attack the player by charging. The sound of its burrowing grows louder and faster as it draws near. Like many other worm-type enemies, its head segment deals more damage on contact, but is also the part of its body most vulnerable to damage. It is the pre-Hardmode counterpart of the Dune Splicer.

The Hive Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Bee Hives, considered unsafe. It drops as an item when destroyed, and can also be obtained via crafting. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player. Unlike Hive blocks, it does not need a Hive Wand to be placed.
can not be collected on the Xbox 360 edition

A Logic Gate Lamp is a mechanism that is placed atop a Logic Gate or another Logic Gate Lamp. The Logic Gate is activated based on its type and the states of the Logic Gate Lamps atop it. The state of a Logic Gate Lamp is toggled via wire. The Logic Gate Lamps, along with the Logic Gates, are purchased from the Steampunker.
The Lesion Block Wall is a type of background walls. Like most walls, they will stop enemy spawning, and can be used for NPC houses.
Stone Wall is a background wall made from Stone Blocks. Like other walls, it stops enemies from spawning when it is placed and can be used for houses.

The Swamp Thing is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event, during which he is about as common as Zombies. He moves very fast and occasionally stops in place, leaving him vulnerable to attacks.

Suffocation is a debuff that is inflicted when the player is submerged in falling Sand, Silt, or Slush, causing them to lose 20 health per second for as long as they are submerged. Drowning will not inflict this debuff. Red damage numbers bounce like other debuffs that inflict continuous damage.

Worm Food is a boss-summoning item used to summon the Eater of Worlds. Worm Food can only be used in the Corruption or Underground Corruption, and attempting to use it outside of the Corruption will have no effect and will not consume it.

The Clinger is a Hardmode enemy found in the Underground Corruption biome. Clingers spawn anchored to a block, with their head attached to an extendable "stem" that does not damage the player. They attack by launching orbs of Cursed Flames at the player, which can inflict the Cursed Inferno debuff.

The Mushroom Spear is a Hardmode spear that summons seven spinning mushroom projectiles when used. The projectiles linger in midair and deal 33.33% of the spear's damage (20 base damage) but do not inflict knockback. Although the mushroom projectiles appear to visually fade out, they will always inflict their full damage. They will disappear 1.07 seconds after being spawned by the spear, if they do not hit an enemy beforehand. The Mushroom Spear can be purchased from the Truffle for 70 GC after at least one of the mechanical bosses has been defeated.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

Orichalcum Bars are Hardmode bars crafted from 4 Orichalcum Ore. They are needed to make the Orichalcum Anvil, a crafting station needed to create most Hardmode equipment. Orichalcum is the equivalent to Mythril.
Crafting all Orichalcum equipment, including the anvil, requires 186 Orichalcum Bars, or a total of 744 Orichalcum Ore. Without the anvil, 174 bars, or 696 ore, will be needed.

Adamantite Ore is one of the two top-tier ores that can spawn from every third destroyed Altar in Hardmode (the other possible ore being Titanium). In worlds where it spawns, it is the rarest and most valuable of the three Altar-spawned ores.

A Mythril / Orichalcum Drill, Mythril / Orichalcum Pickaxe, Palladium Pickaxe / Palladium Drill or better is required in order to mine Adamantite. An Adamantite Forge, crafted from 30 Adamantite Ore and one Hellforge, is required in order to craft Adamantite Bars.
Adamantite Ore, as well as Adamantite Bars, can also be obtained by opening crates, eliminating the need for a higher-tier pickaxe.
Adamantite Ore is also dropped by Ocram (Old-gen console and 3DS versions).

Crafting all Adamantite items requires 174 Adamantite Bars, plus thirty raw ore for an Adamantite Forge, for a total of 696 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 900 (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Adamantite Ore.
Spider Nest Blocks are Hardmode blocks crafted from one Spider Fang and 10 Cobwebs at a Work Bench. They are used to craft Spider furniture and Spider Nest Walls.
Crafting all items requires 153 Spider Nest Blocks.

Aggro, short for aggression or aggravation, is an invisible statistic that determines the distance at which enemies will begin to attack the player. Terraria features various items that can alter this statistic when equipped.
All enemies target the player based on criteria set in their AI. Most will constantly try to find a target, while others may only target if the player is in water, for example.
Armor and other items that "increase/decrease enemy targeting" cause enemies to consider a player to be closer or farther away than they actually are.
If the Eternia Crystal (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is present, the Old One's Army will target it by default, only targeting the player if they get "in the way".

Cursor modes are a type of game mechanic in Terraria. Auto Select and Smart Cursor are the two major cursor modes implemented to make using tools and placing objects more convenient. Additionally, there are several special sprites for the cursor that appear when specific hotkey is pressed, informing the player the current function of the cursor.
The Iron Shortsword is an early game metal shortsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Lead Shortsword.

Like all shortswords, the Iron Shortsword has a very limited range and attacks with a stabbing motion at any direction on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, and horizontally in front of the player on Old-gen console and 3DS, instead of an arc. This makes it almost useless against flying or jumping enemies, although its high attack rate makes it somewhat effective against weaker fighter type enemies.
In Journey Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), newly created characters spawn with an Iron Shortsword instead of a Copper Shortsword.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
Fishing foods are consumable food items crafted from various fish caught during fishing. They grant either the Well Fed or Plenty Satisfied (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) buff when consumed.

There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) six / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) three variations: Cooked Fish, Cooked Shrimp, Sashimi, Seafood Dinner (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Lobster Tail (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Shucked Oyster (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Like all other food items, they can be placed on Plates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) :

The Geyser is a trap that spews a vertical stream of fire which deals a base damage of 40 / 80 / 120 and a knockback of 2 (Very weak). It will activate when a player touches it or when it is triggered via wire. Geysers are found naturally-placed in random areas that are deep enough to generate lava, including the Underworld and deeper Cavern areas. They are generated without Pressure Plates or wires attached to them.
Geysers consume no ammunition, and their output is limited only by a cooldown period of 3.33 seconds. Geyser streams extend approximately 20 tiles up or down, depending on placement.
Geysers can be placed on the top or bottom of blocks, facing upward or downward respectively, but not sideways.
The Meteor Shot is a type of bullet used by guns. When fired, it can either bounce from a solid block once or pierce through one enemy, but not both.

The Mother Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns in the Cavern layer. Upon death, it spawns 1-3 Baby Slimes, and like all slimes, drops Gel. It is one of the largest ordinary slimes in the game, only topped by King Slime, Queen Slime, and the Rainbow Slime.
Like most other slimes, the Mother Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.

The Rainbow Rod is a Hardmode magic weapon that launches a controllable projectile, just like the Flamelash or Magic Missile, and can be considered an upgraded version of them. The projectile can be controlled by holding ⚒ Use / Attack and moving the cursor. If ⚒ Use / Attack is released mid-drag, the missile will be flung in that direction. If the cursor is stationary on release, it continues along the angle formed by the player.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the projectile is a white-sparkling missile with a rainbow trail, and it emits a moderate amount of light that rotates through the entire color spectrum. If any enemies are nearby, the missile will home in on them. The missile will not disappear when touching a block if it is being manually controlled. It can move through liquids (unlike the Flamelash), and can pierce twice before exploding and dealing damage in a small area.
On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the projectile is a light orb shifting through rainbow colors with a rainbow trail.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Spectre Bars are Hardmode bars crafted from Chlorophyte Bars and Ectoplasm. They are used to make the Spectre gear, tools, and painting tools.
Crafting all items requires 176 Spectre Bars (88 Ectoplasm and 176 Chlorophyte Bars, or 880 ores).
The Crimstone Brick Wall is a placeable item that looks like a blood-stained brick wall.

The Mechanic is an NPC vendor who sells wire, actuators, and various mechanisms, as well as Wire Cutters and Wrenches, allowing the player to construct and activate wired devices like traps and critter engines. She will move in once the following criteria have been met:

There is an available vacant house. Rescuing her as the Bound Mechanic, who can be rarely encountered in the Dungeon in the Cavern layer and below after Skeletron has been defeated. Interacting with her in this state with ⚷ Open / Activate will free her. If the Bound Mechanic is killed, she will still be able to respawn afterwards; if the Mechanic NPC is killed, she will move in again after some time as long as there are vacant houses.

On the Desktop, Console, and Mobile versions, the Mechanic uses the Combat Wrench to defend herself, dealing 11 / 16 / 19 damage at the start of the game, and as players progress she will gain various stat increases. The Mechanic also has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of dropping the Combat Wrench upon death.
The Bound Mechanic is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

Pearlwood furniture are furniture items crafted from Pearlwood, obtained by cutting down Hallow Trees found in The Hallow. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 20 / (Old-gen console version) 18 / (3DS version) 15 different Pearlwood furniture items.

The Blizzard in a Balloon is an accessory that combines the effects of the Blizzard in a Bottle and the Shiny Red Balloon. It boosts jump height by 33% and jump speed by 30%, increasing your first jump's height to ~10½ blocks (~75% increase), and provides a double jump that now goes 14½ blocks, for a total height of 25 blocks.
Jump height is oddly reduced when underwater, reducing your total underwater height from 19 blocks (8 + 11 from Blizzard jump) to 16 blocks (7 + 9 from Blizzard jump).

The Clockwork Assault Rifle is a Hardmode gun that fires bullets in three-round bursts. Only the first shot out of the three will consume ammunition. The ⚒ Use / Attack button can be held for repeated fire. The Clockwork Assault Rifle has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by the Wall of Flesh.

Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.

The Ogre Mask is an unobtainable item. It is extremely similar in both name and appearance to the obtainable Ogre Mask. It only exists as an ID and image file in the game's code and therefore does nothing. Attempting to use third-party tools to obtain it will result in it instantly disappearing.
Palm Wood armor is an armor set that consists of the Palm Wood Helmet, Palm Wood Breastplate, and Palm Wood Greaves.

Making this armor set requires the player to chop down Palm trees, which can grow naturally in the Ocean and Oasis (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) biomes or be manually planted using Acorns on Sand Blocks. Like the other Wood armor sets, it is fairly weak, and only useful very early on. It does provide a one defense bonus over the normal Wood armor, meaning if the player comes across the Oasis early on, it may be a wise idea to chop down Palm tree to make this armor set as a minor upgrade.
Wearing a full set grants a basic 3 defense plus a set bonus of 1 defense, which equals a total of 4 defense.
Crafting a full set requires a total of 75 Palm Wood.
The Moon Mask is a vanity headpiece dropped by Lamias in Underground Deserts tainted with The Corruption or The Crimson.

Shadow armor is an armor set that consists of the Shadow Helmet, Shadow Scalemail, and Shadow Greaves. The individual pieces provide a total of 19 defense, equal to its Crimson counterpart, Crimson armor.

On Desktop, Console, and Mobile, each of the 3 pieces provide a +5% boost to universal critical strike chance (for a total of +15%). Wearing all 3 pieces at once grants a 75% increase to acceleration and deceleration, and a 1.15x multiplier to the player's maximum movement speed.

On Old-gen console and 3DS, each of the 3 pieces provide a +7% boost to melee attack speed (for a total of +21%), while wearing all 3 pieces at once grants an additional set bonus of +15% movement speed.

Wearing a full set causes the player to display an afterimage effect during motion (similar to Necro armor), emit shadow particles, and will cause the Rocket Boots to emit purple flames (this does not occur with Spectre Boots or any of its derivatives).

Crafting a full set requires a total of 60 Demonite Bars (180 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 240 (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Demonite Ore) and 45 Shadow Scales. Defeating the Eater of Worlds twice can provide enough to craft a full set.
Shadow armor pieces are interchangeable with pieces from the Ancient Shadow armor set, while still providing the same 15% increased movement speed set bonus, but not the afterimage effect.
Pressure Plates are activation mechanisms that trigger wired mechanisms when stepped on. A pressure plate's color determines which characters can trigger it.

Red, Brown, Gray, Orange, and Lihzahrd Pressure Plates are randomly generated on the map during world creation as the trigger for traps. They only take up a very small space on top of blocks, so they may be difficult to spot. The color of naturally spawned pressure plates is dependent on the color of the block they are generated on top of. Except for Lihzahrd Pressure Plates, they can also be purchased from the Mechanic.

Weighted Pressure Plates activate once on being depressed, and again on being released. All Weighted Pressure Plates of the same color share a single state. As long as one Weighted Pressure Plate of a given color is already pressed down within a circuit, stepping on another identical plate will not send a new signal. They can be crafted from regular pressure plates.

The Teal Pressure Pad is a special kind of pressure plate that responds to projectiles impacting it, which includes pets that touch it. Unlike regular pressure plates, the Teal Pressure Pad can be placed on all four sides of a block, e.g. on the ceiling or sidewall. It can be purchased from the Mechanic.

Neon Tetras are a type of fish which are found commonly by fishing in the Jungle in any layer. Their sole use is to craft Seafood Dinners (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). They sell for twice what other fish in their Catch Quality do, and on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version they have no use except for this sell price.

The Ice Sickle is a Hardmode sword that fires a spinning blue sickle projectile with no ammunition or mana cost. The projectile will gradually reduce speed and eventually stop in midair, exist up to 5 seconds before disappearing, and pierce a limited number of targets. The Ice Sickle can be dropped by Armored Vikings, Ice Elementals, Ice Tortoises, and Icy Mermen, which spawn in the Snow and Ice biomes.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, its projectile deals 67% of the weapon's damage (33 base damage) and can pierce up to 3 enemies, dissipating upon hitting the fourth. Its drop chance is 1/100 (1%).

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, its projectile deals 100% of the weapon's damage (40 base damage) and can pierce up to 4 enemies, dissipating upon hitting the fifth. Its drop chance is 1/180 (0.56%).
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Aqua Scepter is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that auto-fires an arcing stream of water particles. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the projectile can pierce up to 4 targets, hitting a total of 5 targets. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the projectile can pierce an infinite number of targets.  The Aqua Scepter has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from the Locked Gold Chests found in the Dungeon, as well as a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from Golden Lock Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Aqua Scepter can be continuously used to keep enemies juggled. However, the sprite of the Aqua Scepter itself deals no damage. Therefore, an enemy too close to the wielder will not get hit by the water, and simply move past the outstretched wand to hit the player.

Its best modifier is Sluggish for small single target or small groups and Mythical for large single target or large groups. Due to invincibility frames, a Sluggish Aqua Scepter actually hits enemies at a far higher rate than any other modifier, giving better DPS.

Hairstyles determine how the player's hair appears. A limited set of hairstyles are available during character creation, while all (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 165 / (Old-gen console version) 123 are available for purchase from the Stylist (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions). Hair color can also be chosen at character creation, or through the Stylist.

The Builder Potion is a buff potion which grants the Builder buff when consumed. The buff increases tile and wall placement speed by 25% and extends placement range by 1 tile. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 45 minutes / (Old-gen console version) 15 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
In addition to being crafted, Builder Potions can be found in pots and chests.

The Phaseblade is a pre-Hardmode sword. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) seven / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) six different color variations with identical statistics, with the color determined by the type of gem used to craft it. All Phaseblades emit a small amount of light when swung.
The Phasesaber is the Hardmode upgrade of the Phaseblade, being directly crafted from it.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
Neon Moss Brick Wall is a brick background wall that glows in the dark like Neon Moss and the Neon Moss Brick it is made from.
The Power Glove is a Hardmode accessory that doubles melee knockback and adds 12% increased melee speed. It simply combines the effects of Feral Claws and Titan Glove with no benefits lost.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Additionally, the Power Glove enables autoswing on all melee weapons and whips and increases the size of all melee weapons by 10%.

Hunger is a gameplay mechanic that is only present in The Constant and Get fixed boi secret worlds. It consists of three stages, indicated by separate debuffs. The first stage appears immediately after world creation, but has no actual effect. After some time, the second and third stages are reached, which reduce the player's stats and eventually make the player continuously lose health.
Consuming any type of food temporarily disables hunger. The debuff will be suppressed for the duration of the food buff, but once the buff expires, the first stage of hunger will appear again.
Eating a Mushroom while hunger is active also resets the debuff to the beginning of the first stage.
At the beginning of each stage, a corresponding emote will appear.
The Tin Watch is a low-tier watch. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Copper Watch.

When equipped in an accessory slot or simply held in the inventory, a clock will appear in the upper-right corner of the playing screen, revealing the in-game time accurate to the last hour. An hour of Terraria game time is equivalent to one minute of real-world time. The Tin Watch can be used to craft the 5 Second Timer.

The FPV Goggles are a Hardmode, post- Plantera accessory purchased from the Cyborg for 10 GC. It centers the screen on the Kwad Racer Drone while one is active, allowing the player to fly the drone without having to keep it within the screen, or to use it to scout out areas that are difficult to reach.

The Spiky Ball is a consumable ranged weapon that is primarily used as a passive trap by tossing them to the ground, where enemies who pass over them will take damage up to (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 6 / (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 7 times (after which the Spiky Balls vanish). If not destroyed, they will automatically vanish after one minute. They can also be directly thrown at enemies, but they have a very short arc and quickly fall to the ground. Spiky Balls are dropped by all goblins during the Goblin Army event (except for the Goblin Warlock (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) and can be purchased from the Goblin Tinkerer for 80 CC each.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Goblin Tinkerer uses Spiky Balls to defend himself against nearby enemies.

The Bomb is an explosive which can be purchased from the Demolitionist and Skeleton Merchant for 3 SC each or obtained from Pots, Chests, slimes, by powering Bomb Statues, or as a drop from Undead Miners with a 18/25 (72%) chance. It can be used as a mining tool or a weapon, although generally the former. When used, it is thrown a few blocks away from the player and rolls if the terrain allows it. After 3 seconds, it will explode, inflicting 100 points of damage to nearby enemies and destroying multiple blocks around it. The player can also inflict harm to themselves if they are not careful.

Bombs can destroy almost any block, with some exceptions, which can then be collected. They can also be thrown through one-block thick walls, like some other tossables. Additionally, Bombs also work underwater.
It has a small chance to appear as a bonus drop (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) from slimes.

The Artisan Loaf is a permanent booster item that permanently increases the range that the player can access crafting stations by 4 tiles in all directions. The Artisan Loaf can be purchased from the Skeleton Merchant for 10 GC during a Waning Crescent, New Moon, or Waxing Crescent. It can also only be used once per player, and the Skeleton Merchant will cease to sell it once the player has consumed an Artisan Loaf.
The Golf Tee is a furniture item used in golfing purchased from the Golfer for 1 GC. It assists in placement of Golf Balls, and balls struck from a Golf Tee will travel further.
Pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on a Golf Tee places a Golf Ball on top of it.

The Finch Staff is a pre- Hardmode summon weapon that summons a Baby Finch minion. It attacks by flying towards enemies and dealing contact damage. Like other minions, the summoned Baby Finch is invincible and follows the player until they die, summon a replacement minion, cancel the buff, or leave the world. The Finch Staff is a starting item for Journey Mode characters, and also has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of being found in Living Wood Chests within Living Trees in all modes.

While the Baby Finch buff is active, a nest appears on the player's head, in which the Baby Finch will rest when not attacking. When multiple Baby Finches are summoned, they will all be visible and stacked on top of each other on the player's head.
Unlike most other summon weapons, its best possible modifier is Mythical because both the Ruthless and Mythical modifiers only raise its base damage to 8 due to rounding.

The Chocolate Chip Cookie is a Hardmode food item that grants the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 20 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The Chocolate Chip Cookie has a 1/75 (1.33%) chance of being dropped by Gastropods.
Like all other food items, the Chocolate Chip Cookie can be placed on a Plate :
Snow Bricks are bricks crafted from Snow Blocks. Placing snow bricks will cause snow to fall in the background and they count toward the qualifications for a Snow Biome.
Spell Books are magic weapons that fire projectiles at the cost of mana instead of ammunition. Spell Books function the same as Magic Guns and Wands, but they appear as books.
Their best modifier is generally Mythical.

The Granite Cave is a mini-biome found in the Underground and Cavern layers. Granite Caves are generally wide-open caverns dotted with occasional ledges, though their shape may vary due to the presence of overlapping cave systems. They are made entirely out of Granite Blocks and Granite Walls and contain several Pots. Underground Cabins spawned in a Granite Cave will be made out of Granite-themed blocks and furniture.
The Wolf set is a vanity set that has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to drop from Goodie Bags, which are obtained during the Halloween seasonal event. It consists of a Wolf Mask, Wolf Shirt and Wolf Pants.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
The Truffle Worm is a rare Hardmode critter and boss-summoning item that spawns in the underground Glowing Mushroom biome. It is used as bait to summon Duke Fishron in the Ocean biome.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Truffle Worms do not take damage from enemies.

The Truffle Worm can be caught with a Bug Net, Lavaproof Bug Net (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Golden Bug Net (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), however, it is more difficult to catch than other critters, as it burrows away when a player comes too close. It must be approached quickly in order to successfully catch it. After being caught, it can be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Truffle Worm Cage). Once crafted, the Truffle Worm cannot be released again.

Despite having a bait power of 666%, the Truffle Worm cannot be used for ordinary fishing, and can only be used to summon Duke Fishron by fishing in the Ocean. When attempting to use it as bait elsewhere, the bobber will simply sit in the water indefinitely.
The Truffle Worm will always be consumed upon summoning Duke Fishron. Items that reduce the chance of bait consumption such as the Tackle Box or its upgrades will have no effect.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

The Item Frame is a furniture item that can be placed on a 2x2 area of background wall, placed on or hung from blocks, or placed on top of platforms. Once an Item Frame is placed, pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate key on it while holding any item places and displays that item in the Item Frame. Hitting the Item Frame with a pickaxe or drill, or pressing ⚷ Open / Activate again will retrieve the item.
The Smooth Marble Block is a smoother version of the Marble Block. It can be used to craft the Marble furniture set.

Ash Grass Seeds are seeds used to plant Ash grass. They are purchased from the Dryad for 1 SC 50 CC each, when she is talked to in the Underworld. They can also be gathered by clearing Ash grass foliage in the Underworld. Ash trees can grow on planted Ash grass.

Smoke Blocks are animated background furniture blocks that can be purchased from the Party Girl for 1 SC in Hardmode. When placed together, they will connect in a way that each block on the outer left and right sides visually take up half of a block. For example, if a player were to make a 3x3 arrangement of Smoke Blocks, the entire left and right columns of smoke will appear to be halved, resulting in a slimmer appearance.
Chlorophyte Bricks are Hardmode bricks crafted from Chlorophyte Ore and Stone Blocks.
Similarly to Chlorophyte Ore, Chlorophyte Bricks can convert adjacent Mud and Jungle grass blocks into Chlorophyte Ore. See Chlorophyte Ore § Notes for details.
Chlorophyte Bricks can also restrict the spread of the evil biomes around them. See biome spread for further information.
Copper Plating Wall is a background wall made of Copper Plating.
The Aegis Fruit is a Hardmode permanent booster item that permanently increases the player's defense by 4. It can only be used once per player and is obtained by throwing a Life Fruit into Shimmer.

The Vortexian is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Vortex Pillar during the Lunar Events. Upon death, a portal is summoned that shoots a lightning bolt aimed at the player, indicated by a glowing line, similar to one of the attacks of the Lunatic Cultist and the lightning portal of the Vortex Pillar. They are powerful in packs, and can potentially start an overwhelming lightning chain reaction if not dealt with properly.

Bone Lee is a rare Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns in the Dungeon after Plantera is defeated. It moves at an extraordinary speed, deals large amounts of damage, and has high knockback resistance. It will also spawn at any time in the Dungeon regardless of the type of Dungeon wall present.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

Feral Bite is a debuff that may be inflicted when a player is hit by certain types of bats and Duke Fishron in Expert Mode. It increases the player's damage by 20%, but lowers their health regeneration and may randomly inflict the Darkness, Cursed, Confused, Slow, Weak, or Silenced debuffs.
Lead Brick Wall is a type of background wall.

Nanites are a Hardmode crafting material used solely for crafting the Flask of Nanites and Nano Bullets, whose purpose is to inflict the Confused debuff with melee and ranged weapons, respectively. Nanites are purchased from the Cyborg for 15 SC each.

The Band of Starpower is an accessory that increases the player's maximum mana by 20. The Band of Starpower has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being obtained from destroying Shadow Orbs found in the Corruption or a 1/5 (20%) chance from Corrupt Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Defiled Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), which are fished in the Corruption. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it can furthermore be crafted, and on the Nintendo 3DS version, it can be found in Living Trees.
Crispy Honey Blocks are blocks formed when liquid honey comes into contact with lava. On the Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can also be crafted using Honey Blocks at a furnace.

Crispy Honey Blocks generate naturally throughout the world in Not the bees (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds. In Get fixed Boi and For the worthy (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds, the blocks inflict the Burning debuff when touched, have a 1/2 (50%) chance to release lava when mined, and are highlighted by the Dangersense Potion.
Crispy Honey Blocks are not destroyed when dropped in lava, despite having a rarity of 00*.

Grim Dye is a Hardmode dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. When equipped, it turns the color of the armor or vanity currently selected into a blood red type color, while emitting a dark effect around the player, similar to Loki's Dye.
The Windy Balloon is a unique pre-Hardmode flying enemy that only spawns during the Windy Day event in daytime. It can be seen carrying slimes which are bound to the string underneath.

While the Windy Balloon itself does not deal damage, the slimes attached to it will, both while flying and after the balloon is popped. The balloon will pop if the player hits it, gets too close, or when it reaches the ground, and will then always drop the slime to the ground.
The types of slimes that can be attached to the balloon are Green, Blue and Purple Slimes, with a rare chance of a Pinky.
The Mushroom Cap is a vanity hat purchased from the Truffle for 2 GC. It greatly resembles a Glowing Mushroom without the stalk.
The Throne is a decorative furniture item. It fulfills the comfort item requirement for the purposes of NPC housing.

Beams or columns are background furniture items that provide support for Torches and can be used as decoration. They form continuous vertical pillars when stacked. They are found naturally in Underground Cabins, and can be crafted.

Beams and columns can be stacked from the ground, and exist in the background, providing support for suspended Torches that will not inhibit character movement. In this way, beams and columns provide a function similar to trees (which also exist in the background and allow the player to suspend high Torches), but which the player can construct where they like. Where background walls exist, beams and columns can also be placed in "midair", without support from below.

Despite their appearance as background walls, beams and columns instead share a layer with other furniture items (like tables, Torches, statues, Switches, timers, etc.), thus the two cannot share the same tile space. They can also prevent a door from opening.
Frozen Slime Blocks are blocks without any friction, making them more slippery than their constituent block, the Ice Block.

When a character moves atop Frozen Slime Blocks, their movement speed is maintained when direction keys are released, sliding at full speed until the Frozen Slime Blocks end or an obstacle is reached. Speed is maintained even when auto-stepping up single-block steps.

The Wand of Sparking is an early pre-Hardmode magic weapon that fires a piercing spark along a parabolic curve, traveling about 16 tiles before dissipating. The spark has a 1/2 (50%) chance to inflict the On Fire! debuff, and deals no knockback. The Wand of Sparking also has a base 14% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%. The Wand of Sparking has a 1/10 (10%) of being obtained from regular Chests on the Surface or in the Underground layer, and can also be sold by the Skeleton Merchant during a third quarter moon for 1 GC.
Its best modifier is Demonic or Deadly, with the former granting improved critical strike chance and the latter granting improved speed. It cannot get modifiers that affect knockback or mana cost.

The Amarok is a Hardmode yoyo that has a 67/100 (67%) chance to inflict the Frostbite debuff for 2-5 seconds whenever it hits an enemy. The Amarok has a 1/300 (0.33%) chance of being dropped from any enemy in the Snow biome, and can also drop in a Corrupted, Crimsoned, or Hallowed Snow biome.
It has a spin duration of 15 seconds and can reach up to 17 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

Hermes Boots are an accessory that can be found in Chests in the Underground and Cavern layers. When equipped, they allow the player to gain a movement speed boost after running for a certain distance continuously. The speed will continue increasing until maximum speed is attained. At full sprint, they will increase the player's horizontal movement speed to 30 mph. However, the player has to speed up again if they runs into a wall or changes running direction. See sprinting accessories for more information on the sprint effect.

The Hermes Boots, Flurry Boots, and the Sailfish Boots (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) have identical functionality, with their only differences being aesthetic. In the case of the Hermes Boots, the user will leave a lasting trail of small dust clouds as they run, which persists for a few seconds. The Dunerider Boots (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) function similarly, but additionally grant an even larger boost on sand.
All four listed boots are interchangeable when crafting Spectre Boots.

The Terraformer is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord tool. It has the same effects as a Clentaminator but reaches 95 tiles and has a width of 7 tiles and has a 33% chance to not consume Solutions, compared to the Clentaminator which reaches 60 tiles and has a width of 5 tiles. The Terraformer can only be obtained by throwing a Clentaminator into Shimmer after the Moon Lord has been defeated.
The Terraformer cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

The Seed is a pre-hardmode dart which can be used with the Blowgun, Blowpipe, Dart Pistol (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Dart Rifle (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Seeds can be obtained by cutting vegetation growing on normal grass, in Clay Pots, and in Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), while a Blowpipe or Blowgun is in the player's inventory. Flowers typically drop 4 Seeds at a time, while tall grass typically drops 1-2 Seeds.

Shell Piles are a decorative block found naturally in the Ocean biome in large clumps. They are affected by gravity and will fall if supporting blocks are removed, dealing damage to any player or enemy they land on. They can also be found in Ocean Crates or in Seaside Crates.

Oiled is a Hardmode debuff inflicted by Explosive Trap sentries when the player is wearing a full set of Huntress armor or Red Riding armor. It causes the afflicted target to take an additional 25 damage per second if they are also under the effect of On Fire!, Hellfire, Cursed Inferno, Frostburn, Frostbite, or Shadowflame.
The Mace is a pre-Hardmode flail found in Gold Chests located in the Underground. It can be crafted into the Flaming Mace, which inflicts the On Fire! debuff.
Its best modifier is Ruthless. Godly and Demonic modifiers may give higher crit chance, but rounding causes Ruthless to have much higher damage for this weapon.

The Cyborg set is a vanity set which consists of the Cyborg Helmet, Cyborg Shirt, and Cyborg Pants, resembling the Cyborg NPC. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
It is purchased from the Cyborg for 9 GC (set), during Halloween.
The Skeleton Merchant is an NPC vendor that randomly spawns in the Cavern layer. He is not a town NPC and will despawn when off-screen, although enemies will not spawn near him.

The Skeleton Merchant's stock changes at dawn (4:30 AM) daily, and he does not need to respawn for it to do so. The majority of the items in his inventory will vary, depending on the current moon phase.
He will throw Bones to fend off nearby non-skeletal enemies, while ignoring most other skeletons.
Unlike other NPCs, the Skeleton Merchant does not have a map icon.
He is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades. His current name will be displayed (e.g. Rattles Magoo) rather than Skeleton Merchant.
Wood armor is a pre-Hardmode armor set consisting of the Wood Helmet, Wood Breastplate, and Wood Greaves.

It is the least powerful set of armor in the game, making it only useful very early on. It can be crafted almost immediately after spawning, as it only requires Wood to make, which is plentiful in the Forest where the player usually spawns.

Wearing the full set grants a basic (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 2 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 3 defense plus a set bonus of 1 defense, which adds up to a total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 3 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 4 defense.

The Inferno Potion is a buff potion that grants the Inferno buff when consumed. The buff casts a spinning ring of fire around the player that deals (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 20 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 10 damage per second and inflicts the (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Hellfire / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) On Fire! debuff for 2 seconds to all enemies inside of it while also giving off light. Critters and other passive NPCs are unaffected. This lasts for 4 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

The Psycho Knife is a Hardmode, post- Plantera melee weapon that has a 1/40 (2.5%) / 79/1600 (4.94%) chance to be dropped by the Psycho during the Solar Eclipse event. When holding the Psycho Knife and standing still, the player will quickly enter stealth mode, causing them to turn almost completely transparent, move much more slowly, and no longer be targeted by enemies.
Stealth mode is engaged gradually over the course of about one second, during which the weapon's stats are steadily boosted up to the following values:
+300% damage (340 base damage) +30% critical chance (34% base chance) +100% knockback (7 (Strong) base knockback)

Stealth mode is disengaged when successfully attacking an enemy, when switching to a different weapon or when riding a mount. Swinging the weapon alone does not cancel stealth, nor does walking or flying. Standing still again afterward re-engages it. Moving or swinging the weapon during the one-second transition period, however, will cancel stealth mode.
Its best modifier is Legendary. Due to rounding, the Light modifier gives the same speed bonus as Legendary, with fewer other bonuses.
The Musket Ball is the basic type of bullet used as ammunition by guns. It has no special properties and is used for crafting a variety of more advanced ammunition.

Musket Balls can be bought from the Arms Dealer for 7 CC each, or 70 SC for 1000 rounds. They can also be obtained from Shadow Orbs and Crimson Hearts (along with a Musket or The Undertaker), or from a Present (along with a Red Ryder) during Christmas.
The Endless Musket Pouch (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) serves as an infinite amount of Musket Balls.

The Gold Axe is an early game axe, being stronger than the Silver or Tungsten Axe, but weaker than the War Axe of the Night or Blood Lust Cluster. It has an alternate ore version, the Platinum Axe, which is somewhat stronger. Like all axes, it is used to cut down trees, cacti, and giant glowing mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

Seeds are consumable items used to plant grass or grow trees, herbs, or flowers. Seeds are planted in specific soils, and some can also be planted in Clay Pots, Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or Rock Golem Heads (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). To plant a seed, select it in the hotbar and press ⚒ Use / Attack above the planting location.

Mushroom Grass Seeds are a type of seed that has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/40 (2.5%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/50 (2%) chance to drop from harvesting Glowing Mushrooms. The seeds can also be purchased from the Dryad for 1 SC 50 CC each if the Dryad is spoken to in a Glowing Mushroom biome. Shaking (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) a Giant Glowing Mushroom occasionally yields Mushroom Grass Seeds as well.

Mushroom Grass Seeds must be planted on Mud Blocks and can be grown both above and under ground. Once planted, Mushroom grass will begin to spread to adjacent Mud Blocks and grow Glowing Mushrooms, as well as Giant Glowing Mushrooms when enough space is available.

Mushroom Grass spreads much slower than ordinary or Corrupt grass, at a speed comparable to Jungle grass - 3-5 tiles per day for each continuous section of Mud Blocks. Mushroom grass, as well as the mushrooms that grow on it, emit moderate light.

The Flying Knife is a unique Hardmode boomerang that throws a reusable cursor-controllable knife projectile similar to the Magic Missile, though with more erratic movement and with no mana or ammunition cost due to it being a melee weapon. Once the ⚒ Use / Attack button is released or after one minute of continuous use, the knife returns to the player.
