When quick using buff potions, only potions whose buff is not active will be consumed. When quick using health or mana potions, the potion that recovers most health/mana will be consumed.

Potion buffs can be canceled at any time by right-clicking the buff icon, by selecting the buff icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, by selecting the buff with + / then canceling the buff with, by double-tapping the buff icon, or by canceling the buff from the buffs screen. All potion buffs (including food buffs, but excluding flask buffs) are lost when dying.
In Journey Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), most potions require 20 items to be researched. Recovery potions require 30 items.

The Bouncy Grenade is an explosive consumable ranged weapon made of Pink Gel and Grenades. Instead of rolling or sticking in place upon contact with tiles, it will bounce and retain much of its momentum.
Like normal Grenades, they will detonate upon touching an enemy, or the player that threw it.

Water Chests are a type of Chest that can be found in pools of water greater than 250 tiles, most notably in the Ocean, but more rarely in any body of water, including water lakes anywhere in the Underground and Caverns layers, Surface lakes and very occasionally Floating Lakes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). In addition to containing common chest loot based on where they are found, there are special items that can only be found in these chests, listed below.

The Grenade is an explosive consumable ranged weapon which can be purchased from the Demolitionist for 75 CC each, or found rarely in pots and natural Chests. Once Hardmode is activated, they can be found in Pots (replacing Shurikens).
A thrown Grenade will bounce slightly and roll until it either hits a valid target or 3 seconds have elapsed, after which it will explode.
Cosmic Ember Brick is a type of decorative brick obtained by throwing Luminite Brick into Shimmer during a Waxing Gibbous.

The Garden Gnome is a small furniture item formed when a Gnome touches sunlight. A placed Garden Gnome positively influences the player's Luck stat by 0.2. The buff is applied to any players standing within a rectangular area of 170x125 tiles centered on the Garden Gnome, similar to the Heart Lantern. Additional Garden Gnomes do not increase luck further.
Garden Gnomes have five different sprites when placed (which are functionally identical):
Facing a direction with their arms akimbo. Facing a direction while slouching. Facing a direction with their arms on their side. Mooning their bottom toward the screen. Facing the screen.

The Twins are a Hardmode mechanical boss which is essentially a more difficult version of the Eye of Cthulhu. The Twins are two separate flying entities, Retinazer and Spazmatism, connected by a tendril, each with its own attack pattern and health count. Both must be killed in order to defeat the boss.

The Twins can be summoned manually using a Mechanical Eye at night (7:30 PM to 4:30 AM). They also have a 1/10 (10%) chance to spawn naturally at dusk once a Demon or Crimson Altar has been destroyed, as long as they have not yet been defeated at least once in the current world. If spawning this way, their arrival is announced by the status message " This is going to be a terrible night... ".
The Twins must be killed before dawn, otherwise they flee and despawn.

While The Twins are alive, the music Boss 2 https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Boss_2.mp3 will play. When Otherworldly music (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is enabled, the track Boss 2 (Otherworldly) https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Boss_2_(Otherworldly).mp3 will play instead.

Glowing Mushroom Dye is a dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. It colors the object it is used on a deep blue color. Like the name implies, objects colored with this dye will also glow slightly in the dark. Though it does not give off any light to see nearby objects with, this can be useful to increase awareness of where the player is.

A Glowing Mushroom biome, also known as Glowing Mushroom Fields, is a biome characterized by Mushroom grass, Glowing Mushrooms, and Giant Glowing Mushrooms growing on Mud Blocks. The grasses and plants in a Glowing Mushroom biome emit a vibrant blue glow, along with many of its unique enemies. The Truffle NPC requires a house in a Surface (above-ground) Glowing Mushroom biome and sells mushroom-themed blocks, pets, weapons, and vanity items.

Underground Glowing Mushroom biomes are Glowing Mushroom biomes below 0 depth. They can be found naturally, randomly generating on world creation. The background of an Underground Glowing Mushroom biome depicts numerous small mushrooms. Several mushroom-themed versions of normal Cavern enemies spawn here in pre-Hardmode, and some completely unique enemies will spawn in Hardmode. Giant Glowing Mushrooms will grow if there is enough vertical space, (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) though unlike Giant Glowing Mushrooms on the surface, they have smaller caps and lack branches. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Underground Glowing Mushroom biomes are large, layered caverns which feature Mushroom Vines hanging from the ceiling and surface-style Giant Glowing Mushrooms. They generate with set features, including a span of flat ground (for Giant Glowing Mushrooms to grow on), or possibly a wide lake for fishing purposes. These long spans of flat ground are conducive to the spawning of Gold Chests, statues, and other objects which generate underground but rely on having a certain amount of level terrain like Life Crystals, making these biomes attractive when hunting for such things.

Surface Glowing Mushroom biomes are Glowing Mushroom biomes above 0 depth. They do not generate naturally and must instead be created by the player. After placing 100 mushroom-related tiles, the biome background will appear, which depicts towering mushrooms. When the biome reaches a size of 160 mushroom-related tiles, the sky will be darkened. There are several exclusive enemies, some of which can also be encountered in Underground Glowing Mushroom biomes.

A Glowing Mushroom biome can be created manually by planting Mushroom Grass Seeds on Mud Blocks, or spraying the Jungle with the Clentaminator using Dark Blue Solution. To be considered Glowing Mushroom biome, an area needs to contain 100 mushroom-related tiles. These include Mushroom grass, naturally grown Glowing Mushrooms, Underground Giant Glowing Mushrooms, and Mushroom Vines (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). However, in Underground layer and below, the Glowing Mushroom background will only be displayed when there are at least 161 mushroom-related tiles.
The Truffle Worm, a critter used to summon Duke Fishron, can only spawn in an underground Glowing Mushroom biome.

The Bone Serpent is a pre-Hardmode worm enemy that spawns in The Underworld. Due to their large size, speed, and high damage, they can be dangerous enemies to encounter, especially if they attack while the player is exploring a Ruined House.

Crates are consumable grab bag and furniture items which can be caught while fishing, and contain random loot such as ores, bars, potions, accessories, and other items. In addition, biome -specific crates can contain biome-specific loot. Their content can be unloaded by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button, either on their icon in the inventory or while holding them. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Crates can also be placed.

The three standard types of crates (Wooden / Pearlwood (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Iron / Mythril (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Golden / Titanium (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) can be caught anywhere, with Wooden/Pearlwood being the most common, and Golden/Titanium being the rarest. In general, rarer crate types contain more valuable loot. The other crates are biome-specific, i.e., they can only be caught in their respective biome (with the exception of the Obsidian (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / Hellstone Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)). They are slightly less rare than Golden/Titanium Crates. When fishing in an area with multiple biomes, only one biome crate type can be caught; for example, when a Floating Island is Corrupted and changes to Corruption, Sky Crates can no longer be obtained. See Fishing § Biomes for details on which biomes take precedence over others.

Crates are caught every 1 in 10 catches, on average; with a Crate Potion, the chance is increased to (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1 in 4 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1 in 5. The kind of crate the player obtains is dependent on their Fishing Power, with higher Fishing Power increasing the probabilities of rarer crates. As an example, fishing with a Fishing Power of 100 in a lake of at least 300 valid water tiles in the Corruption would yield crates with the following probabilities: Golden Crate : 1/150 (0.67%) ; Corrupt Crate : 7/750 (0.93%) ; Iron Crate : 7/250 (2.8%) ; Wooden Crate : 7/125 (5.6%). The Crate Potion multiplies these chances by (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 2.5 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 2.

Treasure Bags are consumable grab bag -like items obtained in Expert Mode and Master Mode as a reward for defeating bosses. The contents of Treasure Bags depend on the boss it comes from, and are opened by using either ⚷ Open / Activate while inside the inventory, or ⚒ Use / Attack when selected in the hotbar. In multiplayer, each player that deals damage to the boss receives one Treasure Bag upon defeating it. Treasure Bags are client-side and will despawn upon exiting the world. See Notes for details.

Each Treasure Bag contains the boss's usual drops from Classic Mode, along with one Expert Mode-exclusive item (highlighted items below) - with the exception of the Lunatic Cultist, Dark Mage, Ogre, and Betsy, who currently do not provide an Expert Mode-exclusive item. Treasure Bags dropped from Hardmode bosses additionally have a 1/16 (6.25%) chance to contain one random set of developer items (with the exception of Queen Slime).
Expert Mode-exclusive items all have the 12* rarity, with the exception of developer items, which have the 09* rarity.

The Grass Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in above-ground tunnels and grottoes on the surface, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained by purchasing it from the Dryad for 10 CC each, while a Blood Moon is not occurring. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

Block-placing wands are special tools that allow the player to place blocks they would normally not be able to place. They do not consume any mana. Each wand consumes a specific material from the player's inventory (details listed below). There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 6 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 4 different block-placing wands.
Valhalla Knight armor is a Hardmode, post- Golem armor set purchased from the Tavernkeep for 1500000* 150 in total, and provides summon as well as melee damage bonuses.
The set consists of the Valhalla Knight's Helm, Valhalla Knight's Breastplate, and Valhalla Knight's Greaves.
A full set of Valhalla Knight armor provides the following bonuses:
+68 defense +10% melee damage +60% summon damage +20% melee critical strike chance +20% movement speed +4 HP /second health regeneration +3 extra sentry slots

Equipping the full set will increase the velocity of the projectiles of the Ballista sentry summons, will greatly increase their fire rate (from 2.67 seconds to 1.67 seconds), and will increase the maximum number of enemies that can be pierced by them from 3 to 6. It also grants the wearer the Ballista Panic! buff upon taking any damage, which further increases the fire rate of all Ballista sentries summoned by the player (from 1.67 seconds to 0.5 seconds) for 5 seconds.
The Valhalla Knight armor can be considered a direct upgrade of the Squire armor.

Mining armor is an armor set consisting of the Mining Helmet or Ultrabright Helmet (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Mining Shirt, and Mining Pants. The helmets alone provide light when worn in the armor slot, but not when worn in the social slot. A full set grants (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 4 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 3 defense (6 with the Ultrabright Helmet), as well as 30% increased mining speed.

The Mining Shirt and Mining Pants are dropped from Undead Miners with a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 3/25 (12%) / (3DS version) 3/125 (2.4%) chance. The Mining Helmet can be purchased from the Merchant for (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) 4 GC / (Old-gen console version) 8 GC. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Mining Helmet can also be dropped by Undead Miners with a 1/20 (5%) chance.
The Tutorial is a special world scripted to teach the player the basics of the game. It can be accessed by pressing the "Tutorial" option on the title screen.
The world and its presentation differ between game platforms.
The Gold Grasshopper is a harmless critter. It is a golden recolor of the ordinary Grasshopper, with a 1/400 (0.25%) chance of spawning in place of the ordinary version.
The Gold Grasshopper has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Gold Grasshopper can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Gold Grasshopper Cage). Once crafted, the Gold Grasshopper cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Gold Grasshopper itself or the crafted furniture can be sold for 10 GC.
The Gold Grasshopper can be used as bait for fishing, with 50% bait power.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.
The Repaired Life Crystal is a furniture item that places down a decorative Life Crystal. It drops a Life Crystal when destroyed.
The Ship in a Bottle is a decorative furniture item acquired by completing Angler NPC quests.

A Party is an event that can occur randomly, or be activated manually using a Party Center. Parties are mainly visual, having little functional effect on gameplay, with the exception of some exclusive vanity and novelty items available from the Clothier and Party Girl. A Party lasts until 7:30 PM, and if spawned randomly, begins at 4:30 AM.

A Party has a random 1/10 (10%) chance of occurring at any particular dawn ("thrown" by one to three NPCs), without the need for a placed Party Center. See below for the detailed conditions. When NPCs throw a Party, any placed Party Center activates, a burst of confetti appears on each NPC, and a pink status message displays: " Looks like <NPC name>, <NPC name>, and <NPC name> are throwing a party ". At its conclusion, the Party automatically deactivates with a puff of smoke on all NPCs and another pink status message: " Party time's over! ". A Party can still be re-initiated manually afterward.
During a Party:

All NPCs except the Tax Collector, Zoologist, Old Man, and Skeleton Merchant wear Party Hats, including town pets and the Traveling Merchant. Balloons continually rise in the background. Bunnies also wear Party Hats (but drop only normal Bunnies when caught). Gem Bunnies that spawn during a Party are replaced with normal Bunnies (with hats). The Cool Slime town pet moves in if the Party had occurred naturally. The Clothier and Party Girl sell additional Party-exclusive novelty and vanity items. If the Party occurs naturally, the Party Girl will give the player a Slice of Cake when spoken to. She will only give this item the first time she is spoken to after the Party begins, even during multiplayer. Most NPCs display unique quotes when spoken to.

A town is a player-created mini-biome which is created when three or more NPCs are in close proximity (including the Old Man, Traveling Merchant, and town pets, but excluding the Skeleton Merchant). Towns have the greatest effect on reducing the spawn of enemies, though the enemy spawn reduction effect is weaker in the Underworld, and will not have effect when some events are occurring. See Notes for details.
The Shadow Candle (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), when placed and activated or when held, prevents the creation of a town mini-biome, even if enough NPCs are present.

The Razorblade Typhoon is a Hardmode magic weapon that fires a large, fast, disc-shaped Typhoon projectile upon use that homes in on enemies. It can pierce and ricochet any number of times, lasting (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 2.5 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 3 seconds. The Razorblade Typhoon has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being dropped by Duke Fishron.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

Vortex Dye is a Hardmode dye crafted from Vortex Fragments dropped by the Vortex Pillar in the Lunar Events and Bottled Water. The effect produced is reminiscent of a green warp drive effect on all clothing and accessories the dye is applied to.

In Terraria, enemies, critters, and other NPCs will spawn off-screen and enter the screen area based on their AI. The rate at which enemies are spawned, the maximum number of enemies, and the type of enemies spawned are all dependent on the time of day, biome, the tile type of the ground, and other factors.
The number of NPCs that can exist at the same time is capped at 200.
The Hanging Skeleton is a decorative furniture item that can be placed on background walls. It can be found in the Dungeon, where they only appear in areas backed by Slab or Tile Walls.

Lamps are a type of furniture and light source. They also count as valid house lighting and can be toggled on and off by mechanisms. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 34 types of craftable Lamps, three types that are found in the Dungeon (Green, Blue, or Pink Dungeon Lamp), one found in Underworld houses (Obsidian Lamp), and one that can be dropped during a Pirate Invasion (Golden Lamp). All are functionally identical and differ only in their appearance.
The Tiki Torch shares its Tile ID with the rest of these Lamps.
Also see Lamp Post, (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) which does not count as valid House lighting.

Acid Venom (Venom on Old-gen console and 3DS) is a Hardmode debuff that prevents health regeneration and causes the afflicted NPC or player to take damage each second for the duration of the debuff. It is a stronger version of Poisoned. The damage varies by platform :

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 30 damage per second when inflicted to enemies, and 15 damage per second when inflicted to players. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 6 damage per second to any entity.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Enemies immune to Venom are also immune to Poisoned.

Fishing is an activity accomplished by using a fishing pole at a body of liquid (water, honey, or lava) while having bait in the player's inventory. Pressing the ⚒ Use / Attack button will cast a fishing line along with the bobber, which only functions when the bobber is thrown into liquid. Pressing the button again when the bobber moves up and down will reel in the line and often an item will come up with the line. The Angler NPC provides daily fishing quests and rewards their completion with an assortment of equipment, coins, potions, and vanity items.

Fishing provides an assortment of game resources: Crafting materials for potions and food, a variety of very useful accessories such as mobility improvements like the Frog Leg or Balloon Pufferfish, and even pets such as the Zephyr Fish. Some fish can even be used as tools or weapons. Through crates, fishing also provides an alternative source for ores, coins, many chest items, and some specialties such as the Falcon Blade, Sailfish Boots (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Tsunami in a Bottle (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

While fishing is not strictly necessary for game progression, some of the Angler's quest rewards (the Fish Finder components) are required to complete the Shellphone (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Fishing is also required to summon and fight Duke Fishron.
For pre-Hardmode players, fishing can be a good way of obtaining money and equipment; by mid-Hardmode, it is less competitive with other money-making options, enemy drops, and advancing equipment.
Snowfall Wall is one of only a few animated background walls. It depicts falling snow.

The Zombie Merman is a pre-Hardmode enemy that can be spawned by fishing in water during a Blood Moon. When the bobber dips and the player attempts to reel in a fish, a Zombie Merman or a Wandering Eye Fish has a chance to spawn within a few tiles of the bobber in place of a fish. While hindered by a somewhat slow initial walking speed, the Zombie Merman gains exceptional mobility and maneuverability when underwater, and can leap out of the water with great speed if needed. The Zombie Merman also becomes faster as its health is further depleted.

It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades. The Zombie Merman requires 25 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.
Ancient Dungeon Bricks are types of bricks that can be obtained by throwing the respective Dungeon Brick into Shimmer.

The Encumbering Stone is a pre-Hardmode tool that prevents item pickup while inside the player's inventory. While in the inventory, the Encumbering Stone will prevent the pickup of any items, even if the player already has a stackable item in their inventory. The Encumbering Stone will also prevent items from being added to the Void Bag.
Items reeled in from fishing are still placed in the player's inventory. Hearts and Stars will also be picked up even with the Encumbering Stone in the inventory.

Pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on the Encumbering Stone in the player's inventory or hotbar will toggle it between the Encumbering Stone and Uncumbering Stone. Toggling it to the Uncumbering Stone disables its functions, allowing the player to pick up items again.
The Encumbering Stone has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being found in Sandstone Chests in the Underground Desert.

The Underworld (also known as Hell) is the deepest layer of the world. It is a large, open cavern that stretches across the bottom of the world, with a ceiling of Ash Blocks and a lower terrain of large lava pools, Ash Blocks, and Hellstone. It also contains numerous Ruined Houses, which are natural structures containing unique furniture and loot. The Wall of Flesh boss can be summoned in the Underworld; defeating it will cause the world to convert to Hardmode.

The Underworld contains many hazards, such as large pools of lava and various difficult enemies. Hellstone, a valuable crafting material only obtainable in the Underworld, inflicts the Burning debuff when touched and releases half a tile of lava when mined. Further, because the Wall of Flesh is summoned by dropping a Guide Voodoo Doll into lava, killing a Voodoo Demon positioned over lava can inadvertently summon it.

The middle two-quarters of the Underworld contains several Ruined Houses, which are towers made from Obsidian Bricks and, less commonly, Hellstone Bricks that contain Shadow Chests, Hellforges, Pots, Obsidian furniture, and other lootable items. Shadow Chests require the Shadow Key to open (acquired in the Dungeon 's Locked Gold Chests, Golden Lock Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or dropped from Arch Wyverns (Old-gen console and 3DS versions)) and contain unique Underworld-only loot. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The outer sixths of the underworld are occupied by ash forests, which are barren, fiery-looking forests that feature Ash trees growing on Ash grass.
The Pink Snow armor (on Desktop, Console, and Mobile) is an armor set consisting of the Pink Snow Hood, Pink Snow Coat, and Pink Snow Pants.

On Desktop, Console, and Mobile, wearing the full set grants a total of 9 defense as well as immunity to the Chilled and Frozen debuffs. It can be mixed freely with the Snow armor and will still grant this set bonus.

On Old-gen console and 3DS, the set is called Pink Eskimo armor, consisting of the Pink Eskimo Hood, Pink Eskimo Coat, and Pink Eskimo Pants. Wearing the full set grants a total of 4 defense and no set bonus. Due to its low defense and high rarity, its viability as an armor set is rather low.

Asphalt Block is a unique block that dramatically increases the speed of players running along its, along with reducing the time it take to stop running. Its acceleration stacks with other speed-boosting items such as the Hermes Boots and its derivative accessories. It only affects players running directly on it; the speed of enemies, NPCs, and critters will remain unaffected. Immediately after jumping or falling off of Asphalt Block, the speed will returns to normal.
With no other boosts, running on Asphalt has a max speed of 53 mph, with about 3 seconds of acceleration, while the normal maximum running speed is 15 mph.

The Magic Lantern is a light pet-summoning item that spawns a small glowing Magic Lantern which hovers above the player, emitting dim yellow light. The lantern will also expose all treasure within up to 15 tiles from the lantern's location, overlaying small yellow sparkles over nearby valuable treasure, which is the same as what is highlighted by a Spelunker Potion. The Magic Lantern can be purchased from the Skeleton Merchant for 10 GC during the night of a full moon.

The lantern will always try to maintain a position just forward of and above the player, passing through blocks as needed. If the player is far enough away or in midair, the lantern will propel itself with a rocket exhaust in order to catch up to them. The lantern's position can block objects of interest at ceiling height, but if the player just turns around, the lantern will move to their other side.

The Harp is a Hardmode crafting material, used only to craft the Magical Harp. While the Harp can be used itself, it has no functional use, and only makes sounds. It is sold by the Wizard for 1 GC each.

When used, the Harp generates harp sounds. The sound's pitch is determined by the distance between the center of the character and the point clicked. Clicking the center of the character plays middle C, while clicking at a distance of at least that of the top or bottom of the screen plays C6 (two octaves above middle C). The smallest interval between notes the harp can play is a whole tone, or two semitones. A difference of 1/24 of the screen height equals an interval of a whole tone.
The Harp and the Whoopie Cushion have similar effects, although the Whoopie Cushion cannot change pitch.
The Rifle Scope is a Hardmode, post- Plantera accessory. It grants the ability to increase view range while holding a gun by pressing and holding ⚷ Open / Activate and moving the cursor.
The Rifle Scope has a 1/12 (8.33%) / 23/144 (15.97%) chance of being dropped by Skeleton Snipers in the post-Plantera Dungeon.
The Garland is a vanity item for the Social Helmet slot.
The Ruby Staff is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon and shares the fifth tier of gem staff with the Amber Staff, as both have identical stats. It autofires a red bolt that can pierce one enemy.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Crimson Axe is a Hardmode enemy which is found in the Underground Crimson. It hovers and spins before lunging at the player, traveling through any blocks to reach them. Any knockback stops its attack, forcing it to pause and spin up again. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to inflict the Cursed debuff for 4 / 8 / 10 seconds.

The Balloon Pufferfish is an accessory that increases the player's jump height by 33% and jump speed by 30%, increasing the height that the player can jump from 6 blocks (12 feet) to ~10½ blocks (21 feet), effectively a ~75% boost; however, it oddly reduces jump height when underwater, from 8 blocks (16 feet) to 7 blocks (14 feet), meaning it grants the same jump height bonus and downside as the Shiny Red Balloon. It can be obtained via fishing in any biome.

The Fox set is a vanity set. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to drop from Goodie Bags during Halloween. The set consists of the Fox Mask, Fox Shirt, and Fox Pants. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its male and female variants look identical.
The day and night cycle of the Terraria world refers to the rising and setting of the Sun and Moon, and the ways this can affect the world.

Day begins at 4:30 AM, while night begins at 7:30 PM. Day and night each have their respective theme music in some surface biomes. For the " Morning Rain " track, morning lasts from 4:30 AM to 7:30 AM. Some surface enemies only spawn at night (see Enemies below). Some NPCs sell unique items at night, like the Arms Dealer, who sells Illegal Gun Parts at night.

Note that the sun in Terraria rises at the left of the map, even though the left is referred to in-game as "West" (the same for right/East), e.g. when a Goblin Army, Frost Legion, or Pirate Invasion begins approaching.

The Muramasa is a pre-Hardmode, post- Skeletron sword that has a slightly longer reach than the Phaseblade and has a fast attack speed. It is also one of the few autoswing swords that can be found during pre-Hardmode. When swung, it emits a small amount of blue light. Striking an enemy with the Muramasa will generate a blue slash projectile from a random direction, hitting the enemy for 50% of the weapon's damage (12 base damage). The smaller slashes also have 5 armor penetration. The Muramasa has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from the Locked Gold Chests found in the Dungeon, as well as a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from Golden Lock Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Muramasa is one of the key ingredients in crafting the Night's Edge.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Ash Block is a block that covers the upper and lower sections of The Underworld, and can occasionally encase Hellstone. It can be used for building and for growing Fireblossom.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) In the Ash forests on the outer edges of the Underworld, Ash grass naturally generates on ash blocks, with Ash trees growing on them. Ash Grass Seeds can be planted on ash blocks.

The Fetid Baghnakhs are a Hardmode sword with a short range, but an exceptionally low use time (in other words, an exceptionally high attack speed). The Fetid Baghnakhs have a 1/5 (20%) chance of being dropped by Crimson Mimics.
Their best modifier is Legendary.

The Mythril Waraxe is a Hardmode axe that is obtainable after crafting a Mythril Anvil or an Orichalcum Anvil, and is the axe alternative to the Mythril Chainsaw. Along with its slightly stronger counterpart, the Orichalcum Waraxe, it is stronger than the Cobalt or Palladium Waraxe but weaker than the Adamantite or Titanium Waraxe which can be obtained later. Like all other axes and chainsaws, it is solely used to cut down trees, cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Reindeer Bells are a Hardmode, post- Plantera mount-summoning item that summons the rideable Rudolph mount, which greatly speeds a player's movement and adds the ability to fly. The Reindeer Bells have a chance of between (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1.33% and 2.22% / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 0.56% and 0.83% to be dropped by the Ice Queen during or after wave 15 of the Frost Moon event.
Similar to the Hoverboard, flight height can be constrained by holding the ▼ Down key in addition to the ↷ Jump key, so movement will be horizontal only.

Objects, or background objects, are a general type of tile which occupy space but can be passed by the player. Blocks cannot be created on top of them until they are removed. Most types of objects are scattered across the world during world generation, though some (namely pieces of Furniture) can be manually placed by the player. Unlike blocks, objects do not form terrain and act as separate and independent tiles. There are a large number of objects which serve no purpose, and instead are only used for their appearance.
Many background objects yield items when harvested by the player by using a pickaxe or explosives. Notable exceptions include:

Ambient objects, destroying these in the Surface layer or Underground Jungle can spawn certain Critters. Bee Hive, destroying these will release Bees. Larva, destroying these will summon Queen Bee. Plantera's Bulb, destroying these will summon Plantera. Altars, destroying these will generate the first three tiers of Hardmode ores (on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, also spread Corruption / Crimson or Hallow).

The world spawn point is where players appear in a newly created world or when joining a multiplayer server. The world's spawn point will be on a surface within five blocks of the horizontal middle of the world. It will almost always be located in the Forest biome as more hazardous biomes cannot appear at the world's center.

A player's spawn point is initially the world spawn point, but can be changed by crafting a Bed, placing it in a house and pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on it. The spawn point is where players respawn after dying, and where a Magic/Ice Mirror or Recall Potion will teleport them. Once the house the Bed is in is broken or ⚷ Open / Activate is pressed on the Bed a second time, the player's spawn point reverts back to the world's initial spawn point.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The world's spawn point is marked by a green arrow icon on the minimap, and the player's spawn point is marked by a bed icon.

Glass Walls are transparent walls that can be used to make windows that let in natural light, while preventing monster spawns. They are crafted from Glass and also spawn naturally in houses on Floating Islands. They can be crafted into Stained Glass.
Beetles are rare enemies that can be found in different biomes.

There are three types of beetle: The Cochineal Beetle that spawns in the Cavern layer, the Cyan Beetle that spawns in the Ice biome and the Lac Beetle that spawns in the Underground Jungle biome. They respectively drop the Red Husk, the Cyan Husk and the Violet Husk which can be used to respectively make the Red Dye, the Cyan Dye, and Violet Dye.
They are all immune to the Confused debuff.
Astra Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Astra Bricks.

The Cobalt Drill is a Hardmode drill, and is the drill alternative to the Cobalt Pickaxe. In comparison to the Cobalt Pickaxe, the drill is faster. But, unlike pickaxes, drills cannot be reforged with speed modifiers and are not boosted by Mining Speed bonuses.
It can mine any block except Adamantite Ore, Titanium Ore, Chlorophyte Ore, and Lihzahrd Bricks.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it, and furthermore cannot get modifiers that affect its speed, either.

The Golf Cart Keys are a post- Skeletron mount-summoning item that places the player in a rideable Golf Cart. The Golf Cart emits light from its front that reaches about 40 tiles, with the brightest point being at about 15 tiles. The Golf Cart Keys can be purchased from the Golfer for 50 GC after Skeletron has been defeated, and a golf score of 2000 is earned by the player.
The Jack 'O Lantern is a placeable furniture item that gives off light. It can have different faces when placed.

The Old Shaking Chest is a rare entity that can be found in the Cavern layer after Skeletron has been defeated. It resembles a Chest and hops around like a slime, attempting to reach the player. It does not damage the player nor take damage from them, but it does take damage from enemies. If the player presses the ⚷ Open / Activate button on it while having a Golden Key in their inventory, it will transform into the Elder Slime. Afterwards, the Old Shaking Chest will no longer spawn.
If the Elder Slime is killed, it will respawn naturally without the need to unlock another Old Shaking Chest. Only one Old Shaking Chest can be alive at a time.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.

The Scutlix is a Hardmode, post- Golem enemy that spawns during the Martian Madness event. It consists of the Scutlix creature, ridden by a Scutlix Gunner enemy, both of which have individual health meters and can be killed independently. When one is killed, the other will continue to attack.

The Horseman's Blade is a Hardmode, post- Plantera sword. It creates a broad orange circular slash around it when swung that significantly increases the range at which the weapon can deal damage to enemies, including those behind the player. However, it can only damage up to three enemies per swing. Upon striking an enemy, the Horseman's Blade summons a Flaming Jack, a homing pumpkin head projectile which passes through solid blocks to attack its closest target. Flaming Jacks have the same damage and critical strike chance as the sword. The Horseman's Blade is dropped by the Pumpking during the Pumpkin Moon event with a 2.5-12.5% (6.25-12.5%) chance depending on the current wave.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Magical Pumpkin Seed is a pet-summoning item that summons a pet Squashling to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Squashling will twirl and fly after the player to catch up to them. The Magical Pumpkin Seed has a 1/200 (0.5%) chance of being obtained from harvesting fully-grown Pumpkins during the Halloween seasonal event.
Heavenforge Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Heavenforge Bricks.

The Nimbus Rod is a Hardmode magic weapon that creates storm clouds that drop damaging "rain" projectiles directly below itself. When cast, a cloud projectile is fired from the Nimbus Rod and travels towards the cursor. Upon reaching its destination or colliding with a solid block, the cloud stops and starts sending damaging raindrop particles downward, each dealing the weapon's stated damage. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The raindrop can pierce up to 4 targets, hitting a total of 5 targets. / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The raindrop can pierce an infinite number of targets. Each cloud lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) five minutes / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) one minute. Up to two clouds can be spawned at once; using the Nimbus Rod when there are already two active clouds will cause the oldest cloud to disappear. The Nimbus Rod has a 1/15 (6.67%) chance of being dropped by Angry Nimbuses.

Its best modifier is Demonic or Deadly for damage output, or Mystic for mana conservation because it cannot get modifiers that affect knockback. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Because of the weapon's negligible mana cost, Demonic is usually preferred.
The Gingerbread Man is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns during the Frost Moon event. He is much like the Splinterling but drops no items.
Defeating a Gingerbread Man during the Frost Moon event will add 2 / 4 / 5 points to the current score.

The Gigazapper is a Hardmode, post- Golem enemy that appears during the Martian Madness event. It uses a short-ranged electrical spear weapon unavailable to players, with a maximum fire rate of once every half of a second. Its projectiles shock the player, inflicting the Electrified debuff for 4-8 seconds, causing the player to lose health rapidly.
The Gold Bunny is a harmless critter. It is a golden recolor of the ordinary Bunny, with a 1/400 (0.25%) chance of spawning in place of the ordinary version.
The Gold Bunny has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Gold Bunny can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Gold Bunny Cage). Once crafted, the Gold Bunny cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Gold Bunny itself or the crafted furniture can be sold for 10 GC.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.

The Chicken Nugget is a food item that grants the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 14 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The Chicken Nugget has a 1/50 (2%) chance of being dropped by Harpies.
Like all other food items, the Chicken Nugget can be placed on a Plate :

Frostburn is a debuff that prevents health regeneration. It also causes damage over time effect when inflicted on entities. When inflicted on a player, they will lose (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 6 health per second; when inflicted on non-player entities (enemies, town NPCs, etc.), they will lose 8 health per second. If the non-player entity is Oiled (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), they will take an additional 25 damage per second, totaling to 33 damage per second.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, there is a stronger version of Frostburn debuff, called Frostbite.
The debuff is very useful early to mid-game, as only 32 enemies in the game are immune to it. On Old-gen console and 3DS, no enemies inflict Frostburn.

The Daybreak is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist melee weapon that fires a sun spear projectile that is affected by gravity. It sticks onto the targeted enemy upon hit, dealing damage and inflicting the Daybroken debuff, which deals 25 damage per 0.25 seconds for a duration of 5 seconds. Up to a maximum of eight sun spears can be stuck onto a single enemy at one time, resulting in 800 DPS for the debuff. Enemies that die while afflicted with the debuff inflict it onto nearby enemies.
The spears cause Solar Explosions, which deal the weapon's base damage and inflict the Daybroken debuff when any of the following conditions are met:
The duration of the debuff expires. The target dies. When the sun spear collides with solid tiles. When the sun spear limit is reached on a target and another one is thrown on it.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Phase Dye is a Hardmode dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. It seems to invert the colors of the object it is attached to as well as giving a strange purple aura.
When the user is damaged, the dye flashes very quickly.

The Umbrella Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns during rainy days on the surface, holding an umbrella. It is larger than and statistically superior to Blue and Green Slimes.
Like most other slimes, the Umbrella Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
Bowls are a type of decorative furniture that can be placed. Unlike with plates, food cannot be placed in bowls. Only the clay Bowl can be used in crafting.

The Jungle Creeper is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Underground Jungle, and resembles a Black Recluse colored brown with a bit of green and climbs on background walls similarly to other spiders. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it has a 1/10 (10%) chance to inflict the Acid Venom debuff for 4 / 8 / 10 seconds. In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), it gains a special spit attack that inflicts the Webbed debuff for 0.5-2.5 seconds.
Ash Wood furniture are furniture items crafted using Ash Wood. There are 20 different Ash Wood furniture items.

The Magic Dagger is a Hardmode magic weapon that operates exactly as the Throwing Knife, but uses mana instead of consuming stacks of the item and causes more than triple the damage. A single Magic Dagger can be thrown limitlessly whenever mana is available, and is never consumed. The Magic Dagger has a (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) 1/6 (16.67%) / (Old-gen console version) 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being dropped by Mimics.

Magic Daggers will fly in a direct line in the direction of the cursor for the first (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 24 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 16 tiles of distance, then suddenly start being affected by gravity and losing horizontal momentum. They also produce a small amount of light on impact.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Atlantic Cods are a type of fish which are found commonly by fishing in a Snow biome in any layer. Their sole use is to craft Cooked Fish.

The Creeper set is a vanity set consisting of the Creeper Mask, Creeper Shirt, and Creeper Pants. Its male and female variants look identical. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to drop from Goodie Bags during Halloween.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Throwing Knife is a consumable ranged weapon. It can pierce up to 1 target, hitting a total of 2 targets. It can be purchased from the Merchant during a Blood Moon for 50 CC each and may also be found in Chests. Throwing Knife is greatly affected by gravity and arc similarly to Shuriken and Bone. It has the greatest range of these consumable ranged weapons (with Bone having the least).
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Throwing Knives have a 1/2 (50%) chance of being retrievable after use, even after hitting enemies.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Merchant will use Throwing Knives to defend himself against nearby enemies.
The Meteor Hamaxe is a hamaxe, a hammer and axe combination, and is the first hamaxe the player can obtain. Combining these functions is handy, but not essential for game advancement.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Greater Mana Potion is a recovery potion that restores 200 mana and inflicts the Mana Sickness debuff upon use. Unlike most potions, Greater Mana Potions cannot be crafted. Instead, they can be purchased from the Wizard for (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) 5 SC / (Old-gen console version) 10 SC, or dropped by Biome Mimics. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, they can additionally be obtained from Golden Crates, but on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, they cannot be obtained outside of Hardmode.
It is the third tier of mana potion, succeeding the Lesser Mana Potion and Mana Potion, and preceding the Super Mana Potion.

Snow Blocks are found naturally-placed in the Snow Biome. Snow Blocks placed in the Surface layer, either naturally or by a player, will cause a snowfall effect. This is purely visual, and has no functional effects. Snow Blocks cannot be infected by the Hallow or evil biomes. Snow in any form cannot be melted into water, nor produced from water or Ice Blocks.
Snow blocks are also dropped by the Hardmode Frost Legion enemies, and its Snow Balla throws Snowballs that create further Snow blocks when impacting.

Boreal Wood is the Snow Biome replacement for normal wood. Its properties are generally the same as that of normal wood, but it can be used to craft its own unique set of furniture. It is obtained by cutting down trees within the Snow Biome. Boreal Wood can be cultivated by placing an Acorn on top of a Snow Block.

Boreal Wood does have slightly better stats for tools, armor, and weapons (Example: Wood Armor has a total of 3 defense with a full set, and Boreal Wood Armor has a total of 4 defense with a full set).
Boreal Wood uses ice torches instead of normal ones to craft Boreal specific lighting.
Boreal Wood cannot be used by the Living Wood Wand or the Leaf Wand.

Tin Ore is an early game ore, which spawns on the surface as well as in the Underground and Cavern biomes. It is the second weakest and most easily obtained tier of ore in the game. Its primary use is to make Tin Bars, which can be used to create the tin tier of equipment. (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) Tin Ore has a small chance to appear as a bonus drop from Slimes.
Its alternate ore counterpart is the Copper Ore.

The Flamelash is a pre-Hardmode, post- Skeletron magic weapon that launches a controllable fireball, similar to the Magic Missile. When the ⚒ Use / Attack button is released, the Flamelash's projectile keeps its course until it hits an enemy or surface. The projectile can be controlled for up to one minute before dissipating and has a 1/2 (50%) chance of inflicting the On Fire! debuff for 4-8 seconds. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, if an enemy is nearby, the fireball will home into the nearest enemy upon release. It can also pierce one enemy, retaining its homing ability and exploding upon contact with a second enemy or block. The Flamelash has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/5 (20%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being found in Shadow Chests in the Underworld, as well as a 1/5 (20%) chance of being found in Obsidian Lock Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) obtained from Obsidian Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Hellstone Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Guide is usually the first NPC a player encounters. He spawns near the player when the world is created. He provides tips mainly aimed at new players via the "Help" option and displays crafting recipes (including the crafting station required) of items shown to him via the "Crafting" option.

Unlike most other NPCs, the Guide spawns upon world creation, before a house is available. He will, however, move into the first house built. If he is killed, a proper house will need to be built before he can respawn, but he has no additional requirements.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Guide will defend himself against nearby enemies using a Wooden Bow, firing Wooden Arrows initially and then upgrading to Flaming Arrows during Hardmode. He deals 8 / 12 / 14 damage at the start of the game, and as players progress, he will gain various stat increases.

Midnight Rainbow Dye is a dye that creates a "reverse" rainbow effect that waves throughout the colors of the spectrum. This dye can be earned by trading a Strange Plant with the Dye Trader after defeating the Martian Madness event.
Iron Brick is a type of Brick crafted from Iron Ore.

Shiverthorn Seeds are a type of seed that can be obtained from harvesting Shiverthorns while they are blooming or using the Staff of Regrowth on a naturally grown Shiverthorns while they are fully grown. Shiverthorn will always bloom after a period of growth, and unlike other herbs, remains in-bloom permanently thereafter. Blooming Shiverthorn emits a glowing particle effect. Each plant drops 1-3 Shiverthorn Seeds when harvested while blooming.

Shiverthorn Seeds can be placed on Snow Blocks and any type of Ice Blocks, empty Clay Pots, or any types of Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), even inside water or honey, and will grow into harvestable Shiverthorns. They will grow anywhere, not just in the Snow biome, but will only yield seeds when blooming.
Palladium Bars are a Hardmode item made from 3 Palladium Ores. They are the Cobalt Bar 's counterpart.
Crafting all Palladium equipment requires 174 Palladium Bars, or a total of 522 Palladium Ore.

Clay is a block type mainly used as a crafting material. It is found primarily in Surface -level (above 0 elevation) areas, and is more rare at the upper parts of the Underground. Because of this, the largest deposits of Clay can be found simply by exploring the Surface for differently-colored patches in the Dirt.

Chests are storage items that each hold up to (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 40 / 20 item stacks in rows of 10x4 / 8x5 / 5x8 / 5x4. Chests can be broken with any pickaxe or drill, but only when empty. It is impossible to destroy the blocks underneath a placed Chest.

In addition to being craftable, a number of Chests are created during world generation, and placed in random map locations. The loot contained in these Chests is determined during world generation, and will not change if the world enters Hardmode.

There are 20 varieties of naturally-occurring Chests (15 of which cannot be crafted) and 27 craftable ones, plus the Barrel and Trash Can, for a total of 42 Chest types and 44 placed storage items overall (besides Dressers and portable storage items).

There is a maximum limit of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8000 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1000 placed storage items in each world (excluding portable storage like the Safe, Piggy Bank, Void Vault (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Defender's Forge (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), as well as showcase items like the Item Frame, Weapon Rack, and Mannequin). Attempts to place additional storage items beyond the max will result in a dropped item, rather than placement.

On the Desktop, Console, Old-gen console, and Mobile versions, placed Chests can be renamed (20 character max). Hovering the cursor over a renamed Chest will show its name. If the Chest has not been renamed, no name will display. To rename a Chest, first open it via ⚷ Open / Activate. The default Chest name reflects the Chest type (e.g. a Living Wood Chest has the default name "Living Wood Chest"). Select "Rename" and enter a new name. Press ↵ Enter or press "Save" when finished. Chest names can also use the same text formatting as Announcement Boxes and chat messages.
On the Desktop, Console, and Mobile, some types of Chests can be locked by the player using a Chest Lock. When doing so, they will require a key to open again.

Rain Cloud is a type of block found beneath Floating Islands, along with Cloud blocks. Rain Cloud blocks cause purely decorative raindrops to appear beneath them that fall for about 18 tiles before fading away for 5 more. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, landing on Rain Clouds will not inflict fall damage.

The Bunny Stew is a food item crafted at the Cooking Pot. When consumed, it grants the Well Fed buff. This lasts for 10 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Bunny Stew can be placed on a Plate :

Palm Wood is a type of wood harvested from Palm trees found naturally growing in the Ocean biome and Oasis biome. Only regular Palm trees that are growing on regular Sand will drop Palm Wood. Palm trees that are growing on Ebonsand, Crimsand, or Pearlsand will be corrupted, and instead drop Ebonwood, Shadewood or Pearlwood, respectively. Palm Wood can be cultivated by placing an Acorn on top of a regular Sand Block.

Cobalt Ore is the lowest tier of Hardmode Ore, and can spawn on the first breaking of an Altar. More will spawn on the 4th, 7th, 10th, etc destroyed Altars, albeit in decreasing amounts. Mining Cobalt Ore requires at least a Molten Pickaxe. It is immune to all types of explosions.
Palladium Ore may generate in place of Cobalt Ore. It is slightly more valuable, and the tools and weapons it crafts have slightly better stats.

The Lunar Events are a series of four late- Hardmode events initiated by defeating the Lunatic Cultist boss. Once the boss is defeated, four different sections of the world each show a large planet in their backgrounds and spawn several unique enemies at high spawn rates, with one corresponding Celestial Pillar in each. These areas can be found on the minimap via icons that represent each of their Celestial Pillars.

Defeating a Celestial Pillar reverts an area back to normal. In order to damage a pillar, one must first kill 100 enemies from within its section, which removes the shield that protects the pillar and makes it vulnerable to attacks.

Defeating all four Celestial Pillars triggers the status message " Impending doom approaches... ", signifying that the Moon Lord, Terraria 's final boss, is about to spawn. It spawns one minute after the message appears.
After defeating the Moon Lord for the first time, only 50 enemies will need to be defeated to remove the shields protecting the pillars.
Vortex Brick Wall is a background wall made from Vortex Bricks.

The Dog is a town pet. It arrives at dawn (4:30 AM) the day after the player uses the Dog License, which is purchased from the Zoologist for 5 GC. The Dog does not count towards the NPCs ' "crowded" limit and hence will not affect NPC happiness, although it does count as a regular town NPC for the purpose of the Pylon network. There are six breeds of Dog, with one randomly being chosen when it arrives.

The only requirements for the Dog to appear is the use of a Dog License and the presence of a valid house. The Dog's house can be changed, as with any other NPC, however the Dog can share the same house as another NPC. Like other NPCs, the Dog also require a valid standing point in the house (a home tile). It may not be able to share a house with another NPC if the house is too small.

The Dog can be talked to with the ⚷ Open / Activate button, like any other town NPC. It will offer a " Pet " option, which places the player directly in front of the Dog when selected, and displays an animation of them petting the Dog, an effect that is a purely visual. It only works if there are at least two flat tiles on the same level as the Dog in front of it. Using any item, taking damage, or closing the dialogue window terminates the animation.
Like the Angler, the status message displayed when the Dog is killed is " <name of Dog> has left! ". It will respawn within the next days, and may respawn as a different breed.

The Squirrel Hook is a pre-Hardmode grappling hook that fires a single hook that reaches 19 tiles, and functions identically to a normal grappling hook but has the unique ability to grapple and attach to the trunks of trees and Giant Glowing Mushrooms. The Squirrel Hook can be purchased from the Zoologist for 2 GC.

The Gastropod is a flying Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns frequently on the surface of The Hallow at night, and if the player is within its line of sight, opens its shell and fires high-velocity Pink Lasers which emit faint pink light.
The Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version also feature the exclusive Spectral Gastropod variant. The Spectral Gastropod fires a Pink Laser, similar to that of the regular Gastropod.
Like most other slimes, the Gastropod will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.

The Hotdog is a food item that grants the Exquisitely Stuffed buff when consumed. This lasts for 12 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The Hotdog has a 1/30 (3.33%) chance of being dropped by Bone Serpents and Red Devils.
Like all other food items, the Hotdog can be placed on a Plate :

Explosives are a placeable, consumable mechanism that can be triggered using wiring. Triggering them causes a large, circular explosion that covers a radius of ten tiles (up to 314 blocks total), destroying most placed blocks and items (except for explosion-proof items), and inflicting a knockback of 10 (Extremely strong). The explosion deals 500 base damage to players, NPCs, enemies, and critters regardless of difficulty. Therefore, they can kill or severely damage even players with late-game gear.

Explosives can spawn naturally as traps wired to Pressure Plates, or wired to Detonators (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) next to a vein of ores can be found in the Underground and Cavern layer.
The Flintlock Pistol is a pre-Hardmode gun that fires bullets at a fast rate. It can be bought from the Arms Dealer for 5 GC. On Old-gen console and 3DS, it does not deal any knockback.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Unreal.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.

The Shadowflame Apparition is a Hardmode enemy summoned by the Goblin Warlock during the Goblin Army event. Summoned in swarms as projectiles, they pass through blocks while attempting to ram into the player. They are immune to knockback, and both they and their caster move very quickly, allowing them to easily overwhelm the player.

The Stone Slab is a block similar in appearance to regular stone, but smoother, and the texture is made up of much larger bricks. It is extremely easy to produce, although it requires a Heavy Work Bench which cannot easily be obtained very early on. Stone Slabs are more efficient to build with than Gray Bricks due to their recipe.

Obsidian Water Walking Boots are an immunity accessory which combines the abilities of the Water Walking Boots and the Obsidian Skull. They allow the wearer to walk on water, honey, and shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), while also giving immunity to the Burning debuff. They do not allow walking on lava.

The Vortex Fragment is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist crafting material. It is one of the four Lunar Fragments, dropped from the Vortex Pillar during the Lunar Events in stacks of 12-60 / 24-100. Vortex Fragments can be used to craft Vortex armor, an end-game armor set that benefits all types of ranged weapons, as well as Vortex-themed tools, weapons, wings, etc.

Crafting all items requires 121 Vortex Fragments and 68 Luminite Bars (272 Luminite), which necessitates defeating the Vortex Pillar at least 3-11 / 2-8 times (note that the Vortex Fragment can also be crafted from the other fragments) and fighting the Moon Lord at least 4 / 3-4 times.

The Eye Spring is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that summons an Eyeball Spring pet to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Eyeball Spring spins its tentacles to catch up to the player. The Eye Spring has a 1/15 (6.67%) / 1/10 (10%) chance of being dropped by Eyezors.

Shroomite Plating is a building material crafted from Stone Blocks and Shroomite Bars. It produces a small amount of light when placed but it does not count as a light source for housing. It is essentially the Shroomite equivalent of a brick.

The Night Vision Helmet is an armor piece for the helmet slot. For the player wearing it, it increases the apparent light level provided by all light sources on the screen, similarly to the Night Owl buff. The Night Vision Helmet has a 1/30 (3.33%) chance to be dropped by Granite Elementals and Granite Golems. It can also be purchased from the Cyborg for 5 GC, after the Martian Madness event has been completed in the current world.
The Fox set is a vanity set composed of the Fox Tail and Fox Ears. It can be purchased from the Zoologist during a Third Quarter for 6 GC (set).
Mummies are Hardmode enemies that spawn in the Desert biome, spawn in areas where Sand Blocks are present, and follow the Fighter AI, behaving similarly to Zombies.

There are several different types of Mummies: the standard Mummy, as well as the Dark Mummy, Light Mummy, and (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Blood Mummy. On the Desktop, Console, and Mobile versions, they spawn in Corrupted Deserts, Hallowed Deserts and Crimson Deserts, respectively. On the Old-gen console and 3DS versions, Dark Mummies can spawn in both Corrupted/Crimson Deserts.
On the Old-gen console and 3DS versions, there are other two exclusive types of Mummies: the Shadow Mummy and Spectral Mummy, which spawn in Corrupted Deserts and Hallowed Deserts respectively.

Dark Mummies and Blood Mummies are 150% faster than other Mummies. All mummies receive a 200% speed increase when they are reduced to 50% health or lower. In addition, Mummies inflict the following debuffs upon hitting the player:
Regular Mummies: Slow Dark Mummies/Blood Mummies/Shadow Mummies: Silenced, Darkness Light Mummies/Spectral Mummies: Confused

Block Swap is a building mechanic that allows the player to replace placed blocks in a single step, rather than having to remove existing blocks manually first. Block Swap can be activated or de-activated via a toggle located to the left of the main inventory / in the tools menu below the inventory.

Swapping blocks still requires that a player possess a tool with sufficient pickaxe power to free the target blocks, as the game performs a check for a tool of sufficient power before allowing Block Swaps to occur. Additionally, certain blocks can never be swapped via Block Swap (see list below).

When Block Swap is enabled, the player can place blocks over existing placed blocks, causing new blocks to "swap" with those already placed. When swapping blocks, existing placed blocks are automatically freed and dropped for collection.

The Graveyard is a mini-biome that appears when five or more Tombstones are in close proximity of the player. Unique Graveyard enemies spawn here day and night, as well as the usual creatures of the night. The spawn rate is not increased, but the enemy spawn reduction of Towns is weakened. NPC vendors have unique trades here, and the Ecto Mist on the ground enables unique crafting recipes for the player. These functional effects are only active with seven or more Tombstones nearby.
As more Tombstones are added, the Graveyard's visual effects grow stronger: Colors desaturate, lightning randomly strikes in the background, and Ecto Mist accumulates on the ground.
Sunflowers reverse a Graveyard's effects; each Sunflower negates the presence of one Tombstone.
The Molten Charm is a pre-Hardmode immunity accessory crafted from a Lava Charm and an Obsidian Skull, combining the effects of both items.

When the Molten Charm is equipped and the player comes into contact with lava, a 7-second countdown begins, signified by a lava meter that displays over the player's head. It operates similarly to the Breath meter, but displays flame icons instead of bubbles. Lava immunity time is recharged gradually by exiting lava, the same way breathing time is recharged by exiting water (albeit much more slowly).
The Molten Charm also grants immunity to the burning damage normally inflicted by contact with Meteorite, Hellstone, and Hellstone Brick. It does not grant immunity to other fire-based damage.
This accessory can be combined with the Water Walking Boots or the Obsidian Water Walking Boots, which are used in crafting the Lava Waders.

The Titan Potion is a buff potion which grants the Titan buff when consumed. The buff increases the amount of knockback the player inflicts on enemies by 50%. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8 minutes / (Old-gen console version) 4 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
The Grasshopper is a type of critter that can be found when destroying grass plants. The Grasshopper has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Grasshopper can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Grasshopper Cage). Once crafted, the Grasshopper cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Grasshopper can be used as bait for fishing, with 10% bait power.
The Grasshopper can be spawned by the Grasshopper Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, there is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Grasshopper to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

The Star Veil is a Hardmode accessory that combines the functions of the Star Cloak and the Cross Necklace, spawning falling star projectiles and increasing the length of the invincibility frames granted when the player is hurt.
Shadewood Walls are a type of Wall made from Shadewood.

The Ladybug is a small uncommon critter that can be found in Forests with a town during the Windy Day event at daytime. The Ladybug has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Ladybug can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Ladybug Cage). Once crafted, the Ladybug cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Ladybug can be used as bait for fishing, with 17% bait power.
There is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Ladybug to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

Touching naturally spawned Ladybugs will temporarily increase the player's luck, while killing natural or player-released Ladybugs or consuming them as bait will temporarily decrease the player's luck and boost the chance of rain. However, using them for crafting does not affect luck, allowing the following recipes to be made consequence-free.

The Mud Bud is a Hardmode, post- Plantera pet-summoning item that spawns Plantero, a miniature version of Plantera, to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, Plantero flies towards them in a manner similar to Plantera's second form while emitting a trail of falling leaves that are affected by wind. The Mud Bud can be purchased from the Zoologist for 50 GC after defeating Plantera.
Stucco Walls are background Walls crafted from Stucco.

Adamantite armor is a Hardmode armor set. Like most early-Hardmode armors, has three different helmet options, allowing the player to focus on magic, melee or ranged combat; each option changing the armor's set bonus. Crafting a one-helmet set requires 54 Adamantite Bars, made from 216 Adamantite Ore. Crafting all five pieces requires 78 Adamantite Bars, made from 312 Adamantite Ore. The Adamantite armor's alternative is Titanium armor.
A full set of Adamantite armor gives off a faint pulsing aura around the character. This effect is purely visual.

The Shrimpy Truffle is a Hardmode mount-summoning item that spawns Cute Fishron, a miniature rideable Duke Fishron -style mount that can fly and hover indefinitely. The Shrimpy Truffle is always dropped from Duke Fishron 's Treasure Bag in Expert Mode.

Cute Fishron has a base flight speed of 40 mph. Moving through liquids causes Cute Fishron to gain a drastic movement speed bonus of about +105% (to 82 mph, the fastest of any mount), as well as providing the rider with a +15% damage bonus, indicated by Cute Fishron's eyes glowing. These boosts continue for 6 seconds after it leaves liquid, though during this time, its speed boost drops to +100% (to 80 mph). Liquid boosts also take effect when Cute Fishron gets "wet" by flying in the rain, flying through Bubbles filled with liquids, being submerged in liquid from a filled Bucket, or being hit by a Water Gun. The +100% movement speed boost (80 mph) and +15% damage boost also take effect when the rider's health falls below half.

Upon contact with any blocks, Cute Fishron's movement speed is drastically lowered to a very slow crawl (5 mph, or 10 mph if boosted). This speed penalty is removed as soon as it loses contact with blocks.
Ancient Copper Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Ancient Copper Bricks. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Copper Brick Wall prior to 1.2.

The Bone Throwing Knife is a consumable ranged weapon similar to Throwing Knives. It can pierce up to 5 targets, hitting a total of 6 targets. Combined with fossil armor, it can be an effective weapon against the Eater of Worlds due to its piercing.

The Crimson Rod is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that launches a reddish rain cloud towards the cursor, where it rains damaging blood droplets downward onto enemies below. One cloud projectile can be placed at a time and it does not pass through terrain, instead stopping if it hits a surface before it reaches its target location. Once placed, the cloud will remain for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) five minutes / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) one minute, similarly to the Nimbus Rod 's cloud. As well, its coverage area is rather narrow, making it difficult to use in open areas or against agile foes. The droplets can pierce one enemy, dissipating upon hitting a second one or a solid block.

The Crimson Rod has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/5 (20%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/4 (25%) chance of being obtained from destroying Crimson Hearts found in the Crimson or a 1/5 (20%) chance from Crimson Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Hematic Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), which are fished in the Crimson.

Its best modifier is Demonic or Deadly for damage output, or Mystic for mana conservation because it cannot get modifiers that affect knockback.  Note that with the Rod's sentry-like summon pattern, mana usage is unlikely to be an issue, and that boosts to speed only affect how quickly the cloud can be resummoned, not how quickly the cloud produces rain.

Golden furniture are furniture items obtained from pirates during the Pirate Invasion. Each piece of furniture has a 1/300 (0.33%) chance of dropping from Pirate Corsairs, Crossbowers, Deadeyes, and Deckhands, and a 1/1 (100%) chance of dropping from the Flying Dutchman.
Ancient Copper Brick is a type of brick obtained by throwing Copper Brick into Shimmer. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Copper Brick prior to 1.2.
Nebula Brick Wall is a background wall made from Nebula Bricks.

The Moon Leech Clot is a projectile NPC which is spawned at the player's positon when the Moon Lord 's tongue grabs hold of the player. Moon Leech Clots do not deal any damage, but if a Moon Leech Clot manages to reach the Moon Lord's mouth before the Clot is killed, a part of the boss will be healed by 1000 health. Since they have no defense, though, they can be destroyed fairly easily with most Hardmode weapons.

The Snatcher is a pre-Hardmode enemy found in the surface Jungle, and is nearly identical in appearance and behavior to the Underground Jungle 's Man Eater. Snatchers spawn anchored to blocks, with an extendable stem topped by a pincher. The stem itself is a passive component and can be walked through safely without incurring damage; only the pincher inflicts or takes damage.
On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, there is also a slightly stronger Dragon Snatcher variant.

Projectiles are entities that serve various purposes in Terraria. Many projectiles deal damage and are created by either the player (e.g. when using most weapons) or enemies with ranged attacks. Minions, sentries, pets, and light pets are also projectiles. Some projectiles are not directly discernible as such, and are frequently used for visual effects, e.g. the "Lightning Ritual" of the Lunatic Cultist (ID 490) or the "Wire Kite" from The Grand Design (ID 651).

A few entities behave like comparable projectiles, but are NPCs (i.e. enemies) instead. For instance, the Fire Imp 's Burning Sphere has all the characteristics of an enemy (health, defense, knockback resistance, etc.), unlike actual projectiles, even though it merely serves as the Fire Imp's ranged attack "projectile". See Category:Projectile NPCs for the full list.

Relics are furniture items dropped by bosses and mini-bosses in Master Mode. They are golden depictions of their respective boss that hover above a pedestal, have a golden particle effect, and emit light when placed close to a light source.
There are 28 different relics available in Terraria.

The Nail Gun is a Hardmode, post- Plantera launcher -like weapon that consumes Nails as ammunition. When a Nail makes contact with an enemy, it deals 15% damage (17 base damage) and sticks to the damaged enemy before exploding after 1.5 seconds, dealing 135% damage (155 base damage). Nails will also stick to solid blocks and explode in the same manner, and their explosions do not damage the shooter. Nails are unaffected by gravity until they have flown roughly 30 tiles, at which point they fly with an arc similar to that of arrows. If used in PvP, the Nails will not stick to players and will instead deal normal damage (115 base damage).

The Nail Gun has a 1/25 (4%) / 49/625 (7.84%) chance of being dropped by Nailheads during the Solar Eclipse event. When dropped, the Nail Gun is always accompanied by 100 to 200 Nails. Additional Nails are also sold by both the Merchant and the Arms Dealer for 1 SC each when the player has the Nail Gun in their inventory.
Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it.
Racks are decorative items that are placed on walls. They have no functional effect. Unlike the Weapon Rack, these racks cannot be used to display other items.

The Enchanted Moondial is a furniture item that can be placed. It can be triggered by the ⚷ Open / Activate key or wires, doing so will advance time to dusk (7:30 PM) on the current or following day (depending on whether it is activated during day or night). It has a 7-day cooldown period, so once used, it will not be usable again until 7 in-game days have passed (see Notes for details). When the Enchanted Moondial is ready to be used, the dial at the top of its sprite and the moon in the middle will both glow bright blue, and the shape of the glowing moon in the middle corresponds to the current moon phase. The Enchanted Moondial is obtained by throwing an Enchanted Sundial into Shimmer.

The Enchanted Moondial does not turn the time to dusk immediately. It instead "fast-forwards" time, causing it to pass 60 times faster than usual (1 hour of in-game time, which would usually take 1 minute of real-life time, takes only 1 second while the Enchanted Moondial is active). When the Enchanted Moondial is taking effect, the effect of other time-accelerating methods (beds and the Journey Mode Time Menu) will be ignored. However, unlike these methods, the Enchanted Moondial does not increase the tile update rate in the world, meaning that things like plant growth and biome spread are unaffected when it is active.
