The Toolbox is a rare accessory that is obtained when opening Presents dropped during the Christmas seasonal event, with a chance of 0.309% in pre-Hardmode and 0.288% in Hardmode. It increases item placement and tool range by 1. The effect of the Toolbox stacks with that of the Builder buff, Toolbelt, and Extendo Grip or Architect Gizmo Pack.

The Gummy Worm is a permanent booster item that permanently increases the player's fishing power by 3. It can only be used once per player and is obtained when a Gold Worm comes into contact with Shimmer, either as a critter or in dropped item form.

The Frozen Shield is a Hardmode, post- Plantera shield accessory that combines the functionalities of the Paladin's Shield and the Frozen Turtle Shell : It redirects some damage done to teammates to the player, increases defense by 6, grants immunity to knockback, and provides the player with a damage-absorbing shield when they are at low health.

Launchers are a type of Hardmode ranged weapons that fire rockets and other, similar ammunition. The ammo used by launchers generally explodes on contact with an enemy or solid block, dealing heavy damage within the area of the explosion. It may damage the player if not fired carefully. All launchers benefit from the damage bonus of the Shroomite Helmet, as well as other ranged bonuses. They can only be obtained post- Plantera.

The Living Wood Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Living Trees, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained via crafting. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

Unsafe Living Wood Walls only allow Goldfish, Snail, Mouse, Worm, Bunny and Gnome to spawn in front of them. This effect is not applied in Don't dig up (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds.
On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the Living Wood Wall is always considered safe, even if it was naturally generated in Living Trees, and always drops as an item.

Mushrooms are plants which grow randomly on many grasses and other blocks. Biome spread or artificial biome change methods (solutions, Thrown Powders, Thrown Water, etc.) can convert regular Mushroom, Vile Mushroom, and Vicious Mushroom between each other, and convert Glowing Mushrooms and Jungle Spores between each other.
There are 6 types of mushrooms:

Luminite Hammers are tools which are currently unobtainable. The four types are the Solar Flare Hammer, Vortex Hammer, Nebula Hammer, and the Stardust Hammer, each themed after a different Celestial Tower. They are all unable to be crafted, and instead the player must craft the Luminite Hamaxes.

Solar Flare armor is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord armor set that provides melee weapon boosts. It is currently the final melee set available on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version. This armor set also provides the most base defense. Crafting the full set requires a total of 36 Luminite Bars (144 Luminite) and 45 Solar Fragments.
The set consists of the Solar Flare Helmet, Solar Flare Breastplate, and Solar Flare Leggings.
A full set of Solar Flare armor provides the following bonuses:
+78 defense +26% melee critical hit chance +29% melee damage +15% melee speed +15% movement speed +12% damage reduction Increased life regeneration (+3 HP/sec) +900 aggro

Equipping the full set additionally provides a special set bonus, the Solar Blaze buff, which builds the longer the player avoids taking damage, gaining up to a maximum of three "charges" (similar to Beetle armor). Each of these charges takes 3 seconds to build and provides a fixed damage reduction of 20% regardless of the number of charges. The number of charges built is indicated by a shield that appears in front of the player upon gaining the first charge, with two and three spikes appearing on the shield on the second and third charges, respectively.

Taking damage causes one charge to deplete, and discharges fire explosions around the player that can damage enemies in the vicinity. When there is at least one charge available, the player can activate a special dash attack by double-tapping either the ◀ Left or ▶ Right key. If the dash strikes an enemy, a charge is consumed, and enemies hit during the dash will be damaged and cause a fire explosion, i.e. every enemy hit takes damage twice. The player can only dash once per second. The set bonus also grants a 12% base damage reduction, which stacks multiplicatively with the damage reduction from the shield.

Each piece equipped (even if hidden by vanity items) causes the player to emit light, with a higher light level for each additional piece equipped. Additionally, equipping the full set displays both an after-image motion effect and a pulsating effect, similar to Hallowed armor.

The Scarecrow is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns during the Pumpkin Moon event. There are ten varieties of Scarecrow, five of which lack legs and can only move by jumping, while the other five follow the normal Fighter AI. Scarecrows have a 1/10 (10%) chance to inflict the Weak debuff for 1 minute / 2 minutes / 2 minutes and 30 seconds.
Defeating a Scarecrow during the Pumpkin Moon event will add 1 / 2 / 2.5 points to the final score.
All Scarecrow varieties require 150 kills to be awarded completion of their Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Ammo Reservation Potion is a buff potion which grants the Ammo Reservation buff when consumed. The buff reduces the chance of consuming any ammunition by 20%. This lasts for 8 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.
The Lead Broadsword is an early game metal broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Iron Broadsword.
Like all broadswords, this sword has an arc motion, which is more useful for killing flying and jumping enemies than shortswords.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Underground is the first layer below the surface. It fills the area between the Surface and Cavern layers, beginning at a depth of 0ft and extending downward.

Its distinctive background can recognize the Underground, which no longer contains naturally-placed Dirt Walls like surface terrain, but instead displays a unique, often brown, backdrop with no naturally-placed walls. Players cannot remove this backdrop using a Hammer, nor can they place blocks in midair, as no wall generally exists here (though players can place their walls, just as they can above surface terrain). Natural Underground blocks are generally similar to those in the surface, with Dirt and Stone making up the majority of the biome. Clay, Silt, and lower-tier gems and ores can also be found in small pockets here. Some miscellaneous treasures can be found here, including Gem Trees (which drop Gemcorns, Stone, and occasionally their respective gems when chopped down); dye plants including Green Mushrooms, Orange Bloodroot, and Teal Mushrooms ; and the Blinkroot herb.

The Underground is home to more aggressive enemies than the surface. More powerful Red and Yellow Slimes will spawn down here (alongside the rare Pinky), while Blue Jellyfish spawn in the water and Giant Worms are found burrowing through the ground. In Hardmode, more powerful counterparts of these enemies will spawn, with the Digger, Green Jellyfish, and Toxic Sludge mostly replacing Giant Worms, Blue Jellyfish, and regular Slimes respectively.

Traps will also begin appearing in this layer. Underground Cabins, though not as common as in the Caverns, will frequently appear with handy loot such as the Cloud in a Bottle, Hermes Boots, and Magic Mirror.

In general, not much time is spent here, but instead in the Cavern layer, which holds many more enemies, spawns treasures, and unique drops. Therefore, it is a wise idea almost entirely to ignore this layer in favor of exploring the Caverns.

Occasionally, the Mouse and Snail critters will be found scurrying around. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Fairies have a rare chance of randomly showing up and guiding the player to a random treasure (such as chests, Life Crystals, or ores) nearby.

True underground versions of biomes, such as the Ice biome or Underground Corruption, do not begin in this layer, but in the Cavern layer (except for the Underground Desert, which begins in Surface terrain and extends through the Underground and a portion of the Cavern). In Hardmode, some blocks in the Underground can be converted into Hallow, Corruption, or Crimson.

Stinky is a cosmetic debuff that causes anything afflicted by it to emit green particles for a given duration. It can only be encountered by using a Stink Potion or the Flymeal, or by standing on Poo.
Spooky Wood is a type of wood dropped by Splinterlings and Mourning Wood during the Pumpkin Moon event. It is used to craft Halloween-themed furniture and Spooky armor.

The Golf Cup is a block and activation mechanism used in Golf. It can be purchased from the Golfer for 1 GC. When a Golf Ball enters the cup, the Golf Ball projectile is removed from the world, the cup emits a wire signal, and a status message will share how many strokes the player took between placing the ball, hitting it and reaching the cup.

The Eye of Cthulhu is a Hardmode, post- Plantera yoyo which has a 1/3 (33.33%) / 5/9 (55.56%) chance of being dropped by Mothrons during a Solar Eclipse. It is the second-strongest yoyo in the game, only beaten by the Terrarian.
It has an infinite spin duration and can reach up to 22.5 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
The Hanging Pot is a placeable decorative furniture item obtained by opening Obsidian Crates and Hellstone Crates.

The Unholy Trident is a Hardmode magic weapon that autofires high-velocity purple tridents and has a fast fire rate, but a high mana cost. The trident projectiles pierce up to two enemies and dissipate upon impact with a third. The Unholy Trident has a 1/30 (3.33%) chance of being dropped by Red Devils.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

Lihzahrd Chests are chests found in the Jungle Temple. Each contains one Lihzahrd Power Cell, and may contain a Lihzahrd Furnace, some Solar Tablet Fragments, and sometimes, a Solar Tablet. They also contain other typical Gold Chest loot.
The Tongue is a debuff inflicted by the Wall of Flesh when the player has the Horrified debuff and one of the following happens:
The player gets behind the Wall of Flesh. The player attempts to leave the Underworld.

When afflicted with this debuff, the Wall of Flesh draws in the player with a tendril at a base speed of 56 mph, ignoring blocks in the way. In Expert Mode, the debuff also causes the player to take 50 damage per second. If the euclidean distance between the player and Wall of Flesh is more than 187.5 tiles when the debuff is inflicted, the player will die instantly instead of being drawn to the Wall of Flesh.

Living Wood furniture are furniture items crafted from Wood at a Living Loom. There are 20 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 17 (Old-gen console version) / 13 (3DS version) different Living Wood furniture items.

Bones are crafting materials and consumable ranged weapons. They are dropped by Angry Bones, Dark Casters, and Cursed Skulls, which spawn in the Dungeon. On the Nintendo 3DS version, Bones are also dropped by normal Skeletons.

Bones are greatly affected by gravity, and arc similarly to Throwing Knives and Shurikens. Of these three consumable ranged weapons, Bones have the least range (Throwing Knives having the greatest). (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) When used as weapons, Bones have a 1/2 (50%) chance of being retrievable after use, even if they hit enemies.
Furthermore, Bones can be placed as blocks using the Bone Wand, upon which they become Bone Blocks.
The Robe is a vanity item equipped in the shirt slot. It resembles the robes worn by Dark Casters and Tim. It can be augmented by gems to form part of the Wizard set.

The Bee Gun is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that ordinarily fires 1-3 (1-6 with a Hive Pack (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) equipped) piercing bee projectiles per shot, with two independent 1/6 (16.67%) chances to fire an extra bee. The bees deal 100% of the weapon's base damage (9 base damage) and have a 1/2 (50%) chance to deal 1 extra damage. Bee projectiles home in on their closest target and pierce enemies two times (hitting three times) before dissipating after a 10-second duration, after ricocheting off solid blocks three separate times, or immediately upon contact with water or lava. The Bee Gun has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of being dropped by the Queen Bee.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Mythical.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its best modifier is Demonic or Deadly for damage output, or Mystic for mana conservation because it cannot get modifiers that affect knockback.

The Fish Bowl, Gold Fish Bowl (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Pupfish Bowl (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Lava Serpent Bowl (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are decorative furniture items. The Fish Bowl and Gold Fish Bowl also double as wearable items that can be equipped in the player's helmet slot.

Fish Bowls cause only visual effects when placed in the helmet vanity slot. When instead placed in the functional head armor slot, the breath meter appears as if the player were underwater, and if worn long enough the player will drown and die. Breathing aids like the Breathing Reed or Gills Potion will allow for normal breathing when wearing the bowl.
The Fish, Gold Fish and Pupfish Bowls are crafted, while the Lava Serpent Bowl has a 39/200 (19.5%) chance of being found inside Obsidian Crates and Hellstone Crates.
The Code 2 is a Hardmode yoyo that is an upgrade of the Code 1 and can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 25 GC after at least one of the mechanical bosses has been defeated.
It has an infinite spin duration and can reach up to 17.5 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

Poisoned is a debuff that prevents health regeneration and causes the afflicted NPC or player to take damage each second for the duration of the debuff. A player is immune if they have a Bezoar or its upgrades equipped. Debuffed entities will also gain a green tint, and (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) players will squint for the debuff's duration. The damage varies by platform :

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 6 damage per second when inflicted to enemies, and 2 damage per second when inflicted to players. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 2 damage per second to any entity.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Enemies immune to Poisoned are also immune to Venom.

The Celestial Shell is a Hardmode, post- Golem accessory that combines the stat-boosting powers of the Celestial Stone with the transformation powers of the Moon Shell, allowing both of their effects to happen simultaneously while taking only one accessory slot.

The Rage Potion is a buff potion which grants the Rage buff when consumed. The buff increases the player's critical strike chance by 10%. This lasts for 4 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.
The Pink Maid set is a vanity set consisting of the Pink Maid Bonnet, Pink Maid Dress and Pink Maid Shoes. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Umbrella is a held item, and on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, a melee weapon as well. It can be found in surface Chests and (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) in Wooden Crates. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It can also be purchased for 1 GC from the Skeleton Merchant during a Waning Gibbous.
When held, the Umbrella appears above the character, allowing the player to fall at a slower rate and preventing fall damage. The player can hold ▼ Down to increase the fall speed.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Legendary.

Loki's Dye is a Hardmode dye that can be obtained from Hardmode bosses ' Treasure Bags (except Queen Slime 's), as part of Loki's set. It does not change the color of the armor, but rather adds a dark gray flames effect, similar to four other dyes which are obtained by trading Strange Plants with the Dye Trader in Hardmode. Equipping Loki's Dye in all 3 dye slots intensifies the effect. It also makes the item in whatever slot it’s in glow in the dark.

The Spore Bat is a pre-Hardmode bat enemy that spawns in underground Glowing Mushroom biomes. It has the same stats as a Cave Bat. However, Spore Bats have a chance to drop a Shroomerang. In Expert Mode, it can inflict the Feral Bite debuff for 30-90 seconds.

The Mollusk Whistle is a mount-summoning item that summons a rideable Flamingo. The Flamingo mount allows players to float in water, similar to using an Inner Tube, and dive by holding ▼ Down. The mount bobs to the surface when the ▼ Down key is released, and if deep enough, the player will launch out of the water into the air. The Mollusk Whistle can be purchased from the Zoologist for 20 GC after filling out 25% (135 entries) of the Bestiary.

The Dusty Rawhide Saddle, Royal Gilded Saddle, and Black Studded Saddle are mount-summoning items that summon the rideable Painted Horse Mount, Majestic Horse Mount, and Dark Horse Mount, respectively. All three horse mounts are functionally identical. Once they reach a high speed, they will deal damage to enemies they come into contact with. Saddles are sold by the Zoologist for 25 GC each, after completing at least 30% (162 entries) of the Bestiary.
The Titanium Sword is a Hardmode broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Adamantite Sword.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Hardened Sand Block is a type of block, along with Sandstone Blocks, that make up the Underground Desert biome. It looks similar to Sand Blocks, with an altered texture and slightly different color. Unlike sand, it is not affected by gravity. Like all sand-based blocks, it has Corruption, Crimson, and Hallowed counterparts: Hardened Ebonsand, Hardened Crimsand, and Hardened Pearlsand respectively.
The Release Doves are a consumable item sold by the Party Girl for 1 SC when in a Graveyard. Using the item releases three Doves, which fly around and disappear after 5 seconds.
The Apple Pie Slice is an unimplemented item.

The lighting mode determines the way light from all sources renders in the world. The lighting mode can be changed from the settings menu. On the Desktop version, it can also be cycled by pressing ⇧ Shift + F9 while in-game.
The lighting mode also dictates whether the game will utilize certain performance-intensive visual effects, like the smoothing of liquid flow, along with the following shader effects:

The reddish lighting and vignette applied during a Blood Moon The distortion effect around Celestial Towers The heat distortion effect in the Desert and The Underworld The amplified background dust effect seen during Sandstorms The sepia filter applied in a Constant world or while the Radio Thing is equipped

The effects above will only be applied in the Color or White lighting modes, and are deactivated in the Retro and Trippy modes. On the Console version and Mobile version, these effects are controlled by a separate setting and are unaffected by the lighting mode.
The chosen lighting mode will have an effect on the performance of some devices. Refer to the table below for each mode's performance impact.
Red Riding armor is a Hardmode, post- Golem armor set purchased from the Tavernkeep for 1500000* 150 in total, and provides summon as well as ranged damage bonuses.
The set consists of the Red Riding Hood, Red Riding Dress, and Red Riding Leggings.
A full set of Red Riding armor provides the following bonuses:
+48 defense +25% ranged damage +60% summon damage +20% ranged critical strike chance +20% ammo conservation +20% movement speed +3 extra sentry slots

Equipping the full set will greatly increase the fire rate of Explosive Trap sentry summons and will cause their attacks to inflict the Oiled debuff for 4-8.5 seconds, making enemies take increased damage from On Fire!, Hellfire, Cursed Inferno, Frostburn, Frostbite, and Shadowflame.
The Red Riding armor can be considered a direct upgrade of the Huntress armor.

The Nutcracker is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during wave 3 of the Frost Moon event. There are two Nutcracker variants, each with slightly differing damage and defense. The first variant will transform into the more powerful second variant when its health is reduced to below 55% (990 / 1,485 / 2,227). The Nutcracker's spinning second form gains a higher resistance to knockback and significantly increased movement speed.
Defeating a Nutcracker during the Frost Moon event will add 4 / 8 / 10 points to the final score.

The Clentaminator is a Hardmode tool which can be used to create or destroy biomes. It uses Solutions as ammunition, with each Solution spreading a different biome. It has a similar firing pattern to the Flamethrower, but has a much longer range, fires through blocks and works in water. The Clentaminator is generally the fastest means of spreading or removing Hallow, Corruption and Crimson. It can also rapidly convert Jungle to Glowing Mushroom biome and vice versa.
It can be purchased from the Steampunker for 2 PC.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, after the Moon Lord is defeated, the Clentaminator can be upgraded into the Terraformer by throwing it into Shimmer. Also, the Clentaminator will not be sold in don't dig up and get fixed boi worlds.
The Clentaminator cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.
The Silver Shortsword is an early game metal shortsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Tungsten Shortsword.

Like all shortswords, the Silver Shortsword has a very limited range and attacks with a stabbing motion at any direction on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, and horizontally in front of the player on Old-gen console and 3DS, instead of an arc. This makes it almost useless against flying or jumping enemies, although its high attack rate makes it somewhat effective against weaker fighter type enemies.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Ornate Shadow Key is a pet-summoning item that spawns a pet Shadow Mimic to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Shadow Mimic propels itself by spinning towards them while emitting a trail of purple flames. It will also occasionally spit out non-collectible cosmetic coins. The Ornate Shadow Key has a 1/10 (10%) chance of being obtained from Shadow Chests and a 1/20 (5%) chance of being obtained from Obsidian Crates and Hellstone Crates.

Pumpkin furniture are furniture items crafted from Pumpkin, which can be planted and harvested by the player. There are 21 (22 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) different Pumpkin furniture items.

Skiphs' Blood is a Hardmode dye obtained from Hardmode bosses ' Treasure Bags (except Queen Slime 's) along with Skiphs' set. It can also be a random reward from the Dye Trader for completing a Strange Plant quest after the Moon Lord has been defeated. When equipped, it gives the player a dark purple tone, also adding a shimmering purple effect to the player's body.
The Mythical Wyvern is a removed, unimplemented flying enemy that was associated with the Chinese New Year seasonal event. It was a variant of the Wyvern.
The Mythical Wyvern existed in the game files, but was never able to spawn during standard gameplay.
The Deathbringer Pickaxe is a post- Brain of Cthulhu pickaxe. Its Corruption counterpart is the Nightmare Pickaxe.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Deathbringer Pickaxe can mine any blocks and ores weaker than Dungeon Bricks (which requires a pickaxe with at least 100% pickaxe power, e.g. a Molten Pickaxe). Most notably, it can mine Ebonstone, Crimstone, Hellstone, and Pearlstone.
On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the Deathbringer Pickaxe can also mine Dungeon Bricks.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Axe of Regrowth is a multi-purpose tool. It functions identically to the Staff of Regrowth, increasing herb and herb seed collection by the same amount, and can be used to create grass on dirt. It can also be used as an axe, with the unique ability to replant an Acorn on the grass block directly underneath a tree after it is chopped.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.
The Soul of Might is one of the six souls. It is a crafting material dropped by The Destroyer.
The Squirrel and Red Squirrel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are harmless critters that spawn in the Forest biome.
Squirrels have only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

Squirrels can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Squirrel / Red Squirrel Cage). Once crafted, the Squirrels cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Squirrels can be spawned by the Squirrel Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, there is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Squirrel to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

The Boulder is a unique placeable foreground object that is stationary when placed. When unsupported, it falls and begins to roll away, picking up speed and damaging players, enemies, critters, and NPCs along its path. Boulders will also begin to roll if hit with a pickaxe or drill, meaning that they cannot be picked up again once placed.

Boulders will roll across flat surfaces and down slopes, but will break and disappear on contact with an obstacle. They deal 140 / 280 / 420 damage to players (70 damage to NPCs, enemies, and critters) and inflict a knockback of 10 (Extremely strong) on contact. While rolling, Boulders can pierce through an unlimited number of entities and accelerate to a top speed of 36 mph over the course of 2.17 seconds.

Boulder traps occur naturally in the Underground and Cavern layers, and consist of a single Boulder in the ceiling, supported by six (2x3) Active Stone Blocks while wired to a Orange Pressure Plate. Once a player walks onto the Pressure Plate, the Boulder falls down and begins rolling.

In For the worthy (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Get fixed boi (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds, Boulders will release 2-4 miniature Boulders when they break. These function identical to the Boulder projectile, but are smaller and deal 75% base damage (105 / 210 / 315).
Midas is a Hardmode debuff that causes affected enemies to drop 10-49% more coins than usual on death. Affected enemies glow golden, much like enemies afflicted with the Ichor debuff.
Blackout is a debuff that significantly decreases the player's light vision. It can be considered a stronger version of the Darkness debuff.

Fall damage refers to the damage a player character sustains upon falling a large distance. It is one of the basic game mechanics. Fall damage occurs only if the distance of the fall exceeds a fixed threshold, beyond which the damage amount increases linearly with the distance traveled past said threshold. If the damage amount is greater than or equal to the player's current health, the player dies upon impact. Like all kinds of other damage, it provides invincibility frames and can be reduced by the player's defense and damage reduction.

Fall damage works the same way for all solid surfaces, but it does not occur when submerged in water, lava, or honey, nor is it applied in special circumstances, e.g. when landing on the surface of a liquid while wearing an accessory such as Lava Waders or landing on a Minecart Track in a Minecart. Fall damage can also be affected by certain buffs and debuffs, such as Stoned (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). See Interaction for all things that interact with fall damage.
The Spore Skeleton is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in underground Glowing Mushroom biomes. Its behavior, drops, and statistics are all equivalent to normal Skeletons.

The Bouncy Boulder is a placeable object that begins to roll and bounce when it becomes unsupported. Once it is in motion, it will bounce several times before coming to a stop. Its motion is similar to a Bouncy Bomb but faster, and it does damage like a Boulder. It spawns naturally in Celebrationmk10, No traps, and Get fixed boi worlds.

Buggy is one of three critters that occasionally spawn in the Jungle or Underground Jungle biome when a player breaks a background plant, the others being Sluggy (more common) and Grubby (most common). Buggy is the rarest of the three. Buggy has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

Buggy can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Buggy Cage). Once crafted,  Buggy cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Buggy can be used as bait for fishing, with 40% bait power.
Buggy can be spawned by the Buggy Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
Iron Brick Wall is a type of background wall.
The Owl is a critter that spawns on the surface Forest during the night. The Owl has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Owl can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Owl Cage). Once crafted, the Owl cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Owl can be spawned by the Owl Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
Frost Minnows are a type of fish which are found uncommonly by fishing in a Snow biome in any layer. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners and Warmth Potions.

The Heartreach Potion is a buff potion which grants the Heartreach buff when consumed. The buff increases the pickup range of life recovery Hearts by 15.625 tiles, from 2.625 tiles to a total of 18.25 tiles. This lasts for 8 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

The Ballista Rod, Cane, and Staff are special sentry summon weapons. They can summon the Ballista sentry, which lasts for 10 minutes, remains stationary, and does not count against the player's minion capacity. Each Ballista sentry is a large automated crossbow device on the ground that fires Ballista Shot projectiles at approaching enemies, piercing up to three of them, and deals high damage but has rather slow firing speed. The Rod is sold by the Tavernkeep for 50000* 5, the Cane for 150000* 15, and the Staff for 600000* 60.

The Rod is always available. The Cane becomes available after defeating one mechanical boss, and the Staff becomes available after defeating Golem. The three different versions cause an identical effect, but with varying statistics, with the Staff being the most expensive and the most powerful.

These weapons cannot be used outside of the Old One's Army event until the event has been successfully completed. Completing the event on any difficulty allows Rods, Canes, and Staves alike to be used outside of the event.

During the Old One's Army event, Etherian Mana can be collected, which allows the placement of multiple Ballistas that remain permanently until the event is over. Etherian Mana cannot be used outside the event.

Ballista sentries are boosted by the Squire armor and Valhalla Knight armor set bonuses, which increase the velocity of the Ballista Shot projectiles and allow them to pierce up to three more enemies, for a maximum of six. In addition, they grant the Ballista Panic! buff for 5 seconds when the player takes damage, which increases the sentries' fire rate. The Valhalla Knight armor also greatly increases the fire rate.

Their best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting sentry. Additionally, sentries cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Ballista has over a Ruthless one is knockback.
Aetherium Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Aetherium Bricks.

The Robotic Skull is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that spawns Mini Prime, a miniature version of Skeletron Prime that follows the player around. The Robotic Skull has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by Skeletron Prime in Master Mode.
The Corruptor is a Hardmode enemy that spawns within The Corruption and resembles a larger version of the Eater of Souls. It intermittently fires Vile Spit projectiles that inflict the Weak debuff.

The Rich Mahogany Hammer is a low-tier hammer. It is identical in utility to the Copper Hammer, so a beginning player wishing to conserve metal for armor might choose to make this hammer instead, assuming they can reach the Jungle.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.
The Dark Mage is a mini-boss that spawns during the Old One's Army event, during Tier 1 in wave 5, and Tier 3 in waves 4 and 6.

There are four types of liquids in Terraria : water, lava, honey and shimmer. While each has varying properties, all of these liquids share common "liquid mechanics" that describe how they move and interact with their surroundings. For example, all liquids flow to fill the area they occupy, and they can all be collected or moved using certain items. Liquids besides shimmer can become dangerous if the player falls into them if they occupy a deep enough space, as the player can then be subjected to drowning. However, all liquids are useful to some extent since they can be used for crafting, which is one of the main distinctive features between the different types of liquids.

The Hive-Five is a pre-Hardmode yoyo that, upon striking an enemy, has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of summoning a single friendly Bee projectile that attacks nearby enemies. This Bee projectile deals 50% of the weapon's base damage (12 damage), has a 1/2 (50%) chance to deal 1 extra damage, can pierce enemies or ricochet off solid blocks three times in total, and lasts for 10 seconds.
It has a spin duration of 11 seconds and can reach up to 14 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Stinger Necklace is a pre-Hardmode accessory that is obtainable after defeating the Queen Bee. This item combines the Shark Tooth Necklace and the Honey Comb accessories, giving the player 5 armor penetration as well as releasing 1-3 / 1-4 bees when the wearer takes damage and granting the Honey buff for 5 seconds.

A Ghost is a character's representation upon death while playing in Hardcore mode. Ghosts can continue to explore the world, fly limitlessly, and pass through blocks. They cannot be seen by other players and cannot be harmed, nor can they attack, but can open doors, and they can continue to chat with other players in Multiplayer.
When a player dies and becomes a ghost, all their items are dropped at the location of their death. If they log out, their character is permanently deleted.
The Ivy is a novelty instrument. It will always drop from the Steampunker, but only when her name is Whitney. When used, the player strums a chord depending on how far the cursor is from the player.

The Restoration Potion is a recovery potion that restores health ((Old-gen console and 3DS versions) and mana) and inflicts Potion Sickness when used. Despite its appearance, it is not created by upgrading Lesser Restoration Potions.
Consuming a Restoration Potion has the following effect:

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Restores 90 health and inflicts Potion Sickness for only 45 seconds (rather than the usual 60 of health-restoring potions). The duration of Potion Sickness can be further reduced to 33.75 seconds via the Philosopher's Stone or Charm of Myths. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Restores 100 health and 100 mana. Potion Sickness lasts for the full 60 seconds.
Restoration Potions can be found in Shadow Chests in the Underworld.
The Mime Mask is a vanity item equipped in the Social Helmet slot. It is purchased from the Clothier during a Blood Moon for 2 GC.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The game does not display the Mime Mask as a vanity item.

Golf Balls are accessories that are used in golf and come in a variety of colors. The plain, white Golf Ball can be purchased from the Golfer for 1 GC and can be used for crafting the colored variants.
The Golf Ball items are not required to play golf, as pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on an empty Golf Tee will always create a Golf Ball projectile. Their main purposes are:

Changing the color of this projectile, which is a purely visual effect. The Golf Ball item does not need to be equipped for this. Manually placing Golf Ball projectiles anywhere in the world, even outside of Golf Tees. This is done by pressing the ⚒ Use / Attack button while the Golf Ball item is selected. The item will not be consumed.
Golf Ball projectiles can be hit with a Golf Club and despawn when entering a Golf Cup.
Pearlwood armor is a Hardmode armor set consisting of the Pearlwood Helmet, the Pearlwood Breastplate, and the Pearlwood Greaves.
Wearing a full set grants a basic 7 defense plus a set bonus of 1 defense, which equals a total of 8 defense.

The Lavaproof Bug Net is an upgraded version of the Bug Net. It allows the player to successfully catch the Lavafly, Magma Snail, and Hell Butterfly that can be used to fish in lava. It swings faster than the Bug Net and can destroy tall grass and vines.
Its upgraded version is the Golden Bug Net which is faster and bigger.
The Skull Lantern is a decorative piece of Furniture that provides light. They always face left, and cannot be turned off via wires and a switch.

The Pork of the Sea is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that spawns Tiny Fishron, a smaller version of Duke Fishron that acts as a pet. The Pork of the Sea has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by Duke Fishron in Master Mode.

The HiTek Sunglasses are a Hardmode, post- Golem vanity item for the social helmet slot. They are similar to the Sunglasses and Goggles, in that they provide eye graphics without concealing the player's hair. HiTek Sunglasses are purchased from the Cyborg for 5 GC, after the Martian Madness event has been defeated.
The Lead Pickaxe is an early-game pickaxe. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Iron Pickaxe.
Like other low-tier pickaxes, it can only mine blocks and ores weaker than Meteorite (which requires a pickaxe with at least 50% pickaxe power, e.g. a Tungsten Pickaxe).
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Goblin Warrior is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Goblin Army event. It follows the Fighter AI and is the most commonly encountered enemy in the event. Approximately one out of every three goblins will be a Warrior (31.6% chance to spawn).
Like many other enemies that follow the Fighter AI, Goblin Warriors can open doors and Tall Gates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Magic Hat is an armor item that can be equipped in the helmet slot. It increases the player's magic damage and magic critical strike chance by (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 6% / (Old-gen console version) 7% each, and grants 2 additional defense. It is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 3 GC.
The Magic Hat is part of the Wizard set, which further consists of a Mystic Robe or any gem-augmented Robe. It provides a set bonus of +60 mana. The Wizard Hat is an alternative for the helmet slot.

The Herpling is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Crimson. It attacks the player by quickly jumping across the ground. While it cannot jump very high, it can cover horizontal distance very quickly, making it a potent threat.

The Peace Candle is a furniture item that can be placed or held to decrease enemy and critter spawn rates in the area and emits a low amount of light. When placed, it gives nearby players the Peace Candle buff. Holding a Peace Candle does not cause the buff icon to display, but still causes an identical effect. The Peace Candle can be made from a Pink Torch and either Gold Bars or Platinum Bars, meaning that the player needs to have defeated Pinky at least once to craft this item.

The Peace Candle buff decreases spawn rates by 23% in the area and decreases the maximum number of simultaneous on-screen enemies by 30%. The buff is applied to any players holding a Peace Candle or standing within a rectangular area of 170x125 tiles centered on a Peace Candle. In order to be considered "holding" the candle, it must be in the player's hotbar and currently selected; merely being in a player's inventory will not suffice. Multiple Candles will not stack with each other, even if one is placed and the other held. Peace Candles can only be placed on platforms and flat furniture items like Work Benches and Tables.
Pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on Peace Candles shuts them off, and they will toggle when activated via wiring. Peace Candles that are turned off will not activate the Peace Candle buff.

The opposite of the Peace Candle is the Water Candle, which increases enemy spawn rate instead. If a Peace Candle and a Water Candle are active at the same time, they will cancel each other's effects out, resulting in no difference in spawn rate.
Ancient Gold Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Ancient Gold Bricks. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Gold Brick Wall prior to 1.2.

The Obsidian Skin Potion is a buff potion which grants the Obsidian Skin buff when consumed. The buff makes the player immune to lava and the On Fire! and Burning debuffs, subsequently granting immunity to damage from Meteorite, Hellstone, Hellstone Bricks, and Ancient Hellstone Bricks (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) for its duration. This lasts for 6 minutes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 4 minutes (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

The Hematic Crate is a Hardmode crate that can only be obtained by fishing in The Crimson. Hematic Crates contain items found in standard crates, and additionally always drop an item normally obtained by breaking a Crimson Heart. Its pre-Hardmode counterpart is the Crimson Crate.

The Pineapple is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Rich Mahogany tree.
Like all other food items, the Pineapple can be placed on a Plate :

The Cyborg is a Hardmode, post- Plantera NPC vendor who sells several "high-tech" items, most notably rocket ammunition for launcher weapons. He will move in once the following criteria have been met:
There is an available vacant house. Plantera has been defeated.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Cyborg will attack nearby enemies with three different types of explosives to defend himself: grenade, rocket, and proximity mine. These are identical to the attack style of the Grenade Launcher, Rocket Launcher, and the Proximity Mine Launcher. Proximity mines from the Cyborg also deal triple the damage when stationary.
Candy Cane Walls are background walls crafted from Candy Cane Blocks. They can only be obtained during Christmas, but will remain in the world after Christmas passes.

The generation of a new random world follows the process outlined on this page. While it is ongoing, various texts appear over the loading bar, showing what is being generated in the world. In Not the bees (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) worlds, all texts are replaced with " Generating bees ".

The Feather is a common crafting material dropped frequently by Harpies and Turkor the Ungrateful (3DS version). It is used in crafting the Featherfall and Gravitation Potions and once again becomes important in Hardmode for crafting the first tier of wings - Angel, Demon, and Sparkly Wings (Old-gen console and 3DS versions).

The Venom Arrow is a Hardmode, post- Plantera type of arrow used as ammunition for bows and repeaters. They have the highest base damage of all arrows and they inflict the Acid Venom debuff for 10 seconds upon hitting an enemy.

Of all the Hardmode arrows, they are the easiest to craft, as their ingredients can both be bought from NPCs : they require only Wooden Arrows (5 CC each, bought from the Merchant) and a Vial of Venom (15 SC each, bought from the Witch Doctor), totaling 16 SC 75 CC for 35 Venom Arrows (approximately 48 CC per arrow), or 47 GC 85 SC 24 CC for a full stack of 9999 Venom Arrows.

The Lime Kelp is a dye material and type of plant that is found under any liquid (most commonly underwater) in the Underground and Cavern layers. It is most common in the Ice Biome, and spawns very rarely in the regular underground and cavern layers. It can only be harvested with a Pickaxe. Its sole purpose is to make Lime Dye. It can also be found in the Ocean Biome.

Crystal Assassin armor is a Hardmode armor set grants non- class -specific bonuses. The set consists of the Crystal Assassin Hood, Crystal Assassin Shirt, and the Crystal Assassin Pants. It is obtained from Queen Slime, and she always drops one piece / two pieces upon defeat.
A full set of Crystal Assassin armor provides the following benefits:
+36 defense +15% damage +15% critical strike chance +20% movement speed -10% mana cost +10% ammo conservation +10% melee speed Ability to dash by double-tapping either the ◀ Left or ▶ Right key

Potion Sickness is a debuff inflicted on a player whenever they use a healing item. It prevents the player from consuming any more healing items until the debuff runs out. Its duration can be reduced by 25% by equipping the Philosopher's Stone or the Charm of Myths. Equipping both will not cause the effect to stack.
For nearly all healing items, the Potion Sickness debuff lasts 60 seconds, after which time another can be consumed.
The Scarecrow set is a vanity set which consists of the Scarecrow Hat, the Scarecrow Shirt and the Scarecrow Pants. All the parts of the set are dropped by Scarecrows during the Pumpkin Moon event.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Copper Ore is an early game ore, which spawns on the surface as well as in the Underground and Cavern layers. It is the weakest and most easily obtained tier of ore in the game. Its primary use is to make Copper Bars, which can be used to create the Copper tier of equipment. (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) Copper Ore has a small chance to appear as a bonus drop from slimes.
Its alternate ore counterpart is the Tin Ore.

Rarity is a property that applies to all items, loosely indicating their value and the difficulty through which they are obtained. An item's rarity is indicated in-game by the color of its name text, as displayed, for example, when rolling the cursor over the item in an inventory slot. An item's rarity can be raised or lowered by up to two tiers depending on its modifier.
Any item with a rarity of 00* will be destroyed when it is dropped into lava and half-submerged in it, with the following exceptions:

Obsidian Fireblossom Fireblossom Seeds Living Fire Block (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) (only the regular type, not its variants) Grate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Buckets (all 4 variants) Minecart Tracks (all 3 variants) Crispy Honey Block Chain
All items with a rarity that is not 00* will never be destroyed when dropped into lava.

Team Blocks are decorative blocks purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 1 SC each. Team Blocks are available in six different colors, each representing one of the six team colors selectable in the player's inventory, including white for the neutral team.

Unlike Team Dye and Team Hair Dye, these blocks have no special function and are always the same color. The Traveling Merchant will only ever sell one color of Team Block at a time, along with the Team Platform of the same color, meaning that multiple visits will be required to collect all colors.

Repeaters are Hardmode ranged weapons that fire arrows or Stakes as ammunition. They are generally considered upgrades to bows, with only very late-game bows like Tsunami, Eventide (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or Phantasm (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) outperforming them. All repeaters are capable of autofire, unlike most bows.

All repeaters will benefit from the bonuses of the Archery Potion, Magic Quiver and its upgrades, and the Shroomite Headgear. Specially, the Stake Launcher can benefit from the zoom effect of the Rifle Scope or its upgrades.
Their best modifier is Unreal.

Boreal Wood furniture are furniture items crafted from Boreal Wood, obtained by cutting down Boreal trees found in the Snow Biome. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 20 / (Old-gen console version) 18 different Boreal Wood furniture items.

The Megaphone is an immunity accessory that grants the player immunity to the Silenced debuff. It has a 1/100 (1%) / 1/50 (2%) chance to drop from Pixies, Green Jellyfish, Dark Mummies, and Blood Mummies (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
It is one of the ingredients required to make the Countercurse Mantra, which is a crafting material required to make the Ankh Charm, an accessory further required to make the Ankh Shield.

While the Megaphone is exclusive to Hardmode on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it can be obtained in pre-Hardmode on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version by throwing a Nazar into Shimmer.
Pearlwood Wall is a type of wall made from Pearlwood.
The Sky Blue Flower is a type of plant that grows in the Jungle and Underground Jungle. Its sole purpose is to make Sky Blue Dye.

The Spiffo Plush is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Spiffo pet to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, Spiffo will twirl its tail like a propeller to fly towards them. The Spiffo Plush has a 1/1500 (0.07%) chance of being dropped by Zombies, Frozen Zombies, and Raincoat Zombies.
The Ash Wood Hammer is a pre-Hardmode hammer. It is an alternate version of the Wooden Hammer crafted using Ash Wood.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.
The Shark is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Ocean. Sharks are rarer than other Ocean enemies like Crabs or Pink Jellyfish, though they are still relatively common.

Torch God's Favor is a permanent booster item that permanently grants the player the ability to automatically convert regular Torches and Campfires in the player's hand to the current biome 's torch or campfire variant, which increases the player's torch luck in most areas. The Torch God's Favor can only be obtained by surviving The Torch God event if at least 95 Torches were fired during the event.

Torch God's Favor is a one-time consumable whose effect cannot stack (similar to the Advanced Combat Techniques or the Demon Heart). When first used, the ability is switched on by default and can then be toggled off and on via a toggle appearing to the left of the inventory / in the tools menu below the inventory.
Torches and campfires placed with the ability toggled on will permanently remain converted to the biome variant they were placed as, even if freed and picked up.
Pianos are a type of furniture. They also count as a flat surface item, which is one of the required elements in order to make a house.

There are currently (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 34 / (Old-gen console version) 15 / 10 craftable pianos, and 5 non-craftable pianos that can be found in the Dungeon, Ruined houses, and Pirate Invasion event. Some pianos can also be found in Underground Cabins, in which they follow the theme of the cabin that they are found in.

The Squid is a rare pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Ocean. When underwater, it attacks by propelling itself towards the player in short bursts. If led out of the water, it will be unable to move or pursue the player in any way. When killed, it always drops Black Ink, which is used solely to craft Black Dye at a Dye Vat.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

Magic Droppers are Hardmode items used to place "droplets" — dripping liquid effects on ceilings. Once placed, they permanently display an intermittent dripping effect. The effect is purely visual, and has no functional use. Magic Droppers are crafted with an Empty Dropper at Water, Lava, Honey, or with any Sand, with the Crystal Ball nearby.
Magic Droppers can be placed at the bottom side of a block, consuming the item in the process. Droplets can be removed by mining them with a pickaxe, but doing so will not drop any item.

Droplets are also naturally generated in random areas on world generation. They spawn below ceilings that have their corresponding liquid above them, as though that liquid were "leaking through". Natural droplets can be mined just like the player-placed version, and similarly drip indefinitely until removed by a player.

The Thorn Chakram is a pre-Hardmode boomerang that returns to its user after reaching its maximum distance or hitting an enemy. It differs from most other boomerangs in that it does not necessarily return immediately when impacting an object, but instead can ricochet off solid surfaces before returning. The Thorn Chakram has a 1/2 (50%) (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 1/5 (20%) (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) chance to inflict the Poisoned debuff.
It will not fly out through ceilings or floors; but when returning to the player, it will fly back through them.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
The Arcane Flower is a Hardmode accessory which combines the functionality of the Mana Flower and the aggro -reducing effect of the Putrid Scent.

The Adamantite Waraxe is a Hardmode axe that is obtainable after crafting an Adamantite Forge or a Titanium Forge, and is the axe alternative to the Adamantite Chainsaw. Like all other axes and chainsaws, it is solely used to cut down trees, cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

Pho is a food item that grants the (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Plenty Satisfied / (Old-gen console version) Well Fed buff. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10 minutes / (Old-gen console version) 7 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. Pho can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 75 SC.
Like all other food items, the Pho can be placed on a Plate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) :

Corals are crafting materials which can be found in the Ocean biomes at the ends of the world. They grow naturally on Sand Blocks underwater and within 250 tiles of the edges of the map and above the depth of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) −10 feet / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 0 feet, as long as no more than 5 Corals are within a 7-tile range. Corals can be harvested either with a pickaxe / drill, by mining out the sand underneath them, or by placing a block above them. Corals can be placed for decoration and will have one of many appearances, much like Seashells.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Corals will spawn slower on sand under less than 5 tiles of water. Spawn rates scale with rain, wind and empty space up to 14 tiles above the Sand Block.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Corals will only spawn on sand under at least 5 tiles of water. Rain and wind do not affect spawn rates.
The Balla Hat is a vanity item purchased from the Clothier after the Frost Legion has been defeated.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it can only be purchased during the day, for 1 GC. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it can be obtained for free at any time.

The Confetti Cannon is a Hardmode novelty furniture / mechanism. It is purchased from the Party Girl for 25 GC, when the Pirate is present. Once placed, it can be fired by pressing ⚒ Use / Attack key on it with Confetti in hand, by pressing the Auto Select key with Confetti in the player's inventory, or tapping the Confetti Cannon with Confetti in hand.

The angle of a placed Confetti Cannon can be adjusted by pressing ⚷ Open / Activate key on either side of the Confetti Cannon to rotate it in that direction, or tapping the side of the Confetti Cannon. There are 9 possible orientations and it cannot fire downward. Each rotation tilts the Confetti Cannon by one step (22.5°).
The Confetti Cannon can also be triggered by wire. Depending on where the wire is connected, it will either shoot Confetti (with a cooldown of 0.5 seconds) or rotate toward the side the wire is on.
The Confetti shot from the Confetti Cannon is purely aesthetic, dealing no damage or knockback.

The Sauteed Frog Legs are a food item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 10 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Sauteed Frog Legs can be placed on a Plate :

The Mechanical Skull is a Hardmode boss-summoning item used to summon Skeletron Prime, the Hardmode version of Skeletron. It can only be used at night ; attempting to use this item during the day will not spawn Skeletron Prime nor consume the item. The Mechanical Skull is also unusable while Skeletron Prime is already alive. If Skeletron Prime has not been defeated yet in a Hardmode world, all enemies have a 1/2500 (0.04%) chance of dropping a Mechanical Skull, with the exception of statue -spawned enemies, Meteor Heads, and Old One's Army enemies.
Sandstone furniture are furniture items crafted from Smooth Sandstone, which in turn is crafted from Sandstone Blocks at a Furnace. There are 19 different sandstone furniture items.

The Mana Regeneration Potion is a buff potion which grants the Mana Regeneration buff when consumed. The buff increases the rate at which the player's mana regenerates. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8 minutes / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 2 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

The Martian Drone is a Hardmode, post- Golem flying enemy that spawns during the Martian Madness event. It can move through solid blocks. When it is positioned lower than the player, it will directly fly towards a point just above the player. After reaching the point, or the player is positioned lower than the Martian Drone, it will dive down towards the player. Once it gets close enough to the player, it self-destructs, dealing area-of-effect damage.

Pickaxe power is the amount of strength a pickaxe or drill has. It determines how much the player will damage a block before it breaks. Some blocks break instantly, other blocks cannot be mined with low Pickaxe power. Pickaxe power has no effect on the mining speed attribute, in terms of use time per swing, but lower Pickaxe power will generally require multiple hits per block, lowering the rate of blocks cleared over time, and creating the impression that Pickaxe is slower overall.

The Granite Elemental is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in Granite Caves and floats towards the player. In Expert Mode, Granite Elementals will occasionally drop to the ground defensively when attacked, making them immune to all damage until they begin hovering again.
Granite Elementals always drop Granite Blocks upon death, like Granite Golems. They can also rarely drop the Night Vision Helmet.

Stars (or Soul Cakes during Halloween and Sugar Plums during Christmas) are common power-ups which can be dropped by any enemy with a chance of 13/24 (54.17%), as long as the player is below maximum mana. They are not inventory items, but are instead instantly consumed and restore 100 mana. Enemies will only drop Stars if the closest player is not at maximum mana.
It is also possible to spawn Stars (and their seasonal counterparts) with a Star Statue.
They can be collected within range of 2 blocks, which can be increased with Celestial Magnet and its upgrades.

The Parrot is a Hardmode flying enemy that spawns during the Pirate Invasion. It flies towards the player in an attempt to deal contact damage. It will occasionally roost on any block if not pursuing the player, similarly to Ravens and Vultures.
Immunity accessories are a group of accessories that grant immunity to certain debuffs when equipped.
The Snow armor (on Desktop, Console, and Mobile) is an armor set consisting of the Snow Hood, Snow Coat, and Snow Pants.

On Desktop, Console, and Mobile, wearing the full set grants a total of 9 defense as well as immunity to the Chilled and Frozen debuffs. It can be mixed freely with the Pink Snow armor and will still grant this set bonus. Each piece has a 1/30 (3.33%) chance to be dropped by Frozen Zombies.

On Old-gen console and 3DS, the set is called Eskimo armor, consisting of the Eskimo Hood, Eskimo Coat, and Eskimo Pants. Each piece has a 1/150 (0.67%) to be dropped by Zombie Eskimos. Wearing the full set grants a total of 4 defense and no set bonus. Due to its low defense and high rarity, its viability as an armor set is rather low.

Reflective Dye is a dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. When equipped, it will give the selected accessory/armor a "shiny" effect, reflecting the surrounding light around the player. The reflection is more pronounced the closer the player is to a light source. The dye will prioritize light from the sun when the player is outside. From some perspectives, the player may look 3D when this dye is equipped all over.

As with other reflective dyes, this dye is not animated when standing still, but the shading on a dyed piece of equipment will change according to the surrounding light, giving it the appearance of light reflecting off of a shining metallic object.
The Shadewood Bow is the bow crafted using Shadewood. It is the Crimson equivalent of the Ebonwood Bow, having stats identical to it.

Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.

The Titanium Waraxe is a Hardmode axe that is obtainable after crafting an Adamantite Forge or a Titanium Forge, and is the axe alternative to the Titanium Chainsaw. Along with it is slightly weaker alternate, the Adamantite Waraxe, it is stronger than the Mythril or Orichalcum Waraxe, making it the strongest that can be obtained before defeating the mechanical bosses. Like all other axes and chainsaws, it is solely used to cut down trees, cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.
Ash Wood is a type of wood harvested from Ash trees found naturally growing in ash forests. Ash Wood can be cultivated by placing an Acorn on top of Ash grass.

Chlorophyte armor is a Hardmode armor set available after defeating all three mechanical bosses. It can be considered a partial upgrade of Hallowed armor, granting more defense and being geared more towards high ranged and magic damage output.

The set consists of the Chlorophyte Plate Mail and Chlorophyte Greaves, as well as three different headpiece variants: the Chlorophyte Mask, Chlorophyte Helmet, and Chlorophyte Headgear, geared towards melee, ranged, and magic damage respectively.
Equipping the full set causes a Leaf Crystal to permanently appear over the player's head, automatically attacking enemies via a ranged projectile that costs no mana or ammunition.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Leaf Crystal's projectile is a green, laser-like bolt of energy that instantaneously hits its target and deals 100 base damage and inflicts a knockback of 10 (Extremely strong). On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the projectile is a green leaf that travels from the Leaf Crystal to the target. It deals (Old-gen console version) 50 / (3DS version) 40 base damage and inflicts a knockback of (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 5 (Average).

A full set of Chlorophyte armor requires 54 Chlorophyte Bars, or (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 270 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 324 Chlorophyte Ore. Crafting the full set with every helmet type requires 78 bars ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 390 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 468 ore).

The Mechanical Ruler is an informational accessory that, when equipped, draws a cyan, semi-transparent grid overlay on the screen, making individual block distances much clearer. This grid fades out when the player begins moving and returns once movement stops. The row and column of the block the mouse is hovering over are also highlighted in red, drawing a cross on the screen with the cursor at its center. The Mechanical Ruler can be purchased from the Mechanic for 1 GC.
When the Mechanical Ruler is in the inventory or equipped, a toggle for controlling its function appears to the left of the main inventory / in the tools menu below the inventory.

The Glowstick is a consumable light source that can be held or tossed a fair distance. It works underwater but cannot be placed on a wall or floor like Torches can. After being thrown, a Glowstick will emit light for 5 minutes and expire afterward. It has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to drop as an item once expired, making it partly reusable. Glowsticks can be purchased for 10 CC each, either from the Merchant during the night (any moon phase) or from the Skeleton Merchant during the day (except for Full Moons). Glowsticks are always dropped from Blue, Pink, and Green Jellyfish, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) as well as from Flying Fish and Raincoat Zombies. They are also commonly found in Pots and Chests.

The Furnace is a crafting station used mainly to smelt ores into bars, to create ore bricks, and to craft Glass and certain glass items from Sand, but can also be used to craft other items e.g. weapons. It is also a light source. The Furnace smelts all Pre-Hardmode ores besides Hellstone, which must be smelted in a Hellforge.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Furnace can also be purchased from the Merchant when he is in the Jungle biome for 3 SC.
Waterfall Wall is one of only a few animated background walls. It depicts flowing water.

The inventory is a player's stock of carried items and equipment, available for use at all times. Unlike the contents of a Chest, the inventory is bound to the player rather than the world, and its contents will follow a player between multiple worlds and even between multiplayer servers. The inventory is accessed by pressing the Inventory key, the binding for which varies depending on the player's platform of choice.

Items are added to the inventory as the player picks up items found in the world or takes them from a storage item, and can be sorted by using the ⚒ Use / Attack key to pick up and place items, allowing them to be sorted between slots. An item held in the cursor in this way is treated as if the player is holding it; weapons can be used to attack, consumable items can be used, and placeable items can be placed in the world while held in the cursor. However, an item held in the cursor is treated as if it has been removed from the inventory - the space it occupied can be filled by other items, and it will be dropped if the inventory is closed. Dropping an item in this way, or dragging an item and placing it outside of the inventory, will cause that item to be dropped to the ground, which can also be achieved by pressing Throw ; items dropped in this way can be picked up again after a short delay, and will remain in the world until they despawn.

Inventories are made up of multiple slots, each of which can contain one type of item. While some items - such as most weapons - require a slot to themselves, many types of items can have multiples of themselves "stacked" into a single slot. In Desktop, Console, and Mobile versions, all stackable items stack to a maximum of 9999 per slot, however, in Old-gen console and 3DS versions, the amount of items that can be stacked into a single slot depends on the individual item (see Items § Stack); for example, most construction blocks and walls can be stacked up to the maximum of 999 items, but potion types vary, with most health and buff potions stacking to 30 and mana potions to 50, 75, or 99 per slot. When a stack is filled, further items of the same type will take up a new slot in the inventory. The ⚷ Open / Activate key can be used to pick up a single item from a stack of many; in this way, stacks can be divided.
Different sections of the inventory serve different purposes, and may be limited in what they can hold in their slots. Their functions and potential contents are detailed below.

The Terrarian is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord yoyo that fires green, short-lived projectiles at a rapid rate, which home in on nearby enemies and bounces off solid blocks while in use. The Terrarian also has a base 14% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%. The Terrarian has a 2/9 (22.22%) chance of being dropped by the Moon Lord, and is the most powerful yoyo in the game.
It has an infinite spin duration and can reach up to 25 tiles.

Its best modifier is Legendary. Although yoyos cannot normally obtain the Legendary modifier, the Terrarian is an exception and receives a unique set of boosts from the Legendary modifier: +17% damage, +8% critical strike chance, and +17% knockback.
The Bunny License is a consumable item that can be purchased from the Zoologist for 5 GC after filling out 45% (243 entries) of the Bestiary.

Upon use, the status message " The license teleports away to the bunny delivery service... " is displayed. Following this status message, a Town Bunny will move into an available house the next morning. Using a second Bunny License when a Town Bunny is already present in the current world causes it to disappear and be "exchanged". The Town Bunny then respawns the next morning with its name and breed rerolled.

A Trapped Chest is a mechanical item that has the appearance of a normal chest. It cannot be used for storage, as it does not have any storage slots. When it is opened, it emits a signal and can be connected with wire.
Any chest can be crafted into a Trapped Chest at the Heavy Work Bench with the desired chest and 10 wire. The Trapped Chest can be sold for 1 SC.
Ancient Cobalt Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Ancient Cobalt Bricks. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Cobalt Brick Wall prior to 1.2.
The Gold Frog is a harmless critter. It is a golden recolor of the ordinary Frog, with a 1/400 (0.25%) chance of spawning in place of the ordinary version.
The Gold Frog has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Gold Frog can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Gold Frog Cage). Once crafted, the Gold Frog cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Gold Frog itself or the crafted furniture can be sold for 10 GC.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.

Mana is a resource consumed by the player upon using magic weapons or summon weapons (except whips). Magic and summon weapons have a specific mana cost that depletes the player's mana upon use. When a player's mana is depleted completely, a magic or summon weapon cannot be used again until that weapon's mana cost has regenerated.

Similarly to health, the player's current mana supply and capacity are represented by a meter: a column of blue stars displayed on the top-right edge of the screen to the right of the life counter, with each star representing 20 mana. Mana regenerates automatically as long as the player is not using it. It fills more quickly if the player stands still, with a further rate boost based on the current total mana: The more mana a player has, the faster it regenerates.

Each character starts with 20 mana capacity (one star in the mana meter). Using Mana Crystals increases the player's mana capacity by 20 permanently, adding another star to the meter. This can be done up to 9 times, which in addition to the 1 initial star makes 10 stars total, representing 200 mana.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the player can change the style of the mana bar via the "Health and Mana Style" option in the settings. With the Bars styles, the mana meter will be displayed as a blue bar split into multiple small parts located below the life counter, with each part representing 20 mana.

Mana capacity can be increased further through the use of various armors and accessories. Accessories with the Arcane modifier also boost the player's maximum mana capacity by 20. This is maxed out at 400 mana, or 20 stars total.

When mana regeneration has completed and the player again reaches maximum mana, a chirp sound is played https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:MaxMana.wav and a blue sparkle effect is shown briefly on the character's sprite.

Golf is an in-game activity where players hit Golf Balls into Golf Cups using Golf Clubs. Golf supplies can be purchased from the Golfer NPC. Golf courses are not naturally-occurring and must be built.

The Ichor Dart is a type of hardmode dart used with the Blowgun, Blowpipe, Dart Pistol, and the Dart Rifle. They inflict the Ichor debuff on enemies for 7-14 seconds and pierce the enemy infinitely before splitting into 2-5 non-piercing darts shortly after traveling. They are the Crimson 's counterpart to the Corruption 's Cursed Darts.
Smooth Sandstone is a type of block crafted from Sandstone Blocks. It can be used to craft the Sandstone furniture set.

The Pumpkin Seed is a seed which is used to plant Pumpkins. They may be planted on normal green grass or Hallowed grass (including their mowed versions), and will eventually grow into Pumpkins. They need 2 blocks width and 2 blocks height of clear space to grow, and can grow anywhere grass will grow.
Pumpkin Seeds are purchased from the Dryad for 2 SC 50 CC each.

The Hellstone Brick Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Ruined Houses in the Underworld, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, via crafting. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

The Blue Horseshoe Balloon is an accessory that grants immunity to fall damage, increases jump height by 75%, grants a double-jump, and grants +0.05 luck (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The height of the first jump is increased from 6 blocks to 10.5 blocks, while the double-jump's height is increased from 5 blocks to 9 blocks, reaching a total of 19.5 blocks with both jumps.
Jump height is instead reduced by 15% when underwater, reducing total underwater jump height from 15 blocks (8 + 7 from Cloud jump) to 13 blocks (7 + 6 from Cloud jump).

The Magiluminescence is a pre-Hardmode accessory that increases the player's maximum movement speed by 15% and their acceleration and deceleration by 75%. This increase stacks with the bonus of the Hermes Boots and their variants. It also creates an aura of light around the player, which can be useful when exploring underground. The Magiluminescence's movement speed buffs are disabled when the player is not grounded.

Light sources are items that produce light. Some are brighter than others and produce varying colors of light. Note that several weapons and armor types also generate light, but are not listed on this page.

The Silver Hammer is an early-game hammer, being stronger than the Iron Hammer, but weaker than the Gold Hammer. It has an alternate ore version, the Tungsten Hammer. Like all hammers, it is used to remove background walls and create sloped tiles and half tiles.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.
