These two portals are linked; any player that touches one will be instantly transported to the other one, without losing momentum. While NPCs can be teleported with the Portal Gun, enemies or projectiles cannot. The Portal Gun is always dropped from the Moon Lord.
The Portal Gun has a maximum range of 675 blocks (1350 feet). It takes about two seconds for the projectile to travel this distance.

While selected, the Portal Gun will also alter the player's physics: their maximum fall speed is multiplied by 3.5 (from 51 mph to 179 mph) and horizontal momentum/inertia is kept while in the air. This effect is also applied if the last entity that affected the player's fall was a portal. The extremely fast movement may cause performance losses on some devices.
Spider armor is a Hardmode armor set crafted from 36 Spider Fangs. Wearing the full set increases the wearer's minion capacity by 3, along with granting +28% summon damage.

Some items are non-renewable, meaning that in any given world they are in a finite supply from what is naturally available in the world. Some of these items are plentiful and easy to find and use, while others are rare items like rare paintings or the Lihzahrd Altar.

Non-renewable items are finite, so the player can run the world out of them. In general, this is very hard to do or just easy to avoid, but some non-renewable resources can become contested in large multiplayer worlds. In Journey Mode, any item obtainable by the player can be researched and duplicated, allowing all items to be renewable.
Non-renewable items include the following:

Block types generated with the world are generally very plentiful, but some cannot be crafted or otherwise created. Even being finite, it is very difficult to run out of these blocks unless the player puts in effort to rid the world of these blocks. Chests sometimes have items unique to them that cannot be obtained from fishing up Crates. Chest furniture items themselves are also often non-renewable. Uncraftable furniture, especially from locations such as the Dungeon or Jungle Temple. Background walls are often unsafe when generated in the world, but safe when placed by the player. Some of these walls have other methods to place the unsafe variants, while other unsafe walls are non-renewable. Any item which requires a non-renewable resource to be obtained, such as Clay Pots being crafted from Clay Blocks. Most items obtained from NPCs are renewable; however, specifically the Fuzzy Carrot and Angler armor from the Angler are only available once per character.
Non-renewable items are few enough that they can be listed individually. A few of those are "semi-renewable", produced by something that is plentiful but ultimately finite.

The Dangersense Potion is a buff potion which grants the Dangersense buff when consumed. The buff reveals hazardous traps, blocks, and objects that can potentially harm or impede the player by highlighting them in red, even in complete darkness. This lasts for 10 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.

A Gem Lock is a special mechanism which acts as a container or altar for a Large Gem. A Gem Lock will emit an activation signal if the corresponding Large Gem is placed inside it and once again if it gets removed. This allows for a simple contraption that uses only one mechanism to keep something like a door open as long as the gem is inside the lock, because if it gets taken out it will immediately close.
Gem Locks are primarily used in the making of adventure maps, where the player must complete some objective to be rewarded with the gem required to continue.

The Blood Zombie is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a Zombie variant that only spawns during a Blood Moon. It acts mostly the same as normal Zombies, walking towards the player to deal contact damage while attempting to navigate around obstacles, and opening doors if they are in the way. However, it speeds up considerably the closer it gets to the player, and it generally has greater health, damage, and speed than most other Zombies.
It does not have any variants, nor does it have an Armed variation in Expert Mode.
The Gold Dragonfly is a harmless critter. It is a golden recolor of the ordinary Dragonfly, with a 1/400 (0.25%) chance of spawning in place of the ordinary version.
The Gold Dragonfly has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Gold Dragonfly can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Gold Dragonfly Jar). Once crafted, the Gold Dragonfly cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Gold Dragonfly itself or the crafted furniture can be sold for 10 GC.
The Gold Dragonfly can be used as bait for fishing, with 50% bait power.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.
The Mannequin is a decorative furniture item that can be used to display armor and vanity items, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) as well as accessories and dyes.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, items can be placed on a Mannequin by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on it, which opens a small set of inventory -like slots beneath the player's main inventory. There are three slots for helmet, shirt, and pants, and five slots for accessories. In addition, each slot has an associated dye slot underneath it. Placing items in these slots immediately displays them on the Mannequin.

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, items can be placed on a Mannequin by pressing the ⚒ Use / Attack button anywhere on it, which places the item currently held by the player on the Mannequin. If there is already an item in the same slot on the Mannequin, it will be replaced and dropped. Items can also be removed with a pickaxe or drill.
Mannequins can only be removed if no items are placed on them. On Old-gen console and 3DS, they can always be destroyed by explosives, however.

The Mannequin always displays armor and clothing in their male sprite forms. The Womannequin (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) can be used to display them in their female counterparts.

The Goblin Scout is an uncommon pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns on the surface in the farthest edges of the player's world. It looks like an enemy from the Goblin Army event, but it spawns during ordinary gameplay. The Tattered Cloth it drops is a component for the Goblin Battle Standard, which summons a Goblin Army.

Goblin Scouts can only be found in the furthest east and furthest west sixths of the world. They will not spawn on blocks infected by the Corruption, the Crimson or the Hallow and will only spawn during the day.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

The Leather Whip is a pre-Hardmode whip purchased from the Zoologist for 10 GC. Like other whips, it causes minions and sentries to focus on the last-struck enemy and increases their damage against the target by 4.
If the Leather Whip hits multiple targets in a single attack, the damage dealt by each consecutive hit will be reduced by 50%.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Streamers are placeable items that can be climbed on for mobility. They are available in three different colors: Blue Streamer, Green Streamer, and Pink Streamer. These are all functionally identical and can be purchased for 50 CC each from the Party Girl during a Party.

Despite their unique appearance, streamers are functionally the same as Rope. Their ascent speed is 41 mph, the descent speed is 51 mph, and the horizontal speed is 5 mph (although it is listed as 0 mph in the game, it is 7.55 feet per second), though they cannot be crafted into Rope Coils like other Rope variants can. When multiple streamers of the same color are hung in a single horizontal row, they will appear as a banner-style ribbon.

The Sanguine Staff is a Hardmode summon weapon that summons a Sanguine Bat minion that remains by the player's side until an enemy is in sight, and attacks by flying in an elliptical loop between the player and enemy. The Sanguine Bats arrange themselves along a semicircle with the player's head as the center, and immediately return to the player's side once their target dies. The Sanguine Staff has a 1/2 (50%) / 1/1 (100%) chance of being dropped by Dreadnautiluses.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Sanguine Staff has over a Ruthless one is knockback.

The Beach Ball is a novelty item. Using it creates an interactive beach ball for players to bounce around. After (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 2 seconds of sitting still or coming to a full stop and then being tapped, it reverts to its item form which can be picked up and reused.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Beach Ball can be purchased from the Party Girl for 20 CC, and cannot be found in Water Chests. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version it cannot be purchased, and can instead be found in Water Chests.
If the Beach Ball is hit more than ten times without it touching the ground, a status message appears saying " Beach Ball was hit <number of times> times before touching the ground! "

The Flaming Mace is a pre-Hardmode flail that has a 1/6 (16.67%) chance to inflict the On Fire! debuff. Stepping in water or submerging the head extinguishes it and the projectile effectively becomes that of a regular Mace.
Its best modifier is Ruthless. Godly and Demonic may give higher crit chance, but rounding causes Ruthless to have much higher damage for this weapon.
Achievements or Accomplishments are earned by performing various tasks in the world of Terraria.

The Psycho is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event. The Psycho will initially spawn in a nearly invisible, stealthed state, waiting for the player to damage him or draw near before he fully reveals himself and starts attacking. An attack made by contact with the Psycho while in stealth will deal significantly more damage than an ordinary hit, similar to the function of the Psycho Knife it drops.
Hay is a type of block that is harvested from wild grass plants by using a Sickle. It can be used to make Target Dummies.

The Green Cap is (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) a piece of armor / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) a vanity item. It will always drop from the Guide, but only when his name is Andrew. On Old-gen console, the Guide will always drop the Green Cap, regardless of his name. Verify

Reflective Obsidian Dye is a dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. When equipped, it will give the respective equipment an obsidian-plated, "shiny" effect, reflecting the surrounding light around the player. The reflection is more pronounced the closer the player is to a light source. The dye will prioritize light from the sun when the player is outside. From some perspectives, the player may look three-dimensional when this dye is equipped in all slots.

As with other reflective dyes, this dye is not animated when standing still, but the shading on a dyed piece of equipment will change according to the surrounding light, giving it the appearance of light reflecting off of a shining metallic object.
Unlike the other reflective dyes, this dye is rather dark which results in dark highlights.
The Baby Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns in groups of 1-3 from a defeated Mother Slime.
Like most other slimes, the Baby Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
On Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can rarely be found carrying bonus drops, which the player receives upon the slime's death.

The Corrupt Crate is a pre-Hardmode crate that can only be fished in The Corruption. It contains items found in standard crates and always contains an item normally dropped by destroying a Shadow Orb. Its Hardmode counterpart is the Defiled Crate.

The Yoyo Glove is a Hardmode accessory that aids Yoyo attacks. When equipped, and when the player is using a Yoyo to attack an enemy, a duplicate of the Yoyo being used will spawn and orbit around the primary Yoyo projectile at high speeds. A duplicate Yoyo will only appear after hitting an enemy at least once. It is purchased from the Skeleton Merchant for 50 GC during Hardmode.
If a Counterweight is also equipped, the Yoyo Glove will also cause a duplicate Counterweight to spawn during attacks, for a total of four projectiles (2 Yoyos + 2 Counterweights).
When a Yoyo Glove and Counterweight are both equipped:
A duplicate Yoyo appears on the first enemy impact. The first Counterweight appears on the second hit. A duplicate Counterweight appears on the third hit.
The Yoyo Bag offers this same functionality from a single accessory along with increased range.

Mana Sickness is a debuff that reduces the player's magic damage after they consume any mana -restoring item. Automatically drinking Mana Potions with the Mana Flower will also cause the debuff. Whenever a mana-restoring item is consumed, the player is inflicted with 5 seconds of Mana Sickness. The percentage of magic damage reduction is proportional to the remaining debuff duration (see Notes for formula), reducing by 1% every 1/5 second; at 5 seconds remaining, the damage reduction is 25%. All mana-restoring items inflict the same length of the debuff; for example, a Lesser Mana Potion induces the same duration of Mana Sickness as a Greater Mana Potion.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) If the player consumes additional mana-restoring items while the debuff is active, the duration will be increased by 5 seconds for each item consumed, up to a maximum of 10 seconds (50% damage reduction).

The magic damage reduction is multiplicative rather than additive, and is applied after all damage multipliers. For example, if the player has +100% damage from buffs and items, the total damage with the debuff at 5 seconds left comes to 150% (200% x (1 - 25%); -25% comes from Mana Sickness).

The Flask of Fire is a flask that causes melee weapons and whips (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) to inflict the On Fire! debuff for 3-6 seconds on enemies hit. Melee weapons that fire projectiles will also inflict the debuff on enemies hit by the projectiles (except for the Flairon 's bubbles).

The Flask of Fire cannot be used in conjunction with other flasks, and using it will remove any existing flask effects. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Like all other flasks, the effect will not be canceled when the player dies.

The social slots allow a player to change the cosmetic looks of their character, while still retaining the statistics of any armor or accessories worn in the armor or accessory slots respectively. This content is transcluded from Inventory. These slots change the visual appearance of the player's head, torso, and legs. While these slots accept the same types of items as the armor slots, items placed here are entirely visual and will not modify the player's stats or generate any additional effects. Their appearance will, however, override the corresponding armor slot, allowing the player to conceal their armor if it is not to their aesthetic preference.

For players unconcerned about aesthetics, these slots can be used to store an alternate set of armor. For example, a character could wear a set of melee armor while equipping a set of mage armor in the vanity slots, in order to be able to switch to the magic-boosting armor when needed.

Beds are furniture items which allow the player to set a new spawn point by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on the foot half of the Bed. This requires it to be placed in a mostly valid house (see details below). On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Beds furthermore allow the player to sleep in them by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on the head half of the Bed. This makes time pass five times faster and gives a boost to health regeneration, similar to chairs and Sofas.

Beds fulfill the chair (comfort item) requirement for the purposes of NPC housing. Like most other furniture, the direction a Bed is placed in depends on the direction the player is facing when placing it.
There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 35 craftable Beds and 5 that can be acquired from the environment. All Beds are functionally identical and differ only in appearance.

The Starfury is a pre-Hardmode sword which occasionally summons a star projectile from the sky to the location of the cursor when swung, and costs no ammunition or mana. The star emits light, deals 1.5x the sword's damage (37 base damage) but no knockback. The star can pierce up to 1 target, hitting a total of 2 targets. The star will travel through all blocks until it reaches the lowest empty space at or above the player's cursor, after which it will break on the next block it hits. The Starfury has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being found inside Skyware Chests on Floating Islands, as well as a 1/4 (25%) chance of being obtained from Sky Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Azure Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Wrath Potion is a buff potion which grants the Wrath buff when consumed. The buff generally increases damage dealt by weapons by 10%. This lasts for 4 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.
Pumpkin armor is an armor set crafted from Pumpkins at any Work Bench. Wearing a full set increases all damage dealt by the player by 10%. 75 Pumpkins are required to craft a full set.
Shinobi Infiltrator armor is a Hardmode, post- Golem armor set purchased from the Tavernkeep for 1500000* 150 in total, and provides summon as well as melee damage bonuses.
The set consists of the Shinobi Infiltrator's Helmet, Shinobi Infiltrator's Torso, and Shinobi Infiltrator's Pants.
A full set of Shinobi Infiltrator armor provides the following bonuses:
+54 defense +20% melee damage +20% melee speed +60% summon damage +25% melee critical strike chance +30% movement speed +3 extra sentry slots
Equipping the full set will increase the attack rate of Lightning Aura sentries, will cause them to deal critical hits with a fixed 1/4 (25%) chance, and will increase their radius by 4 tiles.
The Shinobi Infiltrator armor can be considered a direct upgrade of the Monk armor.

The Green Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that commonly spawns in Forest biomes during the daytime. It is the weakest slime and also one of the most common ones to encounter, likely making it the first enemy a player will come across in a new world. Green Slimes will not target the player under usual circumstances, but will become aggressive when damaged, during the night, or if brought underground.
Like most other slimes, the Green Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
On Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can rarely be found carrying bonus drops, which the player receives upon the slime's death.

The Jungle Bat is a common pre-Hardmode bat enemy that spawns in the Jungle and less commonly in the Underground Jungle. In Expert Mode, it can inflict the Feral Bite debuff. Like most other bats, it cannot enter water.

The Valor is a pre-Hardmode, post- Skeletron yoyo that has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from the Locked Gold Chests found in the Dungeon, as well as a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from Golden Lock Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
It has a spin duration of 11 seconds and can reach up to 14 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Cursed Inferno is a Hardmode debuff that prevents health regeneration and causes the afflicted NPC or player to take damage each second for the duration of the debuff. The damage varies by platform :

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 24 damage per second is inflicted to enemies, and 12 damage per second is inflicted to players. Affected enemies also take 10% more knockback. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Enemies and players alike take 6 damage per second.
If the afflicted target is Oiled (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), they will take 25 additional damage per second, totaling 49 damage per second to enemies or 37 damage per second to players.

The Unicorn is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Hallow. It is a very fast enemy and has a rather large amount of health. It can jump approximately 7 tiles high and 20 tiles wide. It leaps around and charges, attempting to trample the player. Its unpredictable and speedy behavior, combined with a high damage output, can make fighting it difficult. It always drops one Unicorn Horn, a valued item. It can also drop the Blessed Apple, though it is rare.

The Sign is a decorative furniture item that can store a player-written message. A Sign must be placed and then the ⚷ Open / Activate button must be pressed on it to edit or display its message. A Sign can be placed on top of blocks, beside them, or hanging from their underside. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, they can also be placed on walls. A Sign's message can be up to 10 lines long, at 48 characters max per line, for a total of 480 characters maximum per sign. Signs can be used for decoration, labeling areas, adventure text, etc.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) There is a maximum limit of 1000 placed Signs that can be written on in each world. If more than 1000 are put down, only the first 1000 Signs that are interacted with can be edited; the rest do not open a menu upon pressing ⚷ Open / Activate (until one of the first 1000 Signs is removed). Verify
On the Nintendo 3DS version, Signs are limited to 16 characters, with a maximum of 5 numbers, and no punctuation or special symbols can be used.
The Trash Can is a storage item which has 40 storage slots. They essentially serve the same purpose as Chests, only having the appearance of a trash can. Trash Cans can only be harvested when empty.
The Blood Butcherer is a pre-Hardmode sword crafted from Crimtane Bars.

Striking an enemy with the Blood Butcherer will inflict the Blood Butchered debuff, dealing 4 damage per second for 9 seconds and causing enemies to visibly bleed. Similarly to the Tentacle Spike or Bone Javelin, repeated attacks will cause the debuff to stack up to five times, for a total of 20 damage per second.
The Blood Butcherer's Corruption counterpart is the Light's Bane, which is smaller and somewhat weaker but with higher speed, and it is one of the key ingredients in crafting the Night's Edge.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
Chlorophyte Brick Walls are Walls that can be manually crafted. When placed, it presents a dark shade of green followed by a gemstone-like pattern.

Chainsaws are tools that can be used to destroy trees and cacti, similarly to axes, but are also viable melee weapons. Much like the Muramasa and other fast-swinging swords, chainsaws can deal large amounts of damage quickly, but trade off the wide arc of such weapons for the ability to be pointed in any direction. None of the chainsaws, nearly all of which are Hardmode -exclusive, surpass the pre-Hardmode Molten Hamaxe in terms of axe power (the Butcher's Chainsaw ties it), but, from Palladium and on, they are able to cut down trees faster due to the rapid rate at which they hit the tree.
The best modifier for any chainsaw is Godly, as they cannot obtain a modifier that affects size or speed, unlike axes.
The Mummy set is a Hardmode vanity set consisting of the Mummy Mask, the Mummy Shirt, and the Mummy Pants. Each piece is dropped by Mummies with a 1/75 (1.33%) chance.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Portal Gun Station is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord furniture / mechanism that can fire portals, similar to the Portal Gun. The Portal Gun Station can be purchased from the Cyborg for 10 GC if the player has a Portal Gun in their inventory.

Once placed, pressing ⚷ Open / Activate key on different spot on the Portal Gun Station triggers different effects: pressing at the top toggles between orange and blue portal colors; pressing at the base fires a portal; pressing at the left or right side rotates its shooting direction. There are 9 possible orientations and it cannot fire downward, each rotation tilts it by one step (22.5°).

The Portal Gun Station can also be triggered by wire. Depending on where the wire is connected, it will either change portal color, shoot portal (with a cooldown of 0.5 seconds), or rotate toward the side the wire is on.

In multiplayer, if the source of activation is not directly a player, then the Portal Gun Station will not fire nor swap colors, though any signal can rotate it. For example, flipping a Switch that fires a Dart Trap at a Teal Pressure Pad connected to the Station will not result in the Station firing, as it cannot find a player to bind its portals to. Note that other, player-based projectiles like arrows or minions will cause the Teal Pressure Pad to activate the Station. Timers and Sensors (except Player Above Sensors) also cannot fire the Station.
Only a pair of portals can exist at a time for each player that has the Portal Gun or Portal Gun Station, whether created by the former or the latter. Portal shots have a maximum range of 673 tiles.

The Eye Patch is a vanity item placed in the helmet social slot. It can be dropped by the Pirate Corsair, Pirate Deckhand, Pirate Deadeye, and the Pirate Crossbower with a chance of 1/500 (0.2%). These enemies can all be found during a Pirate Invasion event.
Flinx Fur is a crafting material dropped by Snow Flinxes, an enemy found in the Ice biome. They drop 1-2 / 1-3 Flinx Fur.
Valentine's Day is a seasonal event that occurs during February 1st - 29th. It references the real-world Valentine's Day, featuring items of romantic character.
The Spectre Hamaxe is a Hardmode, post- Plantera hamaxe.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Light Disc is a Hardmode boomerang that returns to the owner once it hits an enemy or reaches its maximum range. The Light Disc's physics are similar to those of the Thorn Chakram, being able to bounce off solid blocks, though Light Discs have nearly twice the range. It also has a glowing texture, allowing it to be seen in complete darkness.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Light Disc cannot be stacked, but can be rapidly fired, with a maximum of 6 Light Discs being thrown out at the same time. It also has a blue trail effect when thrown. Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the Light Disc can be stacked up to 5 in one slot. The bigger the stack is, the more can be thrown out at the same time. The Light Disc cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

The Cultists are Hardmode, post- Golem enemies that spawn along with a Mysterious Tablet at the entrance to the Dungeon after Golem has been defeated. Four Cultists will appear there: two Cultist Archers and two Lunatic Devotees. Defeating all four of the Cultists causes the Lunatic Cultist to spawn instantly at their location, destroying the Mysterious Tablet in the process. Defeating the Lunatic Cultist then initiates the Lunar Events.

Until one of the Cultists is attacked, they are passive and deal no contact damage, and players can walk through them freely without activating them. Attacking any of the four will awaken the Archers, who will begin to fire Wooden Arrows using bows and will deal contact damage. Lunatic Devotees are always passive and never deal contact damage.

All four Cultists respawn and reset their location and initial passive state after 12 minutes (12 in-game hours), if the Lunatic Cultist was not summoned, if the player runs away or dies during the fight, when all four Celestial Pillars are destroyed, or when the world is closed and restarted. Restarting the world can be the fastest option to reset them to their original state.
The Lunatic Devotee and Cultist Archer require 25 kills to be awarded completion of their Bestiary entries and corresponding banners, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Giant Fungi Bulb is a Hardmode enemy found in Glowing Mushroom biomes both above and below the surface. They act similar to Man Eaters and Snatchers, but have a longer reach and launch Fungi Spores towards the player, dealing high damage. Fungi Spores fly towards their target, breaking upon contact with blocks, and glide downward in a serpentine pattern. They can be destroyed by one hit with any weapon or damage-inflicting tool.

The Illuminant Slime is a Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns in the Underground Hallow, replacing normal cave slimes (Black and Mother Slimes) in most cases. Compared to its pre-Hardmode counterparts, it deals much more damage and has more health. The Illuminant Slime gives off a small amount of light and leaves an after-image (like the Chaos Elemental and Illuminant Bat), which appears as a long, pink trail.
Like most other slimes, the Illuminant Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
Leather is a crafting material that is used to create the Archaeologist's Jacket and the Archaeologist's Pants. It is made using Rotten Chunks, a material only obtainable in Corruption worlds.

It cannot be obtained in a Crimson world unless the player makes an artificial Corruption biome (e.g. using Corrupt Seeds, purchased from the Dryad in a Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) or uses a Corrupt Statue.

The Antlion Mandible is a crafting material dropped by Antlions, Antlion Larvae (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Antlion Chargers (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Antlion Swarmers (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) found in the Desert and Underground Desert biomes.

The Lamia set is a Hardmode vanity set which consists of the Lamia Mask, Lamia Wraps and the Lamia Tail. It is rarely dropped by Lamias, with a 1/180 (0.56%) chance per piece for the Light Lamia and a 1/120 (0.83%) chance per piece for the Dark Lamia.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
The Blood Crawler is a pre-Hardmode enemy commonly found in the Crimson. In addition to walking, it can crawl on background walls.
The Princess set is a vanity set that can be obtained from Goodie Bags with a 2/57 (3.51%) chance. It consists of a Princess Hat and Princess Dress.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
The Palladium Sword is a Hardmode broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Cobalt Sword.
Compared to the Cobalt Sword, however, it has higher knockback, slightly higher damage, and slightly higher use time.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Waffle's Iron is a Hardmode sword that shoots a waffle projectile once per swing, which is significantly affected by gravity. The frying pan itself also has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to inflict the Hellfire debuff upon contact for 5 seconds. The Waffle's Iron is always dropped by Mechdusa, a boss exclusive to Get fixed boi worlds.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Bestiary is an in-game catalog of Terraria 's various entities, including NPCs, enemies, critters, and bosses. It can be viewed by opening the inventory and pressing ⚒ Use / Attack on the book icon located to the right of the item trash can, at the bottom right of the inventory, or opening the settings and tapping the Bestiary button. The Bestiary's entries display flavor text and basic statistics for each entity, including biomes, health, damage, defense, and knockback resistance, as well as advanced information such as rarity (on a 0-5 star scale), coins, item drop rates - these stats are based on the current gameplay session (based on difficulty, seed, etc). The kill count of a specific entity is also displayed. Entries can be sorted and filtered by various criteria, including statistics, locations, times, events, etc.
Initially, no information is available about any particular entity. The information progression is tracked by various methods, depending on the entity type:

For enemies, kills of specific enemy types are counted (kills made before the 1.4.0.1 update will not count). Same "types" of enemies with multiple entries (such as Zombies) have a separate tracker for each entry (50 Pincushion Zombie kills, 50 Slimed Zombie kills, etc). The information for the event-exclusive mini-bosses of the Pumpkin Moon and Frost Moon also follow this formula. There are four stages of progression for each enemy, each unlocked based on the kill count of that enemy in the world:

For a boss, only one kill is required to display all information. For a critter, the entry will be fully unlocked after the player comes into proximity with the respective critter. The player must get within about 15 tiles of the critter for it to count towards its Bestiary entry. For more detailed info, see Notes. For a town NPC, the entry will be fully unlocked after the player opens the dialogue window of that NPC.

At the bottom of the Bestiary is a bar that fills as the Bestiary is completed, allowing players to track their progress. Hovering the cursor over it will display the exact percentage. Bestiary progress is tied to a world, not a character. Unlocking 10% of the entities in the Bestiary (54 entries) makes the Zoologist NPC available, who sells progressively more items (e.g. the Bunny License) as the player completes more of the Bestiary. Unlocking all information for the entries is not a requirement for this, the entries themselves only need to be unlocked to count toward completion.
There are 540 Bestiary entries in total.

The Spectre Goggles are a Hardmode, post- Plantera accessory which allows the player to see Echo Blocks, Echo Platforms, Echo Walls, Ghostly Stinkbug Blockers, and tiles painted with Echo Coating while equipped. They are sold by the Cyborg for 10 GC when he is spoken to in a Graveyard.

The Spicy Pepper is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking an Ash tree.
Like all other food items, the Spicy Pepper can be placed on a Plate :
The Lesser Restoration Potion is a recovery potion that combines the effects of the Lesser Healing Potion and Lesser Mana Potion.

Shimmer is a shiny, lavender-colored, pearlescent liquid. It can be found at any point in the game in the Aether, a mini-biome that generates once per world in the Underground or Cavern layers, and always on the same half of the world as the Jungle. After the Moon Lord has been defeated, it can be obtained limitlessly by using the Bottomless Shimmer Bucket.
Shimmer has the unique function of transforming ("transmuting") certain dropped items and entities submerged in it:

Most crafted items are transformed back ("decrafted") into their crafting materials. Certain items are transformed into other items. A few items can only be obtained via this transformation, such as Ambrosia. Some item transformations only work under certain conditions. The sprite of town NPCs is changed. Certain enemies are transformed into other enemies. Most critters are transformed into Faelings.

Items will float upwards after transformation until they leave the liquid, then linger in midair and produce vibrant lights until a player picks them up, similarly to souls. Items that cannot be transformed will sink to the bottom of the Shimmer.
In addition to its transforming effect, Shimmer also has an effect on other entities that enter it:

When a player is submerged in the liquid, they will be inflicted with the Shimmering debuff, beginning to fall slowly and phasing through all blocks until they reach an opening. Certain projectiles will bounce upwards upon contact with a Shimmer pool, such as a falling Fallen Star. When enemies that have no special transmutations and are not immune to the Shimmering debuff (e.g. the Werewolf) enter Shimmer, they will slowly become more transparent, and eventually turn completely invisible. Then they will slowly become more and more opaque. Attacking the enemy will make it turn opaque faster.

Unlike other liquids, the player cannot fish or use items in Shimmer, nor can it be picked up with an Empty Bucket. Shimmer also does not have a liquid bomb variant. It can still be moved by pumps, however.
Upon contact with any other liquid, Shimmer will form Aetherium Blocks.

The Corrupt Grass Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in The Corruption, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, by purchasing it from the Dryad during a Blood Moon for 2 SC 50 CC each. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

The Clentaminator / Terraformer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (using Purple Solution) and Unholy Water convert Grass Walls, Flower Walls, and Jungle Walls (both safe and unsafe) to unsafe Corrupt Grass Walls.
Corrupt Grass Walls can spread The Corruption to nearby pure walls. See Biome spread for further information.

The Slime Gun is a novelty weapon that deals no damage. It auto-fires an arc of slime that inflicts the Slime debuff on players, enemies, and NPCs, causing them to drip blue goo for 30 seconds. This effect is purely cosmetic. The Slime Gun can be used limitlessly and does not consume any ammunition or mana. It has a 2/3 (66.67%) chance of being dropped by King Slime.
The Slime Gun cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.
It can be considered a counterpart to the Sparkle Slime Balloon.

Trees are the largest plants in Terraria, appearing mostly at the surface and often in clusters with similar height. Most trees can be chopped down with an axe or chainsaw, or destroyed with the use of explosives or by pouring lava on their bases. Destroying or chopping down a tree will yield many units of its respective Wood, an essential crafting material, and has a chance of dropping one or more Acorns that can be planted to grow more trees. Larger trees will yield more of these two items when removed; one unit of Wood will drop for each block of tree (including branches), and one Acorn may drop for each leaf patch.

It is possible to cut off parts of the tree, but cutting at the lowermost center tile will destroy the entire tree. If parts of the tree are left, they will not regrow. Tiles directly beneath trees cannot be destroyed or actuated.
Tree saplings can be painted, although this will not affect the tree at all. However, painting the blocks underneath the sapling will result in the tree being painted when it matures.

Three other large plants do not drop Wood and spawn differently, but are otherwise treated similarly to trees. These are Giant Glowing Mushrooms, Cacti and Bamboo stalks (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Thrown Water refers to a set of three consumable weapons that each convert a small area into a biome (Hallow, Corruption, or Crimson for Holy Water, Unholy Water, and Blood Water respectively) when thrown. This conversion affects a roughly circular area with a radius of four tiles from the center. Enemies within this radius are also damaged slightly; this damage is not classified as any of the four damage types and therefore cannot be modified by any buffs or equipment.

Holy Water is only available in Hardmode. It is possible for Corrupted or Crimson Deserts to be generated naturally with the world, making the other two throwable waters available from the beginning of the game, however these biomes will not spread onto sand until Hardmode begins, therefore worlds generated without Corrupted/Crimson Deserts will not have Ebonsand / Crimsand until then. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, however, Vile Powder or Vicious Powder can be used to convert sand into its corrupt counterpart.

The Creeper Egg is a Hardmode light pet-summoning item that spawns a Flickerwick to follow the player around. When active, it is similar to the Wisp in a Bottle, where it provides light wherever the player goes. The summoned Flickerwick has the same movement speed as the player, and cannot be left behind easily. The Creeper Egg is dropped by Ogres during the Old One's Army event, with a 1/5 (20%) / 1/4 (25%) chance during Tier 2, and a 1/10 (10%) chance during Tier 3.

The Spear is the most basic pre-Hardmode spear. The Spear has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/10 (10%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being found in Wooden Chests that are located on the surface as well as in the underground layer.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Solar furniture can be made from Solar Bricks using the Ancient Manipulator. There are 20 different Solar furniture items.

The Underground Desert is a biome located directly underneath the main Desert of the world. The Desert above may generate different features which inform that the Underground Desert is underneath (see Surface Desert below for details). The Desert/Underground Desert pair will always generate on the same side of the world the Jungle is on.

The structure of the Underground Desert resembles that of a real-world ant hive, featuring numerous small caves mainly composed of Sandstone Blocks and Hardened Sand Blocks, which are connected in varying degrees. It is always either circular or oval in shape and is very large, rivaling even the Dungeon in size. Many types of Antlion enemies inhabit the Underground Desert, and it is also riddled with traps, namely Antlion Eggs, Rolling Cacti, and sand traps, making it a challenge to navigate.

The player is considered to be in an Underground Desert biome if they are in front of any Sandstone Walls or Hardened Sand Walls, and there are at least 1500 Sand Blocks, Hardened Sand Blocks, or Sandstone Blocks nearby. (Also see the spawning mechanics section for details about Underground Desert enemy spawning.)

The Underground Desert becomes significantly more challenging in Hardmode. Along with harder enemies, it is extremely vulnerable to conversion by Corruption, Crimson, or Hallow due to Sand, Hardened Sand, and Sandstone all being susceptible to conversion. Conversion further strengthens the Underground Desert's enemies, and in Corruption and Crimson Underground Deserts causes the spawn of Desert Spirits.

The Chlorophyte Arrow is a type of Hardmode arrow obtainable after all three mechanical bosses are defeated. Chlorophyte Arrows can ricochet off blocks four times, and will attempt to bounce in the direction of a nearby target if one is in range. Their damage is reduced by 33% after ricocheting.
Apart from the homing behavior, Chlorophyte Arrows ricochet in a different manner than other projectiles: They always return in the direction from which they hit the surface, making a 180° angle.
Illegal Gun Parts are a crafting material used to craft the Sandgun, the Megashark and the Flamethrower. They are sold by the Arms Dealer at night.

Plantera's Bulb is a Hardmode background object that will summon Plantera when broken. Plantera's Bulbs are usually found naturally placed in random Underground Jungle locations once all three of the mechanical bosses have been defeated (on the Nintendo 3DS version, one suffices) - the status message " The jungle grows restless... " indicates that Plantera's Bulbs have begun spawning. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, one Plantera's Bulb will immediately spawn when all three mechanical bosses are defeated for the first time.
A Plantera's Bulb must be destroyed with a pickaxe, a drill, a block, an actuator, a Clentaminator using any but the Green Solution, or with explosives in order to summon Plantera.

Plantera's Bulbs emit faint pink light in total darkness and will appear on the minimap in pink in areas the player has already explored. They spawn one at a time after a delay of about half a day between them, and unless destroyed, several will eventually be present (10-15 in a large world's naturally generated Underground Jungle). If destroyed, they respawn after the same delay (though not necessarily in the same spot), allowing the player to summon Plantera an infinite number of times. Plantera's Bulbs cannot be detected by the Metal Detector (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

The Wooden Spike is a type of trap block that damages players who come in contact with it, and is the upgrade of the regular, metal Spike. Despite its name and appearance suggesting that it is made of a weaker material, it deals more damage than the metal variant. The Wooden Spike deals (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 80 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 60 damage on contact. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it also inficts Bleeding for 10 / 20 / 25 seconds. Wooden Spikes are exclusively obtainable in limited quantities from the Jungle Temple, and can be broken with any drill, pickaxe, or explosive, unlike the Lihzahrd Bricks found around them, which require a Picksaw or stronger mining tool to break.
The Party Present is a decorative furniture item that can be purchased from the Party Girl during a Party for 20 SC. It has one of several different appearances when placed, similar to Books.

The Corrupt Penguin is a pre-Hardmode enemy that results from a Penguin that has been corrupted, either by the player using Vile Powder on it or when a Penguin spawns during a Blood Moon in a Corruption world.

Biome backgrounds are images that appear behind objects and blocks in each biome. Each biome has its own set of backgrounds that usually show a landscape of the biome. In a world, each biome is randomly assigned a background from its own set, and can be changed by using a World Globe (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Backgrounds can also be overridden using monoliths (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Backgrounds do not affect a biome in any way, except in The Hallow, where the current background affects the style of hallowed trees. Turning off backgrounds in Settings hides them, though ambient entities will still appear.

The Cat is a town pet. It arrives at dawn (4:30 AM) the day after the player uses the Cat License, which is purchased from the Zoologist for 5 GC. The Cat does not count towards the NPCs ' "crowded" limit and hence will not affect NPC happiness, although it does count as a regular town NPC for the purpose of the Pylon network. There are six breeds of Cat, with one randomly being chosen when it arrives.

The only requirements for the Cat to appear is the use of a Cat License and the presence of a valid house. The Cat's house can be changed, as with any other NPC, however the Cat can share the same house as another NPC. Like other NPCs, the Cat also require a valid standing point in the house (a home tile). It may not be able to share a house with another NPC if the house is too small.

The Cat can be talked to with the ⚷ Open / Activate button, like any other town NPC. It will offer a " Pet " option, which places the player directly in front of the Cat when selected, and displays an animation of them petting the Cat, an effect that is a purely visual. It only works if there are at least two flat tiles on the same level as the Cat in front of it. Using any item, taking damage, or closing the dialogue window terminates the animation.
Like the Angler, the status message displayed when the Cat is killed is " <name of Cat> has left! ". It will respawn within the next days, and may respawn as a different breed.
Jellyfish (bait) are a type of Bait which are found rarely by Fishing. Each has a Bait Power of 20%.

The Blue Jellyfish bait item is caught by Fishing in Underground or Cavern water bodies. The Green Jellyfish bait item is caught under the same conditions as Blue Jellyfish, but requires Hardmode. Once Hardmode is activated, there is a 1/2 (50%) chance that a Jellyfish bait item caught in the Underground or below will be Green (likewise for Blue). The Pink Jellyfish bait item is caught by Fishing in an Ocean biome.
Unlike Critter bait items, Jellyfish bait items are not caught using the Bug Net. Jellyfish bait items are separate and unrelated to Jellyfish enemies.

The Gold Brick Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Jungle Shrines in some worlds. It drops as an item when destroyed, and can also be obtained via crafting. It is always considered a safe wall.

The Golden Crate is a pre-Hardmode crate that can be obtained by fishing in any biome, at any layer. It is the highest tier of standard crate, having the greatest value if sold directly. Its Hardmode counterpart is the Titanium Crate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Meteor Head is a pre-Hardmode flying enemy that only spawns in a Meteorite biome. They override all other enemy spawns in the biome, except the Ocean biome. Once only (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 74 / (Old-gen console version) 49 / 22 blocks of Meteorite remain, the area is no longer considered a Meteorite biome. Therefore, Meteor Heads will no longer spawn.

Meteor Heads follow the Flying AI, and slowly float towards the player while passing through solid blocks. They inflict large amounts of damage upon contact with the player, and have a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of inflicting the On Fire! debuff for 7 / 14 / 17.5 seconds.

The Wizard Hat is an armor item that can be equipped in the helmet slot. It increases the player's magic damage by (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 5% / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 15% and grants (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 4 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 2 additional defense. It is guaranteed to be dropped by Tim.
In Celebrationmk10 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Getfixedboi worlds, the Wizard Hat also grants an additional minion slot.

The Wizard Hat is part of the Wizard set, which further consists of a Mystic Robe or any gem-augmented Robe. It provides a set bonus of +10% magic critical strike chance. The Magic Hat is an alternative for the helmet slot.
The Mahogany Leaf Block is a type of block that can be found naturally at the top of Living Mahogany Trees located in the Underground Jungle biome.

Mahogany Leaf Blocks can be placed by players via the Rich Mahogany Leaf Wand at a cost of 1 Rich Mahogany each. Mahogany Leaf Blocks cannot exist in a player's inventory, as breaking placed Mahogany Leaf Blocks will not drop any items.
The Snow Flinx is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Ice biome and is very susceptible to knockback, and when hit, will tumble over and fly backwards.

The Probe is a Hardmode enemy which is spawned by The Destroyer. When one of its red-lit segments is damaged, there is a 1/25 (4%) chance that a Probe is spawned from it. Probes can move through blocks and attack by firing Pink Lasers.
Probes make fighting The Destroyer an easier and harder task at the same time - the Hearts they drop will keep the player alive, but they are a major source of damage during the boss fight.

Reflective Gold Dye is a dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. When equipped, it will give the selected accessory/armor a gold-plated, "shiny" effect, reflecting the surrounding light around the player. The reflection is more pronounced the closer the player is to a light source. The dye will prioritize light from the sun when the player is outside. From some perspectives, the player may look 3D when this dye is equipped all over.

As with other reflective dyes, this dye is not animated when standing still, but the shading on a dyed piece of equipment will change according to the surrounding light, giving it the appearance of light reflecting off of a shining metallic object.

The Headless Horseman is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) wave 5 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) wave 9 of the Pumpkin Moon event. He is an exceptionally dangerous enemy due to his speed, high contact damage, and immunity to knockback. The Headless Horseman attacks by charging forward and doing a low, quick jump to reach the player. Additionally, on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Headless Horseman can also throw a Pumpkin Head projectile, which moves in a wavelike manner and homes into the player for an extended period of time.
Defeating a Headless Horseman during the Pumpkin Moon event will add (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 50 / 100 / 125 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 25 points to the final score.

Vortex Fragment Blocks are blocks made from Vortex Fragments which are dropped by the Vortex Pillar. The blocks have a crystal-like appearance with intense shades of green and blue. They can be crafted with the Ancient Manipulator. Walls cannot be crafted with them.
Shadewood armor is an armor set consisting of the Shadewood Helmet, Shadewood Breastplate, and Shadewood Greaves.

It is crafted solely from Shadewood harvested from Shadewood trees. It acts as the Crimson counterpart to the Corruption's Ebonwood armor, which shares the same stats. Along with its counterpart, it is the most powerful Surface pre-Hardmode wooden set, though it still pales in comparison to most other armor sets. It requires 75 Shadewood to craft a full set.
Wearing a full set grants a set bonus of 1 additional defense, providing a total of 5 defense.

The Crystal Ball is a Hardmode furniture item which functions as a crafting station. It is purchased from the Wizard for 10 GC. Placing and pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on a Crystal Ball grants the Clairvoyance buff.
The Clairvoyance buff boosts the following magic-related stats:
+20 maximum mana +5% magic damage +2% magic critical strike chance −2% mana usage

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Clairvoyance buff lasts until the player dies or leaves the world. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it lasts for 10 minutes. On all versions, the buff can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

Unlike equipment buff items, the Crystal Ball must be placed in order to activate the buff. It can be mined with a pickaxe or drill and picked up again, even while the buff is active, which will not cancel the buff. Placement is only dependent on an adequate space of 2x2 tiles being available.

The Fallen Tuxedo set is a set of vanity items consisting of the Fallen Tuxedo Shirt and the Fallen Tuxedo Pants. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
They are purchased from the Clothier for 50 GC (set), during a Blood Moon.
Helium Moss Brick is a type of brick made from Helium Moss that glows in the dark and cycles through the colors of the rainbow.

Cages are placeable decorative furniture items that display animated critters. A critter caught with the Bug Net, Lavaproof Bug Net (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or Golden Bug Net (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is combined with a Terrarium to craft a cage.
Gold cages (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are regular cages containing gold critters. They sell for 10 GC each. Aside from the sell price, they are the same as regular cages.

Cages are background furniture, however cages can be stacked and stood on like platforms. Nothing expect cages can be placed on them, On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, cages cannot be stacked and stood on in a fashion similar to platforms.
All cages measure either 6 tiles wide by 3 high, or 3 tiles wide by 2 high, and are partially transparent.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, cages can be converted back into their ingredients by throwing the cage into shimmer.

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, cages cannot be opened, broken, or crafted back into their ingredients, so once a critter is crafted into a cage, that particular critter can no longer be released.
There are currently (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 63 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 17 cages, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10 of which are gold variants.
The Mechanical Glove is a Hardmode accessory that boosts melee weapons in the following ways:

+100% knockback +12% damage +12% attack speed (also applies to whips) (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) They gain autoswing (also applies to whips) (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +10% size
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Mechanical Glove is only available after defeating all three mechanical bosses.
The White Cultist Archer is a Cultist variant that exists in Terraria's game files, but never actually spawns. It looks and behaves identically to the Blue Cultist Archer that appears in-game.

The Tiki Torch is a stationary light source that must be placed in order to provide light. Like Torches, it can be placed on platforms, and will be put out, broken and subsequently dropped when coming into contact with water. However, the Tiki Torch cannot be collected by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on it.

The Ancient Doom is one of the Lunatic Cultist 's attacks in Expert Mode and Master Mode. It will only appear when the boss is at relatively low health (less than 50%). A short time after creation or upon death, the Ancient Doom will burst and send slow-moving "Prophecy's End" projectiles in all four cardinal directions. These projectiles pierce and cannot be destroyed by weapons, and they deal a very significant amount of damage, especially in Master Mode.

Ambient entities are objects that appear and move around in the background, and cannot be interacted with in any way. They are displayed depending on the time of day, biome, weather, and current events. While some can be seen regularly, others are only displayed rarely. Clouds can be considered background entities although they are not affected by biomes. Ambient entities' motion speeds up with time.

The Necromancer is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns in the Dungeon after Plantera is defeated. It attacks by rapidly firing Shadow Beams at the player, thin rays of purple light that reflect off walls multiple times. They travel at an extremely high velocity, being fired nearly instantly, and inflict the Slow debuff. Necromancers teleport to a different location on-screen after firing projectiles six times or when being hit.
Necromancers spawn most often in areas of the Dungeon backed by brick walls. They can also spawn in other areas, but with a significantly reduced chance.
The Sawmill is a crafting station for advanced Wood and Furniture crafting. It is 3 blocks wide, 3 blocks high, and must be placed on top of solid blocks or platforms.

Prismatic Dye is a Hardmode, post- Plantera dye dropped by the Empress of Light with a 1/4 (25%) chance. The dye creates a prism-esque effect, making the equipped item seem transparent and glow in a cycling rainbow.

The Frost Staff is a Hardmode magic weapon that fires a frost bolt which travels in a straight line, pierces a single enemy, and disappears after hitting a second enemy or upon contact with tiles (while also inflicting the Frostbite (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) debuff for 7 seconds). The Frost Staff has a 1/50 (2%) chance of being dropped by Icy Mermen and Ice Elementals, both of which are found in the Snow and Ice biomes.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Spider Nest Wall is a type of wall. As with most placed walls, it is compatible with NPC housing and will stop enemies from spawning.

Team Dye is a dye that can be purchased from the Dye Trader while playing Multiplayer. The color of this dye will correspond to the team the player is on; if the player is not on a team, it acts as though no dye was equipped.

Crimtane Brick is a brick made from Crimtane Ore and Crimstone. A box of it appears after the Wall of Flesh has been defeated in a Crimson world. It is red and black in color, it is not resistant to explosions, and it gives off a faint red glow.

Storage items are Furniture items that can be right-clicked after being placed, to reveal forty Inventory slots, in four rows of ten, for storing items. These items allow the player to offload excess items, freeing space in their inventory. They can also be used for organizing items, eg. one Chest can hold Ores, while another can hold Gems. Stationary storage can also be renamed, to further help in organizing items (see Rename below).

All Storage items must be Placed in order to access their contents or store items. They can be freed by a Pickaxe, but most need to be emptied beforehand (see Stationary vs. portable storage below). (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Money Trough summons a Flying Piggy Bank, enabling players to access their Piggy Bank contents without having to place the Piggy Bank or any furniture for it to rest on.
Grates are foreground blocks which allow liquids to fall through while remaining solid for everything else, acting like a drainage system.

Grates can be toggled open and closed when triggered via wire. An open Grate is transparent, allowing light and liquid through, while a closed Grate is opaque and acts as a solid block. If a Grate is triggered while liquid is passing through it, the Grate holds the liquid until it is opened again or the liquid is removed by a player, e.g. via the use of an Empty Bucket, Super Absorbant Sponge, or Dry Bomb.
Bubbles function as the opposite of Grates, acting as background objects which prevent the flow of liquids through them but allow through other things like players.
Grates are not destroyed when dropped in lava, despite having a rarity of 00*.
The Frog Leg is an accessory that can be fished in any viable body of water. It aids jumping in the following ways:

Increases the player's jump speed by (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1.6 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 2.4. The player automatically jumps while the ↷ Jump key is held. This effect also works with Climbing Claws and other climbing accessories. Increases the maximum safe falling distance by (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 15 tiles.
These effects also apply with wings equipped.
The Star Princess set is a vanity set consisting of the Star Princess Crown and Star Princess Dress.

These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance. They are purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 1 PC (set), and is always sold along with the Celestial Wand.

The Rod of Harmony is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord tool. It functions identically to the Rod of Discord, instantly teleporting the player to the location of the cursor when used, but does not inflict the Chaos State debuff, allowing the player to teleport safely and as many times as desired without any drawbacks.
It can only be obtained by throwing a Rod of Discord into Shimmer in any world where the Moon Lord has been defeated.

The Lifeforce Potion is a buff potion that grants the Lifeforce buff when consumed. The buff increases the player's health capacity by up to 20% (see below for details). This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8 minutes / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

Cenx's Dress set are vanity developer items that can be obtained rarely (5% chance) from Treasure Bags dropped from Hardmode bosses (except Queen Slime 's). It is one of two vanity sets made for Cenx, the Creative Director on Terraria. Equipping the full set produces pink glowing particles when the player is near a light source.
Cenx's Dress equipment also includes a non-vanity item, which will drop in addition to her clothing set:
Cenx's Wings

Cenx's set, another vanity set created for Cenx, has the same chance of being dropped by Treasure Bags. One bag will never contain all of Cenx's items. Both do however contain Cenx's Wings and Cenx's Tiara.

Detonators are activation Mechanisms that can be found underground as part of Traps, wired to Explosives. They are often found planted on top of suspiciously large veins of underground metals (E.g. Silver).

Detonators act as switches, sending an activation trigger to other mechanisms connected to it through Wire. They are tripped either by right-clicking or when a player falls on the plunger, similar to a Pressure Plate.

Unlike pressure plates, a player has to actually fall from above to trigger a detonator. Even walking off a 1.5 block high column will not work, while walking off a 2 block high column reliably triggers it. This makes explosive traps that use a detonator instead of a pressure plate slightly less dangerous as they are more difficult to trigger accidentally (as well as much easier to see).
A detonator is not triggered by enemies or NPCs falling on it.

When triggered by player, a detonator disables itself for one second. When activated by a wire, it is disabled until it is activated by wire again. When it is disabled, plunger is stuck down and it cannot be triggered by a player clicking it or falling on it.

The Black Recluse is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in and around Spider Nests in the Cavern layer. It has a 1/10 (10%) chance to inflict the Acid Venom debuff for 4 / 8 / 10 seconds. In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), it gains a special spit attack that inflicts the Webbed debuff for 0.5-2.5 seconds.

The Bride is a rare pre-Hardmode enemy and a Zombie variant that spawns during a Blood Moon or very rarely at any time in a Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) biome. She acts the same as normal Zombies, slowly walking towards the player to deal contact damage while attempting to navigate around obstacles and opening doors if they are in the way. She has greater health than most other Zombies and is dressed in a traditional bride's outfit, which she can drop in the form of the Wedding Veil and Wedding Dress.
She does not have any variants, nor does she have an Armed variation in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Groom is her marriage counterpart.

She is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades. The Bride requires 10 kills to be awarded completion of her Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Lamia is a Hardmode enemy that can only be found in the Underground Desert biome. When found in regular or Hallowed Underground Deserts, it has pale blonde hair and has a chance to drop the Sun Mask. Corruption / Crimson Underground Deserts will spawn an alternate variant having much darker hair than its normal counterpart. The "corrupted" version has a chance to drop the Moon Mask.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Both variants have a rare chance to drop a piece of the Lamia set.

Skeletron is a pre-Hardmode boss. Defeating Skeletron for the first time grants unlimited access to all Dungeon areas for players within the current world and allows the Clothier NPC to move into an available vacant house.

If attempting to enter the Dungeon before killing Skeletron, Dungeon Guardians spawn once a player reaches 0 depth. These enemies deal 1,000 damage and generally kill any player in a single hit. Managing to defeat a Dungeon Guardian does not grant access to the Dungeon, thus defeating Skeletron is mandatory for accessing the Dungeon safely.

While Skeletron is alive, the music Boss 1 https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Boss_1.mp3 will play. When Otherworldly music (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is enabled, the track Boss 1 (Otherworldly) https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Boss_1_(Otherworldly).mp3 will play instead.

The Deer Thing is a boss-summoning item used to summon Deerclops. It can be used at any time of day, but only inside of a Snow or Ice biome. Attempting to use it outside of these biomes will have no effect and will not consume the item.

Silenced is a debuff that prevents the player from using any item that uses mana, stopping them from using magic and summon weapons (though existing summons will still remain). The debuff cannot be afflicted on players with a Megaphone, Countercurse Mantra, Ankh Charm or Ankh Shield equipped. If the player equips one of these items while the debuff is in effect, it will instantly be cured.

The Superheated Blood is a mount-summoning item that summons a rideable Lava Shark Mount. The Superheated Blood has a 19/100 (19%) chance of being obtained from Obsidian Crates or Hellstone Crates found by fishing in lava.

Riding the mount will allow the player to swim very quickly in lava without taking damage. It can also swim in water and honey, but will not protect the player from drowning. It has a maximum speed of 73 mph in liquids and 11 mph on land.
The mount maintains its velocity in the air, allowing for jumps similar to while riding a Minecart. When moving upwards or downwards, it tilts towards that direction.

The Bouncy Slime is a Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that is frequently summoned by Queen Slime alongside Crystal Slimes and Heavenly Slimes. It shoots Bouncy Gel projectiles at the player every 0.67 / 0.5 seconds.
The Topaz Robe is an armor item that can be worn in the shirt slot. It is part of the Wizard set and is the second weakest type of gem robe.

Wearing the Wizard Hat alongside the Topaz Robe provides a set bonus of +10% magic critical strike chance, whereas wearing a Magic Hat alongside it provides a set bonus of +60 mana. Any leg-slot equipment can be worn with these set bonuses remaining intact.
The Santa set is a vanity set which consists of the Santa Hat, the Santa Shirt, and the Santa Pants. It is purchased from Santa Claus for 45 GC (set) after the Frost Legion has been defeated.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
The Sandfall Block is an animated block type. It is one of the few items that uses the Crystal Ball as a crafting station.
The Ginger Beard is a vanity accessory found in Iron and Mythril Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), which can be obtained by fishing in any biome, at any height.
The Ginger Beard cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

The Reindeer Antlers are a vanity item that is dropped from Presents obtained during the Christmas seasonal event, with a chance of 2.308% in pre-Hardmode and 2.154% in Hardmode. When worn in the helmet slot, they place antlers on the player's head.

The Maggot is a critter that replaces Worms in the Graveyard biome, and can also be spawned from Maggot Zombies when they are killed. The Maggot has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Maggot can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Maggot Cage). Once crafted, the Maggot cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Maggot can be used as bait for fishing, with 22% bait power.

The Poison Dart is a type of pre-hardmode dart used with the Blowgun, Blowpipe, Dart Pistol (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and the Dart Rifle (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). They always inflict the Poisoned debuff on enemies which have a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to last for 60 seconds, and a 2/3 (66.67%) chance to last for 30 seconds.

The Solidifier is a crafting station used to craft Slime furniture out of Slime Blocks, from which the Solidifier can also be used to craft. It can also be used to craft Frozen Slime Blocks, which are special friction-less blocks, and Pink Slime Blocks, which negate fall damage and cause players to bounce. The Solidifier is always dropped by King Slime on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it can only be purchased from the Steampunker for 10 GC, during the day.

The Blindfold is a Hardmode immunity accessory that grants the player immunity to the Darkness debuff. It has a 1/100 (1%) / 1/50 (2%) chance to drop from Corrupt Slimes, Slimelings, Shadow Slimes (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), Crimslimes ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)), Dark Mummies, and Blood Mummies (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

It is one of the ingredients required to make the Reflective Shades (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), which are a crafting material required to make the Ankh Charm, an accessory further required to make the Ankh Shield.

The Raincoat Zombie is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a Zombie variant that spawns during rain on the surface at night. It acts the same as normal zombies, slowly walking towards the player to deal contact damage, while attempting to navigate around obstacles and only being able to open doors during a Blood Moon. It is differentiated from other zombies in that it is dressed in traditional yellow raincoat attire, which it can also drop in the form of the Rain Hat and Rain Coat armor pieces.
Raincoat Zombies can appear in three different size variations with slightly different stats. Unlike normal zombies, it does not have an Armed variation in Expert Mode.

The Javelin is a consumable ranged weapon. It can pierce up to 2 targets, hitting a total of 3 targets. It flying straight for approximately 36 tiles before dropping abruptly. Javelins have no chance of dropping themselves after impacting blocks or hitting enemies. They are only obtainable from Hoplites found in Marble Caves, which drop 40-80 Javelins with a 1/2 (50%) chance.
Smooth Granite Wall is a type of Wall that can be crafted with Smooth Granite Blocks.
Palladium Column Wall is a wall crafted from Palladium Columns.
The Copper Watch is a low-tier watch. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Tin Watch.

When equipped in an accessory slot or simply held in the inventory, a clock will appear in the upper-right corner of the playing screen, revealing the in-game time accurate to the last hour. An hour of Terraria game time is equivalent to one minute of real-world time. The Copper Watch can be used to craft the 5 Second Timer.
Ancient Cobalt armor is an armor set obtained from Hornets and Man Eaters in the Underground Jungle. Each piece is dropped individually with a 1/300 (0.33%) chance.

The Ancient Cobalt armor design is based on a version of Cobalt armor that appeared before the 1.0.3 update, when it was replaced by Jungle armor. The old design was later re-introduced, in 1.2, as Ancient Cobalt armor. It currently shares identical stats with Jungle armor, but differs in appearance. Furthermore, Jungle armor and Ancient Cobalt armor pieces can be mixed and matched while still providing their set bonus.
With a full set equipped, the player leaves an after-image effect when in motion, similar to Shadow armor, Necro armor, and the current version of Cobalt armor.
The Explosive Bunny is an item that serves as ammunition for the Bunny Cannon. Crafting it requires a Bunny, which must be caught with any Bug Net.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It can also be released as a critter, and will wander around like other critters. On death, it will explode, dealing damage but not destroying tiles. It will always be placed at the player's feet when released, instead of at the cursor like with most other critters.

Huntress armor is a Hardmode armor set purchased from the Tavernkeep for 450000* 45 in total after defeating any mechanical boss, and provides summon as well as ranged damage bonuses. The set consists of the Huntress's Wig, Huntress's Jerkin, and Huntress's Pants.
A full set of Huntress armor provides the following stats:
+36 defense +20% ranged damage +30% summon damage +10% ranged critical strike chance +20% movement speed +10% ammo conservation +2 sentry slots

Additionally, wearing the full set will increase the fire rate of Explosive Trap sentry summons and will cause their attacks to inflict the Oiled debuff for 4-8.5 seconds, making enemies take increased damage from On Fire!, Hellfire, Cursed Inferno, Frostburn, Frostbite, and Shadowflame.
The Red Riding armor can be considered a direct upgrade of the Huntress armor.
The Undead Viking is a pre-Hardmode enemy found in the Ice biome. It behaves similarly to the Skeleton, but spawns more frequently and jumps higher.
Large Bamboo is a block created from Bamboo that visually appears to be one large stalk as opposed to several bundled together.
Smooth Granite Blocks are blocks with a dark blue appearance. The block can be crafted or found as walls in underground houses in Granite Caves. They can be used to craft the Granite furniture set.

Topaz is a gem found within the Underground and Cavern layers of a world. They are obtained by breaking special blocks that have noticeable yellow-orange gemstones embedded in it. They can also be extracted from Silt, Slush, or Desert Fossil by putting them in an Extractinator. Rarely, Topaz can be found in bulk in its own Gemstone Cave mini biome, or in one that contains all of the other gems as well (besides Amber). Topaz is the second-least valuable gem available, being able to craft the Sandgun, a type of ranged weapon, along with the rest of the items that usually all gems have counterparts of.
