The Platinum Broadsword is an early game metal broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Gold Broadsword.
Like all broadswords, this sword has an arc motion, which is more useful for killing flying and jumping enemies than shortswords.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Coins are the main unit of currency in Terraria, primarily used for transactions with NPCs. The currency comprises four different metals, making four types of coins: Copper Coins, Silver Coins, Gold Coins, and Platinum Coins. Coins can also be used as ammunition for the Coin Gun.

Coins can be obtained by killing enemies, selling items to or interacting with NPCs, or finding them in multiple forms of loot. Despite coins appearing as the materials copper, silver, gold, or platinum, they are not related to their respective ores and cannot be crafted from them.
The coin value an enemy drops upon death is calculated from fixed base values with some random variation. See NPC drops § Coin drops for further information.

Monk armor is a Hardmode armor set purchased from the Tavernkeep for 450000* 45 in total after defeating any mechanical boss, and provides summon as well as melee damage bonuses. The set consists of the Monk's Bushy Brow Bald Cap, Monk's Shirt, and Monk's Pants.
A full set of Monk armor provides the following stats:
+46 defense +20% melee damage +30% summon damage +15% melee critical strike chance +2 sentry slots +20% melee speed +20% movement speed
Additionally, wearing the full set will increase the attack rate of the Lightning Aura sentry summons and will cause them to deal critical hits with a fixed 1/6 (16.67%) chance.
The Shinobi Infiltrator armor can be considered a direct upgrade of the Monk armor.

The Storm Spear is a pre-Hardmode spear that fires a Storm Spear Shot when thrust, a small, non-piercing bolt of electricity that deals 150% of the spear's damage (21 base damage) and inflicts half its knockback (base knockback of 3 (Very weak)). The Storm Spear can be found in Sandstone Chests in the lower 3/7ths of the Underground Desert and in Oasis Crates and Mirage Crates obtained from fishing in the Oasis.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Cooked Marshmallow is a food item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 10 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

The Cooked Marshmallow is created by holding a Marshmallow on a Stick over a Campfire for up to 15 real-world seconds (15 in-game minutes). The Marshmallow on a Stick must be held by the player, either by attaching it to the cursor in the inventory or selecting it in the hotbar, for the entire duration over the Campfire in order for it to be cooked. Selecting a different item in the hotbar, moving/turning away from the Campfire, or turning the Campfire off resets the timer.
Like all other food items, the Cooked Marshmallow can be placed on a Plate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) :

The Prismatic Lacewing Jar is a placeable furniture item which displays the Prismatic Lacewing, normally a Critter which summons the Empress of Light boss if killed. This item is a safe method of displaying captured Prismatic Lacewings.
The item cannot be used to summon the Empress of Light, and is purely decorative. Another Prismatic Lacewing must be caught or killed to summon the boss.

The Jungle Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that only spawns in the Jungle during the daytime. They have relatively high damage and health compared to most other slimes in the early game.
Notably, Jungle Slimes drop a much larger amount of coins than any common slime prior to Hardmode.
Like most other slimes, the Jungle Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
On Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can rarely be found carrying bonus drops, which the player receives upon the slime's death.

Pad Thai is a food item that grants the (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Plenty Satisfied / (Old-gen console version) Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8 minutes / (Old-gen console version) 4 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. Pad Thai can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 55 SC.
Like all other food items, the Pad Thai can be placed on a Plate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) :

The Ancient Chisel is an accessory that increases mining speed by 25%, similarly to a Mining Potion. It can be found in Sandstone Chests in the top 4/7ths of the Underground Desert and in Oasis Crates and Mirage Crates obtained from fishing in the Oasis.
Demonite Brick Wall is a wall crafted from a Demonite Brick. Like its block variant it emits a faint blue glow when placed.
Bamboo Wall is a type of wall. As with most placed walls, bamboo walls are compatible with NPC housing and will stop monsters from spawning.
Darts serve as ammunition for the Blowpipe, Blowgun, Dart Pistol, and Dart Rifle.

The Hoppin' Jack is a Hardmode enemy that will only appear at night during the Halloween seasonal event, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or in Graveyards (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) at any time of year. He attacks by hopping towards the player in a manner identical to most slimes. The difference, however, is that the lower health he has, the quicker he becomes.

Notably, despite using the Slime AI, he is not treated as a slime for most other purposes. Hoppin' Jack drops no Gel on death, and killing one is not necessary to earn the Gelatin World Tour ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) or Slimer/King of Slimes achievements.

The Eternia Crystal is an event-summoning item. When used on the Eternia Crystal Stand while under the correct terrain requirements, the Old One's Army event begins. The Eternia Crystal can be purchased from the Tavernkeep for 25 SC (pre- mechanical bosses), 1 GC (post-mechanical bosses), or 4 GC (post- Golem).
The Illuminant Bat is a Hardmode bat enemy that only spawns in the Underground Hallow. It is the Hallowed version of the Giant Bat, but is much stronger and emits a blurred, after-image effect.

The Confetti Block is an animated block type showing falling confetti. It is one of the few items that uses the Crystal Ball as a crafting station. Besides the confetti, it is transparent, like Glass. The Midnight Confetti Block is a dark, non-transparent version of it.

Explosives are a type of consumable weapon. Explosive devices are thrown from stacks in the player's inventory, after which there is a short delay before they explode. This detonation causes area-effect damage and destroys blocks, walls, and other placeable objects within the radius of an explosion. Only a small number of objects are resistant to these explosions.
Explosives deal a set amount of damage which cannot be altered by any bonuses, unlike the great majority of weapons.
Hellstone Bricks are placeable blocks that occur naturally in unique Ruined Houses, though they can also be crafted.

Like plain Hellstone, players without an Obsidian Skull or one of its upgrades in their accessory slot will receive the Burning debuff from making contact with the brick. Mining the block or carrying it in one's inventory incurs no negative effect, however. As with most damaging blocks, NPCs and enemies are immune to this damage.
Unlike Hellstone itself, Hellstone Bricks are always vulnerable to explosions.

The Demon Bow is a pre-Hardmode bow crafted solely using Demonite Bars. It is an upgrade over the Gold Bow and the Platinum Bow, being stronger and faster. The Demon Bow, along with its counterpart, the Tendon Bow, is the last type of ore bow the player will be able to craft until they reach The Underworld, as they could craft the Molten Fury.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Chik is a Hardmode yoyo. It is relatively easy to craft when first entering Hardmode.
It has a spin duration of 16 seconds and can reach up to 17 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Shield of Cthulhu is a pre-Hardmode shield accessory that allows the player to perform a dash attack by double-tapping either the ◀ Left or ▶ Right key. Dashing into an enemy deals 30 melee damage, recoils the player backward, and grants 0.07 seconds of invincibility frames. The Shield of Cthulhu is always dropped from the Eye of Cthulhu 's Treasure Bag in Expert Mode.
The Waterfall Block is an animated block type showing flowing water.
Ranged weapons are weapons which are used in ranged combat. The defining trait of ranged weapons is generally their requirement of ammunition in order for the weapon to operate.
Ranged weapons are roughly categorized into bows, repeaters, guns, and launchers. Note that Terraria classifies consumable weapons as ranged weapons as well, and boomerangs as melee weapons.

Due to the usage of ammo alongside the weapon, the total damage and knockback values in effect during use are actually the sum of the weapon's stats combined with those of the ammo type used. A ranged weapon with a knockback value of zero, for example, will still usually apply some knockback, since nearly all ammunition types have their own knockback values.

The following lists present all ranged weapons along with their damage and how to acquire them. The intention of this is to convey an idea of their strength and the approximate time during gameplay at which they can be obtained. For a sortable list that displays all statistics of all ranged weapons, see List of ranged weapons.

The Alien Hornet is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Vortex Pillar during the Lunar Events, summoned from opened portals in groups of two. If not killed fast enough, it will fairly quickly grow into an Alien Queen. They also grow from the Alien Larva that spawned from the death of an Alien Queen.

The Orichalcum Drill is a Hardmode drill, and is the drill alternative to the Orichalcum Pickaxe. In comparison to the Orichalcum Pickaxe, the drill is faster. But, unlike pickaxes, drills cannot be reforged with speed modifiers and are not boosted by Mining Speed bonuses.
It can mine any block except Chlorophyte Ore and Lihzahrd Bricks.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it, and furthermore cannot get modifiers that affect its speed, either.

Boomerangs are melee weapons that are thrown outwards when used and return to the player after a short amount of time. They have a much greater range than most other types of melee weapons but are not considered ranged due to not requiring any ammunition.
The best modifier for all boomerangs is generally Godly. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) The two stackable boomerangs cannot receive any modifiers.

The Endless Quiver is a Hardmode item that acts as ammunition, and can be placed in the ammo slots in the player's inventory. While in the user's inventory, it acts as a single Wooden Arrow that can be fired from any appropriate bow or repeater without being depleted. Bows that convert arrows into special types will fire their special shots indefinitely, including those such as The Bee's Knees that specifically require Wooden Arrows for their specialized shot types to work.

The Jungle Temple (also known as the Lihzahrd Temple or simply The Temple) is a large, enclosed structure constructed out of Lihzahrd Bricks and located in the Underground Jungle. It is always present in any generated world, but can only be properly entered after Plantera has been defeated. The Jungle Temple contains unique Lihzahrd-themed enemies, traps, and furniture. The Lihzahrd Furnace, a crafting station for further Lihzahrd-themed furniture, can be found in its Chests. The Lihzahrd Altar found in the Temple's final chamber is used to summon the Golem boss. Defeating Golem triggers the spawning of Cultists, used to summon the Lunar Events.

The Temple is entered via the Lihzahrd Door located at one of its two top corners. The door is initially locked, requiring a Temple Key to open, which is dropped by Plantera. Unlocking the door consumes one Temple Key from the player's inventory, and the door remains permanently unlocked for all players in the world. It is generally impossible to enter the Temple via any other conventional means since Lihzahrd Bricks can only be mined with at least the Picksaw dropped by Golem, and Lihzahrd Brick Walls impose numerous restrictions, e.g. on Teleporter use. There are, however, several methods to enter the temple prior to defeating Plantera.

The Temple's entrance leads to a long corridor that winds downward through several chambers, ending in a large room at the bottom containing the Lihzahrd Altar. The Altar can be used to summon Golem at the cost of one Lihzahrd Power Cell. Lihzahrd Power Cells are guaranteed to be found in the Temple's Lihzahrd Chests and are also dropped randomly by the Temple's Lihzahrds and Flying Snakes.

The entire Temple is filled with several types of traps, including Flame, Spear, Spiky Ball, and Super Dart Traps. Traps occur much more frequently in the Temple than in the Dungeon and are far more dangerous and damaging. They are activated by Lihzahrd Pressure Plates, which only respond to players (enemies walk on them freely without triggering them). As in the Dungeon, all Temple traps, pressure plates, and wires can be looted by the player for use in player-built mechanisms.

The Fireplace is a decorative furniture item with a style similar to that of the Chimney. A Fireplace operates similarly to a Campfire, having the same dimensions, emitting light, and granting nearby players the Cozy Fire regeneration buff. The buff is applied to all players who are within a rectangular area of 170x125 tiles centered on the Fireplace.
A Fireplace differs from a Campfire in the following ways:

A Fireplace has a flat surface on which other items can be placed, and will function as a valid surface for a Placed Bottle crafting station. A Fireplace functions as a valid light source for NPC housing, while the Campfire does not. A Fireplace cannot be toggled manually via the ⚷ Open / Activate button, while the Campfire can be. However, both can be toggled via Wire. A Fireplace cannot be used to produce a Cooked Marshmallow, while a Campfire can. A Fireplace will function within water, while most Campfires (those other than the Coral Campfire, Cursed Campfire, and Ichor Campfire) will not.

The Step Stool is an accessory used by holding ▲ Up. A stationary player using a Step Stool appears to be standing on a stool, which increases their jump reach. The Step Stool can be found inside surface Chests, Wooden Crates, and Pearlwood Crates. It can also be purchased for 2 GC 50 SC from the Skeleton Merchant during a Waning Crescent.
Martian Madness is a Hardmode, post- Golem invasion-style event that spawns several alien-themed enemies. It can only be triggered after Golem has been defeated.

Martian Madness is triggered by a Martian Probe, which spawns randomly in the two outer lateral thirds of the map (with a higher spawn chance in the Space layer). When this small flying enemy detects a player or is attacked, it immediately attempts to fly away. If the Probe escapes, the event starts. This requires at least one player with at least 200 maximum health to be in the world - otherwise, the event will not start.

Once triggered, the status message " Martians are invading! " appears, and UFOs start flying in the background (as seen in the banner above); though Martian Madness enemies will not actually begin spawning until the player is located near the default spawn point or near an NPC with valid housing. As with other invasion-style events, a progress bar is shown in the bottom right corner while the event is ongoing. This bar fills as event enemies are defeated. When it reaches 100%, the event ends and Martian enemies stop spawning.
Martian Madness currently features 11 exclusive enemies and one exclusive mini-boss (Martian Saucer), resulting in 11 different banners and one trophy.

The Magic Missile is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that fires an exploding projectile that can be controlled by holding the ⚒ Use / Attack button and moving the cursor. If the ⚒ Use / Attack button is released mid-drag, the missile will be flung in that direction. If the cursor is stationary on release, it flies directly away from the player. Once it is released, the missile homes in on nearby enemies. Upon contact with an enemy or solid block, it creates a small explosion that can hit enemies through a one-block-thick wall. The projectile also always emits a moderate amount of light. The Magic Missile has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from the Locked Gold Chests found in the Dungeon, as well as a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being obtained from Golden Lock Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Decay Chamber is a Hardmode crafting station used to craft Lesion furniture (Corruption -themed furniture) out of Lesion Blocks. The Decay Chamber can be purchased from the Steampunker for 10 GC but only appears for sale in worlds that are generated with the Corruption. It can also be crafted from the Flesh Cloning Vat, its Crimson counterpart.
Lesion Blocks are crafted using a Meat Grinder, so the Decay Chamber is of little use without one.
The SWAT Helmet is a vanity item that has a 1/12 (8.33%) / 23/144 (15.97%) chance to drop from Tactical Skeletons in the post-Plantera Dungeon.

The Snapthorn is a pre-Hardmode whip crafted out of Jungle materials. Like other whips, it causes minions and sentries to focus on the last-struck enemy and increases their damage against the target by 6.

If the Snapthorn hits multiple targets in a single attack, the damage dealt by each consecutive hit will be reduced by 40%. Upon striking an enemy, the Snapthorn has a 1/5 (20%) chance to inflict the Poisoned debuff on enemies for 3 seconds, and will also grant the Jungle's Fury buff, increasing attack speed by 12% for 3 seconds. The buff's duration can be refreshed by hitting enemies with the Snapthorn again.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Iron Pickaxe is an early-game pickaxe. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Lead Pickaxe.
Like other low-tier pickaxes, the Iron Pickaxe can only mine blocks and ores weaker than Meteorite (which requires a pickaxe with at least 50% pickaxe power, e.g. a Tungsten Pickaxe).
In Journey Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), the Iron Pickaxe replaces the Copper Pickaxe as a starting item for new characters.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Bat Scepter is a Hardmode, post- Plantera magic weapon that auto-fires (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1-3 / (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 2-3 homing bat projectiles per shot. These projectiles will not ricochet off of blocks but dissipate upon contact with an enemy or block instead, unlike the Bee Gun or Wasp Gun. The Bat Scepter is dropped by the Pumpking during the Pumpkin Moon event with a 2.5-12.5% (6.25-12.5%) chance depending on the current wave.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Emerald Staff is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon and is the fourth tier of gem staff. It fires a green bolt that can pierce one enemy. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It is the weakest gem staff capable of autofire, because its alternate-ore counterpart, the Sapphire Staff, does not autofire.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Death Sickle is a Hardmode melee weapon that autofires a large, spinning purple sickle projectile once per every swing, which costs no mana or ammunition and travels through blocks. The short-range sickle projectiles emit a small amount of light and travel approximately 12 tiles before stopping in place, and can pierce up to four enemies or linger in midair while stationary for three seconds before dissipating. The Death Sickle has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/40 (2.5%) / 79/1600 (4.94%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/250 (0.4%) chance of being dropped by Reapers during the Solar Eclipse event.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Adamantite Sword is a Hardmode broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Titanium Sword.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
Goggles are a piece of armor placed in the helmet slot. Unlike most helmets, Goggles do not cover the player's hair. Due to their low defense, they are often used as vanity items.

The Obsidian Crate is a pre-Hardmode crate that can only be fished in lava. Opening Obsidian and Hellstone Crates is the only way to obtain the Obsidian Lock Box, and therefore any Underworld-exclusive items normally found in locked Shadow Chests, once the Underworld has been fully looted. Its Hardmode counterpart is the Hellstone Crate.

The Peach is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Forest tree.
Like all other food items, the Peach can be placed on a Plate :
The Wasp Gun is a Hardmode, post- Plantera magic weapon that, as a direct upgrade of the Bee Gun, autofires homing wasp projectiles that damage and pierce enemies.

On the Desktop, Console, and Mobile, the Wasp Gun fires 2-4 wasps that ricochet or pierce enemies a maximum of three times before dissipating. The Wasp Gun also has 10 armor penetration, and its wasp projectiles cause static immunity frames. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the Wasp Gun fires 2-6 wasps that ricochet or pierce enemies a maximum of four times before dissipating. The Wasp Gun cannot inflict any knockback, and its wasp projectiles cause global immunity frames.
The Wasp Gun has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/7 (14.29%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being dropped by Plantera.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Mythical.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its best modifier is Demonic or Deadly for damage output, or Mystic for mana conservation because it cannot get modifiers that affect knockback.

The Cave Dirt Wall, Craggy Stone Wall, Fractured Stone Wall, Mottled Stone Wall, Old Stone Wall, Rocky Dirt Wall, Rough Dirt Wall, Stalactite Stone Wall, and Worn Stone Wall are types of background walls which can be found naturally generated in the Underground and Cavern layers, considered unsafe. They do not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained on the Desktop, Console, and Mobile, via crafting. They are considered safe walls when placed by the player.
The Craggy Stone, Fractured Stone, Mottled Stone, and Stalactite Stone Walls are unavailable on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version.
Worm AI is an AI type followed by most multi-segmented enemies.

The Flask of Venom is a Hardmode, post- Plantera flask that causes melee weapons and whips (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) to inflict the Acid Venom debuff for 5-9 seconds on enemies hit. Melee weapons that fire projectiles will also inflict the debuff on enemies hit by the projectiles (except for the Flairon 's bubbles).

The Flask of Venom cannot be used in conjunction with other flasks, and using it will remove any existing flask effects. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Like all other flasks, the effect will not be canceled when the player dies.
The Flask of Venom will inflict the Acid Venom debuff in PvP scenarios.
The Copper Broadsword is an early game metal broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Tin Broadsword.
As with all other broadswords, this sword is swung overhead, which makes it easier to defeat flying and jumping enemies than shortswords.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Kobold Glider is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Old One's Army event. It spawns during Tier 2 during waves 5-7, and Tier 3 during waves 4-5.

When it is close to or below the player or the Eternia Crystal, it will briefly spin upwards before lighting its fuse and diving towards its closest target, effectively turning itself into a homing missile. Upon contact with the player, Eternia Crystal, or solid blocks, it will detonate with a radius similar to that of a Grenade. The explosion cannot destroy tiles.
The Kobold Glider requires 100 kills to be awarded completion of its corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Hero Shield is a Hardmode post- Plantera shield accessory that redirects 25% of damage from players on the same team while above 25% health, similar to the effect of the Paladin's Shield. Furthermore, it increases defense by 10, increases aggro by 400, and grants immunity to knockback.

The Crimson Heart is a light pet-summoning item that summons a fast-moving bleeding Crimson Heart that emits dim, red light. It follows the player around while affected by gravity, rolling or hopping along the ground. If it falls far behind the player, it will fly through blocks to catch up. The Crimson Heart has a 1/5 (20%) chance of dropping from destroyed Crimson Hearts, but it also has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being acquired from Crimson Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Hematic Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), which are obtained by fishing in the Crimson.
The Corruption counterpart to the Crimson Heart is the Shadow Orb.

Infernal Wisp Dye is a Hardmode, post- Plantera dye obtained by turning in Strange Plants to the Dye Trader. Any equipment it is applied to is colored bright orange, while also emitting an orange glow.

The Climbing Claws are an accessory that lets players partially "stick" to the sides of blocks, slowly sliding down them when moving against them in midair. Jumps can also be performed off the sides of blocks. By repeatedly sticking and jumping, vertical blocks can be scaled. When sliding down, the slide speed can be accelerated using the ▼ Down key. Climbing Claws can be found in surface chests (including Water Chests) and they also have a 1/100 (1%) chance of being found in Wooden Crates and Pearlwood Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). They can also be purchased for 2 GC 50 SC from the Skeleton Merchant (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) during a Waxing Crescent. Their availability very early in the game makes them a useful accessory for mobility, as they allow the player to slowly but surely climb up some walls without needing ropes.

Climbing Claws function identically to the Shoe Spikes, but are found in different locations. When both Climbing Claws and Shoe Spikes are equipped, the wearer remains completely "stuck" at a fixed point when moving against the sides of blocks, and may slide down with the ▼ Down key. This effect can also be achieved using a single accessory if the Climbing Claws and Shoe Spikes are combined into the Tiger Climbing Gear at a Tinkerer's Workshop.
The Magic Quiver is a Hardmode accessory that boosts arrows and stakes. Unlike the general ranged damage bonuses, it only boosts the damage of the weapons and does not affect damage of the ammo.
It grants the following boosts to arrow and stake -firing weapons:
+10% damage +100% velocity (does not affect Jester's, Ichor, Venom Arrows, and Stakes) +20% chance not to consume ammo
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It will also increase the knockback of all arrow and stake-firing weapons by 10%.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It also affects the knockback of some arrow and stake-firing weapons by between around −40% and +9%; see notes.
The Magic Quiver has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/40 (2.5%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/80 (1.25%) chance of being dropped from Skeleton Archers.
The Angry Trapper is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Jungle and Underground Jungle biomes and is a much stronger version of the Man Eater and Snatcher.
This page discusses how the player health regeneration mechanism works, and how equipment and buffs affect the regeneration rate.
If the player is not hit for a short time, health starts regenerating until the player is hit again. The rate at which the player regenerates health is dependent on five factors:

The time the player has to wait until regeneration starts is highly variable from roughly 1/10th of a second to 17 seconds (32 seconds on Expert Mode) and is again dependent on maximum life, movement, and buffs/debuffs.

Hellfire is a Hardmode debuff that is a stronger version of On Fire!, preventing health regeneration and causing afflicted entities to lose 15 health per second. If affected by the Oiled debuff, afflicted entities will also take an additional 25 DPS, totaling 40 DPS.

The Blood Thorn is a Hardmode magic weapon that summons three penetrating Blood Thorn projectiles upon use, which erupt from solid blocks and platforms to damage enemies near the player's cursor. It has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped by Hemogoblin Sharks.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Molten Hamaxe is a tool which functions as both a hammer and an axe, and is an upgrade from the Meteor Hamaxe. It is crafted solely using Hellstone Bars. This tool has a chance of inflicting the On Fire! debuff. Its hammer and axe powers are the highest of all pre-Hardmode tools. While it has more axe power than most Hardmode axes, it is hindered in usage by its comparatively slow tool speed, making many later tools a better choice.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

Christmas Tree decorations are Hardmode furniture items used to decorate Christmas Trees. There are four categories: toppers, bulbs, lights, and garlands. Each tree can only include one of each type. Most decorations can be purchased from Santa Claus for 5 SC each, except for the Old-gen console -exclusive Star Topper 4, which can be found in Presents.
Decorations can only be removed by replacing specific decorations with another of the same type, or by removing the tree with a pickaxe, drill, or explosives and placing it again.
The Beetle Husk is a Hardmode, post- Golem crafting material dropped by Golem.

Crafting all Beetle Husk items requires (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 42 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 26 Beetle Husks. Crafting one full set of Beetle armor (without wings) requires 18 Beetle Husks, meaning the player will have to fight Golem 3-5 times / 1 time to guarantee enough Beetle Husks for a full set.

The Green Mushroom is a type of mushroom that grows in the Cavern and Underground layers. The Green Mushroom will not be uprooted when attacked, so harvesting it requires a pickaxe, drill, or explosives. Its sole purpose is to make Green Dye.

Titanium armor is a Hardmode armor set crafted from Titanium Bars, and is the alternative to Adamantite armor. Like many Hardmode armors, it has three different headgear/helmet options, allowing the player to focus on magical, melee, or ranged combat. Crafting a one-helmet set requires 59 Titanium Bars, made from 236 Titanium Ore. Crafting all five pieces requires 85 Titanium Bars or 340 Titanium Ore.

When the full set is equipped, striking an enemy with a melee, ranged, or magic weapon, or having an enemy be hit by a minion or sentry, will grant the Titanium Barrier buff, in which titanium shards spawn and rotate around the player, damaging enemies who come in contact with them. Seven shards can spin around the player at once, each dealing 50 damage with a knockback value of 15 (Insane), but cannot deal critical hits. Each shard lasts 10 seconds and refreshes when the player deals damage.
The Magma Snail is a critter that spawns in The Underworld. The Magma Snail has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Magma Snail can only be caught with the Lavaproof Bug Net or the Golden Bug Net. Trying to catch it with a standard Bug Net will only set the player on fire. After being caught, it can be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Magma Snail Cage). Once crafted, the Magma Snail cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Magma Snail can be used as bait for fishing, with 35% bait power. Using it as bait also allows fishing in lava.

The Kobold Dynamite Backpack is an unimplemented item that resembles the dynamite backpack worn by Kobolds and Kobold Gliders. It only exists as an ID and image file in the game's code. Attempting to use third-party tools to obtain it will result in it instantly disappearing.
The Copper Hammer is an early-game hammer. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Tin Hammer.
Like all hammers, it is used to remove background walls and create sloped tiles and half tiles.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Tendon Bow is a pre-Hardmode bow crafted solely using Crimtane Bars. It is the Crimson counterpart to the Corruption 's Demon Bow, with a slightly higher base damage and slower speed. Along with its counterpart, it is the last type of ore bow the player can craft until they reach The Underworld, where they could craft the Molten Fury.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Mechanical Lens is an informational accessory which will reveal placed wires and actuators. Each color of wire can be shown at maximum brightness, regular, or faded, which is configurable by the toggles. The Mechanical Lens is purchased from the Mechanic for 1 GC.

The Binoculars are a tool that can be held in order to shift the player's view based on the cursor location. They must be placed in the hotbar and selected. While highlighted in the hotbar, the screen view is scrolled a short distance away from the character, following the mouse pointer. The view becomes centered not on the player, but on a point almost halfway between the player and the cursor. The Binoculars have a 1/40 (2.5%) / 1/30 (3.33%) chance of being dropped by the Eye of Cthulhu.

The Iron Anvil and Lead Anvil are pre-Hardmode crafting stations used mainly to craft weapons and armor. Both anvils can craft the same items. Most of their recipes require metal bars, although they are also used to make other items, such as the Jungle tier of equipment. An anvil is a vital crafting station for most of the game, as it is used to make items from every tier up to Cobalt and Palladium, after which it must be replaced by a Mythril Anvil or Orichalcum Anvil.
Both anvils are craftable, but can sometimes also be found in Underground Cabins. The Iron Anvil can furthermore be purchased from the Merchant.
Crimson Tigerfish are a type of fish which are found commonly by fishing in the Crimson in any layer. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners and Heartreach Potions.

The Charm of Myths is a Hardmode accessory which combines the effects of the Band of Regeneration and the Philosopher's Stone. When equipped, it regenerates 1 health every second and decreases the Potion Sickness debuff duration by 25%. This debuff normally imposes a 60-second cooldown after consuming a recovery potion ; the Charm of Myths reduces it to 45 seconds.

The Rainbow Slime is a rare Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns on Hallowed blocks ((Old-gen console and 3DS versions) in the Hallow on non-Hallowed blocks) while it is raining. It constantly changes color, as do the Rainbow Bricks it drops.
Like most other slimes, the Rainbow Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.
Offline Gemspark Walls are a group of walls made from Gemspark Blocks. Unlike Gemspark Blocks, they produce no light, and have no mechanical function. Gemspark Walls are the illuminant variant.

Honey is a liquid found at the bottom of Bee Hives, as well as in small patches along with Honey Blocks in the Underground Jungle near Bee Hives. It is also sometimes created when destroying Hive blocks. Honey flows even more slowly than lava, and it also greatly slows the movement speed of most entities and projectiles (with the exception of the Old One's Army enemies and bosses). Like other liquids, honey can be transported with buckets or pumps. Like water, the player can drown in honey, and any item which allows breathing, walking on, or swimming in water will do likewise for honey.

Honey has the unique effect of granting players the Honey life regeneration buff, which lasts for as long as they remain standing or swimming in the honey, plus 30 seconds after leaving. The player does not need to be submerged, but the honey pool must be at least two tiles wide, and at least 5/8 of a tile deep. The buff increases the rate at which player health regenerates by 1 HP per second and increases natural heal rate acceleration by a factor of three. In addition, it reduces the damage from life-losing debuffs like Acid Venom by 2 HP per second.

Masks are vanity items dropped by all non- event bosses, as well as those from the Old One's Army (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). They are worn in the social head slot. Each boss has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance to drop its own mask in all difficulties, with the only exceptions being the Skeletron Mask, which has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to drop from Skeletron 's Treasure Bag, and the Dark Mage and Ogre Mask, which have a 1/14 (7.14%) chance to drop from their respective boss in Tier 3.
The Adamantite Beam is a building material crafted from Stone Blocks and Adamantite Ore. It is essentially the Adamantite Ore's equivalent of a brick.
Vulkelf Ears are a vanity item purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 2 GC 50 SC.

Turtle armor is a Hardmode armor set available after defeating all three mechanical bosses. A full set grants a vastly amplified Thorns effect upon taking contact damage from an enemy, which reflects (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 200% / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 100% of the enemy's contact damage back at them and inflicts a knockback of 10 (Extremely strong). The set consists of the Turtle Helmet, Turtle Scale Mail, and Turtle Leggings.
A full set of Turtle armor will also provide the following stats:
+14% melee damage +12% melee critical strike chance +750 aggro (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +15% damage reduction
With no vanity items covering the Turtle armor, a turtle shell appears on the player's back (much like the Leaf Blower, Flamethrower, Elf Melter, and Heat Ray backpacks), if the full set is equipped.
Crafting this set requires a total of 54 Chlorophyte Bars ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 270 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 324 Chlorophyte Ore) and 3 Turtle Shells.
The Victorian Goth set is a vanity set consisting of the Victorian Goth Hat and Victorian Goth Dress.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance. They are purchased from the Clothier for 20 GC (set) when he is spoken to in the Graveyard biome.
The Moon Lord Legs are an armor item for the pants slot. They have a 1/15 (6.67%) chance to be found in Chests in drunk worlds or Get fixed boi worlds.

The Moon Lord Legs replace the player's legs with Moon Lord -themed tentacles which produce a unique walking animation, a purely visual effect. In addition to providing 3 defense, the item has the following effects:
Increases the maximum safe falling distance by 10 tiles, jump speed by 1.8, and jump duration by 1 Increases movement speed by 25%
The Armored Skeleton is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Cavern layer. It has a 1/6 (16.67%) chance to inflict the Broken Armor debuff for 2 / 4 / 5 minutes on contact.

The Charged Blaster Cannon is a Hardmode, post- Golem magic weapon that possesses multiple firing modes with escalating speed, damage, and method of attack depending on how long the ⚒ Use / Attack key is held while firing it.

A single tap of the ⚒ Use / Attack key fires a small energy orb that dissipates after hitting an enemy or solid block. Holding ⚒ Use / Attack rapidly fires small orbs at a rate of six orbs per second. Mana is only consumed upon firing the first small orb. After holding ⚒ Use / Attack for one second (i.e., after 6 small orbs have been fired), it will shoot a larger orb with infinite piercing and 2.5x the weapon's base damage (250 base damage). Continuing to hold ⚒ Use / Attack fires larger orbs at a rate of 2 orbs per second. Mana is only consumed upon firing the first large orb. Holding ⚒ Use / Attack for two more seconds (i.e., after 3 large orbs have been fired) and holding the key down continuously fires a large, solid blue energy beam that travels for a maximum of 300 tiles, deals 1.5x the weapon's base damage (150 damage), and infinitely pierces enemies at a rate of every 20 ticks or three times per second. Mana is consumed at the same rate, i.e. 42 base mana per second.

The attack is immediately canceled when mana is depleted, the ⚒ Use / Attack key is released, or after the beam is fired for five seconds. The Charged Blaster Cannon has a 1/800 (0.13%) chance to drop from all basic enemies during the Martian Madness event.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Ice Bow is a Hardmode bow that converts any type of arrow into special Frost Arrows which travel faster with less of an arc as a result and lose any special properties, but retain increased damage when used with stronger arrows. However, unlike the craftable Frostburn Arrows, they do not inflict the Frostburn debuff. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it is capable of autofire. The Ice Bow has a 19/60 (31.67%) chance of being dropped by Ice Mimics.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Bone Key is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Baby Skeletron Head to follow the player around. The Baby Skeletron Head floats around the player and sometimes spins its head, similarly to Skeletron 's spinning head attack or the Dungeon Guardians in general. This action may also occur if the player is a bit further away from the Skeletron Head. The Bone Key is always dropped from Dungeon Guardians. Because Dungeon Guardians have extremely high stats intended to instantly kill all players, this can be a difficult item to acquire.

The Bone Javelin is a consumable ranged weapon crafted from Sturdy Fossils. Upon hitting an enemy, it will stick to the enemy and inflict the Penetrated debuff, dealing 3 damage per second for 15 seconds. Up to six Bone Javelins can be stuck onto an enemy, dealing a total of 18 damage per second.

The Solar Fragment is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist crafting material. It is one of the four Lunar Fragments, dropped from the Solar Pillar during the Lunar Events in stacks of 12-60 / 24-100. Solar Fragments can be used to craft Solar Flare armor, an end-game armor set that benefits all types of melee weapons, as well as Solar-themed tools, weapons, wings, etc.

Crafting all items requires 121 Solar Fragments and 68 Luminite Bars (272 Luminite), which necessitates defeating the Solar Pillar at least 3-11 / 2-8 times (note that the Solar Fragment can also be crafted from the other fragments) and fighting the Moon Lord at least 4 / 3-4 times.

The Pygmy Staff is a Hardmode, post- Plantera summon weapon that spawns a Pygmy minion, which attacks by throwing long-ranged spears aimed at nearby enemies at a rate of twice per second. Pygmy Spears break upon contact with an enemy or solid block, and, on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, also inflict the Acid Venom debuff for a 5-10 second duration. Like other minions, summoned Pygmies are invincible and follow the player indefinitely or until the player dies, summons a different minion, cancels the buff, or leaves the world. The Pygmy Staff has a 1/4 (25%) / 1/2 (50%) chance of being dropped by Plantera.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Pygmy Staff has over a Ruthless one is knockback.

Spectre Boots are an accessory crafted from Rocket Boots and either Hermes Boots, Flurry Boots, Sailfish Boots (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or Dunerider Boots (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and combine their functionality (except the faster speed on sand from Dunerider Boots). They increase the player's max horizontal movement speed to 30 mph, and grant a total flight time of 1.17 seconds. During flight, they emit a white/blue cloud trail, but unlike the Rocket Boots, they do not produce any light.

The Snowman Cannon is a Hardmode, post- Plantera launcher that can be considered an upgraded version of the Rocket Launcher, firing unique snowman-shaped rockets that chase after the nearest enemy before exploding upon impact. The Snowman Cannon is dropped from the Ice Queen during the Frost Moon event with a 5.19%-10.37% (15.56%-31.11%) chance depending on the current wave.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The World Globe is a thrown consumable item sold by the Zoologist after the Bestiary is 50% complete (270 entries). Once a World Globe is thrown and shatters on a surface, the background for the current biome changes permanently for the current world, to a random one of the backgrounds available for that biome. This lasts until another World Globe is thrown. The World Globe can be used in any biome.

The Explosive Trap Rod, Cane, and Staff are special sentry summon weapons. They can summon the Explosive Trap sentry, which lasts for 10 minutes, remains stationary, and does not count against the player's minion capacity. Each Explosive Trap sentry is a small device on the ground that explodes when an enemy comes in close proximity. It does not disappear upon exploding, but remains at its summon point to explode repeatedly until its time is exhausted or the Old One's Army event ends. The Rod is sold by the Tavernkeep for 50000* 5, the Cane for 150000* 15, and the Staff for 600000* 60.

The Rod is always available. The Cane becomes available after defeating one mechanical boss, and the Staff becomes available after defeating Golem. The three different versions cause an identical effect, but with varying statistics, with the Staff being the most expensive and the most powerful.

These weapons cannot be used outside of the Old One's Army event until the event has been successfully completed. Completing the event on any difficulty allows Rods, Canes, and Staves alike to be used outside of the event.

During the Old One's Army event, Etherian Mana can be collected, which allows the placement of multiple Explosive Traps that remain permanently until the event is over. Etherian Mana cannot be used outside the event.

Explosive Trap sentries are boosted by the Huntress armor and Red Riding armor set bonuses, which increase their fire rates and cause them to inflict the Oiled debuff on struck enemies for 4-8.5 seconds.

Their best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Explosive Trap sentry summons has over a Ruthless one is knockback.

The Love Potion is a Hardmode thrown potion that functions similarly to Thrown Water, though causes no functional effect. Upon colliding with solid blocks, it inflicts the Lovestruck debuff on players, enemies, critters, and NPCs within a radius of 9 tiles, causing them to emit red hearts for 30 seconds, similar to the Water Gun 's dripping effect. This effect is purely cosmetic.

The Vicious Mushroom is a type of mushroom found on grass in the Crimson, where they can be cut and collected with a single swing of any weapon or tool.  Vicious Mushroom can only grow when there are proper walls behind the soil block, or no walls at all.

Vicious Mushroom cannot be eaten or brewed into any potions; they are used solely to craft Vicious Powder. Vicious Mushroom plants will be converted into ordinary Mushrooms and Jungle Spores if they are purified using Purification Powder or the Clentaminator.

The Wall Skeleton is a Decorative Furniture item that can be placed on walls, similar to Paintings. Wall Skeletons can only be obtained by looting them from the Dungeon, where they only appear in areas backed by Slab Walls.
Mc MoneyPants was an unspawnable NPC introduced alongside the Chinese New Year content. It served no unique purpose, and was promptly removed.
Ice Brick Wall is a type of Wall that is made using Ice Bricks.
The Platinum Shortsword is an early game metal shortsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Gold Shortsword.

Like all shortswords, the Platinum Shortsword has a very limited range and attacks with a stabbing motion at any direction on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, and horizontally in front of the player on Old-gen console and 3DS, instead of an arc. This makes it almost useless against flying or jumping enemies, although its high attack rate makes it somewhat effective against weaker fighter type enemies.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Enchanted Sword Shrine is a terrain feature that generates as a small cave below the surface. It has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to generate with a 1-tile wide shaft leading into the top of the cave. The cave's background is made of Flower Walls and features a small hill with pools of water on either side. Atop the hill rests a sword in stone as a background object, which, when destroyed, has a 1/50 (2%) chance to drop a Terragrim and an Enchanted Sword otherwise.

The Enchanted Sword Shrine generates in the surface or underground layers in the outer two-thirds of the map, in dirt or stone terrain. Multiple shrines may generate in a world, with larger worlds having a slightly increased chance to generate more, although not guaranteed to generate any.

Ice Blocks are a common block type found alongside Snow Blocks in the Snow and Ice biomes. They can be mined with a pickaxe or drill. Ice Blocks have low friction, causing a player walking over them to slide when stopping or changing directions. This effect can be mitigated by equipping Ice Skates or other accessories crafted from them.
Ice Blocks can be converted into three other variants via the spread of biomes :
Corruption spreads onto Ice to create Purple Ice Blocks Crimson spreads onto Ice to create Red Ice Blocks Hallow spreads onto Ice to create Pink Ice Blocks
These will also spread their respective biomes.

The Lunar Hook is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist grappling hook crafted from Lunar Fragments. It has four glowing hooks which can be launched simultaneously and reach up to 34.375 tiles. Each hook is themed after one of the four Celestial Pillars.

Ores are primary crafting materials necessary for game progress. They generally must be crafted into bars at a Furnace, after which they can craft several essential tools, weapons, armor, and other items. Some items require raw ores themselves, most commonly bricks and potions. Raw ores can also be used as plain blocks for construction.

Ores generally appear as veins of placed blocks in the Underground layer and below, and are mined with a pickaxe or drill. Lower-tier ores appear among Dirt near the surface, or within Floating Islands. Some ores are also dropped by bosses, namely Eye of Cthulhu, Eater of Worlds, Brain of Cthulhu, Ocram (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), and Moon Lord (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
An Extractinator and crates (from fishing) also provide ores as random rewards.

A world will generally only contain one ore type from each tier, which is chosen at random, for instance; one world may have Copper and Iron Ores, while another may have Copper and Lead Ores (see tables below). The alternate ore types which do not generate naturally in a world can still be obtained by other means, such as crates, bonus drops (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions), or loot from an Extractinator. Hardmode ore types are chosen at random as soon as the player destroys an Altar.
In a drunk world (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), both ore variants of each tier will spawn instead of one.
There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 21 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 20 different types of ores.
Tungsten armor is an alternative to Silver armor. It takes a total of 60 Tungsten Bars to craft a full suit, this translates to 240 Tungsten Ore to craft all the necessary bars for this armor.
It consists of a Tungsten Helmet, Tungsten Chainmail and Tungsten Greaves.
A full set grants a basic 12 defense plus a set bonus of 3 defense, which equals a total of 15 defense. This is 2 more than its silver counterpart, and 1 less than the next type, Gold armor.

The Possessed Skull is a pet-summoning item that spawns Skeletron Jr. to follow the player around. When the player is too far away or in midair, Skeletron Jr. will start spinning its head in order to catch up to them. The Possessed Skull has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by Skeletron in Master Mode.

The Adamantite Repeater is a Hardmode repeater crafted solely using Adamantite Bars. It is one of the strongest of the Hardmode ore repeaters, only beaten by the Chlorophyte Shotbow. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Titanium Repeater.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

Shadewood furniture are furniture items crafted from Shadewood, obtained by cutting down Crimson trees found in The Crimson. There are 18 (20 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) different Shadewood furniture items.

Silver Brick is a type of Brick and an aesthetic building material. Like the ore it is made of, placed Silver Bricks will sparkle. It is not recommended that it be used for building unless the player has silver ore to spare. Despite being made of Silver, it has no sell value. It can be crafted into Silver Brick Walls.

The Pigron is a Hardmode enemy found in the Ice biome when it is overlapped with the Underground Corruption, Underground Crimson, or Underground Hallow. It has multiple color variants, depending on which overlapping biome it spawns in, but all share identical stats and behavior.

Pigrons have a special ability to become transparent and nearly invisible, allowing them to fly through solid blocks. As a transparent Pigron starts to attack, it will become visible again. When it starts moving towards the player, it occasionally makes an audible growl. If it is in its solid, visible state and is blocked by solid blocks on its path to the player, it will become transparent again to pass through them.
The Constant is a secret world seed. It is a crossover with Klei Entertainment's Don't Starve Together.
The following seeds can be used to generate a Constant world (case-insensitive):
Lucky is a buff which increases the player's luck. The more time the buff has left, the more the player's luck is increased.
Potted Crystal Plants are placeable furniture items. They are purchased from the Princess for 10 GC each.

The Shadow Jousting Lance is a Hardmode, post- Plantera melee weapon. When attacking using ⚒ Use / Attack, the lance will extend, and holding ⚒ Use / Attack will keep it extended at a fixed angle. The damage and knockback will increase depending on the player's movement speed, making mounts, sprinting accessories, or dash abilities (such as those granted by Shield of Cthulhu, Tabi / Master Ninja Gear, or Solar Flare armor) useful for maximizing damage. When the player takes damage, the Shadow Jousting Lance will stop being active. The Shadow Jousting Lance has a 1/25 (4%) / 49/625 (7.84%) chance of being dropped by Giant Cursed Skulls in the post-Plantera Dungeon.
It is the upgrade of the Jousting Lance and Hallowed Jousting Lance.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Cutlass is a rare Hardmode sword that deals good damage and can be swung continuously at very high speed. The Cutlass has a 1/200 (0.5%) chance of being dropped by regular Pirate Invasion enemies (excluding the Parrot), a 1/50 (2%) chance from Pirate Captains, and a 1/10 (10%) chance from the Flying Dutchman (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Mining Potion is a buff potion which grants the Mining buff when consumed. The buff increases mining speed by 25%. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10 / (Old-gen console version) 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
In addition to being crafted, Mining Potions can be found in pots, chests, and crates, and have a small chance to appear as a bonus drop from slimes.

The Water Strider is a harmless critter that spawns on bodies of water on the Surface during the day. It only spawns near Sand or Jungle grass blocks, but not in the Ocean biome. It will not spawn if the wind speed exceeds 20 mph. The Water Strider moves by gliding on water and hopping around on land. The Water Strider has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Water Strider can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Water Strider Cage). Once crafted, the Water Strider cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Water Strider can be used as bait for fishing, with 17% bait power.
There is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Water Strider to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

The Icy Merman is a Hardmode enemy found in the Ice biome. Upon gaining line of sight of the player, it will stop in place and begin firing Icewater Spit projectiles similar to those fired by the Frost Staff, but with less frequency. Its projectiles also behave similarly to those of the Ice Elemental, but deal less damage and are fired more rapidly. The Icewater Spit attack always inflicts the Chilled debuff, and has a 1/10 (10%) chance to inflict Frozen.
The Paintbrush is a tool which is used to apply paint to tiles. It is purchased from the Painter for 1 GC. Its upgrade, the Spectre Paintbrush, grants a bonus to range.
The Paintbrush cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

The Reaper is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it will only spawn after all mechanical bosses have been defeated.

Reapers behave in a similar manner to Wraiths, but they have higher stats. They also move significantly faster than Wraiths, and with the higher spawn rate of the Solar Eclipse, they often attack from multiple directions at once.

They are fairly vulnerable to knockback. Like many creatures that pass through blocks, they do not take damage from lava. Furthermore, weapons whose animations do not stop upon hitting blocks, like most melee weapons, will damage them despite not normally being able to attack through blocks.

Glommer's Flower is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that summons a Glommer pet that follows the player around. Glommer's Flower is dropped from Derplings with a 1/100 (1%) chance and increased to 1/40 (2.5%) in The Constant secret seed.
Astra Brick is a type of decorative brick obtained by throwing Luminite Brick into Shimmer during a Third Quarter.

The Alien Larva is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Vortex Pillar during the Lunar Events. They move fairly slowly along the ground, and will only naturally spawn in groups of two or three upon the death of an Alien Queen. If unattended, they will grow into Alien Hornets, which in turn become Alien Queens later on.
The Gold Broadsword is an early game metal broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Platinum Broadsword.
Like all broadswords, this sword has an arc motion, which is more useful for killing flying and jumping monsters than shortswords.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Vilethorn is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that extends a 15-tile-long spear-like projection from the player's position. It passes through blocks, pierces multiple enemies, and scores a rapid succession of up to seven hits per enemy. Its total effect lasts roughly 1.5 seconds. The Vilethorn has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being obtained from destroying Shadow Orbs found in the Corruption or a 1/5 (20%) chance from Corrupt Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Defiled Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), which are fished in the Corruption.
Its best modifier is Ruthless. While Mythical gives a wider array of bonuses, damage rounding causes Ruthless to deal more DPS.

The Frostspark Boots are an accessory crafted by combining Lightning Boots and Ice Skates together at a Tinkerer's Workshop. It provides the benefits of both. They also have an 8% increased movement speed.
Frostspark Boots display a different particle effect than the Spectre Boots or Lightning Boots: they produce snow clouds similar to those made by the Blizzard in a Bottle.

Fences are a type of safe wall that are visually thin with most of them having transparency to allow view of the background. The only fences that have no transparency to them are Palm Fence, Mahogany Fence, and Shadewood Fence. Unlike most other safe walls, they allow for wild plants and trees, except for palm trees and its variants, to grow. The safe grass wall, flower wall, and jungle wall are functionally identical to fences.

Mining speed (also known as tool speed) is an invisible statistic that determines how fast the player can mine (or break walls, or chop down trees/cacti). Its value shows the time per hit in 60ths of second. It is therefore something of a misnomer: it is presented in the form of the amount of time taken for a certain event, whereas speed is the number of events that take place in a certain amount of time (or, in mathematical terms, the number that is seen is the reciprocal of the speed). This means that faster tools have smaller numbers, not larger. For example, a mining speed of 15 means that the tool will hit the block every 15/60 of a second, or four times per second. A mining speed of 20, on the other hand, means that the tool will hit the block every 20/60 of a second, or three times per second.
When breaking walls, its value is cut in half, then any numbers after the decimal point removed (e.g. 2.8 would be rounded down to 2). Thus, walls break at least twice as fast as blocks.
The final mining speed is determined by the following:

The tool 's base tool speed, which is hidden in the game's code and not normally visible in game (but can be looked up on this wiki, referred to as "tool speed" on each tool's page and as "mining speed" as a column header in a table of tools). Any speed-modifying modifier on the tool (the best being "Light," with a 15% increase. Note that for some tools, there are other modifiers which will work just as well. Details below). Changing other stats via a modifier (e.g. damage) has no effect on mining speed. Buffs and items specifically affecting mining speed. Note that these only apply to tools that can pick blocks (including the Gravedigger's Shovel, but excluding drills). Interestingly, tools that can function as both pickaxes and axes will always benefit from these bonuses - regardless of if they are being used as pickaxes or axes.

In particular, a tool's mining speed is independent of how quickly it swings, which is the speed visible in the in-game tooltip (e.g. " Copper Pickaxe —Fast Speed") which can also be referred to as "use time." Speed-modifying modifiers affect both mining speed and use time, potentially leading to the misconception that "melee speed" bonuses from armor and accessories improve mining speed. In truth, melee speed bonuses affect only use time, which is useful for combat but has no influence on mining speed.

What this wiki refers to for clarity's sake as "use time" is represented by an item's useAnimation property in the game's source code, and what it refers to as "mining speed" or "tool speed" is actually represented by useTime. Thus, "use time" and useTime are two separate things and should not be confused.

Slimes are the most common enemy type. They are almost always the first enemy the player encounters in a new world. They come in multiple sizes and colors, each with different health, defense, and damage. Slimes generally follow the basic Slime AI : They hop in the direction of the player and rest a short amount of time afterwards. When a slime is preparing to hop, it bobs up and down rapidly. Slimes can float in water and move significantly faster while doing so, but only the Lava Slime can float in lava.

Slimes spawned on or near the surface are usually neutral and do not chase the player during the day, unless they take damage. All slimes become hostile at night and slimes spawned underground are always hostile. Green, Blue, Red, Purple, and Yellow Slimes usually spawn on or near the surface, while Mother Slime, Baby Slime, and Black Slime can only be found underground. Pinky may appear anywhere, yet rarely. Similar to Pinky, the Golden Slime (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) may appear anywhere rarely, but only in Celebrationmk10 and getfixedboi worlds.
Most types drop 1-2 Gel, with exceptions noted in the table below. Most slime types also have a very small chance of dropping a Slime Staff.

The Peach Sangria is a food item that grants Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 10 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Peach Sangria can be placed on a Plate :
Enemies are hostile entities which attempt to inflict damage on players. This page lists all enemies that can be encountered in Terraria.
Enemies do not take fall damage. See NPC spawning and NPC despawning for details on how the game determines where and when enemies spawn.

There are a total of 359 enemies: 133 pre-Hardmode, 224 Hardmode, and 2 unspawnable. Out of these, 121 belong to events (26 pre-Hardmode and 95 Hardmode), 20 are bosses (9 pre-Hardmode and 11 Hardmode), 14 are event bosses (1 pre-Hardmode and 13 Hardmode), and 19 are bosses' servants (7 pre-Hardmode and 12 Hardmode).

The Demon Eye is a common pre-Hardmode flying enemy that appears in most surface biomes during nighttime, particularly in Forests. It has a slow turn rate, follows the player, and bounces off blocks. Its trajectory is changed when hit with a weapon that causes knockback.

The Amber Horseshoe Balloon is an accessory that increases jump height by 75% (6 blocks → 10.5 blocks), reduces it by 15% when underwater (8 blocks → 7 blocks), makes the player immune to fall damage, and releases bees when attacked, which seek out and damage enemies. It also grants +0.05 luck (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). It can be crafted at a Tinkerer's Workshop with a Lucky Horseshoe and a Honey Balloon. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it also grants the Honey buff after being damaged.

The Iron Hammer is an early-game hammer, being stronger than the Copper Hammer and weaker than the Silver Hammer. Like all hammers, it is used to remove background walls and shape blocks. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Lead Hammer.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The Iron Hammer can be crafted with 8 Iron Bars and 3 of any Wood. However, it is also obtained upon creation of a Journey Mode character, placed in the fourth slot of the hotbar.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.
Fritz is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event. It moves very quickly on the ground and leaps into players to attack.
The animal skins are decorative furniture items that are used like paintings. They are purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 1 GC each.

Slow is a debuff that halves the player's horizontal movement speed. It has a chance to be inflicted by direct contact from a Pixie, Wraith, Mummies or Rusty Armored Bones. The beams fired by Necromancers also have a chance to cause this debuff. Equipping the Fast Clock, The Plan, the Ankh Charm, or the Ankh Shield makes the player immune to the debuff.

Minion Summon Items are summon weapons that spawn secondary characters that will aid the player during battle by automatically attacking enemies within range. They cannot be hurt or killed, and deal summon damage. Minions are mobile characters that follow the player.

Whips are related weapons that deal summon damage without summoning any minions. Hitting an enemy with a whip causes a player's minions to target it immediately. Some whips have bonus effects which can be activated by minions.
The best modifier for pre-hardmode minion summon items is generally Mythical, while the best modifier for hardmode minion summon items is generally Ruthless.
The Pirate set is a vanity set which consists of the Pirate Hat, Pirate Shirt and Pirate Pants. They are purchased from the Pirate for 15 GC (set).
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
The Pygmy Necklace is a pre-Hardmode accessory that provides the player with one additional minion slot. It is purchased from the Witch Doctor for 20 GC at night.

The Shoe Spikes are an accessory that lets players partially "stick" to the sides of blocks, slowly sliding down them when moving against them in midair. Jumps can also be performed off the sides of blocks. By repeatedly sticking and jumping, vertical blocks can be scaled. When sliding down, the slide speed can be accelerated using the ▼ Down key. Shoe Spikes can be found in Gold Chests underground and in Rich Mahogany Chests found in the Underground Jungle.

Shoe Spikes function identically to the Climbing Claws, but are found in different locations, Climbing Claws only appearing in surface chests. When both Shoe Spikes and Climbing Claws are equipped simultaneously, the wearer remains completely "stuck" at a fixed point when moving against the sides of blocks, and may slide down with the ▼ Down key. This effect can be achieved using a single accessory if the Shoe Spikes and Climbing Claws are combined into the Tiger Climbing Gear at a Tinkerer's Workshop.
Shifting Pearlsands Dye is a Hardmode dye that is very similar to the Shifting Sands Dye, but its color is more pink. It can only be crafted, and cannot be obtained any other way.

Spider Nests, also known as Spider Caves or Spider Caverns, are mini-biomes located in the Cavern layer. They feature distinct almost pitch-black Spider Walls and there are numerous Cobwebs filling the area. The Spider Walls make Cobwebs rapidly grow back, which is a unique feature of the biome. Spider Nests can rarely contain Web Covered Chests. The Webbed Stylist NPC can also spawn here.

Silk is an item used to craft the Bed, as well as several placeable decorative items and vanity clothing items. One unit of Silk can be crafted out of seven Cobwebs at a Loom. While raw Cobwebs have no value, Silk sells for 2 SC each.

The Flower Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in the Forest and in Enchanted Sword Shrines, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained by purchasing it from the Dryad for 10 CC each. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

The Bamboo Leaf is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Baby Red Panda to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Baby Red Panda will fly towards the player while surfing on a bamboo leaf in order to catch up to them. The Bamboo Leaf can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 1 PC.
The Mermaid set is a vanity set composed of the Seashell Hairpin, Mermaid Adornment, and Mermaid Tail. The complete set is awarded randomly for completing a fishing quest for the Angler NPC.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Daybroken is a debuff that causes enemies lasting damage for up to 5 seconds. It is applied by the Daybreak and the Solar Eruption, and the Daybreak is able to stack this debuff up to 8 times, octupling the damage in the process.
The Chimney is a decorative structure with a style similar to a Fireplace. It serves no in-game purpose, aside from cosmetics.

It has 3 states that can be toggled via wire. In the first state it is turned off, the second adds a small smoke animation, and the third adds smoke particles which behave like bubbles from the Bubble Machine.

The Lava Waders are an immunity accessory that allow the player to walk on the surface of all liquids, including water, honey, shimmer and even lava, without taking lava damage or triggering the On Fire! debuff (unlike the Water Walking Boots and Obsidian Water Walking Boots, which only allow walking on water, honey, and shimmer).

Lava Waders also allow the player to submerge in lava safely for 7 seconds (press the ▼ Down key to submerge), without incurring lava damage or triggering the On Fire! debuff. The 7-second countdown is signified by a lava meter that displays over the player's head, similar to the Breath meter, but displaying flame icons instead of bubbles. Lava immunity time is recharged gradually by exiting lava, the same way breathing time is recharged by exiting water (albeit much more slowly).

All liquids, including lava, can be walked on indefinitely while the Lava Waders are equipped. The countdown only applies when submerged in lava, whereas the player can stand on its surface indefinitely.

Lava Waders additionally provide immunity to the Burning debuff incurred from contact with Meteorite, Hellstone or Hellstone Brick. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It also reduces lava 's base damage from 80 to 35.

The Obsidian Wall, Ember Wall, Cinder Wall, Magma Wall, and Smouldering Stone Wall are types of background walls which can be found naturally generated in the lower Cavern layer, considered unsafe. They do not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained on the Desktop, Console, and Mobile, via crafting. They are considered safe walls when placed by the player.
The Ember, Cinder, Magma, and Smouldering Stone Walls are unavailable on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version.

Pixie Dye is a Hardmode dye sometimes acquired from the Dye Trader after completing a Strange Plant quest. It can only be obtained after defeating Plantera. When equipped, it turns the player yellow-orange, giving the slight glow that Pixies give off.
Pre-Hardmode items are items obtainable before Hardmode is activated. A world permanently converts to Hardmode when the Wall of Flesh is defeated for the first time in that world.
Compared to Hardmode, a pre-Hardmode world has fewer obtainable items. This list is provided to assist players of pre-Hardmode worlds in determining which items are available to them.

Seashells are decorative items that can be found in the Ocean biomes. They can spawn on Sand Blocks within the biome, both on the beach and underwater. When placed, they can appear as one of three variants.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Seashells can appear back on beaches and underwater, as long as no more than 3 Corals or Seashells are within an 8-tile range. Spawn rates scale with Rain, Wind, and empty space up to 14 tiles above the Sand Block. When a Seashell spawns, there is a 79.4% chance for either a regular Seashell or a Starfish, 9.8% chance for a Tulip Shell, 8.8% chance for a Lightning Whelk Shell, and 2% chance for a Junonia Shell.
(Old-gen console version) Seashells do not respawn and are limited to the number spawned during world generation, making them a non-renewable item.

The Spore Zombie is a zombie variant that only appears on Mushroom Grass above the Surface at any point in the game. It acts the same as normal zombies, slowly walking towards the player to deal contact damage, while attempting to navigate around obstacles. However, it is differentiable by normal zombies due to its mushroom-covered appearance, spawning at any time of day, and generally more powerful stats. Unlike normal zombies, it is always able to open doors regardless of whether or not it is a Blood Moon.
Spore Zombies can appear in two different variations with slightly different stats. Unlike normal zombies, it does not have an armed variation in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Ice Skates are a pre-Hardmode accessory that improves a player's movement control on Thin Ice, all Ice Blocks, Ice Rod blocks, Frozen Slime Blocks and Aetherium Blocks. The player accelerates faster, slides shorter distances, and will no longer cause Thin Ice to break when landing from falls or jumps. Ice Skates have a 1551/10000 (15.51%) chance of being found inside Frozen Chests in the Ice biome, as well as a 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being obtained from Frozen (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Boreal Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

A Heart Shrine was an exclusive structure that occasionally generated in the Snow biome. Heart Shrines were roughly heart-shaped caves that contained two guaranteed Crystal Hearts, along with a Frozen Chest that contained several heart-themed items. They could spawn regardless of depth, allowing them to spawn on the surface. They were commonly found in the Ice biome and rarely in the Corruption / Crimson if a Snow biome was generated on top of it. The map showed the heart shape of a Heart Shrine by coloring the top half and a small bit of the outline red.
The Avenger Emblem is a Hardmode accessory that grants 12% increased damage to all weapons.

Rain armor or Rain set is an armor / vanity set that consists of the Rain Hat and the Rain Coat. It is armor on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the set only acts as vanity items, and offers no defense when equipped.
