The Goldfish is a harmless critter that swims in water and walks on land during rain. The Goldfish has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Goldfish can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Fish Bowl). Once crafted, the Goldfish cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Goldfish can be spawned by the Fish Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, there is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Goldfish to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

During a Blood Moon, or when hit with Vile Powder or Vicious Powder (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Goldfish will turn into Corrupt Goldfish or Vicious Goldfish (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Gentleman's set is a vanity set consisting of the Gentleman's Beard, the Gentleman's Long Beard, the Gentleman's Magnificent Beard, the Gentleman's Vest, and the Gentleman's Trousers. The Vest and Trousers can be crafted, while the Gentleman's Beard can be bought from the Stylist for 5 GC.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

When equipped in an accessory slot, the Gentleman's Beard will grow longer over time. After 12 minutes of being equipped, the beard has a 1/9 (11.11%) chance every second to grow to the next stage. This growth is not affected by speeding up time, and will not occur when the beard is equipped in a vanity slot. The beard also changes colors based on the player's hair color. The longer versions of the beard can be crafted back into the shorter versions.
The Maid set is a vanity set consisting of the Maid Bonnet, Maid Dress and Maid Shoes. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Projectile melee weapons are melee weapons that fire projectiles at no mana or ammunition cost. These tend to do more damage than the weapons themselves, although they often cannot fire quite as frequently as the weapon can be swung.
Boomerangs, while also constituting projectile-only melee weapons, are grouped separately and are thus not included here.

The Rune set is a Hardmode vanity set consisting of the Rune Hat and Rune Robe. Both pieces are always dropped by the Rune Wizard, a rare Underground enemy. Wearing the full set causes the player to emit a pulse effect, as well as a bright orange and green particle effect from their feet when walking. The particles are visible in darkness but do not emit light onto other objects.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Hemopiranha are a type of fish which are found uncommonly by fishing in the Crimson in any layer. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners and Rage Potions.

The Ancient Light is a projectile NPC fired by the Lunatic Cultist once its health is lowered below 50% of its maximum health. It is fired in spreads of five and can be destroyed with some hits from any weapon. Despite the fact that the NPC itself has a round sprite, it appears as a star in-game.

Timers are triggering mechanisms that periodically send an activation signal to other mechanisms. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) five / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) three different types of timers, which differ in the interval at which the signal is sent: 5 Second Timer, 3 Second Timer, 1 Second Timer, 1/2 Second Timer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and 1/4 Second Timer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Timers need to be placed in order to function; they require either a block or a platform beneath them. They are toggled on and off by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on them. Timers can also be activated and deactivated using other mechanism activation items. For example, a Switch on the same path of wires will toggle a timer on and off. Multiple timers on the same circuit will also repeatedly toggle each other on and off.
On the Desktop, Console, Old-gen console, and Mobile versions, timers can be crafted at an Iron or Lead Anvil. On Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can be purchased from the Mechanic.
Large Bamboo Wall is a wall created from Large Bamboo that visually appears to be made of larger stalks than Bamboo Wall.

The Nymph is a rare pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Cavern layer of any biome. When encountered, she appears as the Lost Girl, who seems to be a helpless, stationary NPC in need of rescue. However, when a player gets close or attacks the Lost Girl, she transforms into the Nymph and starts attacking the player. For a pre-Hardmode enemy, she deals comparatively high damage.
The Lost Girl will only transform into a Nymph if any of the following conditions are met:

The Lost Girl does not have full health. The distance between the player and the Lost Girl is less than 12.5 tiles, and she has a direct line of sight to the player. The Lost Girl is moving in any direction (e.g. caused by falling or knockback).
The Lost Girl is immune to the Confused debuff, but the transformed Nymph is not.

She is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades. The Nymph requires 25 kills to be awarded completion of her Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Butcher's set is a Hardmode vanity set that consists of the Butcher Mask, Butcher's Bloodstained Apron and Butcher's Bloodstained Pants. It is dropped by the Butcher during the Solar Eclipse event.
The Purple Mucus is a dye material that is dropped by Sea Snails, which only spawn in the Ocean biome. Its sole purpose is to make Purple Dye.
Luminite Brick Wall is a background wall crafted from Luminite Bricks. It stops enemies from spawning on the tile where it's placed. It can be used to make houses for NPCs.
The Grebe is a critter that spawns in bodies of water in the Desert biome. The Grebe has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Grebe can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Grebe Cage). Once crafted, the Grebe cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The evil biomes and the Hallow, unlike all other biomes, can spread to other areas of a world. They slowly convert, or "infect", certain tiles which are near their own biome-exclusive tiles to their respective biome counterparts, increasing the size of the biome. The exact rules for biome spread are slightly different for each of the three infectious biomes, as described in depth below.

Collectively, these three biomes can be called the "infectious biomes". Blocks and walls which are vulnerable to infection are called "corruptible", and those which cannot be infected under any circumstances are "non-corruptible". Blocks and walls which could be infected, but have not been, are called "pure".

Biome spread starts immediately upon world generation, is greatly enhanced and sped up after defeating the Wall of Flesh for the first time (after initiating Hardmode), and is slowed down again after defeating Plantera for the first time. Once Hardmode begins, the world's evil biome and the Hallow have few restrictions on their spread, and without player effort, will eventually take over almost the entire world between them.

The biome spread process is part of the game's "tile update cycle": Every game tick, the game chooses a handful of tiles to update, which covers several processes including biome spread. The tiles above and below the surface level are selected in separate passes; as an approximation, "surface" tiles will each average about one update every 140 seconds, while "underground" tiles each average about one update every 830 seconds. (That is, above-ground tiles get updated about six times as often as below-ground tiles, so biome spread will be that much faster above ground.) Due to the random selection method, even the averages here are approximate, and the actual length of time between a given tile's updates can vary wildly. When an infected tile is updated, it is considered as a potential "source tile", which can infect multiple other tiles in a single update.

The Confetti Gun is a consumable novelty weapon that fires a cloud of colorful confetti, and inflicts no damage. Its effect is purely visual and causes no functional effect. Confetti Guns are consumed upon use, and can therefore be used only once. They are purchased from the Party Girl for 1 SC each.

Golf Clubs are tools used in the golf minigame. There are four types of Golf Clubs, the Driver, Iron, Wedge, and Putter, which are each used to hit the Golf Ball a different horizontal and vertical distance.
Special variants of Golf Clubs can be unlocked by achieving different golf scores. All upgrades are purely aesthetic, despite being more expensive as the tier increases.
They do not harm enemies or critters.
Cobalt Brick is a сobalt tier brick. Unlike Cobalt Ore, Cobalt Bricks are not immune to explosives.

The Acorn is a type of seed used to plant trees. Acorns can be planted on regular green grass, Hallowed grass, Corrupt grass, Crimson grass, Jungle grass, Sand, or Snow, where they will create saplings that will grow into trees, under the right conditions. Acorns are randomly dropped when cutting down or shaking (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) trees and can also be purchased from the Dryad for 10 CC each.
Acorns cannot be retrieved after being placed. Destroying the sapling will not yield any items.

Luminite is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord ore dropped exclusively by the Moon Lord in stacks of 70-90 (90-110). It can be used to craft Luminite Bars, which can then be used to craft several endgame items such as the Solar, Nebula, Vortex, and Stardust tools and armor.

Crafting all items (excluding ammunition, dye, and bricks) requires a total of 362 Luminite Bars and 25 Luminite (1,473 Luminite; requires defeating the Moon Lord 17-22 / 14-17 times). Crafting all items pertaining to one type of Lunar Fragment (i.e., armor, wings, pickaxe/drill, and hamaxe) requires 68 Luminite Bars (272 Luminite) in addition to 85 of the Lunar Fragment; this requires defeating the Moon Lord only 4 / 3-4 times.

Vortex armor is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord armor set that provides ranged weapon boosts. It is the final ranged armor set available on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version. Crafting the full set requires a total of 36 Luminite Bars (144 Luminite) and 45 Vortex Fragments.
The set consists of the Vortex Helmet, Vortex Breastplate, and Vortex Leggings.
A full set of Vortex armor provides the following bonuses:
+62 defense +36% ranged damage +27% ranged critical strike chance +25% chance not to consume ammunition +10% movement speed
Additionally, equipping a full set grants the player the ability to toggle stealth mode, which has the following effects:
Near-invisibility −1200 aggro +80% ranged damage +20% ranged critical strike chance +50% knockback −33% movement speed

Unlike Shroomite armor, standing still is not required to enter Vortex armor's stealth mode. Instead, it is toggled manually by double-tapping the ▼ Down key. Moving or grappling does not cancel the effect, and like Shroomite armor, its stealth bonuses are applied to all ranged weapon types. Dashing with items such as the Shield of Cthulhu or Tabi, or riding a mount will cancel stealth mode. Stealth mode cannot be activated while on a mount.

The Jewel of Light is a Hardmode, post- Plantera light pet-summoning item that spawns a Fairy Princess that provides pink-colored light. It is fast and will always position itself slightly elevated behind the player. The Jewel of Light has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by the Empress of Light in Master Mode.

The Corruption is an evil biome with a dark purple wasteland, death, and decay theme, with an evil forest design to it, in contrast to the red gore theme of its counterpart, The Crimson. Every world will contain one of the two, generated randomly (each with a 50% chance of occurring) or (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) chosen by the player upon world creation. Both contain similar hazards and feature their own unique enemies, items, and blocks. The tools, weapons, and armor obtained via Corruption materials are generally faster, but slightly less powerful than those obtained via Crimson materials. Corruption enemies tend to have slightly lower stats, such as health, defense, and damage.

The Corruption surface contains purple Corrupt grass, Corrupt Trees, and Vile Mushrooms. Purple thorny bushes grow on the grass and will damage the player when touched. Water in the Corruption is also purple. The Corruption also contains multiple chasms, underground extensions of the biome. Chasms lead downwards in a straight line, some crossing a horizontal connector, ending with a Shadow Orb. Demon Altars generally line the chasm's passages, appearing inside and around it. Chasms consist of Ebonstone, which can be blown up by explosives, mined with a Nightmare / Deathbringer Pickaxe or higher, or purified to Stone by using Purification Powder, the Clentaminator, and the Terraformer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Corruption spreads, meaning it slowly converts adjacent tiles to their Corruption variants. See below for details. Chasms, Demon Altars, and Shadow Orbs will only appear upon world generation, and will not spawn in a Corruption area that has formed through spreading. For an area to be considered a Corruption biome, at least (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 300 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 200 tiles of Corrupt grass or Corruption blocks must be present.

The Golden Bullet is one of the six types of craftable bullet made from Empty Bullets, which are sold by the Arms Dealer after Hardmode has been enabled. Like the Flask of Gold, they inflict the Midas debuff on enemies, causing them to drop 10%-50% more Coins when killed. Note that the debuff wears off after 2 seconds.
The cost of a stack of 50 Golden Bullets is 19 SC 50 CC, which is 39 CC per bullet. The cost of crafting 1000 Golden Bullets (20 stacks of 50) is 3 GC 90 SC.

The Crystal Vile Shard is a Hardmode magic weapon that is an upgraded version of the Vilethorn and a precursor to the Nettle Burst. It fires a larger, colorful, crystalline version of the Vilethorn's spear projectile, piercing through blocks and enemies, and, like the Nettle Burst, the Crystal Vile Shard has 10 armor penetration. The Crystal Vile Shard has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by Hallowed Mimics.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Lavafall Wall is one of few animated background wall types. It depicts flowing lava, and also emits light in a similar manner to lava. Despite it being made from lava, it will still burn in lava.

The Mourning Wood is a Hardmode, post- Plantera mini-boss that spawns during the Pumpkin Moon event. It is the Pumpkin Moon equivalent of the Everscream, which behaves in an almost identical way to the Mourning Wood.
Defeating the Mourning Wood during the Pumpkin Moon event will add 75 / 150 / 187.5 points to the final score.

The Vulture is a pre-Hardmode flying enemy that commonly spawns in Deserts during the day ; however, they can also spawn roosting on Sand Blocks in any biome. When the player comes close or attacks a Vulture, it will begin to fly at the player. Vultures will hover above the player for a second before swooping down to attack. They will continue to pursue the player until they die.
Ancient Mythril Brick is a type of brick obtained by throwing Mythril Brick into Shimmer. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Mythril Brick prior to 1.2.
The Black Lens is a crafting material dropped by Demon Eyes and Wandering Eyes with a 1/100 (1%) chance. A total of only 3 Black Lenses are needed to obtain all related items.
The Wizard is a Hardmode NPC vendor who sells magic -related items. He will move in once the following criteria have been met:

There is an available vacant house. Rescuing him as the Bound Wizard, who can be rarely encountered in the Cavern layer once the Wall of Flesh has been defeated. Interacting with him in this state with ⚷ Open / Activate will free him. If the Bound Wizard is killed, he will still be able to respawn afterwards; if the Wizard NPC is killed, he will move in again after some time as long as there are vacant houses.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) When enemies are in his vicinity, the Wizard hurls fireballs at them in a similar fashion to the Flower of Fire while casting an aesthetic magic circle, dealing 18 / 27 / 31 damage.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) He will occasionally replace his regular quote with a comment about the player's luck. This is the only way to estimate a player's luck value in the game.
The Bound Wizard is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.
Bullets are a form of ammunition fired by guns. Many types can inflict debuffs on enemies.

The Swiftness Potion is a buff potion which grants the Swiftness buff when consumed. The buff increases the player's maximum movement speed by 25%, but does not stack with sprinting accessories (such as Hermes Boots), nor does it affect the speed of mounts. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 8 minutes / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 4 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.
In addition to being crafted, Swiftness Potions can be found in pots, chests, and crates, (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) and have a small chance to appear as a bonus drop from slimes.

Pearlwood is the Hallowed form of Wood. Being a Hallowed item, it can only be obtained in Hardmode. Pearlwood can be acquired by harvesting trees that have been afflicted by Hallow, which are easily distinguished by their vivid pastel-colored foliage. Pearlwood trees can also be planted anew in existing Hallow via Acorns.

Items crafted from Pearlwood generally have much better stats than those crafted from normal Wood. For example, a Wooden Sword does 7 damage, while a Pearlwood Sword does (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 30 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 11 damage. However, since the player will need to have defeated the Wall of Flesh before Pearlwood becomes available, they will already likely have access to much higher tiers of equipment than any wooden form can provide.

The Musket is a pre-Hardmode gun. It will always drop from the first Shadow Orb destroyed in a Corruption world (along with 100 Musket Balls) and has a 1/5 (20%) chance of dropping from destroyed Shadow Orbs afterward. It also has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being obtained from Corrupt (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Defiled Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) fished in the Corruption. The Musket has a base 11% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%.
Its Crimson counterpart is The Undertaker. Compared to The Undertaker, the Musket deals much higher damage per shot at the cost of a slower rate of fire.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Weather Vane is a decoration piece that will periodically sway in the wind if placed above 0 depth and without a background wall behind it. During the Windy Day event, it will point to the direction of the wind.
The Eternia Crystal is a background object that acts as the centerpiece of the Old One's Army event.

Pressing ⚒ Use / Attack on the Eternia Crystal Stand with an Eternia Crystal in the player's inventory will place the Eternia Crystal on the stand. A long, flat area is required in order to place the Eternia Crystal successfully and summon the event; otherwise, the Eternia Crystal will not be placed. Once this is done, two Mysterious Portals will appear far away from either side of the Eternia Crystal, and, after a 5-second countdown, the Eternia Crystal (now considered an NPC) must be protected from waves of enemies from the Old One's Army who will prioritize attacking it. If the Crystal is destroyed, the event ends in failure. If it is kept "alive" until all waves are cleared, the event is won.
The Eternia Crystal can be purchased from the Tavernkeep for 25 SC (pre-any mechanical boss) / 1 GC (post-any mechanical boss) / 4 GC (post- Golem).
Stucco blocks are decorative building materials that are available in four different colors.

The Tinkerer's Workshop is a crafting station that is used primarily to combine multiple accessories into single items that usually provide the abilities of their components. For instance, it can combine the Rocket Boots and Hermes Boots into a single item (the Spectre Boots) that provides the same rocket-jumping and accelerated movement as the individual items do, without occupying two accessory slots. The Tinkerer's Workshop can be purchased from the Goblin Tinkerer for 10 GC.

(Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) When combining items, the Tinkerer's Workshop will assign a new random modifier to the crafted item. The modifiers the individual items had beforehand do not influence the modifier of the new combined item.
(3DS version) Items crafted at the Tinkerer's Workshop will be assigned no modifier.

The Tinkerer's Workshop is also used to craft most of the unrecordable Music Boxes, the Shellphone (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), The Grand Design (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Boulders on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version.
The Bone Block Wall is a type of wall which is crafted from Bones. Despite the naming similarity to Bone Blocks, it has never been able to craft them, or been used to craft them.
The Rubblemaker is a Hardmode tool used to place ambient objects ("rubble") using items from the player's inventory. It is sold by the Goblin Tinkerer during Hardmode for 25 GC.

By pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button, the Rubblemaker can toggle between three placement sizes: Small, Medium, and Large. The Small setting corresponds to one tile-wide rubble, the Medium setting to two tile-wide rubble, and the Large setting to three tile-wide rubble. Rubble within each setting can be cycled through using the ▲ Up and ▼ Down buttons. The material which is highest and furthest to the left in the player's inventory will be prioritized, and only that material's rubble will be placeable until another supersedes it.
Destroying an object that was placed by the Rubblemaker drops the item used for placing it.

Flares are a type of ammunition used solely by the Flare Gun. Flares fired from the Flare Gun travel in a slight arc and stick to blocks (similar to Sticky Glowsticks), but have greater velocity and range. They are waterproof, can be fired into and out of water, and emit low-level, flickering, tinted light that lasts for 10 minutes. They stick to the blocks they impacted and will function underwater. Flares cannot be recovered once they burn out.
All types of Flares (except the Cursed Flare) inflict the On Fire! debuff. There is a 2/3 (66.67%) chance that the debuff will last 5 seconds, and a 1/3 (33.33%) chance that it will last 10 seconds.

The Brick Layer is an accessory which increases the player's placement speed by 50% when placing blocks, furniture, and any other placeable items. It is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 10 GC.

The Red Devil is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in The Underworld after any mechanical boss has been defeated. While flying toward the player in a similar manner to that of the Demon, it fires four purple trident projectiles that deal extremely large amounts of damage upon contact. It is considered a more difficult version of the Demon, having more health and dealing much more damage. Similar to the Demon, it drops a magic weapon resembling its means of attack, the Unholy Trident.

While the contact damage of a Red Devil is comparably low, its trident attack is capable of dealing large amounts of damage even to players wearing endgame armor. The tridents are fired in the same burst-like pattern that Demons fire scythes in, although they are slower and move at a constant velocity.
The Splinterling is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during wave 2 of the Pumpkin Moon event. It is one of the only sources of Spooky Wood, the other being the Mourning Wood.
Defeating a Splinterling during the Pumpkin Moon event will add 2 / 4 / 5 points to the final score.
The Splinterling requires 150 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Fallen Log is a naturally-generated background object that appears on the Surface in Forest biomes. At night, fairies will occasionally spawn at a Fallen Log. Fairies can also spawn underground, but only as long as there is at least one Fallen Log present at the surface layer in the world (see exact area below). Thus, destroying all Fallen Logs in a world will permanently stop Fairies from spawning naturally, and shaking Hallowed trees will be the only way to obtain them.

Unlike most background items, Fallen Logs can only be destroyed with an axe. They will be destroyed when the grass beneath them is converted to Corrupt grass or Crimson grass, but Hallowed grass conversion does not destroy them. They drop 10-20 Wood upon destruction. The blocks beneath them cannot be mined until the log is destroyed, similarly to trees.
Pin Flags are furniture items used in golfing. They are purely decorative and come in multiple colors. They can be purchased from the Golfer for 20 SC each.
Adamantite Bars are crafting subproducts made from 4 Adamantite Ore, one of the three top-tier hardmode ores that are obtainable in a world. Its counterpart is Titanium.

Adamantite equipment is colored maroon red. To craft all Adamantite equipment, the player needs to acquire 266 bars, or a total of 1064 ore. Adamantite is most importantly used to craft a Adamantite Forge, which is useful throughout the game.

The Bubble Machine is a novelty furniture mechanism purchased from the Party Girl for 4 GC (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) during the day / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) at any time. When placed, it continuously produces bubbles. These bubbles are purely visual, have no functional effect, and can be produced infinitely at no cost.

Each bubble is of a random size, and a random one of four possible colors: pink, purple, green, or blue. With no obstacles in the way, bubbles last for random durations. They will pop on contact with characters or foreground blocks.
It can be activated and deactivated via wire, but is always on by default when first placed.
Tin Plating Wall is a background wall made of Tin Plating. Due to the need of Tin, it cannot be crafted in worlds generated with Copper without the use of an Extractinator.

Instruments are items that produce distinct notes or sounds when used by the player via the ⚒ Use / Attack button. Most are pure novelty items, but some have functional effects. The pitch/note played is usually controlled by the distance between the center of the character and the location of the cursor when ⚒ Use / Attack was pressed. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, playing musical instruments now shows the note on the cursor.
There are eight playable instruments in the game.

The Axe is a Hardmode, post- Plantera hamaxe, a combination of a hammer and an axe. It produces an overdriven electric guitar sound when swung, which changes in tone depending on the distance from the cursor to the player. The Axe has a 1/50 (2%) / 1/20 (5%) chance of being dropped by Plantera on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, and a 1/200 (0.5%) chance on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

Orichalcum Ore is a magenta-colored Hardmode ore which can replace Mythril Ore in a given world. It requires a pickaxe power of 110% to mine (Cobalt / Palladium Pickaxe or better, or any drill). Like most Hardmode ores, Orichalcum Ore is generated upon destruction of a Demon/Crimson Altar with a Pwnhammer or any better hammer.
Xenon Moss Brick Wall is a brick background wall that glows in the dark like Xenon Moss and the Xenon Moss Brick it is made from.
Ancient Gold Brick is a type of brick obtained by throwing Gold Brick into Shimmer. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Gold Brick prior to 1.2.

The Breathing Reed is a tool that aids in underwater breathing, and, on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, also functions as a sword. It has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 9/40 (22.5%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 7/30 (23.33%) chance of being found in Water Chests, Ocean Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Seaside Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

For the Breathing Reed to take effect, it must be held, i.e. selected in the hotbar or attached to the cursor. It appears held above the player, the rate at which their breath meter depletes is slowed, and the rate at which they lose health while drowning is halved. The reed's tip does not need to be above the surface of the water for this to take effect. Additionally, the breath meter refills as soon as the tip of the reed is outside of water, but not within a block.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Its best modifier is Legendary.

Nachos are a food item that grant the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 16 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. Nachos have a 1/30 (3.33%) chance of being dropped by Angry Tumblers and all Sand Shark variants.
Like all other food items, the Nachos can be placed on a Plate :

Ice Cream is a food item that grants the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 14 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. Ice Cream has a 1/150 (0.67%) chance of being dropped by Ice Bats, Ice Slimes, and Spiked Ice Slimes.
Like all other food items, the Ice Cream can be placed on a Plate :

The Wandering set or Wandering Ronin set is a vanity set consisting of the Wandering Jingasa, the Wandering Yukata, and the Wandering Geta. It is one of the six sets that were added as part of the Journey's End Vanity Contest ; the original concept was submitted by crowflux.
When the full set is worn, fireflies can be seen flying around the player.

The Pink Slime Block can be created with Pink Gel if the player is near a Solidifier. In a similar way to Silly Balloons, landing on Pink Slime Blocks negates fall damage and causes the player to bounce. Like with Slime Blocks, running over Pink Slime Blocks produces droplet particles.

The height of the bounce is dependent on the player's speed, not on the distance they've fallen. Holding a Portal Gun or riding the Slime Mount can allow for higher bounce due to the higher speed limit.
Chippy's Couch is a furniture item that has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being dropped by Skeletron.

Twilight Dye is a Hardmode dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. It can, like other dyes, be equipped in the dyes slot in the player's equipment or accessory tabs in their inventory. When the dye is used, the armor or vanity item associated with it will get a very night-sky-like effect which will move dynamically with the player.

The True Night's Edge is a Hardmode sword that is a stronger version of the Night's Edge, doing more damage and firing a projectile when swung. It is one of the ingredients necessary to craft the Terra Blade. The True Night's Edge is capable of autoswing.

The sword itself has a large aura of dark energy around the blade when swung, which significantly increases the range at which the weapon can deal damage to enemies, including coverage behind the player. Each time the sword swings, a projectile resembling a spinning disc of energy will be fired. The projectile will move relative to the player, staying on the same course on the screen as the player moves. The projectile deals 50% damage (35 base damage) and strikes up to 3 times. It also applies 10 ticks of immunity frames on the targets it hits, but can still hit a target multiple times (if the target is large enough for the projectiles to still stay on it after 10 ticks). If the blade or its aura strikes an enemy, a purple flash is created. If its projectile strikes an enemy, a green flash is created.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Chattering Teeth Bomb is a Hardmode enemy spawned by Clowns during Blood Moons. It hops about, similarly to the Herpling, making small jumps and then large jumps as it makes its way toward the player to explode.

The Baby Grinch's Mischief Whistle is a Hardmode, post- Plantera pet-summoning item that spawns a Baby Grinch to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, a red balloon will carry the Baby Grinch to catch up with them. The Baby Grinch's Mischief Whistle is dropped by the Ice Queen during the Frost Moon event with a 1.11%-2.22% (3.33%-6.67%) chance depending on the current wave.

Statues are furniture items. There are a total of 117 different statues: 25 decoration statues, 36 text and numerical statues and 56 functional mechanisms that have an effect when connected to wires and activated (26 hostile, 22 passive and 9 miscellaneous). Depending on the statue, upon activation it may spawn enemies, drop items, or teleport an NPC to the statue's location. Most statues can be found already placed in any area underground (most frequently in the Dungeon, Underground Cabins, and Cavern level), though Angel Statues also appear in chests. Like all furniture, a pickaxe is used to collect them.

Neptune's Shell is a Hardmode accessory that aids maneuverability in water, honey, and shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) by granting indefinite breathing time while submerged, swimming via the ↷ Jump key, and eliminating the slow movement speed usually caused by submerging underwater. Entering applicable liquids with this accessory equipped transforms the player into a merperson and grants the Merfolk buff. While in this form, the breath meter will refill as if the player is in open air, therefore effectively preventing drowning.
Neptune's Shell has a 1/50 (2%) / 99/2500 (3.96%) chance of being dropped by Creatures from the Deep during the Solar Eclipse event.

Neptune's Shell can be considered an upgrade from the Diving Gear in most respects, but it lacks the extra mobility on Ice Blocks from the Arctic Diving Gear and the extra lighting underwater of the Jellyfish Necklace.

Crimtane Ore is a pre-Hardmode ore. It is The Crimson counterpart to The Corruption 's Demonite Ore, and will not appear naturally in Corruption worlds. It can be found very rarely in small veins Underground in worlds that contain Crimson, however larger quantities can be obtained from the Brain of Cthulhu boss, and from the Eye of Cthulhu (only in worlds containing Crimson). Crimtane Ore emits a faint red glow when placed, similar to Demonite Ore's faint blue glow.
The pickaxe power required to mine Crimtane Ore changes with location. When below 0ft in elevation, a Gold Pickaxe or better is needed, otherwise any pickaxe can be used.

Sentry Summon Items are summon weapons that spawn secondary characters that will aid the player during battle by automatically attacking enemies within range. They cannot be hurt or killed, and deal summon damage. Unlike minions, sentries do not follow the player, but remain stationary.
Whips are related weapons that deal summon damage without summoning any minions. Hitting an enemy with a whip causes a player's sentries to target it immediately.
The best modifier for sentry summon items is Ruthless.

The Mushroom Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Underground Cabins in the Glowing Mushroom biome, considered safe. It is also considered a safe wall when placed by the player.
Spraying Mud Walls or Jungle Walls with Dark Blue Solution creates unsafe Mushroom Walls. These do not drop as an item when destroyed.

Inlet and Outlet Pumps are mechanisms used to transport liquids (water, lava, honey, and shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)), without having to construct pathways through blocks or rely on gravity. Instead, an Inlet and Outlet Pump need only be connected to each other with Wires and activated, which transfers fluid from the Inlet Pump to the Outlet Pump. Each activation transfers up to four tiles of liquid. For continuous automated pumping, a timer can be used.

Despite its appearance as a pipe that takes in liquid from beside it, an Inlet Pump must be submerged in liquid, as it removes liquid that lies directly over its graphic, and does so equally from all of its 2x2 tile space. Similarly, an Outlet Pump spawns liquid directly over its graphic, and does so equally over all of its 2x2 tile space.

Sandstone Slab is a building material which is similar in appearance to Sandstone Bricks, but darker and larger. Unlike most other building blocks (Stone Slabs in particular), the Sandstone Slab does not have a wall counterpart.
As Sand is affected by gravity, Sandstone Slabs can be used instead of sand when building sand-related structures, as they look almost identical.

The Summoning Potion is a buff potion which grants the Summoning buff when consumed. The buff increases the player's maximum number of minions by 1. This lasts for 8 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

Placed items are those that have become fixed parts of the world, requiring a Tool in order to free and pick up. This is in contrast to inventory items or dropped items. Items can be "naturally placed" by the game, which most commonly occurs when a world is first generated. Items can also be placed by the player: When a player builds structures, they are placing items such as Blocks and Furniture.

The Ale Tosser is a pre-Hardmode ranged weapon which allows the player to throw Ale, which shatter upon contact with an enemy or surface. The Ale Tosser has a 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being dropped from the Tavernkeep.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Necromantic Scroll is a Hardmode, post- Plantera accessory that increases the player's maximum number of minions by one and increases the damage of all summon weapons by 10%. It is dropped by the Mourning Wood during the Pumpkin Moon event with a 2.86-20% (5-20%) chance depending on the current wave.

Mounts are creatures or objects that act as vehicles that a player can use for transportation or dealing damage. When a mount-summoning item is used, it applies an unlimited buff to the player, spawns the mount, and places the player on or in it. Mount movement can be controlled using the player's usual movement keys. Like pets and minions, mounts can be used limitlessly, and their summoning items are not consumed. Only one mount can be in effect at a time. Mounts will unequip automatically when the player dies.
Weapons and tools (as well as any other item, except hooks) can be used while riding a mount, except for the Drill Mount (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Grounded mounts will get extra jumps from accessories and float from Featherfall Potions. However, they will not benefit from jump speed or movement speed increases or be able to use Gravitation Potions.
All mount items can be placed in the mount slot and then summoned with Quick Mount, and can be dyed. Equipping a mount provides a short burst of light (except Bee and Scutlix).

There are currently 27 mounts, each with varying abilities and movement statistics. All mount-summoning items have the 08* rarity, except for the Shrimpy Truffle and Witch's Broom, which have the 12* rarity, and Master Mode -exclusive mounts, which have the 13* rarity.
All mounts that do damage (e.g Slime Mount) will do summon damage.
Mount-summoning items do not have modifiers and therefore cannot be reforged.

The Giant Tortoise is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Jungle and Underground Jungle. It walks around slowly, and occasionally retracts into its shell. It then starts spinning and hurls itself at the player, gaining increased defense and dealing high contact damage. It drops Turtle Shells, which are vital for crafting Turtle armor.
A functionally identical variant of the Giant Tortoise, the Ice Tortoise, can be encountered in the Ice biome.

The Nightglow is a Hardmode, post- Plantera magic weapon that fires four rainbow-colored projectiles which emerge from the player and home in on nearby enemies. Each of the projectiles ricochets off solid blocks and can pierce and hit enemies three times before dissipating, resulting in high potential damage, but loses 20% of their damage for each enemy struck. The Nightglow's projectiles last for approximately one second before disappearing but have their duration reset upon tracking a nearby enemy. The Nightglow has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by the Empress of Light.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Chain Guillotines are a Hardmode autoswinging flail that fires two blade projectiles attached to chains in rapid succession, with a maximum range of 22 tiles. It can also pierce multiple enemies when standing inside them or very close, therefore being a lot more effective at close quarters. The Chain Guillotines have a 1/5 (20%) chance of being dropped by Corrupt Mimics.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Familiar set is a vanity set that displays the player's default clothes. It consists of the Familiar Wig, the Familiar Shirt, and the Familiar Pants, and can be purchased from the Clothier for 3 GC (set).

When a piece of the Familiar set is equipped in the vanity armor slot, it will disable the graphics of any item worn in the corresponding armor slot. As such, the Familiar Wig will show the character's hairstyle whereas the Familiar Shirt and Familiar Pants will show the character's default shirt and pants, respectively.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Nano Bullet is a Hardmode, post- Plantera type of bullet and is one of six types of craftable ammunition made from Empty Bullets, which are sold by the Arms Dealer after Hardmode has been enabled. It will inflict struck enemies with the Confused debuff, which causes them to have their movement reversed, running away from the player rather than towards them. Nano Bullets have the second highest base damage of all bullets, tied with Venom Bullets and beaten out by Luminite Bullets.

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) If a Nano Bullet hits a solid block, it will ricochet off it in the direction of the closest enemy, but will only deal 66%  damage afterward. Nano Bullets can only ricochet once.
The cost of a stack of 50 Nano Bullets is 17 SC 50 CC, which is 35 CC per bullet. The cost of crafting 1000 Nano Bullets (20 stacks of 50) is 3 GC 50 SC.
Forbidden armor is a Hardmode armor set that provides a combination of magic and summon damage bonuses. Crafting the full set requires 3 Forbidden Fragments and 46 Titanium Bars or Adamantite Bars.
The set consists of the Forbidden Mask, Forbidden Robes, and the Forbidden Treads.
A full set of Forbidden armor provides the following bonuses:
+26 defense +25% magic and summon damage +80 maximum mana +2 minion capacity

While wearing the full set, a golden, spiky, rune-like object known as the Forbidden Sign floats behind the player in a very similar fashion to the Stardust Guardian from the Stardust armor set. Double tapping ▼ Down or ▲ Up (depending on the "Activate Set Bonuses" setting) will send a beam of dust particles that summon an Ancient Storm at the nearest block surface beneath the cursor position at the cost of 20 mana. The beam itself does not deal any damage, but the storm rapidly hits any enemy that comes in direct contact with it for 20 base damage. The dust particles cannot pass through solid objects, which means that if there is a solid object between the character and the cursor, the beam will hit the solid object, stop there, and the Ancient Storm will not be summoned.
The Frostburn Arrow is a type of arrow which has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to inflict the Frostburn debuff upon hitting an enemy.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Similar to Flaming Arrows, Frostburn Arrows have a 1/9 (11.11%) chance to drop as Frostburn Arrows and a 2/9 (22.22%) chance to drop as Wooden Arrow.

The Guide to Plant Fiber Cordage is an accessory that, when equipped, allows the player to collect Vine Ropes when destroying vines. The Guide to Plant Fiber Cordage has a 1/10 (10%) chance of being found inside surface Chests, or a 1/100 (1%) chance in Wooden Crates and Pearlwood Crates obtained from fishing. It can also be purchased from the Skeleton Merchant for 2 GC 50 SC during First Quarter moons.
The Mythril Halberd is a Hardmode spear. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Orichalcum Halberd.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Chaos Fish are a type of fish which are found rarely by fishing in the Underground Hallow. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Teleportation Potions.

The Hell Armored Bones is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawn in the Dungeon after Plantera is defeated. Similar to Angry Bones, they come in multiple varieties and follow the Fighter AI. Hell Armored Bones are visible in darkness but do not actually emit light, except for a faint glow when immersed in water. They also inflict the On Fire! debuff for 10 / 20 / 25 seconds.
Hell Armored Bones spawn most often in areas of the Dungeon backed by tiled walls. They can also spawn in other areas, but with a significantly reduced chance.

The Wraith is a Hardmode enemy that spawn on the surface at night, can travel through blocks, and have a 1/8 (12.5%) chance to inflict the Slow debuff upon contact with the player for 15 / 30 / 37.5 seconds. They have ghostly, pitch-black bodies which render them almost completely invisible in dark areas, but have two glowing red eyes that remain visible even in complete darkness. Although Wraiths appear to fly freely, they can only hover slightly above the ground. They need foreground blocks to "swim" through in order to fly any higher.

The Honeyfin is a consumable fish and recovery potion that restores 120 health and inflicts Potion Sickness for 60 seconds when used, making it superior to standard Healing Potions. This duration can be reduced via the Philosopher's Stone or Charm of Myths. It can also be used to craft Seafood Dinners.

The Honeyfin can be fished from honey found in Bee Hives within the Underground Jungle. Other than the Bumblebee Tuna that can be found during Angler quests, Honeyfins are the only fish that can be caught in honey.

The Potion of Return is a potion that teleports the player back to their spawn point, similar to the Recall Potion, and additionally creates a portal exit at the location where the potion was consumed. A portal entrance will be created at the spawn point, which can be used to teleport back to where the player consumed the potion. The portal can only be used once and will disappear afterwards. In addition to being crafted, the Potion of Return can be found in Shadow Chests and Pots in the Underworld.
The Platinum Bar is an early-game metal bar, used mainly to create the Platinum tier of equipment. Its alternate ore version is the Gold Bar. It can also be placed on the ground, like furniture.

Spectre tools are a set of Hardmode, post- Plantera tools crafted from Spectre Bars (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / Ectoplasm and Chlorophyte Bars (Old-gen console and 3DS versions). They uniquely each have a +3-tile range bonus.

Damage is the number of health points subtracted from an entity's current health. It can be inflicted by a multitude of entities, most prominently weapons, enemies, and NPCs (and all related projectiles). Furthermore, it can be caused by environmental hazards (such as thorny bushes, traps, or lava) and game mechanics (such as fall damage, drowning, or debuffs). Damage can generally only be inflicted on entities with a health statistic, i.e., players, most enemies, and NPCs. Most damage sources additionally inflict knockback on the damaged entity and briefly render it invincible.

When an entity receives damage, several calculations increasing or decreasing the amount of damage (depending on several factors; see below) are performed before the actual damage is applied to the entity. Therefore, the damage statistic of any damaging entity is usually only the average damage it inflicts. The actual damage of most hits will deviate from this average number.

Damage inflicted by player-wielded weapons is categorized into four different types: melee, ranged, magic, and summon. Accessories, buffs, and other damage-boosting or damage-decreasing effects often only affect one of these damage types. A few weapons as well as all other damaging entities are not categorized into any of the four types.

The Spooky Twig is a Hardmode, post- Plantera crafting material used solely for crafting Spooky Wings. It is dropped by the Mourning Wood during the Pumpkin Moon event with a 2.86-20% (5-20%) chance depending on the current wave.

The Arcane Crystal is a permanent booster item that permanently increases the player's mana regeneration. It slightly reduces mana regeneration delay and increases mana regeneration rate. See technical info about mana regeneration for details. It can only be used once per player and is obtained by throwing a Mana Crystal into Shimmer.

The Volatile Gelatin is a Hardmode accessory that periodically fires small, purple slimeballs similar to those of the Queen Slime's Regal Gel projectiles at nearby enemies. The Volatile Gelatin's projectiles can pierce up to three enemies or ricochet up to three times, and deal 65 classless damage while inflicting a knockback value of 7 (Strong) ; these values are unaffected by any boosts. The Volatile Gelatin is always dropped from Queen Slime 's Treasure Bag in Expert Mode.

The accessory has a fixed cycle: Once every 0.833 seconds (50 ticks), it attempts to release a projectile in the direction of the nearest enemy. If there is no enemy within 40 tiles, no projectile will be fired and the accessory will go on cooldown for the following 50 ticks.

The Stardust Fragment is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist crafting material. It is one of the four Lunar Fragments, dropped from the Stardust Pillar during the Lunar Events in stacks of 12-60 / 24-100. Stardust Fragments can be used to craft Stardust armor, an end-game armor set that benefits all types of summon weapons, as well as Stardust-themed tools, weapons, wings, etc.

Crafting all items requires 121 Stardust Fragments and 68 Luminite Bars (272 Luminite), which necessitates defeating the Stardust Pillar at least 3-11 / 2-8 times (note that the Stardust Fragment can also be crafted from the other fragments) and fighting the Moon Lord at least 4 / 3-4 times.

The Moon Stone is a Hardmode accessory which has a 1/35 (2.86%) / 69/1225 (5.63%) chance to drop from Vampires during the Solar Eclipse event. It grants the same stat bonuses as the Sun Stone, but these bonuses will only activate during the night or during a Solar Eclipse.
The stat bonuses are:
+10% melee speed +10% damage (all types) +2% critical strike chance +1 HP/s health regeneration +4 defense +15% mining speed +0.5 summon knockback

Bamboo is a placeable block obtained by harvesting Bamboo stalks, which generate naturally in the Jungle biome, with any pickaxe or drill. It can also be found in Jungle and Bramble Crates. Bamboo can be used to craft themed furniture, blocks, and walls.

Bamboo stalks grow on Jungle grass submerged in shallow (more than 1 and no more than 5 tiles deep) water or Shimmer. Like most plants, they will not grow in front of a wall (including Glass Walls and fences). Unlike most other plants, however, Bamboo stalks grow over time and tend to grow in very long intervals.
Fishing Bobbers are accessories that change the appearance of a fishing pole 's bobber and increase the player's Fishing Power by 10.

The Fishing Bobber is acquired as a 1/34 (2.94%) chance reward for completing a Fishing quest for the Angler NPC, depending on the number of completed quests and other factors (for details, see Angler), while the rest are crafted.

The Angler will not give the player a Fishing Bobber as a reward if they already have one in their inventory, in any of their portable storage items or loadouts. However, if the player has all of Angler's fishing and informational accessories (or their upgrades like the Angler Tackle Bag and Fish Finder) in their inventories, this rule will be ignored.

Negative Dye is a type of dye bought from the Dye Trader during a full moon, or given as a possible reward for turning in a Strange Plant. When applied, it will completely invert the color of dyed armor or accessories. It is not combinable with other dyes.
Void Dye is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord dye crafted using Luminite Bars. The dye causes a pulsating effect, much like the pulsating effect that the Moon Lord creates moments before he spawns.

The Silver Axe is an early game Axe, being stronger than the Iron or Lead Axe, and weaker than the Gold or Platinum Axe. It has an alternative version, the Tungsten Axe, which is slightly stronger. Like all Axes, it is used to cut down Trees, Cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Fledgling Wings are the only pre-Hardmode wings. Like all wings, they grant the player the ability to fly and glide when equipped, as well as not take fall damage. At top speed, they allow traveling at 15 mph horizontally and 22 mph vertically. They have a flight time of 0.42 seconds and a vertical speed multiplier of 150%.
The Fledgling Wings have a 1/40 (2.5%) chance of being obtained from Skyware Chests, Sky Crates, and Azure Crates. Journey Mode characters always spawn with a pair of Fledgling Wings.

The Compass is an informational accessory that enables an on-screen display of the player's lateral position when equipped. Position is shown in the number of feet (1 foot = 1/2 tile) to the East or West of the center of the map. The centerpoint of the map is usually very close to the initial spawn point. The Compass has a 79/6400 (1.23%) chance of being dropped by Crawdads, Giant Shellies, and Salamanders, a 1/75 (1.33%) chance to be dropped by Piranhas, and a 1/50 (2%) chance to be dropped by Mother Slimes, Snow Flinxes, Undead Vikings, and Armored Vikings.

The Compass is one of the three parts necessary to make the GPS, with the others being the Depth Meter and the Gold Watch or Platinum Watch, and as such is a required ingredient in crafting the Shellphone.

The Chlorophyte Saber is a Hardmode sword which occasionally fires a Spore Cloud projectile when swung. It costs no ammunition or mana, emits light, deals (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 70% / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) the same damage as the sword but no knockback, is not affected by gravity, and can pierce an infinite number of enemies. The Chlorophyte Saber is the less powerful but faster sword of the two that can be crafted from Chlorophyte Bars, with the other being the Chlorophyte Claymore.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Safeman's set are vanity developer items that can be obtained rarely (5% chance) from Treasure Bags dropped from Hardmode bosses (except Queen Slime 's). It is the vanity set made for Safeman, the Community Manager at Re-Logic.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Safeman's equipment also includes a non-vanity item, which will drop in addition to her clothing set:
Safeman's Blanket Cape
The Defender's Forge is a portable, personal storage item which is purchased from the Tavernkeep for 500000* 50.
The storage provided by the Defender's Forge is separate from the Piggy Bank, Safe, and Void Vault, so it allows the player to carry significantly more items at any given time.

The Plasma Lamp is a mechanism item that emits a faint blue light and has an animated texture. It is not considered a suitable light source for an NPC house. It is used purely as a decorative light source. The Plasma Lamp can be purchased from the Party Girl for 2 GC.

Generic furniture is the basic furniture set and is generally crafted with common materials. Generic furniture is mainly furniture made of normal Wood, obtained by cutting down normal Trees, but some of it is made of early-game metal instead. Though if you go by individual items instead of types of furniture, the generic furniture set is technically more metal than Wood. There are 26 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 24 (Old-gen console version) / 23 (3DS version) different generic furniture items.

The Purple Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that commonly spawns in Forest biomes during the daytime. It is a larger and stronger variant of the Blue Slime. Purple Slimes will not usually target the player but will become aggressive when damaged, during the night, or if brought underground.
Like most other slimes, the Purple Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
On Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can rarely be found carrying bonus drops, which the player receives upon the slime's death.
The Firestarter's set is a vanity set consisting of the Firestarter's Sweater and the Firestarter's Skirt. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Bloody Tear is an event-summoning item used to summon a Blood Moon. It can only be used at night, and attempting to use it during the day or while a Blood Moon is already active will not summon a Blood Moon, affect the ongoing Blood Moon, or consume the item.

The Bloody Tear can only be dropped during a Blood Moon from non- statue -spawned enemies (i.e. enemies killed after the Blood Moon has ended do not drop it), or by The Groom and The Bride at any time. The drop rates are 1/100 (1%) chance from Blood Zombies and Dripplers, 1/25 (4%) chance from Wandering Eye Fish, Zombie Mermen, Blood Eels, and Hemogoblin Sharks, 1/10 (10%) chance from Clowns, and 1/5 (20%) chance from The Groom and The Bride.
Additionally, Dreadnautiluses have a 1/2 (50%) / 1/1 (100%) chance of dropping it at any time.

The Snow Balla is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Frost Legion event. It moves by hopping towards the player and throws snowballs at them which form Snow Blocks on impact with other blocks, similar to the attack of the Antlion. The Snow Blocks can also spawn in the air if Snow Balla throws it into the sky. If it falls into a pit, it is possible for it to trap itself. By trapping the Snow Balla, one can create a renewable farm for Snow Blocks in a similar manner to an Antlion-based sand farm.

The Tabi is a Hardmode, post- Plantera accessory which allows the player to perform a dash by double-tapping either the ◀ Left or ▶ Right key. The dash ability has a one-second cooldown between uses. The Tabi has a 1/12 (8.33%) / 23/144 (15.97%) chance to drop from Bone Lees in the post-Plantera Dungeon.
Mirage Dye is a dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. Unlike other dyes, it does not change the color of objects, but instead applies a multicolored shimmering effect.

Flurry Boots are an accessory that can be found in Frozen Chests in the underground Snow Biome, as well as Frozen (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Boreal Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). When equipped, they allow the player to gain a speed boost after running for a certain distance continuously. Your speed will continue increasing until maximum speed is attained. The Flurry Boots, Hermes Boots, Dunerider Boots and the Sailfish Boots have identical functionality, with their only differences being aesthetic (and being faster on Sand Blocks, in the case of the Dunerider Boots). In the case of the Flurry Boots, the user will leave a short dust trail under themselves as they run, which disappears immediately upon stopping, unlike the Hermes Boots.
All four listed boots are interchangeable when crafting Spectre Boots.

The Frozen Zombie (on Desktop, Console, and Mobile) or Zombie Eskimo (on Old-gen console and 3DS) is a Zombie variant that only appears on the Surface Snow biome at night. It acts the same as normal Zombies, slowly walking towards the player to deal contact damage, while attempting to navigate around obstacles and only being able to open doors during a Blood Moon. It is differentiated from other Zombies in that it is dressed in a light blue snow suit, which it can drop as armor pieces in the form of the Snow Hood, Snow Coat, and Snow Pants (on Desktop, Console, and Mobile), or Eskimo Hood, Eskimo Coat, and Eskimo Pants (on Old-gen console and 3DS).
Like normal Zombies, it has an armed variation in Expert Mode, which can perform a "slashing" attack when close to the player to deal extra damage with increased range.

The Razorpine is a Hardmode, post- Plantera magic weapon that rapidly fires 2-4 green pine needle projectiles at a high velocity. The projectiles drop off after a modest distance, much like Throwing Knives and the Magic Dagger, though with a slightly longer range. The Razorpine is dropped by the Everscream during the Frost Moon event with a 3.46%-10.37% (6.22%-31.11%) chance depending on the current wave.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

Death occurs when a player's health reaches zero. A death message is displayed dependent on how the player died. For example, " <Player name> tried to swim in lava. " is one that is displayed if the player died from lava damage.

When a player dies, a Tombstone is flung from the location of their death. When it finds a suitable space, it will become a 2x2 tile. It stores text, much in the way a Sign functions, with the player's death message, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and the real-world date.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) If the player holds more than 10 GC when they die, the spawned Tombstone will be one of the five following golden Tombstones:.

Upon death, a large red text saying " You were slain... " will be displayed on the center of the screen. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) The amount of dropped coins will be shown underneath, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and a timer is displayed underneath, which shows the time remaining until the player respawns.

There is a 10 / 15 second delay between the player's death and subsequent respawn, which is doubled in duration during Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) boss fights. Upon respawning, the player will be placed at the world's spawn point, or at the most recent Bed they had set as their spawn point.

The Shadewood Hammer is a low-tier hammer. It lies between the Copper and Tin Hammers and the Lead and Iron Hammers in hammering utility, so it is recommended for a starting player to chop down a tree when they first locate the Crimson and make this hammer.
Its Corruption counterpart is the Ebonwood Hammer. The stats of the Ebonwood Hammer are identical to the Shadewood Hammer's.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Enchanted Boomerang is a pre-Hardmode boomerang that can be fired rapidly, has medium range, and releases light particles during use. Like all boomerangs, it inflicts melee damage, so melee-boosting accessories and armor bonuses will benefit it. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it is crafted with a Wooden Boomerang and a Fallen Star. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it is found rarely in naturally-occurring Gold Chests.

The Enchanted Boomerang operates at range without using any mana, and knocks enemies back much further than most other weapons. Like most other Boomerangs, it returns to the user after reaching its maximum distance, or after colliding with an object.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Neon Moss Brick is a type of brick made from Neon Moss that glows in the dark.

The Crystal Block is a Hardmode decorative building block crafted from Crystal Shards at an Adamantite or Titanium Forge. It has a luminous shade with colors ranging from magenta to blue. It can be made into Crystal Block Walls and other Crystal furniture.

The Martian Saucer is a large flying Hardmode, post- Golem mini-boss that spawns during the Martian Madness event. It can only spawn if the Martian Madness event is 30% completed or higher. The Martian Saucer can pass through blocks and has four turrets with independent health meters that each must be destroyed, which include two rocket launchers and two laser machine guns. In addition, the Martian Saucer itself fires a " Martian Deathray ", a large yellow beam that can only be fired directly downwards and cannot be destroyed independently.

The Lead Axe is an early game axe, stronger than the starting Copper Axe and weaker than the Silver or Tungsten Axe. Like all axes, it is used to cut down trees, cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Iron Axe.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.
The Vertebra (Vertebrae (Old-gen console and 3DS versions)) is a crafting material that has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of being dropped by Crimeras, Blood Crawlers, Face Monsters, Floaty Grosses.

Cloud is a type of block found beneath Floating Islands, along with Rain Cloud blocks; on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, they can be found in stacks in Skyware Chests, Sky Crates and Azure Crates as well. Cloud blocks display as solid blocks, but light passes through them as if they were empty space. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, landing on them will not inflict fall damage.
Pumpkin is a crafting material obtained by harvesting Pumpkin plants using almost any weapon or tool.
The Fedora is a vanity item purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 2 GC 50 SC.

Crossover content is content added from a different game or other media, while the other game also adopts some content from Terraria, with mutual permission. Homages and references, however, are not crossover content.

The Flamethrower is a Hardmode ranged weapon that uses Gel for ammunition. Every press of the ⚒ Use / Attack button consumes one Gel and generates five bursts of fire in quick succession that can be spread over an area by moving the mouse while firing. With some modifiers that increase firing speed (e.g. Unreal and Rapid), each attack consumes two Gel and fires six bursts.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Flamethrower's fire bursts have unique graphics, and fly out of the weapon at a high velocity while expanding with time, before disappearing a short distance ahead of the player, creating a cone-like area of effect. The fire has 15 armor penetration, inflicts the Hellfire debuff for 20 seconds, and can pierce through three enemies before dissipating upon hitting a fourth. Additionally, the projectile's damage decreases by 15% for each enemy it pierces.

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the flamethrower's bursts are straight lines of fire particles, which travel out from the weapon to a short distance ahead of the player before stopping, lingering briefly. The fire inflicts the On Fire! debuff for 20 seconds, and can pierce through three enemies before dissipating upon hitting a fourth.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Pink Vase is a decorative furniture item. A placed Pink Vase also serves as a Placed Bottle for potion crafting.
The Rockfish is a hammer that can be fished from the underground layer but is more likely to be caught in the cavern layer, within any biome. Its hammer power is equal to that of the Molten Hamaxe.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Parka set is a vanity set which consists of Parka Hood, Parka Coat, and Parka Pants. It is dropped from Presents obtained during the Christmas event, with a chance of 1.08% in Pre-Hardmode and 1.001% in Hardmode. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Crate Potion is a buff potion which grants the Crate buff when consumed. The buff increases the chance of getting a crate from 1/10 (10%) to (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/4 (25%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/5 (20%) when fishing. This lasts for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 4 minutes / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 3 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen. The potion can be obtained both from crafting and as a quest reward from the Angler.

Deathweed is a type of herb which appears as a short, withered purple stalk. It grows naturally on Ebonstone, Crimstone, Corrupt grass, Crimson grass, Corrupt Jungle grass (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Crimson Jungle grass (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Deathweed can be harvested with virtually any weapon or tool, and can be planted manually using Deathweed Seeds in Clay Pots and Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or on suitable soil tiles.

Deathweed blooms during a Blood Moon or a full moon (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) at nighttime (7:30 PM to 4:29 AM). Its blooming is indicated by the pulsating purple glow. Harvesting blooming Deathweed yields 1 Deathweed item and 1-3 Deathweed Seeds. Harvesting mature or blooming Deathweed with the Staff of Regrowth or Axe of Regrowth (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) yields 1-2 Deathweeds and 1-5 Deathweed Seeds instead. Note that these tools can only directly harvest mature stage herbs planted on soil ; see Herbs § Growth for details.
Both Deathweed and Deathweed Seeds have a chance to be obtained from the Herb Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Paper Airplane and White Paper Airplane are consumable ranged weapons. When thrown, they will travel in a different path each time, as they are affected by wind speed and direction, which is especially apparent on a Windy Day. The two variants are functionally identical. They are sometimes dropped by slimes that are carried by Windy Balloons, which can spawn during a Windy Day.
Unlike other consumable ranged weapons, Paper Airplanes always drop as an item when flying for too long, hitting a block, or hitting an enemy.

The Frost Core is a Hardmode crafting material that is always dropped from Ice Golems, which spawn during Blizzards in the Snow biome. To craft all items that require this material, 5 Frost Cores are required.

The Mana Potion is a recovery potion that restores 100 mana and inflicts the Mana Sickness debuff upon use. It can be crafted or occasionally obtained from any Crates except for Wooden and Pearlwood Crates. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) They are also sold by the Merchant in Hardmode for 2 SC 50 CC.
It is the second tier of mana potion, succeeding the Lesser Mana Potion, and preceding the Greater Mana Potion and Super Mana Potion.
Defense items provide defense to the player when worn in the appropriate slot.

The Clinger Staff is a Hardmode magic weapon that generates a 15-tile high wall of Cursed Flame, which deals damage and inflicts the Cursed Inferno debuff to enemies that walk through it for a duration of 7 seconds. The point at which the wall is generated must be in a direct line of sight; otherwise, the wall will not generate, though still consume mana. The Clinger Staff's wall lasts for about 5 minutes. Only one wall may be generated at a time; if another is summoned, the first one will vanish. The Clinger Staff has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being dropped by Corrupt Mimics.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but the only stats that improve damage output are damage and critical chance. Switching to a different magic weapon causes existing projectiles to use that weapon's critical chance instead, meaning that the Clinger Staff's DPS is optimized with the Ruthless modifier when used in the intended way.
The Boring Bow is an unimplemented item. It has no name set and will thus display as "ItemName.BoringBow". No other stats, behaviors, or associated projectiles exist for this item.
Like other unobtainable items, the circumstances of players obtaining it are always descriptive of major bugs which cause items to spawn.

The Mechanical Worm is a Hardmode boss-summoning item used to summon The Destroyer, the Hardmode version of the Eater of Worlds. It can only be used at night ; attempting to use this item during the day will not spawn the Destroyer nor consume the item. The Mechanical Worm is also unusable while the Destroyer is already alive. If the Destroyer has not been defeated yet in a Hardmode world, all enemies have a 1/2500 (0.04%) chance of dropping a Mechanical Worm, with the exception of statue -spawned enemies, Meteor Heads, and Old One's Army enemies.

Cobalt armor is a Hardmode armor set crafted from Cobalt Bars and is the alternative to Palladium armor. Crafting a full set with a single headpiece requires 45 Cobalt Bars (135 Cobalt Ore). Crafting all five pieces requires a total of 65 Cobalt Bars (195 Cobalt Ore).

The set consists of the Cobalt Breastplate and Cobalt Leggings, as well as three different headpiece variants: the Cobalt Helmet, Cobalt Mask, and Cobalt Hat, geared towards melee, ranged, and magic damage respectively.

Wearing the full set grants a total of (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) +3% critical hit chance and +10% movement speed / (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +3% damage, +5% critical hit chance and +10% movement speed, from its individual pieces. Wearing the full set also causes the player to display an after-image effect while in motion, similar to the Ninja armor, Shadow armor, and Necro armor.
This armor is not the same as the Ancient Cobalt armor set dropped by Jungle enemies; the latter is effectively reskinned Jungle armor, using the former sprites of this set.
The Fancy Dishes are a furniture item purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 20 SC.

The Angry Dandelion is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns on grass during the Windy Day event at daytime. It is stationary and shoots 1-3 damaging Dandelion Seed projectiles at the player every 0.67 seconds.

The Phantasm Dragon is a Hardmode, post- Golem enemy that spawns exclusively during the Lunatic Cultist fight. Its behavior is nearly identical to the Wyvern 's. The Lunatic Cultist summons a Phantasm Dragon when the player attacks one of the Lunatic's duplicates or takes too long to hit the real one during its ritual attack. If the player does the above action again while a Phantasm Dragon is still alive, the Lunatic Cultist will summon an Ancient Vision instead.

The Goblin Battle Standard is an event-summoning item that initiates the Goblin Army event when used. The Goblin Battle Standard is consumed when used, so one must be crafted for each invasion the player wishes to summon. In order for it to be used, at least one player in the current world must also have 200 health or more.
The Tattered Cloth required for crafting the Goblin Battle Standard is obtained by killing Goblin Scouts, which spawn occasionally in the East and West sixths of the world.

The Meteor Staff is a Hardmode magic weapon which summons a falling Meteor projectile from the sky. The Meteor falls in the direction of the cursor, damaging nearby enemies upon colliding with an enemy or solid block. Meteors cannot pass through solid objects but may pass through platforms, and also emit light particles that continue traveling after the impact.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Molten Fury is a pre-Hardmode bow that lights ordinary Wooden Arrows ablaze, effectively transforming them into Flaming Arrows, and causing them to emit light and inflict the On Fire! debuff to enemies it hits. Other arrow types fired from Molten Fury will retain their original properties. Wooden Arrows do not inherit the increased damage of actual Flaming Arrows. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) However, they do have a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to drop as one rather than a Wooden Arrow when they hit an enemy.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Molten Fury has the highest base damage of all bows available prior to Hardmode. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it is beaten only by the Sharanga.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Womannequin is a decorative furniture item that can be used to display armor and vanity items, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) as well as accessories and dyes.

This content is transcluded from Mannequin. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, items can be placed on a Womannequin by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on it, which opens a small set of inventory -like slots beneath the player's main inventory. There are three slots for helmet, shirt, and pants, and five slots for accessories. In addition, each slot has an associated dye slot underneath it. Placing items in these slots immediately displays them on the Womannequin.

On the Old-gen console version, items can be placed on a Womannequin by pressing the ⚒ Use / Attack button anywhere on it, which places the item currently held by the player on the Womannequin. If there is already an item in the same slot on the Womannequin, it will be replaced and dropped. Items can also be removed with a pickaxe or drill.
