Jellyfish jars function as valid light sources for houses and illuminate underwater, but are not controllable mechanisms like some other light sources.

The True Eye of Cthulhu is an invincible Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns when an eye of the Moon Lord is defeated. Since the Moon Lord has three eyes to defeat before his core is revealed, there will eventually be three True Eyes of Cthulhu pursuing the player until the end of the battle.
The Superhero set is a vanity set which consists of the Superhero Mask, the Superhero Costume, and the Superhero Tights.

The Flocko is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during wave 11 of the Frost Moon event. Flockos tend to spawn along with the Ice Queen and attack by flying toward the player while spinning at high speed.
Defeating a Flocko during the Frost Moon event will add 5 / 10 / 12.5 points to the current score.

The Cavern layer is the largest layer of the world, beginning just below the Underground and extending down until the Underworld layer. Darker stone background tiles characterize it. Stone is the predominant block in this layer (as opposed to Dirt in the Underground), with frequent patches of Dirt, Silt, and Mud. Caverns contain occasional Underground Cabins where valuables can be found, as well as Glowing Mushroom biomes, mini-biomes like the Spider Nest, and occasional traps. In the lower areas of the Cavern layer, pools of lava can be found.

Furthermore, the Cavern layer contains the underground versions of several surface biomes: the Ice biome, Underground Jungle, Underground Desert (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Underground Corruption / Crimson and Hallow. A large section of the Dungeon also extends through the Cavern layer.
After defeating at least one Goblin Invasion, the Goblin Tinkerer NPC can be found in this layer. The Wizard NPC can also be found in this layer at any time during Hardmode.

Acid Dye is a dye acquired as a random reward from the Dye Trader for giving him a Strange Plant. When equipped in the dye slot, it applies a dark green rippling effect that pulses outward, similar to Blue Acid Dye and Red Acid Dye. Items dyed by it can be seen in the dark but do not emit light.

Ale is a potion that grants the Tipsy debuff when consumed, which increases many of the player's stats but lowers the player's defense for two minutes. Ale can be crafted at a Keg or purchased from the Tavernkeep (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) for 1 SC each.
The Tipsy debuff has the following effects: This content is transcluded from Tipsy.
-4 defense +2% critical hit on melee attacks +10% melee attack speed +10% melee damage (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +5 Fishing Power
Ale is also used as ammunition for the Ale Tosser (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and can therefore be stored in the player's inventory ammo slots.
Ale can be placed on a Plate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) :

The Gungnir is a Hardmode spear crafted using Hallowed Bars. When used, it emits the light particles typical of the Hallowed theme. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) It creates a small shockwave at the end of its tip when used.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

Stinkfish are a type of fish which are found rarely by fishing in any biome in any layer, with the exception of The Corruption, The Hallow and (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) the Desert. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners and Stink Potions.

The Plumber's set is a vanity set made up of the Plumber's Hat, the Plumber's Shirt, and the Plumber's Pants. On the Desktop version, Console version, Mobile version, and Nintendo 3DS version, the set's upper part is red and the lower part is blue. On the Old-gen console version, the colors are inverted. The Plumber's Hat has a 1/250 (0.4%) chance to be dropped by Fire Imps. The shirt and pants are purchased from the Clothier for 25 GC each, during a full moon.
These items are purely vanity items and provide no increase in defense or other bonuses.

The Smoke Bomb is a throwable, consumable novelty item that, when thrown, emits thick gray smoke for one minute. Upon throwing a Smoke Bomb, it will bounce or roll until it comes to a complete stop and continues to release smoke. Each can only be used once and cannot be picked up again once thrown. Smoke Bombs can be purchased from the Party Girl for 20 CC each.

The Scaly Truffle is a Hardmode mount-summoning item that summons a Pigron Mount that allows the player to fly for a limited time and run faster on land. The Scaly Truffle is obtained by fishing in the cavern layer of an Ice biome overlapping a Hallow, Corruption, or Crimson biome in Hardmode.
The Pickaxe Axe is a Hardmode pickaxe and axe combination which can be crafted after all mechanical bosses have been defeated. It is able to mine any block other than Lihzahrd Bricks.
The Pickaxe Axe is an alternative to the Drax, having a slower mining speed but longer range and benefiting from mining speed bonuses.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Suspicious Grinning Eye is a pet-summoning item that summons a Suspicious Eye pet which resembles the Eye of Cthulhu. It normally shows a blue iris and pupil, but when moving faster than 31 mph the pupil slides up and reveals a mouth, similar to the Eye of Cthulhu's second form. The Suspicious Grinning Eye has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by the Eye of Cthulhu in Master Mode.
The Candy Cane Sword is a Christmas-themed sword that has a 0.639% (pre-Hardmode) / 0.596% (Hardmode) chance to be obtained from Presents dropped during the Christmas event.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Life Crystal is a permanent booster item that permanently increases the player's health capacity by 20, adding a red heart to the player's health bar, while also restoring 20 health.

Life Crystals can be found naturally placed in any area in the Underground layer and below, though they are fairly uncommon. They cannot be found in the The Underworld or the Dungeon, unless on Old-gen console. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Life Crystals also have a 1/8 (12.5%) chance to drop from a Golden Crate, or 19/160 (11.88%) chance from a Titanium Crate.

Up to 15 Life Crystals can be used per player, increasing health capacity by 300 health (15 hearts). Added to the 100 health (5 hearts) new players begin with, a total of 400 health (20 hearts) can be achieved. Additional Life Crystals can no longer be used at that point, and attempting to do so will not consume the item.

After a world converts to Hardmode, and after the 400 health maximum is reached from consuming Life Crystals, Life Fruits can then be used to increase health capacity further, to a maximum of 500 health (20 Life Fruits).

The Seedler is a Hardmode, post- Plantera sword that, when swung, fires Seedler Nut projectiles which travel in an arc before exploding into four to seven Seedler Thorns upon hitting an enemy or after a duration of 0.33 to 2.17 seconds. Seedler Thorns inflict 66% of the weapon's base damage (33 damage), are unaffected by gravity and directed to hit enemies within a 125-tile radius, with each individual projectile being directed to target separate enemies if possible. Otherwise, Seedler Thorns are shot in randomized directions. The Seedler has a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of being dropped by Plantera.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Mysterious Package was an unobtainable pet summon, which was supposed to summon a pet drone that would drop a box every few minutes. It was likely intended to be available to those who bought Terraria on Amazon. It was only obtainable through hacks and was removed entirely shortly after its introduction.
Watches are informational accessories that show the current in-game time in the top-right corner of the screen.
The accuracy of a watch is determined by the type of metal bars used to craft it:

The Copper Watch and the Tin Watch display time to the hour, rounded down. The Silver Watch and the Tungsten Watch display time to the half-hour, rounded down. The Gold Watch and the Platinum Watch display time to the last minute, rounded down.
Watches are crafted at a Table and Chair placed near each other.
The display of time can be toggled by clicking the watch icon underneath the minimap while the inventory is open or selecting the watch icon in the equipment menu.

The Angry Bones is a pre-Hardmode enemy found in the Dungeon. They follow the Fighter AI and can open closed doors after one or two hits. They will sometimes leap towards the player when they get close, or if the player is above them.
The Quad-Barrel Shotgun is a pre-Hardmode gun that can be purchased for 35 GC from the Arms Dealer when he is spoken to in a Graveyard, and Skeletron has been defeated.

It fires a spread of eight bullets at a 45° angle while having twice the spread of the Shotgun. This spread is very substantial and it is difficult to aim without being right next to a foe due to its unreliable spread variation (although one of the pellets is always aimed towards the cursor accurately). However, it can be used against groups of enemies and can reliably hit bosses and bigger enemies.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

Whips are close-ranged summon weapons that swing in an arcing motion and produce a unique sound https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Item_153.wav. Like all summoning weapons, whips receive damage bonuses from summon damage and cannot normally deal critical hits.

When an enemy has been hit with a whip, any minions and sentries the player has summoned will target that enemy, much like when pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on an enemy with a minion/sentry-summoning weapon.

If a whip hits multiple targets in a single attack, the damage dealt will be reduced by a fixed percentage on each consecutive hit. This stat for each whip is listed as "Multihit penalty" in the following table.
Most whips inflict a special debuff on struck enemies for 4 seconds, "tagging" them.
Whips can have the same modifiers as swords, including Legendary. Their best modifier is Legendary.

Betsy is a Hardmode, post- Golem mini-boss that spawns once during the seventh and final wave of Tier 3 of the Old One's Army event. Like all enemies in the Old One's Army, she will despawn upon completion or failure of the event. Defeating Betsy is the only way to complete the final wave of the event successfully.

The Everscream is a Hardmode, post- Plantera mini-boss that spawns during the Frost Moon event. It is the Frost Moon equivalent of the Mourning Wood, which behaves in an almost identical way to the Everscream.
Defeating the Everscream during the Frost Moon event will add 50 / 100 / 125 points to the final score.

The Decorative Healing Potion is a furniture item. By pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button or mining it, it drops a Lesser Healing Potion. This item generates naturally in the Dungeon. It can be placed on a flat furniture item, where it functions as a Placed Bottle crafting station.

The Cobalt Pickaxe is a Hardmode pickaxe, and is the pickaxe alternative to the Cobalt Drill, having a slower mining speed but longer range and benefiting from mining speed bonuses. Its alternate ore version, the Palladium Pickaxe, is slightly stronger than the Cobalt Pickaxe.
It can mine any block except Adamantite Ore, Titanium Ore, Chlorophyte Ore, and Lihzahrd Bricks.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Roasted Bird is a food item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 10 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Roasted Bird can be placed on a Plate :
The Angel Halo is a vanity accessory purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 40 GC.
The Angel Halo cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

Mushroom furniture are furniture items crafted from Glowing Mushrooms, which can be found in Glowing Mushroom biomes. There are 19 (20 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) different Mushroom furniture items.

The Life Drain is a Hardmode magic weapon that deals continuous damage to all enemies near the cursor's position, as long as the distance between the player and the cursor is unobstructed. A stream of red particles flows toward the user from each targeted enemy. While the weapon is in use, the user receives the Life Drain buff, which adds 1.5 health per second to existing health regeneration, plus 0.5 health per second for every two extra enemies hit, while also increasing the ramp-up speed of natural regeneration greatly. While an enemy is being damaged by the Life Drain, it is also inflicted with the Life Drain buff that deals 25 damage per second. The Life Drain has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being dropped by Crimson Mimics.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Golem is a Hardmode, post- Plantera boss found in the Jungle Temple.

While Golem is alive, the music Golem https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Golem.mp3 will play. When Otherworldly music (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is enabled, the track Boss 2 (Otherworldly) https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Boss_2_(Otherworldly).mp3 will play instead.

The Spelunker Potion is a buff potion which grants the Spelunker buff when consumed. The buff illuminates valuable nearby objects, and the highlight color varies between versions. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.
The Spelunker buff illuminates the following:
Ores Gems Pots Herbs Dye plants Chests Life Crystals Life Fruit Statues ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) Paintings ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions))

Bats are common flying enemies. They follow the Bat AI, randomly flying around and bumping into things while trying to make contact with the player. In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), some types have a chance to inflict the Feral Bite debuff on players.

The Amber Mosquito is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Baby Dinosaur to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, a pterosaur will carry it by the tail to continue following them. The Amber Mosquito can be obtained by putting Silt, Slush, or Desert Fossils (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) into an Extractinator or Chlorophyte Extractinator (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). With Silt or Slush, it only has a 1/10,000 (0.01%) chance to drop, while with Desert Fossils it has a slightly higher chance of 27/100,000 (0.027%).

The Angry Nimbus is a Hardmode enemy that spawns when the weather is rainy in any surface biome except for the Snow biome. It will follow players around the map and attempt to release damaging raindrops on top of them similar to that of the Crimson Rod and the Nimbus Rod. It floats directly above the player, making it difficult to hit with close-range weapons.

Yoyos are melee weapons that can be thrown and seek after the player's cursor when used. Once deployed, a yoyo will stay in the air for up to a certain maximum flight time which varies per yoyo. Yoyos can be controlled freely with the cursor but they bounce off of enemies on impact. Yoyos can be acquired in several different ways, including from crafting, as rare drops from enemies, and as merchandise from certain NPCs. There are currently 21 different types of yoyos.

All yoyos deal 25% less damage if at least one solid block is between the yoyo and its user. Checking if the string overlaps any blocks is a good way to tell if the yoyo's damage is reduced. The remaining flight time of a yoyo is decreased by 1/3 of a second every time it strikes an enemy. Flight time is decreased by a full second instead of only one third if the yoyo has its damage reduced by being out of line of sight.

There are several accessories that affect the function of yoyos. String can be equipped to increase the range, a Counterweight can be equipped to release a second damaging projectile after hitting an enemy with the yoyo, and the Yoyo Glove allows the use of two yoyos. These three accessories can then be crafted into the Yoyo Bag, which combines the effects of all of them.

Yoyo range is determined by melee attack speed. However, yoyos cannot have their speed modified, and therefore cannot obtain the Legendary modifier. A Godly modifier has slightly better crowd control than a Demonic one, but the increased knockback may reduce the number of hits per second. Both modifiers can be regarded as the best. Unlike the rest of the yoyos, the Terrarian can obtain the Legendary modifier, albeit with slightly different stats.
The Slime is a common enemy.
Slime may also refer to:

Baby Slime, a minion summoned by the Slime Staff Slime Mount (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions), a mount summoned by the Slimy Saddle Winged Slime Mount (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), a mount summoned by the Gelatinous Pillion Town Slimes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), town pets that can move into houses Slime Pet (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), a pet summoned by the Petri Dish Slime Prince (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), a pet summoned by the Royal Delight Slime Princess (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), a pet summoned by the Regal Delicacy
The Merchant is an NPC vendor who will move in once the following conditions have been met:

There is an available vacant house. All players in the current world have more than 50 SC total between them in their inventories. Coins stored in chests and portable storage items like the Piggy Bank do not count toward this requirement.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, these requirements only apply to the initial spawning. If the Merchant is killed, he will automatically respawn after some time.
On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, if the Merchant is killed, he will only respawn if the above conditions are met again.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Merchant will lob Throwing Knives at nearby enemies to defend himself, dealing 12 / 18 / 21 damage at the start of the game, and as players progress he will gain various stat increases.

Tools are an association of items that are used to perform the various non-combat tasks involved in Terraria gameplay, such as construction and exploration, among others. Tools are generally wielded via the ⚒ Use / Attack key while they are held as the active hotbar item; though they are differentiated from weapons, whose primary use is instead to inflict damage upon enemies. Tools are also differentiated from accessories, which provide passive abilities, while tools are used proactively.

Pickaxes, axes, and hammers are tools that are essential at all stages of gameplay for their ability to precisely dismantle world tiles, like placed blocks, background walls, plants, or placed furniture, and convert them all to collectible inventory items for re-placement in other locations, or for other uses, such as crafting. They also double as weak melee weapons and generally inflict far less damage than actual weapons of corresponding tiers.

Other important tools include: the Magic Mirror, which will teleport the player back to their spawn point ; hooks, which aid travel above and below ground; the Bucket, which transports liquid ; the Bug Net, used to catch critters ; and the Wrenches, used for constructing mechanisms. Many of these tools are generally used throughout all stages of the game.

Paint is used to modify the color of objects. Nearly anything can be painted, including blocks, background walls, and furniture, along with non-collectable environment objects like trees, tall grass, flowers, and other ambient growth. Basic paint is purchased from the Painter NPC. Two of the same color can be combined at a Dye Vat to create "deep" color versions, which apply their color more vividly and are required in order to paint certain objects.
Coating (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is used to apply a special effect over a block and can be applied in tandem with paint and other coatings. It is purchased from the Painter NPC.

Paint and coatings are applied to blocks and furniture with the Paintbrush, and to walls with the Paint Roller, with each tile consuming one item of paint/coating. The Paint Sprayer will automatically paint items when placing them. Paint and coatings can be removed with the Paint Scraper, although they will never be retrieved upon doing so. Destroying a painted block will not drop the paint item either.
If more than one color is present in the player's inventory, the color in the earliest inventory slot is used first (starting from the top-left slot).

The Fruit Salad is a food item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 25 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Fruit Salad can be placed on a Plate :
The Amphibian Boots are an accessory crafted by combining the Sailfish Boots and Frog Leg at a Tinkerer's Workshop. It provides the benefits of both.
Equipping it has the following effects:
Increases the player's maximum movement speed to 22.5 tiles/second (31 mph) Allows auto-jumping Increases the maximum safe falling distance by 10 tiles Increases jump speed by 1.6

The Nebula Brick is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist brick that is crafted from Nebula Fragments. It is one of the four Fragment Bricks, bricks which are crafted with Lunar Fragments. It can be used to craft Nebula furniture.
Cups are a type of decorative furniture that can be placed on a table, Work Bench, or other flat furniture item. Once placed, all cups function as Placed Bottle crafting stations.
There are four cup variants. Three are crafted and one (the Chalice) is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 50 SC.
The Plate is a decorative furniture item that can be placed. Once placed, food can be placed onto or removed from the Plate by pressing ⚷ Open / Activate.

Silt Blocks are a type of soil that generates in the Underground and Cavern layers, appearing more frequently at lower depths. Silt is affected by gravity and will deal damage to any player or enemy they fall on. Unlike Sand Blocks, silt can stop the Hallow, the Crimson, and the Corruption from spreading. Silt looks similar to Ash Blocks, but is a lighter color.

Silt can be placed in an Extractinator or Chlorophyte Extractinator to be converted into various valuable materials, including gems, coins, ores, and very rarely, the Amber Mosquito pet summoning item.

The Mythril Chainsaw is a Hardmode chainsaw that is obtainable after crafting a Mythril Anvil or an Orichalcum Anvil, and is the chainsaw alternative to the Mythril Waraxe. Along with its slightly stronger alternate the Orichalcum Chainsaw, it is stronger than the Cobalt or Palladium Chainsaw but weaker than the Adamantite or Titanium Chainsaw which can be obtained later. Like all axes and chainsaws, it is used to cut down trees, cacti and giant glowing mushrooms.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Lunar Rust Brick is a type of decorative brick obtained by throwing Luminite Brick into Shimmer during a Waning Gibbous.
Tin Plating is a brick crafted at the Heavy Work Bench. It is the tin equivalent of Copper Plating.

The Vampire set is a vanity set obtained from Goodie Bags, which drop from all enemies with a 2/57 (3.51%) chance during the Halloween seasonal event. It consists of a Vampire Mask, Vampire Shirt and Vampire Pants.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Tips are phrases shown briefly during loading screens, chosen at random from the list below.
The Unicorn Horn is a Hardmode crafting material that is always dropped by Unicorns in The Hallow.

The Deadly Sphere Staff is a Hardmode, post- Plantera summon weapon that summons a Deadly Sphere minion. The Deadly Sphere minion passively levitates around the player and attacks enemies by charging into them at high velocity. Once every three attacks, it briefly stops in place to cycle through one of four visual forms before continuing to attack its chosen target. The Deadly Sphere's forms are circulated in a predetermined order and are entirely cosmetic. It cannot move through blocks. Like other minions, the summoned Deadly Sphere is invincible and follows the player until they die, summon a replacement minion, cancel the buff, or leave the world. The Deadly Sphere Staff has a 1/30 (3.33%) / 59/900 (6.56%) chance of being dropped by Deadly Spheres.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Deadly Sphere Staff has over a Ruthless one is knockback.

The Bouncy Glowstick is a consumable light source that bounces off surfaces while also providing light. Bouncy Glowsticks are the opposite of Sticky Glowsticks, bouncing off of surfaces instead of sticking to them.
Caster AI is an AI followed by the caster class of enemies. Casters move exclusively via teleporting, and fire slow-moving projectiles that travel through blocks.

The Martian Costume set is a Hardmode vanity set consisting of the Martian Costume Mask, Martian Costume Shirt, and Martian Costume Pants. Each piece has a chance to drop during the Martian Madness event.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Honey Blocks are blocks formed when water comes into contact with honey. When placed, they slow the movement of any player walking on them. Vertically, a player can slowly slide down them (even without having the Climbing Claws or Shoe Spikes equipped). They also greatly reduce jump height to one tile, or 3 tiles with the Shiny Red Balloon equipped. NPCs, critters and enemies are not affected.

The Golf Whistle is a tool used in golf that allows a player to recover Golf Balls, returning it to the previous position before it was hit when used. Using the Golf Whistle adds one stroke to the player's golf score for the shot as a penalty. The Golf Whistle can be purchased from the Golfer for 10 GC.

The Martian Officer is a Hardmode, post- Golem enemy that spawns during the Martian Madness event. It will always initially spawn with a protective Bubble Shield, which provides the Officer significantly added defense and hit points, as well as immunity to lava and knockback, until it is depleted. After the Bubble Shield is destroyed, the Officer can now actually be harmed. If the Martian Officer is not killed within three seconds after the Bubble Shield is depleted, the Bubble Shield will re-activate with full strength. The Officer's health will not be restored.

The Cannonball is a type of ammunition used by the Cannon. While held by the player or selected in the hotbar, using ⚒ Use / Attack on a Cannon will fire one shot from the Cannon's current angle. Cannonballs can also be fired from in the inventory by clicking on the cannon while holding the Auto Select key. On contact with a solid block, a Cannonball will explode, dealing damage in a small radius but leaving placed blocks intact. Cannonballs can be purchased from the Pirate for 15 SC each.

Skyware furniture is a furniture set made from Sunplate Blocks at the Sky Mill (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions). There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 22 / (Old-gen console version) 12 / (3DS version) 5 different Skyware furniture items.
Cat Ears are a headpiece vanity item that can be obtained from Goodie Bags during Halloween with a 2/57 (3.51%) chance.

Daybloom Seeds are a type of seed that can be obtained from harvesting Dayblooms while they are blooming or using the Staff of Regrowth on naturally grown Dayblooms while they are fully grown. Daybloom will only bloom during daytime, showing off a sunflower-like head. Each plant will drop 1-3 Daybloom Seeds when harvested while blooming.

Daybloom Seeds can be placed on pure and Hallowed grass (including Mowed grass (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Mowed Hallowed grass (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)), empty Clay Pots, or any types of Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and will grow into harvestable Dayblooms. They will grow anywhere, not just in direct sunlight on the Surface, but will only yield seeds when blooming.

Dashing is an ability which allows the player to quickly travel a short distance when double-tapping ◀ Left or ▶ Right. Dashing gives the player a sudden increase in horizontal momentum, which can be used to accelerate low-acceleration Mounts such as the Blessed Apple to high speeds much faster, trigger sprinting or evade attacks during fight (especially during boss fights).
There are 5 items that grant this ability.
Cactus is a crafting material obtained by harvesting Cactus plants, using an axe or chainsaw just like with trees. In addition to crafting, Cactus can be used as a building material.

The Mythril Anvil and Orichalcum Anvil are Hardmode crafting stations that serve and extend the function of a pre-Hardmode Anvil. These are very crucial to game advancement, as they account for making nearly every Hardmode recipe before the Ancient Manipulator (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). In addition to acting as a direct replacement to Lead and Iron Anvils and inheriting all of their crafting recipes, they further serve the similar function of crafting bars forged of Hardmode ores into weapons, armor and tools, as well as several other items, such as wings.

Items are entities that are among the most basic components of Terraria. The player can interact with most items by using, consuming, or placing them. Items are always in one of two forms: "dropped", i.e. being part of the world, or in an inventory pertaining to a player, NPC vendor, or storage item. Dropped items can usually be picked up by the player to move them into their inventory, and they can usually be dropped out of the inventory again.
Most items can be grouped based on certain shared characteristics, e.g. armor items, blocks, or weapons. See Category:Items for the complete categorization.

The Possessed Hatchet is a Hardmode, post- Golem boomerang that homes in on enemies while flying through the air at high velocity before returning to the player when thrown. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the weapon acts similarly to stacked Light Discs, capable of throwing multiple hatchets despite being incapable of being stacked, with no limit to the number of hatchets that can be out at once. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it acts as a singular boomerang and throws out only one hatchet at a time. When it has no enemy to home in on, the Possessed Hatchet returns to the player after flying a relatively short distance of only 25 tiles. The Posssessed Hatchet has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/7 (14.29%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped from Golem.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Gatligator is a Hardmode gun that fires as fast as the Megashark, and shares the 50% chance not to consume ammo. This weapon is very inaccurate, spreading bullets in random directions over a spread of about 30°, making it very difficult to hit enemies from a far distance. It also fires at varying velocity. It is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 35 GC, while in Hardmode.
The Chain Gun operates similarly, and can be considered an upgrade.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Trimarang is a boomerang crafted using three other pre-Hardmode boomerangs. Up to three can be thrown at a time, similar to the Light Disc and Bananarang.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Sandstorm is an event specific to the Desert, and occurs in all Deserts at the same time. While this event is active, the Mighty Wind debuff will be continuously inflicted upon the player, though it can be counteracted by standing in front of a background wall. The Weather Radio and its upgrades will switch between " Sandstorm " and its standard display while a Sandstorm is occurring.

During a Sandstorm, many particles of sand can be seen flying across the screen. The color of these particles will depend on whether the Desert is pure, Corrupt, Crimson, or Hallow. Vision is also limited. While the effects are amplified with Color and White lighting, which may be resource-intensive on some devices, using the Retro or Trippy setting will remove much of the effects.
Certain enemies often found in the Underground Desert will spawn on the surface during a Sandstorm, as well as several new and dangerous enemies.
The Kaleidoscope is a Hardmode, post- Plantera whip that has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by the Empress of Light.

Like other whips, it causes minions and sentries to focus on the last-struck enemy and increases their damage against the target by 20. Uniquely, it also grants minions and sentries the ability to deal critical hits at a fixed 10% chance.

If the Kaleidoscope hits multiple targets in a single attack, the damage dealt by each consecutive hit will be reduced by 10%. Enemies tagged by the Kaleidoscope also emit multicolored sparkles when hit by a minion or sentry for as long as they are tagged.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
Meteorite Brick is a type of decorative brick crafted with Meteorite. It emits a small amount of light when placed.
Unlike plain Meteorite, Meteorite Bricks do not inflict the Burning debuff or deal damage to players on contact. They are vulnerable to explosions.

The Tragic Umbrella is a held item and melee weapon which can be purchased from the Clothier for 10 GC while in a Graveyard. It functions exactly like the standard Umbrella, aside from dealing higher melee damage.
While held, the Tragic Umbrella appears above the character, allowing them to fall at a slower rate than normal and preventing fall damage. The player can hold ▼ Down to increase the fall speed.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Fireblossom is a type of herb which appears as a small, magma-colored flower. It grows naturally on Ash Blocks and Ash grass (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Fireblossom can be harvested with virtually any weapon or tool, and can be planted manually using Fireblossom Seeds in Clay Pots and Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or on suitable soil tiles.

Fireblossom blooms (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) at sunset, from 3:45 PM to 7:30 PM, unless it is raining / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) when partially submerged in lava. Its blooming is indicated by the fiery flower and fire particles emitted. Harvesting blooming Fireblossom yields 1 Fireblossom item and 1-3 Fireblossom Seeds. Harvesting mature or blooming Fireblossom with the Staff of Regrowth or Axe of Regrowth (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) yields 1-2 Fireblossoms and 1-5 Fireblossom Seeds instead. Note that these tools can only directly harvest mature stage herbs planted on soil ; see Herbs § Growth for details.
Both Fireblossom and Fireblossom Seeds have a chance to be obtained from the Herb Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Hallowed Seeds are Hardmode seeds that can be planted in Dirt Blocks to create Hallowed grass and spread The Hallow. Hallowed Seeds are purchased from the Dryad in Hardmode for 20 SC each.

Cactus furniture are furniture items crafted from Cactus, which can be obtained by cutting down Cactus in the Desert biome. There are 20 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 18 (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) different Cactus furniture items. Crafting all pieces of furniture requires 160 Cactus.
The Blood Feeder is a Hardmode enemy that spawn in pools of water in the Crimson during Hardmode. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) They have higher stats than Corrupt and Vicious Goldfish.
The Rotten Chunk is a crafting material that has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of being dropped from Eaters of Souls, Devourers, Corruptors, and on the Nintendo 3DS version, the Eater of Worlds.

Mister Stabby is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Frost Legion event. It chases the player and occasionally stops in place to do a considerably long stabbing animation with its knife. When attacking the player, it will dash and bounce around the terrain, making it difficult to hit.

The Yeti is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during wave 12 of the Frost Moon event. It behaves similarly to Krampus and the Nutcracker, although it is much stronger and is immune to knockback.
Defeating a Yeti during the Frost Moon event will add 18 / 36 / 45 points to the current score.

Empty Bullets are a Hardmode crafting material purchased from the Arms Dealer for 5 CC (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 3 CC (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) each. While they have no function as ammunition on their own, Empty Bullets are used to craft Hardmode bullets with special effects.

The Wand of Frosting is an early pre-Hardmode magic weapon and the direct upgrade to the Wand of Sparking. It fires a blue spark along a parabolic curve, traveling about 16 tiles before dissipating. The spark can pierce one enemy and has a 1/2 (50%) chance to inflict the Frostburn debuff for 2 seconds (2/3 (66.67%) chance) or 3 seconds (1/3 (33.33%) chance). The Wand of Frosting deals no knockback, but it has a base 14% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%.
Its best modifier is Demonic or Deadly, with the former granting improved critical strike chance and the latter granting improved speed. It cannot get modifiers that affect knockback or mana cost.
Titanstone Block Wall is a wall made from Titanstone Blocks.

The Adamantite Chainsaw is a Hardmode chainsaw that is obtainable after crafting an Adamantite Forge or Titanium Forge, and is the chainsaw alternative to the Adamantite Waraxe. Along with its slightly stronger alternate, the Titanium Chainsaw, it is stronger than the Mythril and Orichalcum Chainsaws, making it one of the strongest chainsaws that can be obtained before defeating a mechanical boss. Like all axes and chainsaws, it is used to cut down trees, cacti and giant glowing mushrooms.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Crystal Dart is a type of Hardmode dart used with the Blowgun, Blowpipe, Dart Pistol, and the Dart Rifle. They move in a straight line and are unaffected by gravity when shot, ricocheting, or piercing six times before disappearing. The darts will also bounce off tiles and automatically target enemies if they are close enough.

The Enchanted Sword is a Hardmode enemy which spawns in the Underground Hallow. It hovers and spins before lunging at the player, traveling through any blocks to reach them. Any knockback dealt to it disrupts its attack, forcing it to pause and spin again. It has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of inflicting the Cursed debuff for 4 / 8 / 10 seconds upon contact.
Tin armor is an armor set, and is also one of the most simply craftable armor sets in the game. It consists of the Tin Helmet, Tin Chainmail and Tin Greaves.
Its alternate ore counterpart is the Copper armor.

It takes a total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 48 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 60 Tin Bars to craft a full suit, or (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 144 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 180 Tin Ore.
A full set grants a basic 5 defense plus a set bonus of 2 defense, which equals a total of 7 defense. That means a full set of tin armor grants 1 more defense than Copper armor's 6 defense.

Defender Medals are a form of currency used to purchase items from the Tavernkeep. They are obtained by completing waves, beginning with the third, in the Old One's Army event, dropped by the Eternia Crystal at the end of each wave. Betsy 's Expert Mode Treasure Bag also rewards 30-49 Defender Medals when opened. In addition, the player can obtain 10 Defender Medals by talking to the Tavernkeep and selecting the " Eternia Crystal " option, but this can only be done once per character.

The White Tuxedo set is a vanity set consisting of the White Tuxedo Shirt and the White Tuxedo Pants. It is purchased from the Clothier for 50 GC (set), on the night of a Full Moon. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
The set exists on Old-gen console and 3DS, but is unobtainable on these versions.

The Stylist is an NPC vendor who can change the player's hairstyle and hair color. She also sells a variety of Hair Dyes, which apply dynamic effects to the player's hair. She will move in once the following criteria have been met:

There is an available vacant house. Rescuing her as the Webbed Stylist, who can be encountered randomly in Spider Nests in the Cavern layer. Interacting with her in this state with ⚷ Open / Activate will free her. If the Webbed Stylist is killed, she will still be able to respawn afterwards; if the Stylist NPC is killed, she will move in again after some time as long as there are vacant houses.

Hair Dyes range in price from 5 GC to 30 GC. Switching to another normal hairstyle (styles #1 through #51 only) costs 2 GC (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 1 GC (Old-gen console version), while any other hairstyles (including all Stylist-exclusive hairstyles) cost 20 GC (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 5 GC (Old-gen console version) ; changing hair color costs 2 GC (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 1 GC (Old-gen console version).

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Stylist's prices can vary depending on her Happiness ; this also affects her prices for hairstyle and/or color changes, as follows: The total cost of the chosen hairstyle and/or hair color change is multiplied by her happiness-based price multiplier, and then rounded to the nearest multiple of 1 GC. Thus, the cost of changing hairstyles can be 2 GC - 3 GC (for basic styles) or 15 GC - 30 GC (for expensive styles); changing hair colors can range from 2 GC - 3 GC ; and changing both hairstyle and hair color can range from 3 GC to 33 GC.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version when confronted by enemies, the Stylist will use Stylish Scissors to defend herself, dealing 10 / 15 / 17 damage at the start of the game, and (on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version) as players progress she will gain various stat increases. The Stylist also has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of dropping the Stylish Scissors upon death. Note that she can only defend herself once freed, not while still webbed.
The Webbed Stylist is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades.

The Shroomite Digging Claw is a Hardmode, post- Plantera pickaxe and axe. It is capable of mining every type of block except Lihzahrd Bricks. It is the pickaxe with the fastest mining speed in the game.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.
The Obsidian Brick Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Ruined Houses in the Underworld, considered unsafe.
It can be obtained as item via crafting or destroying natural Obsidian Brick Walls. When placed by the player, it is considered a safe wall.

A Bottle is a crafting material required to craft most potions. Like the Pink Vase, Mug, and different Cups, placing it (on most " flat-surface items " or a platform) allows it to act as a Placed Bottle where the player can craft potions. Bottles can also be "filled" when standing near water or honey, turning them into Bottled Water or Bottled Honey, respectively.
Bottles can be crafted from Glass and found in chests.

Living Mahogany is a type of block that makes up the trunks and roots of Living Mahogany Trees in the Underground Jungle. Upon destruction it will turn into regular Rich Mahogany. It can be created by the player using a Living Mahogany Wand, which in turn consumes Rich Mahogany.
The Honeyfall Block is a block that operates like the Waterfall Block and Lavafall Block, having an animated texture of flowing honey.

Water Walking Boots are an accessory that allows a player to walk on water, honey, and shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The player moves across these liquids at normal speed without sinking. They do not allow walking on lava. When the player is on a liquid, they may press ▼ Down to fall through the liquid, similar to a platform. Water Walking Boots have a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/10 (10%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/15 (6.67%) chance of being obtained from Water Chests, Ocean Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Seaside Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Tiger Climbing Gear is an accessory that allows for sliding down, and completely stopping while touching walls. Holding the ▼ Down key while clinging to a wall allows the player to slide down walls a little faster than if they only had one of the ingredient accessories. While either clinging or sliding the player can jump off of the wall, allowing them to scale vertical surfaces with ease. This accessory is useful if paired with wings, as the player's flight time is reset when latching onto a wall.

The Bird, Blue Jay, and Cardinal are flying critters that can spawn in the Forest biome. Much like the Vulture, Birds remain still until approached, whereupon they will fly away. Birds will occasionally chirp when nearby.
Birds have only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

Birds can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Bird / Blue Jay / Cardinal Cage). Once crafted, the Birds cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Birds can be spawned by the Bird Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, there is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Bird to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

The Presserator is an accessory that automatically places Actuators to objects when placing them. It requires Actuators to be in the player's inventory in order to function. The Presserator is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 10 GC.

The Presserator can be used as long as it is in the player's inventory or equipped. When held or equipped, a toggle for controlling the function of this item appears to the left of the main inventory / in the tools menu below the inventory.

The Viking Helmet is an armor piece for the helmet slot. It has a 1/50 (2%) chance to be dropped by Undead Vikings in the Ice biome. It provides a sizeable amount of defense (as much as a Gold Helmet or Tungsten Helmet), but it does not have an associated set or set bonus, hindering its utility.

The Heat Ray is a Hardmode, post- Golem magic weapon that auto-fires yellow laser beams that instantaneously travel to its maximum distance and strike its chosen target. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Heat Ray's laser beams do not pierce enemies, whereas on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, the beams can pierce an infinite number of enemies. The Heat Ray has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/7 (14.29%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped by Golem.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Celebrationmk10 (also known as the Birthday World or Anniversary World) is a secret world seed. It celebrates Terraria 's tenth birthday, May 16, 2021.
The following seeds can be used to generate a Celebrationmk10 world (case-insensitive):

The Empty Dropper is a Hardmode crafting material purchased from the Wizard for 1 SC. It is used in the crafting of Magic Droppers. The Crystal Ball must be near water, lava, and honey, respectively, in order to craft the different liquid droppers.

The Blade of Grass is a pre-Hardmode sword crafted using materials from the Underground Jungle. It has a decent size and swing reach, and has a 1/4 (25%) chance of inflicting the Poisoned debuff for 7 seconds upon striking enemies.

The Blade of Grass is roughly equal to the Volcano in size, making it one of the largest swords in pre-Hardmode. When swung, it fires a small, green Leaf Blade projectile that flies upwards in a circle, leaving behind a green particle effect resembling leaves. The Leaf Blade projectile can pass through blocks, has 20 armor penetration, can automatically target enemies within a radius of 9.375 tiles, deals 25% base damage (4 base damage), can pierce one enemy, and has the same chance to inflict Poisoned for the same duration as the sword itself.
The Blade of Grass is one of the key ingredients in crafting the Night's Edge.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Flesh Block is a Hardmode block. They are used to craft Flesh furniture and Flesh Block Walls. When placed, eyeballs and intestines can be seen bulging out of the block. Flesh Blocks will not spread The Crimson.

The Sand Poacher is a Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Underground Desert biome. Following the Spider AI, it will follow and attempt to deal contact damage to the player while also being capable of climbing onto background walls. If the Sand Poacher is climbing on a wall and detects the player within its line of sight, its movement speed increases drastically, making escape more difficult for the player. Upon contact, the Sand Poacher also inflicts the Acid Venom debuff for 4 seconds.
The Lesion Block is a Hardmode block. It is used to craft Lesion furniture and Lesion Block Walls. Lesion Blocks will not spread the Corruption.
The Party Center is an animated novelty mechanism furniture item bought from the Party Girl NPC for 20 GC. Pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on a Party Center toggles the Party event.

The Old One's Army is a unique Dungeon Defenders 2 crossover event that can be triggered by placing an Eternia Crystal on an Eternia Crystal Stand. Waves of enemies begin spawning from portals on both sides of the crystal, seeking to destroy it. The objective is to protect the Eternia Crystal until all waves are cleared - if the crystal is destroyed, the event automatically ends.
There are three different versions, or "tiers", of the event:

After defeating the Eater of Worlds or Brain of Cthulhu, the Old One's Army is unlocked in its first tier with an initial maximum of five waves. After defeating any mechanical boss, the event receives a substantial increase in difficulty in its second tier and gains two more waves, totaling a maximum of seven. After defeating Golem, the event reaches its third, final tier of difficulty, with the full range of enemies and mini-bosses present in some way during the seven waves.

Clearing later waves rewards the player with Defender Medals, a unique currency that can be used to purchase special weapons, armor, and the Defender's Forge from the Tavernkeep NPC. This gear is specifically suited for the event, due to its exceptional level of difficulty, and stronger equipment is unlocked with each progressed tier. Not only are its enemies extraordinarily resistant, but it also employs numerous anti-cheat/exploit mechanisms, such as preventing the player from placing or removing blocks or liquids for the event's duration.
Health is the character's life count, represented by a meter of heart icons at the top-right of the screen. Each red heart shown represents 20 health, and each gold heart represents 25 health.

Taking damage causes health to drop, signified by the meter fading from right to left. Health regenerates when the character stops taking damage, and regeneration occurs at ever-increasing rates the longer the character avoids further damage, with a further rate boost if the character stands still. Regeneration can also be boosted using various equipable items, potions, and placed furniture items that grant area-of-effect buffs, such as Campfires and Heart Lanterns.

New characters begin with 5 red hearts, i.e. 100 health. Health capacity can be increased using Life Crystals, which add a single red heart each to the health meter permanently, increasing health capacity by 20 each. This can be done until the health meter reaches 20 red hearts (400 health).

Later in the game, the character can use Life Fruit to increase the capacity of their hearts by 5 health each, signified by permanently turning the color of each heart gold. With 15 Life Crystals and 20 Life Fruits used, a character can gain up to 20 gold hearts, which equals 500 health capacity. A further temporary boost to 600 health capacity can be achieved using a Lifeforce Potion.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the player can change the style of the health bar via the "Health and Mana Style" option in the settings. With the Classic style, Hearts will decrease in size and fade away if they are "empty".

On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, hearts will lose pieces of themselves to reveal a darkened "empty" heart. Each red piece represents 5 health, and each gold piece represents 1 1/4 health. The gold hearts are also on a separate layer than the red hearts.
On the Nintendo 3DS version, hearts are also larger prior to getting over 10 hearts.

The Wooden Sword is an early-game melee weapon, and the weakest of the seven wooden swords. It is considered a significant upgrade from the starting Copper Shortsword due to its higher damage and broadsword arc motion. This facilitates pushing enemies further away, and it is therefore recommended to craft this sword as soon as possible if one is not strictly adhering to another class.

On the, all newly created characters begin with a Wooden Sword instead of a Copper Shortsword. However, here it inflicts less damage than the Copper Shortsword. This disadvantage may be negated by the fact that it can strike flying enemies (unlike the Copper Shortsword).
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Adamantite Forge and Titanium Forge are Hardmode crafting stations that incorporate the same functions as a regular Furnace and Hellforge, with the additional bonus of being able to smelt Adamantite, Titanium and Chlorophyte ores into their respective bars. They give off fire particles like the Furnace and Hellforge.
The Adamantite Forge and Titanium Forge are functionally identical.

Buffs are positive status effects granted to a player upon consuming, equipping, or otherwise activating various items. Active buffs are shown as icons below the hotbar, along with their remaining duration. Buffs are almost universally positive or at least benign effects, in contrast with debuffs, over which the player has much less control. Pets, light pets, minions, and mounts also have their own associated buffs while they are activated.

Buffs can be easily activated with the buff hotkey (default B), which activates all the buff-granting consumables in the player's inventory (starting from the top-left) that are not currently activated. A player is limited to 44 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 22 (Old-gen console version) / 10 (3DS version) active buffs and debuffs at any one point, and the leftmost buff in the bar will be deactivated if another is applied after this limit is reached. Most buffs can be deactivated prematurely  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen. However, buffs that are granted by proximity to an entity will only deactivate when the player is no longer in range (see Environmental below).

Most activated buffs are bound to a character, and persist as that character moves from server to server and from world to world, with the exception of buffs granted from equipments, which disappear when they leave the world. Buffs are always deactivated on the player's death, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) with the exception of those granted by flasks.
The Ultrabright Helmet is an armor piece for the helmet slot that combines the functionalities of the Mining Helmet and the Night Vision Helmet.

The Shotgun is a Hardmode gun that fires a spread of three to five bullets, but consumes only one item of ammo. It can be purchased from the Arms Dealer for 25 GC once the Wall of Flesh has been defeated.
It is an upgrade of the pre-Hardmode Boomstick. The Onyx Blaster (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and the Tactical Shotgun are upgrades of the Shotgun.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Steampunk Boiler is a Hardmode crafting station used to craft Steampunk furniture out of Cogs. The Steampunk Boiler can be purchased from the Steampunker for 10 GC, once the Eye of Cthulhu, Eater of Worlds / Brain of Cthulhu and Skeletron have been defeated.
The Skyware Chest is a storage item found only on Floating Islands.

The Gelatin Crystal is a Hardmode boss-summoning item used to summon Queen Slime. When a Crystal Shard is to be generated, it has a 1/50 (2%) chance to be replaced by a Gelatin Crystal instead. It drops the item used to summon Queen Slime upon breaking it and can be used at any time of day and any depth when the player is in the Hallow.
Palladium Ore is an orange-colored Hardmode ore which can replace Cobalt in a given world. It appears similar to Copper Ore but is slightly more saturated.

Like other Hardmode ores, Palladium is generated upon destruction of an Altar with a Pwnhammer, it is immune to all types of explosions and requires at least a Molten Pickaxe to mine. It can also be obtained from Crates.

Debuffs are negative status effects inflicted on a player or enemy during combat or through various items or the environment. Active debuffs are shown as icons below the hotbar, along with their remaining duration. Debuffs are almost universally negative or at least malign effects, in contrast with buffs, over which the player has much more control.

In general, damaging debuffs will stack: If a player is both Poisoned and On Fire!, they will take damage from both debuffs. However, Poisoned and Acid Venom do not stack, and Poisoned will have a lower priority than Acid Venom. Death always cancels any active debuffs.

Unlike buffs, debuffs cannot be canceled by right-clicking their icons. The Nurse can cancel debuffs at a cost that varies from 2 SC 50 CC to 3 GC per active debuff, depending on some factors (see Nurse § Price increases for more details). This does not apply to the Potion Sickness debuff, which cannot be canceled.
The Royal Scepter is a vanity accessory sold by the Princess for 1 PC.
The Royal Scepter cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

Daybloom is a type of herb that appears as a small yellow flower with a straight green stem. It grows naturally on regular grass and Hallowed grass. Daybloom can be harvested with virtually any weapon or tool, and can be planted manually using Daybloom Seeds in Clay Pots and Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or on suitable soil tiles.

Daybloom blooms during daytime (4:30 AM to 7:29 PM). Its blooming is indicated by the yellow sunflower-like head. Harvesting blooming Daybloom yields 1 Daybloom item and 1-3 Daybloom Seeds. Harvesting mature or blooming Daybloom with the Staff of Regrowth or Axe of Regrowth (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) yields 1-2 Dayblooms and 1-5 Daybloom Seeds instead. Note that these tools can only directly harvest mature stage herbs planted on soil ; see Herbs § Growth for details.

Both Daybloom and Daybloom Seeds have a chance to be obtained from the Herb Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Daybloom can also be dropped by Angry Dandelions (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Magic Guns are magic weapons that fire projectiles at the cost of mana instead of ammunition. Magic Guns function the same as Spell Books and Wands, but they appear as guns.
Their best modifier is generally Mythical.

The Rich Mahogany Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Underground Cabins in the Underground Jungle, as well as in Jungle Shrines in some worlds. It drops as an item when destroyed, and can also be obtained via crafting. It is always considered a safe wall.

The Ball O' Fuse Wire is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that spawns a pet Dynamite Kitten resembling the Orange Tabby variant of the Town Cat to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Kitten will ride towards them on a stick of Dynamite and immediately dismount when it is on solid ground. The Ball O' Fuse Wire can be purchased from the Zoologist for 50 GC after completing 70% (378 entries) of the Bestiary.

Apprentice armor is a Hardmode armor set purchased from the Tavernkeep for 450000* 45 in total after defeating any mechanical boss, and provides summon as well as magic damage bonuses. The set consists of the Apprentice's Hat, Apprentice's Robe, and Apprentice's Trousers.
A full set of Apprentice armor provides the following stats:
+32 defense +20% magic damage +30% summon damage +20% magic critical strike chance −10% mana usage +20% movement speed +2 sentry slots

Additionally, wearing the full set will increase the attack range of Flameburst sentry summons by 50%, allowing them to attack up to 84 tiles away. It also increases their projectile velocity by 40% and increases their field of view significantly.
The Dark Artist armor can be considered a direct upgrade of the Apprentice armor.
The Moon Lord is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist boss. He is the final boss of the Desktop, Console, and Mobile versions of Terraria.

While the Moon Lord is alive, his exclusive music Moon Lord https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Moon_Lord.mp3 will play. When Otherworldly music (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is enabled, the track Lunar Boss (Otherworldly) https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/File:Music-Lunar_Boss_(Otherworldly).mp3 will play instead.

The Lantern Night is a peaceful event that generally occurs the night after a boss or invasion has been defeated for the first time. During the event, many lanterns can be seen floating up into the sky in the background. The player will have a flat +0.3 increase to their luck stat and the Party Girl will sell the Release Lantern.

If a boss is summoned or another event (Blood Moon, Frost Moon, Pumpkin Moon, etc.) is activated during the event, it will stop, and will not continue even after the boss despawns or the event ends. However, if a Lantern Night is set to start but a boss or event is active when night begins, the Lantern Night may be pushed back instead; see the Notes section below for details.
In addition, a Lantern Night fulfills the requirements for Enchanted Nightcrawlers to spawn naturally only if a Meteor Shower is also ongoing.

The Deerclops Eyeball is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Tiny Deerclops to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, Tiny Deerclops flies while holding onto a bird to catch up with them. The Deerclops Eyeball has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped from Deerclops in Master Mode.

The Water Bolt is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that autofires a slow-moving, ricocheting water ball projectile that travels in a straight line, emits a dim blue light, and is unaffected by gravity. The Water Bolt's projectile can last up to 30 seconds but will dissipate when it ricochets five times or upon hitting ten enemies. The Water Bolt is uniquely found only in the Dungeon, hidden as one of the many Books on the shelves. It cannot be crafted, purchased, found in Chests, or obtained in other ways.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Bloody Machete is a rare and unique boomerang -type weapon that has a 1/2000 (0.05%) chance of being dropped by any weak enemy during the Halloween seasonal event. When thrown, it falls downward after reaching a maximum range, and it returns to the thrower upon impacting a block or enemy. Its physics are similar to the Magic Dagger, but it must return to the player before being thrown again. It inflicts melee damage, rather than magic or ranged damage.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Reaper set is a vanity set which consists of the Reaper Hood and Reaper Robe. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to be obtained from Goodie Bags during Halloween. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its male and female variants look identical.

The Flow Invader is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Stardust Pillar during the Lunar Events. When it spawns, three smaller minions will appear one at a time and begin orbiting it. The Flow Invader utilizes these as attacks, sending them as 1-2 high-speed projectiles towards the player. The orbiting minions will reappear over time. The Flow Invader will launch all of its remaining minions at the player upon death.

Cobalt Bars are bars crafted from 3 Cobalt Ore. Cobalt is the first tier of the three Hardmode ores that the player is able to obtain. Cobalt is the equivalent of Palladium. After the first Demon Altar is broken in a world, either Cobalt or Palladium will be chosen at random and the other one will not spawn naturally in that world.
On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, Cobalt Bars drop from Shadow Hammers.

Crafting all Cobalt equipment requires (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 143 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 145 bars, or (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 429 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 435 ores.

The Fireworks Box is a placed novelty mechanism that launches colorful visual effects. Once placed, it can be activated via wire or by right-clicking the Box directly. Each activation causes the Box to fire a random one of four possible fireworks effects that cause no damage. It can be used infinitely at no cost. The Fireworks Box is purchased from the Party Girl for 5 GC.

The Palladium Chainsaw is a Hardmode chainsaw that is obtainable after defeating the Wall of Flesh, and is the Chainsaw alternative to the Palladium Waraxe. It is one of the earliest available Chainsaws upon entering Hardmode, as is its slightly weaker alternative, the Cobalt Chainsaw. Like all Axes and Chainsaws, it is used to cut down Trees, Cacti and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

Sake is a potion that grants the Tipsy debuff when consumed, which increases many of the player's stats but lowers the player's defense for four minutes, twice the duration of Ale. Sake can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 5 SC.
The Tipsy debuff has the following effects: This content is transcluded from Tipsy.
-4 defense +2% critical hit on melee attacks +10% melee attack speed +10% melee damage (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) +5 Fishing Power
Sake can be placed on a Plate (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) :

The Key of Night is a craftable item that spawns a Corrupt Mimic or a Crimson Mimic when placed in any slot of any empty Chest, depending on whether the world generated with The Corruption or The Crimson, respectively. The world must be in Hardmode and the only item inside the Chest must be a single Key of Night.
The Corrupt/Crimson Mimic is spawned as soon as the Chest is closed, consuming both the Key of Night and the Chest.
Mercury Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Mercury Bricks.
The Cat set is a vanity set consisting of the Cat Mask, Cat Shirt, and Cat Pants. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to be dropped by Goodie Bags.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Its male and female variants look identical.
The Extendo Grip is an accessory that extends block mining and placement reach by 3 tiles horizontally and 2 tiles vertically. It is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 10 GC.

Glass furniture are furniture items crafted from Glass, which in turn is crafted from Sand at a Furnace, using the Glass Kiln. There are 20 (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 4 (Old-gen console version) different Glass furniture items.

Cracked Dungeon Bricks are blocks which can be found in the Dungeon and appear very similar to ordinary Dungeon Bricks. If jumped on, walked across, grappled to, mined with any pickaxe or drill, or hit by projectiles, several Cracked Dungeon Bricks nearby the targeted block, including the block itself, may fall and be destroyed upon hitting solid ground, dropping no item. Cracked Dungeon Bricks can conceal important pathways to significant portions of the Dungeon, potentially making it seem much smaller than it actually is. Additionally, naturally-generated Cracked Dungeon Bricks often conceal rectangular pits lined with Spikes, which may sometimes be filled with water to make escape more difficult.

Cracked Dungeon Bricks can be crafted with regular Dungeon Bricks at a Heavy Work Bench. Crafted Cracked Dungeon Bricks behave the same as naturally generated Cracked Dungeon Bricks, and do not drop an item upon destruction.

Wings are Hardmode (with the single exception of Fledgling Wings) accessories that can allow the player to fly temporarily by pressing and holding the ↷ Jump key. Flight time is reset when the player rests on solid objects, including both standing on blocks and using climbing items like Ropes, hooks, Shoe Spikes, and Climbing Claws. Certain wing types also allow the player to hover at fixed heights by holding the ▼ Down key during flight, and/or accelerate their ascent speed by holding the ▲ Up key.
After flight time has been exhausted, a player can continue holding the ↷ Jump key to glide. Gliding fall speed can be accelerated by holding the ▼ Down key in addition.

Wings additionally grant immunity from fall damage (except when overridden by the Stoned (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) debuff), rendering fall damage protection items like the Lucky Horseshoe unnecessary.

Flight is much more controlled with wings than with Rocket Boots, Spectre Boots, etc. alone, and they allow for much greater flight range. Equipping wings generally replaces jumps entirely with flight, rather than requiring a double-jump to activate. Extra jump accessories like the Cloud in a Bottle will still grant an additional jump, which is used when the (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) ↷ Jump button is released and pressed again / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) when all flight time has run out. This can be used to instantly boost the wing to full speed upon reactivation in midair.
There are currently 47 unique wing types in total: 45 are available on Desktop, Console, and Mobile and 21 on Old-gen console and 3DS. Flight time and speed can vary by the version.
The Mana Cloak is a Hardmode accessory that combines the effects of the Mana Flower and Star Cloak. It also adds a new effect to the stars spawned by the Star Cloak.

When the player takes damage, the Mana Cloak will spawn three stars that damage enemies. When one of these stars strikes an obstacle, it will transform into a special glowing mana star that travels towards the player, restoring 50 mana upon collection. The mana star will disappear 5 seconds after it is spawned if not picked up. Note that only one mana-restoring star can spawn per second, no matter how many times the Mana Cloak is triggered.

The Slap Hand is a Hardmode broadsword that is notable for having extremely high base knockback - a rating of 20, one of the highest values among all player-caused sources of knockback. Additionally, the Slap Hand also has a 19% base critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%.
The Slap Hand can be purchased from the Skeleton Merchant for 25 GC during a Hardmode Blood Moon.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Lavafly is a critter that spawns occasionally in the Underworld at night. The Lavafly has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Lavafly can only be caught with the Lavaproof Bug Net or the Golden Bug Net. Trying to catch it with a standard Bug Net will only set the player on fire. After being caught, it can be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Lavafly in a Bottle). Once crafted, the Lavafly cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Lavafly can be used as bait for fishing, with 25% bait power. Using it as bait also allows fishing in lava.

The Abeemination is a boss-summoning item used to summon the Queen Bee. It can only be used in the Jungle or Underground Jungle. Attempting to use it outside of these biomes will have no effect and will not consume the item.

Beetle armor is a Hardmode, post- Golem melee armor set. Crafting the full set with one chest piece requires 18 Beetle Husks and a full set of Turtle armor (54 Chlorophyte Bars (or 270 pieces of Chlorophyte Ore), and 3 Turtle Shells). Crafting all four pieces from scratch requires 26 Beetle Husks, 78 Chlorophyte Bars (or 390 pieces of Chlorophyte Ore), and 4 Turtle Shells.
The set consists of the Beetle Helmet and Beetle Leggings, as well as two different chestpiece variants: the Beetle Scale Mail and Beetle Shell.
The full set grants the following effects while equipped:
With Beetle Scale Mail :

+61 defense +8% melee critical strike chance +14% melee damage +12% melee speed +12% movement speed +500 aggro The Beetle Might offensive buff: Increases melee speed and damage by increments of 10% upon dealing melee damage to enemies. The boost can be raised up to 30%, and the rate at which it increases depends on total damage dealt per second. Dealing less than roughly 180 damage per second will not grant Beetle Might at all. The buff depletes at an accelerating rate as long as the player does not deal damage, meaning that the buff will reset very quickly outside of combat.
With Beetle Shell :

+73 defense +5% melee critical hit chance +11% melee damage +6% melee speed +6% movement speed +900 aggro The Beetle Endurance defensive buff: When the player avoids taking damage, this buff reduces damage taken on the next hit by 15%, with further boosts to 30% and 45% if the player continues to avoid damage for a longer duration. The buff gets first applied after 3 seconds from taking damage, and will then increase after another 3 seconds. When the player takes damage thereafter, each hit lowers the boost applied to the next hit by one step. This buff features a visual effect showing one to three "beetles" flying around the player, showing the strength of the damage reduction boost currently in effect.
Leaf could refer to:

Waterleaf Leaf Block Mahogany Leaf Block (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Living Leaf Wall (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Leafy Jungle Wall (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Leaf Wand Rich Mahogany Leaf Wand (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Leaf Crystal Leaf Blower Leaf Wings Bamboo Leaf (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)
The Tin Bar is an early-game metal bar, used to create the Tin tier of equipment. It can also be placed on the ground, like furniture. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Copper Bar.

The Platinum Crown is a craftable vanity item that can be worn in the Social Helmet inventory slot. It is also one of the crafting materials for the Slime Crown, which is used to spawn the King Slime.
The Gold Crown is its alternate ore counterpart.
The Summoner Emblem is a Hardmode accessory that increases summon damage by 15%. It has a 1/4 (25%) chance to drop from the Wall of Flesh.

The Underground Hallow is a dangerous Hardmode biome, being one of the biomes that spawns when the Wall of Flesh is defeated. It is the underground version of the surface -level Hallow, and appears in the Cavern layer. It operates similarly to the surface Hallow, being comprised of Pearlstone and Pearlsand ; though it spawns different enemies, along with Crystal Shards, a common Hardmode crafting material. Gelatin Crystals can also be found to summon Queen Slime. The Underground Hallow spreads just like its surface counterpart, The Hallow, and similarly will conflict with Corruption and Crimson, as well as their underground variants.
Underground Hallow does not suppress the spawn of other underground and cavern enemies.
All enemies killed in the Underground Hallow have a 1/5 (20%) chance to drop a Soul of Light. In Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), this chance increases to a 9/25 (36%) chance.

(Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Small pockets of Underground Hallow can be created through the breaking of altars, which has a 2/3 (66.67%) chance to convert a single random Stone Block in the world into Pearlstone.
Note: Most characteristics of the surface Hallow apply to the Underground Hallow, with the exception of the enemies that spawn. See The Hallow for more extensive information.

The Nebula Fragment is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist crafting material. It is one of the four Lunar Fragments, dropped from the Nebula Pillar during the Lunar Events in stacks of 12-60 / 24-100. Nebula Fragments can be used to craft Nebula armor, an end-game armor set that benefits all types of magic weapons, as well as Nebula-themed tools, weapons, wings, etc.

Crafting all items requires 121 Nebula Fragments and 68 Luminite Bars (272 Luminite), which necessitates defeating the Nebula Pillar at least 3-11 / 2-8 times (note that the Nebula Fragment can also be crafted from the other fragments) and fighting the Moon Lord at least 4 / 3-4 times.
