It has slightly higher attack than the plain Wooden Sword but requires going to a rather dangerous area, especially for new characters who would be interested in upgrading from their Copper Shortsword.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Background walls, also just known as walls, are tiles that create backgrounds on top of biome backgrounds. Walls are hidden behind everything else, such as blocks. Some types of walls are naturally generated at world creation, being abundant in certain biomes like the Underground Jungle. They are one of the main components a Terraria world consists of alongside blocks and liquids. The player can also place walls manually on any tile which does not already contain a wall, given that it is adjacent to another wall or block. Walls can be removed with a hammer or explosives.

The Tungsten Bow is a strong, mid-tier bow crafted solely using Tungsten Bars. Like other bows, it uses arrows as ammo. It does not convert used arrows into special arrows.Its alternate ore counterpart is the Silver Bow.

Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.

The Hellhound is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during wave 3 of the Pumpkin Moon event. Hellhounds follow the Unicorn AI and run and leap towards the player to deal contact damage; the player will be barely able to outrun them with boots or similar movement accessories, thus attacking them while out of their reach is important while fighting them.
Defeating a Hellhound during the Pumpkin Moon event will add (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 5 / 10 / 15 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 4 points to the final score.
The Hellhound requires 100 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.
Rainbow Brick Walls are Hardmode background walls crafted from Rainbow Bricks. Like Rainbow Bricks, they continuously change color.

The Lunar Portal Staff is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord sentry summon weapon. It can summon the Lunar Portal sentry, which lasts for 10 minutes, remains stationary, and does not count against the player's minion capacity. When summoned, the Lunar Portal continuously fires cyan beams that sweep across enemies within its 60-tile range, piercing through an unlimited number of enemies but unable to pass through tiles. The Lunar Portal Staff has a 2/9 (22.22%) chance of being dropped by the Moon Lord.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Lunar Portal Staff has over a Ruthless one is knockback.

The Grapefruit is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Forest tree.
Like all other food items, the Grapefruit can be placed on a Plate :

The Anti-Gravity Hook is a Hardmode, post- Golem grappling hook that fires up to three hooks which reach 31.25 tiles at maximum. When any hook latches onto a block, the player will be pushed 12 blocks away from the latch point if there is room to do so. While latched to a block, the player can use the movement keys to orbit around the latch point, or reposition themselves if they are caught between two or three latch points; however, they will return to the farthest point when they let go of the movement keys.
The Anti-Gravity Hook has a 1/800 (0.13%) chance of being dropped from all basic enemies during the Martian Madness event.

The Celestial Stone is a Hardmode post- Golem accessory crafted from a Moon Stone and a Sun Stone at the Tinkerer's Workshop. It offers the same boosts as its components do, and as such, it is active during both day and night. It can be combined with the Moon Shell to form a Celestial Shell (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Stat boosts:
+10% melee speed +10% damage (all types) +2% critical strike chance +1 HP/s life regeneration +4 defense +15% mining speed +0.5 summon knockback

The Sea Snail is a rare pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Ocean. The Sea Snail's spawn rate is the lowest of all enemies in the Ocean, one-third that of Squids. It slowly crawls along the seafloor while attempting to deal contact damage. When killed, it drops Purple Mucus, which is used solely to craft Purple Dye at a Dye Vat.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.

Platinum armor. is a pre-Hardmode armor set. It consists of the Platinum Helmet, Platinum Chainmail, and Platinum Greaves. It takes a total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 75 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 90 Platinum Bars ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 300 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 360 Platinum Ores) to craft a full set.
Its same-tier counterpart is the Gold armor.

The Phoenix Blaster is a pre-Hardmode gun that essentially acts as an upgraded Handgun, featuring increased bullet damage and velocity but slightly less knockback than its predecessor. It is second only to the Musket for base damage among guns available prior to Hardmode, but with more than triple the rate of fire of the Musket, although it does not normally have autofire.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Vicious Penguin is a pre-Hardmode enemy that results from a Penguin that has been corrupted, either by the player using Vicious Powder on it or when a Penguin spawns during a Blood Moon in a Crimson world.

The Cactus Pickaxe is an early-game pickaxe. Like other low-tier pickaxes, it can only mine blocks and ores weaker than Meteorite (which requires a pickaxe with at least 50% pickaxe power, e.g. a Tungsten Pickaxe).
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

Fossil armor is a pre-Hardmode armor set consisting of the Fossil Helmet, Fossil Plate, and Fossil Greaves. The Helmet and Greaves increase ranged critical strike chance by 4% per each, with the Plate increasing ranged damage by 5%, and wearing the full set grants a 20% chance not to consume ammo.
The Fossil armor set is made using 60 Sturdy Fossils.

The Chlorophyte Pickaxe is a Hardmode pickaxe, and is the pickaxe counterpart to the Chlorophyte Drill, having a slower mining speed but longer range and benefiting from mining speed bonuses. It can mine any block except Lihzahrd Bricks.
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

Grox The Great's set are vanity developer items that can be obtained rarely (5% chance) from Treasure Bags dropped from Hardmode bosses (except Queen Slime 's). It is the vanity set made for Grox The Great, one of the programmers who develops Terraria.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Grox The Great's equipment also includes a non-vanity item, which will drop in addition to his clothing set:
Grox The Great's Wings

Crimson Seeds are seeds which can be planted on Dirt Blocks to create Crimson grass, which will then spread The Crimson in all directions. They drop from the Eye of Cthulhu and can be purchased from the Dryad for 5 SC each during a Blood Moon in a world with Crimson. In a world with Corruption, Crimson Seeds can be purchased from the Dryad if she is spoken to in a Hardmode Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Crimson Seeds can be used to farm Vicious Mushrooms and may be used to spread Crimson in Corrupt worlds. In the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, Crimson Seeds cannot be obtained within Corrupt worlds and must instead be brought over from a Crimson world.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Crimson Seeds can also be planted on Mud Blocks to create Crimson Jungle grass.
The Orichalcum Repeater is a Hardmode repeater crafted solely using Orichalcum Bars. It can be auto-fired and is thus easy to use. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Mythril Repeater.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Wandering Eye Fish is a pre-Hardmode enemy that can be spawned by fishing in water during a Blood Moon. When the bobber dips and the player attempts to reel in a fish, a Wandering Eye Fish or another enemy has a chance to spawn within a few tiles of the bobber in place of a fish.

It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades. The Wandering Eye Fish requires 25 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

Rope Coils are consumable mobility items that, when thrown by the player, travel in an arc affected by gravity until striking a block. On making contact, a vertical string of ten pieces of the respective Rope type will be placed, starting from the point of contact and descending until the Rope runs out or makes contact with another block below. Once in place, the Ropes created by a Rope Coil are ordinary Rope items that can be climbed, expanded with other placed Ropes, and collected with a pickaxe or drill.

If a thrown Rope Coil strikes the top of an already placed Rope, it will automatically extend the existing Rope. If the coil cannot extend lower than ten tiles because of an obstacle, the excess Rope pieces will drop as items. If the coil cannot extended at all, the excess Rope will drop as the coil item.
There are no rope coil analogues for chains nor streamers.

Golden Carp are a type of fish which are found extremely rarely by fishing in any biome in the Underground, Cavern and Underworld layers, with the exception of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) the Desert / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) an Ice biome that is Corrupted, Crimsoned, or Hallowed. Unlike most other fish, Golden Carp are not used for crafting. Instead, they have an extraordinarily high sell value of 10 GC.

The Piña Colada is a food item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 20 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Piña Colada can be placed on a Plate :
The Exotic Scimitar is a pre-Hardmode sword that has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped from the Dye Trader.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Enchanted Sundial is a Hardmode furniture item that can be placed. It can be triggered by the ⚷ Open / Activate key or wires, doing so will advance time to sunrise (4:30 AM) the following day. It has a 7-day cooldown period, so once used, it will not be usable again until 7 in-game days have passed (see Notes for details). When the Enchanted Sundial is ready to be used, the dial at the top of its sprite and the sun in the middle will both glow bright yellow. The Enchanted Sundial is obtained from fished Pearlwood (1/200 (0.5%) chance), Mythril (1/60 (1.67%) chance), and Titanium Crates (1/20 (5%) chance).

The Enchanted Sundial does not turn the time to the next day immediately. It instead "fast-forwards" time, causing it to pass 60 times faster than usual (1 hour of in-game time, which would usually take 1 minute of real-life time, takes only 1 second while the Enchanted Sundial is active). When the Enchanted Sundial is taking effect, the effect of other time-accelerating methods (bed and Journey Mode Time Menu) will be ignored. However, unlike these methods, the Enchanted Sundial does not increase tile update rate in world, meaning that things like plant growth and biome spread is unaffected when it is active.
The Enchanted Moondial is its night counterpart, allowing the player to advance time to dusk (7:30 PM) of the current or following day.

Throwing weapons or thrown weapons historically refer to consumable ranged weapons. They are used in medium-ranged combat, and stack in a player's inventory, with one unit being removed from the stack every time it is used to attack, leaving the slot empty when the last has been used. Many consumable ranged weapons have a chance of being retrievable after being used.

The Brand of the Inferno is a Hardmode sword that has a 1/4 (25%) chance of inflicting the Hellfire debuff for five seconds upon hitting enemies and also allows the player to "parry" incoming damage while equipped with a shield.

While holding the Brand of the Inferno with any equipped shield (excluding the Huntress's Buckler), pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button will cause the player to raise the shield and brace for the next attack. When timed correctly, just before taking a hit, the enemy's attack will be parried, which negates the contact damage being dealt to the player, deals 200% of the contact damage of the attacking enemy, inflicts a knockback value of 5 (Average), and grants the player 30 invincibility frames (60 with the Cross Necklace equipped). Successfully parrying an attack also grants the Striking Moment buff, causing the next melee-based attack to deal 500% or five times its usual base damage for the next five seconds. Alternatively, if the shield is held in place, 20 defense is temporarily gained; this lasts until the shield is once again lowered.
The Brand of the Inferno is dropped by Ogres during the Old One's Army event, with a 1/10 (10%) / 1/5 (20%) chance during Tier 2, and a 1/20 (5%) chance during Tier 3.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Events (some also known as invasions) are temporary occasions where varieties of special enemies spawn, most at elevated spawn rates, even near NPCs, and attack players. Some events can occur randomly during gameplay, while others can be triggered via certain summoning items or special circumstances. Events spawn their own unique enemies not seen during ordinary gameplay, which can, in turn, drop unique items that are only obtainable within the event. Some events also bring unique visuals and a unique atmosphere, such as an altered moon and noticeable shaders applied to the screen. Events also are accompanied by their own special music, adding on to their theme. Depending on the particular event, they may last until a certain time limit is reached, or until a certain number of enemies are defeated.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, a progress bar can be seen in the bottom right corner of the screen to indicate how far the player has gone into the event, and how far they are from completing it. It only appears during invasion-style events (Goblin Army, Old One's Army (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Frost Legion, Pirate Invasion, Pumpkin Moon, Frost Moon, and Martian Madness (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) and will not appear during events that are time-limited (Blood Moon, Rain, Slime Rain (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Sandstorm (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Solar Eclipse).

Note that certain invasions (Goblin Army, Frost Legion, Pirate Invasion, and Martian Madness) have location requirements. The player must be no deeper than 67.5 tiles below the surface, and the player must be within 187.5 tiles horizontally of the location of the invasion. If the invasion has reached the center of the world, then the horizontal check can also be satisfied by the player being within 187.5 tiles horizontally of any town NPC, although at a reduced spawn rate. The town NPC's vertical position is not checked and so they can be housed far above or below the arena.
There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 19 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 8 different events and invasions.
The Party (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and the Lantern Night (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are the only events that do not spawn unique enemies nor play special music.

The Mushroom set is a vanity set consisting of the Mushroom Hat, Mushroom Vest, and Mushroom Pants. All three pieces have a 1/2 (50%) chance of being found in Mushroom Chests in underground Glowing Mushroom biomes.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Amber is a gem. It can be obtained by placing Silt, Slush, or Desert Fossil into an Extractinator, or by searching through Underground Deserts.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, they can be crafted into their Stone Block forms at a Heavy Work Bench in a Graveyard biome, and can be obtained by cutting down an Amber Gem Tree. They also have a 2/7 (28.57%) chance to be dropped by Geodes.
Like all other gems, Amber can be placed on blocks.

Presents are a furniture item which were dropped by Present Mimics during Christmas. Once placed, they would not show up (due to the lack of a placed Present sprite in the game files), and instead, normal Present loot is dropped directly on the player.
Bows are a type of ranged weapon that fire arrows as ammunition. Unlike repeaters, the majority of bows are not capable of autofire, especially those obtainable in pre-Hardmode.
All bows will benefit from the bonuses of the Archery Potion, Magic Quiver and its upgrades, and the Shroomite Headgear.
The best modifier for bows is Unreal, with the exception of the Wooden Bow and early ore bows, whose lack of knockback make their best modifier Demonic or Rapid instead.
Fragment Bricks are Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist bricks that are crafted from Lunar Fragments. They can be used to craft Solar, Vortex, Nebula, and Stardust furniture.
The Pearlstone Block is a Hardmode block type found in The Hallow. It requires at least a Nightmare Pickaxe, Deathbringer Pickaxe, or explosives to mine.

Pearlstone is the Hallow version of Stone (similar to Ebonstone in The Corruption, or Crimstone in The Crimson). In a way similar to Ebonstone and Crimstone, Pearlstone can be converted into ordinary Stone via Vile Powder, Vicious Powder, or the Clentaminator with the Green Solution.

During the initial creation of the Hallow biome upon the defeat of the Wall of Flesh, Stone blocks in the conversion path become Pearlstone blocks (see Hardmode). Pearlstone itself also continues to spread Hallow to all Stone, Sand, Ice, and Grass covered dirt within a three tile radius. Over time, it will grow Crystal Shards if it is in the Underground or below.

The Flask of Cursed Flames is a Hardmode flask that causes melee weapons and whips (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) to inflict the Cursed Inferno debuff for 3-6 seconds on enemies hit. Melee weapons that fire projectiles will also inflict the debuff on enemies hit by the projectiles (except for the Flairon 's bubbles).

The Flask of Cursed Flames cannot be used in conjunction with other flasks, and using it will remove any existing flask effects. (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Like all other flasks, the effect will not be canceled when the player dies.
The Flask of Cursed Flames will inflict the Cursed Flames debuff in PvP scenarios.

The Resplendent Dessert is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that is a combination of the Royal Delight from King Slime and the Regal Delicacy from Queen Slime, allowing the player to summon both the Slime Prince and Slime Princess at the same time.

The Boreal Crate is a Hardmode crate that can only be fished in the Snow and Ice biome. Boreal Crates contain items found in standard crates, and always contain one item normally found in Frozen Chests. Its pre-Hardmode counterpart is the Frozen Crate.

Blue Acid Dye is a dye acquired as a random reward from the Dye Trader for giving him a Strange Plant. When equipped in a dye slot, it applies a dark blue rippling effect that pulses outward, similar to Acid Dye and Red Acid Dye. Items dyed by it can be seen in the dark, but do not emit light.
Bone furniture are furniture items crafted from Bones, at a Bone Welder. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 19 / 16 different Bone furniture items.
The Skull Lantern is crafted from Bone and could arguably be considered the Candle of the Bone furniture set.

The Yellow Horseshoe Balloon is an accessory that grants immunity to fall damage, increases jump height by 75%, grants a double-jump, and grants +0.05 luck (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The height of the first jump is increased from 6 blocks to 10.5 blocks, while the double-jump's height is increased from 15 blocks to 26.5 blocks, reaching a total of 37 blocks with both jumps.
Jump height is instead reduced by 15% when underwater, reducing total underwater jump height from 27 blocks (8 + 19 from Sandstorm jump) to 22 blocks (7 + 15 from Sandstorm jump).

The Mango is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Rich Mahogany tree.
Like all other food items, the Mango can be placed on a Plate :
Confetti is a crafting material used to make several festive items. It is also used as ammunition for the Confetti Cannon. It is purchased from the Party Girl for 2 SC each.
The Sea Turtle is a critter that appears in the Ocean biome, swimming in the water and crawling slowly on land.
The Sea Turtle has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.
Unlike most critters, the Sea Turtle cannot be caught with a Bug Net, which means there is no craftable cage for it.

Candles are a type of furniture and light source. Candles can be placed on Tables, Platforms, Crates or Work Benches. Candles will produce light underwater if placed and can be toggled on and off by mechanisms.

Certain types of candles provide buffs or debuffs. The Water Candle is a special type of candle found in Dungeons which increases enemy spawn rates by 33% and the maximum number of simultaneous on-screen enemies by 50% when placed or held, and can be turned off ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)). The Peace Candle reduces spawn rates by 23% in the area and decreases the maximum number of simultaneous on-screen enemies by 30%, in contrast to the Water Candle. The Shadow Candle (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) nullifies the enemy spawn reduction benefits of towns in the area. For Water Candles and Peace Candles, multiple placed candles cannot stack, but the bonuses from holding and placing a candle do.

The Tin Axe is an early game axe, and is weaker than the Iron or Lead Axe. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Copper Axe. Like all axes, it is used to cut down trees, Cacti, Giant Glowing Mushrooms, and Fallen Logs (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The First Fractal is an unobtainable melee weapon that was originally supposed to be the new endgame sword for 1.4.0.1, but the concept was discarded during development. Its place is now taken by Zenith, though this item is still in Terraria 's code. It strongly resembles the Terra Blade.

Using the weapon summons projectiles that resemble copies of the player (with all dyes removed) holding one of 15 different sprite variations of the sword in a flying barrage of attacks that follow the cursor. When there are enemies nearby, the weapon automatically targets them instead, ignoring the cursor position.
It cannot be reforged in-game. Using inventory editors, its best modifier is Unreal, since size bonuses have no impact on the projectile.
Sandfall Wall is one of only a few animated background walls. It depicts falling sand.
The Yellow Cockatiel and Gray Cockatiel are critters that spawn in the Jungle during the daytime.
Cockatiels have only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

Cockatiels can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Yellow / Gray Cockatiel Cage). Once crafted, the Cockatiels cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Cockatiels can be spawned by the Cockatiel Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.

The Monster Lasagna is a food item that grants the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 8 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Monster Lasagna can be placed on a Plate :

Striking Moment is a buff granted when the ⚷ Open / Activate is pressed when holding the Brand of the Inferno or the Sergeant United Shield to successfully block an enemy attack with a shield accessory equipped, right before damage is taken. Striking an enemy with a melee weapon within 5 seconds of the block deals five times the usual damage, after which the buff will be removed. This bonus can be used with any melee weapon.

The Lesser Mana Potion is a recovery potion that restores 50 mana when used and inflicts the Mana Sickness debuff upon use. It can be purchased from the Merchant for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1 SC / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 2 SC each, and can also be found in Wooden and Pearlwood Crates obtained from fishing.

Naturally-placed Lesser Mana Potions appear frequently on platforms in the Dungeon (along with Lesser Healing Potions). When encountered in placed form, they function as Placed Bottle crafting stations. They also show the "bottle" tooltip on the map. They can be freed with a pickaxe or ⚷ Open / Activate and retrieved, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and can be placed by the player by crafting them into Decorative Mana Potions.
It is the first tier of mana potion, preceding the Mana Potion, Greater Mana Potion, and Super Mana Potion.

The Platinum Axe is an early game axe, being stronger than both the Silver and Tungsten Axe, and weaker than both the War Axe of the Night and Blood Lust Cluster. It has an alternative version, the Gold Axe, which is slightly weaker. Like all axes, it is used to cut down trees, cacti, and Giant Glowing Mushrooms.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

Bookcases are a type of furniture and crafting station used for the crafting of three Hardmode magic weapons : the Crystal Storm, Cursed Flames, and Golden Shower. Bookcases also fulfill a house 's flat surface item requirement.

There are currently 41 types of Bookcases: 35 craftable Bookcases, and 6 looted from the environment: one from the Underworld, four from the Dungeon, and one from the Pirate Invasion. Some bookcases can also be found in Underground Cabins ; their style follows the theme of the cabin where they are found.

Chests contain different loots depending on where it is, generated during the world generation, this page lists all of them.
Most chests contains a "primary" loot, that is always one item from a pool, then "secondary" loot that consists of rare items, then "common" loot that depends on the depth of the chest.

The Grapes are a Hardmode food item that grant the Plenty Satisfied buff when consumed. This lasts for 16 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The Grapes have a 1/40 (2.5%) chance of being dropped by Derplings and Giant Flying Foxes.
Like all other food items, the Grapes can be placed on a Plate :

Tissue Samples are a crafting material dropped from Creepers and found in the Brain of Cthulhu 's Treasure Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). They can be used in conjunction with Crimtane Bars to create Crimtane tools and the Crimson armor set.
A total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 126 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 61 Tissue Samples are required to craft one of each item.

The Nazar is a post- Skeletron immunity accessory that grants the player immunity to the Cursed debuff. It has a 1/100 (1%) / 1/50 (2%) chance to drop from Cursed Skulls, Giant Cursed Skulls ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)), Dragon Skulls (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), Cursed Hammers, Crimson Axes, and Enchanted Swords.
It is one of the ingredients of the Countercurse Mantra, which is a crafting material required to make the Ankh Charm, an accessory which can be further crafted into the Ankh Shield.

The Ironskin Potion is a buff potion which grants the Ironskin buff when consumed. The buff increases the player's defense by 8, thus reducing damage by 4 / 6 / 8. This lasts for 8 minutes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 5 minutes (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.
In addition to being crafted, Ironskin Potions can be found in pots, chests, and crates, (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) and have a small chance to appear as a bonus drop from slimes.

Copper Brick is a type of Brick and an aesthetic building material. Like the ore used to make it, placed Copper Bricks will sparkle. As copper becomes fairly useless quite early in the game, this is an inexpensive ore brick to build with. Despite being made of Copper, it has no sell value, as with most other bricks. Copper Plating is also available as a decorative block, with the same ingredients and color but a different texture.

The Seahorse is a critter that spawns in the Ocean. They occasionally move in water by swimming in bursts at random directions. The Seahorse has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Seahorse can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Seahorse Cage). Once crafted, the Seahorse cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
There is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Seahorse to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

The Golem Fist is a Hardmode, post- Golem flail that fires a large stone fist attached to a chain that retracts on impact, similar to the one Golem uses. It fires forward at a rapid rate, similar to the KO Cannon and Harpoon. Firing at closer targets causes its fire rate to increase. The Golem Fist has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/7 (14.29%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped by Golem.

The Golem Fist has a very short cooldown period; therefore its auto-fire rate is dependent only on the distance to its impact, meaning that an enemy or object in close range will cause a faster autofire rate.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Artery is a pre-Hardmode yoyo that can be crafted from Crimtane Bars. It has slightly more damage and reach than its Corruption counterpart, the Malaise, but has slightly lower knockback and duration.
It has a spin duration of 6 seconds and can reach up to 13 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Spectre Paint Roller is a tool which is used to paint walls, much like the regular Paint Roller sold by the Painter. The advantage over its predecessor is the Spectre Paint Roller's increased range of +3 tiles.
The Spectre Paint Roller cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.
The Silver Bar is an early-game metal bar, used to create the Silver tier of equipment. Its alternate ore version is the Tungsten Bar. It can also be placed on the ground, like furniture.

Crafting all items (excluding bullets) requires (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 151 / (Old-gen console version) 159 / (3DS version) 141 Silver Bars; this translates to (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 604 / (Old-gen console version) 636 / (3DS version) 564 Silver Ore.
Armored Bones may refer to skeletal enemies found in the Dungeon:
Rusty Armored Bones Blue Armored Bones Hell Armored Bones

The Solar Brick is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist brick that is crafted from Solar Fragments. It is one of the four Fragment Bricks, bricks which are crafted with Lunar Fragments. It can be used to craft Solar furniture.
Red's Throw is a Hardmode, Expert Mode -exclusive yoyo that can be obtained from any Hardmode boss 's Treasure Bag (except Queen Slime 's) as part of Red's set.
It has an infinite spin duration and can reach up to 23 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Pressure Plate Tracks are activation mechanisms that work similarly to Pressure Plates and are activated while riding over with a Minecart. They can be crafted using any type of Pressure Plate.

The Lead Bar is an early-game metal bar created from Lead Ore which is normally found in the Cavern and Underground layers, used to create the Lead tier of equipment, along with many other items. It can also be placed on the ground, like furniture. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Iron Bar.

The Jungle is a surface biome composed primarily of grass, vines, Mud, Jungle Trees, Bamboo (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and pools of water, with a dark green background. Jungle trees grow automatically on Jungle grass found there, though traditional Acorns can also be planted. The Underground Jungle is found just below the Jungle, beginning at cavern depths.

The Jungle is one of the more challenging surface biomes, especially for those just entering Hardmode. Jungle enemies have much more health and deal more damage than those typically found in other surface areas.

Players can seed new Jungle areas by planting Jungle Grass Seeds in Mud Blocks. Jungle grass spreads much more slowly than ordinary grass. A Jungle biome requires a minimum of 140 Jungle-related tiles, this includes Jungle Grass blocks, Jungle plants, Lihzahrd Bricks, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Hive blocks.

The Jungle becomes substantially harder during Hardmode. Additionally, there is a danger that the Jungle can be completely overtaken by the spread of Corruption / Crimson once Hardmode has been in effect for some time, making essential Jungle items more difficult to acquire. Defeating Plantera will slow down the spread of Corruption/Crimson and Hallow to 50% of their original speed.
Butterfly Dust is a rare Hardmode crafting material used solely to craft Butterfly Wings. It has a 1/2 (50%) chance of being dropped by Moths in the Underground Jungle.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, at least one mechanical boss must be defeated before it will drop.
Thanksgiving is a seasonal event that lasts from November 1st through November 30th, based on the player's device's date setting.
During Thanksgiving, the Cursed stuffing and Turkey feather can be sacrificed to summon Turkor the Ungrateful, a pre-Hardmode boss.

Counterweights are accessories sold by the Traveling Merchant and the Skeleton Merchant. They fire a second yoyo-type projectile after hitting an enemy with a yoyo, dealing the same damage of the yoyo and traveling towards it, then arcing over the player.
There are 6 variants, all functioning identically.

The Holly is a decorative item resembling an Advent wreath, a typical Christmas ornament. It can be placed on a background wall, similar to paintings. It is dropped from Presents obtained during the Christmas event, with a chance of 9.001% in pre-Hardmode and 8.401% in Hardmode.

The Ogre's Club is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that spawns a Baby Ogre to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Baby Ogre will hold onto an Etherian Wyvern by its tail in order to catch up to them. The Ogre's Club has a 1/4 (25%) chance of dropping from the Ogre in Master Mode.

The Mana Regeneration Band is an accessory item made by combining a Band of Starpower and a Band of Regeneration at a Tinkerer's Workshop. It somewhat combines the effects of both bands, increasing a player's maximum mana and converting the bonus health regeneration provided by the Band of Regeneration into mana regeneration.

The Pot o' Gold was a pet -summoning item used to summon Leprechaun o'Fyffe. The Leprechaun had a chance to drop coins when it jumped. It usually dropped Copper Coins, but had a chance to sometimes drop Silver, Gold, or even Platinum Coins. The 5 Rainbow Pieces needed to craft it used to fall from the sky during the St. Patrick's Day season.

The Poltergeist is a Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that begins to spawn during (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) wave 4 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) wave 5 of the Pumpkin Moon event. It behaves similarly to a Wraith, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) except it can fly freely through the air without needing solid ground to hover on.
Defeating a Poltergeist during the Pumpkin Moon event will add (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10 / 20 / 25 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 8 points to the final score.
The Poltergeist requires 100 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Banana is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Palm tree or its Corrupt, Crimson, or Hallowed variant in the Ocean biome.
Like all other food items, the Banana can be placed on a Plate :
Wands are magic weapons that fire projectiles at the cost of mana instead of ammunition. Wands function the same as Magic Guns and Spell Books, but they appear as wands or staves.
Their best modifier is generally Mythical.

The Anti-Portal Block is a Hardmode block that prevents portals made from the Portal Gun to form. This can be useful for map makers who want to make some places inaccessible by portals. They are purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 1 SC each.

The Gravity Globe is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord accessory that allows the holder to flip gravity, so that the player falls up instead of down, and toggle gravity back to normal afterward. Once equipped, pressing the ▲ Up key toggles the gravity direction. This only affects the player with the item equipped. The Gravity Globe is always dropped from the Moon Lord 's Treasure Bag in Expert Mode.

The Blackcurrant is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Ebonwood or Ebonwood Palm tree.
Like all other food items, the Blackcurrant can be placed on a Plate :

The Purple Clubberfish is a pre-Hardmode sword that can be obtained by fishing in the Corruption with a 1/10 (10%) chance with 100 Fishing Power, up to a maximum 1/4 (25%) chance with 300 Fishing Power.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Emerald Robe is an armor item that can be worn in the shirt slot. It is part of the Wizard set and is the fourth strongest type of gem robe.

Wearing the Wizard Hat alongside the Emerald Robe provides a set bonus of +10% magic critical strike chance, whereas wearing a Magic Hat alongside it provides a set bonus of +60 mana. Any leg-slot equipment can be worn with these set bonuses remaining intact.

The Slime Staff is a pre-Hardmode summon weapon that summons a Baby Slime minion. The Baby Slime attacks by bouncing on the ground and chasing enemies, rapidly dealing contact damage. If the player is far away, the Baby Slime will fly with wings to catch up with them. Like other minions, the summoned Baby Slime is invincible and follows the player until they die, summon a replacement minion, cancel the buff, or leave the world.

The Slime Staff generally has the rarest drop chance of any weapon, with minor exceptions. The typical drop rate from most slimes and Slimed Zombies is 1/10000 (0.01%) / 1/7000 (0.0143%). Pinky has a greatly increased drop rate of 1/100 (1%) / 1/70 (1.4286%). Additionally, Sand Slimes have a drop rate of 1/8000 (0.0125%) / 1/5600 (0.0179%). The slimes which cannot drop the Slime Staff are: Shimmer, Golden, Lava, Dungeon, Umbrella, Hoppin' Jack, Corrupt (Shadow (Old-gen console and 3DS versions)), King Slime, Queen Slime, Crimslime, Gastropod (Spectral (Old-gen console and 3DS versions)) and Rainbow.
Unlike other summon weapons, its best possible modifier is Mythical because both the Ruthless and Mythical modifiers only raise its base damage to 9 due to rounding.

The Desert Spirit Lamp is a decorative furniture item and crafting material. It must be placed on a platform or other flat-surface item. It has a 1/40 (2.5%) chance of being dropped from Desert Spirits, which can be encountered in the Corrupted or Crimson Underground Desert.
The Wire Cutter is a tool that allows players to free and harvest Wires and Actuators. It is sold by the Mechanic NPC who is initially found in the Dungeon.
The Wire Cutter has a large range bonus, making it easier to remove wires at a distance.

The Sniper Scope is a Hardmode, post- Golem accessory that provides 10% increased ranged damage and 10% increased ranged critical strike chance. Furthermore, it grants the ability to increase view range while holding a bullet -firing gun by pressing and holding ⚷ Open / Activate and moving the cursor.

The Slice of Cake is a furniture item acquired by being the first player to talk to the Party Girl during a Party that occurred by random chance at dawn. Player-initiated Parties (caused by a Party Center), or the Party initiated at the creation of Celebrationmk10 or Get fixed boi worlds will not cause her to give players the Slice of Cake.

Placing and pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on the Slice of Cake grants the Sugar Rush buff, which grants +20% movement speed and +20% mining speed. This lasts for 2 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.

Unlike equipment buff items, the Slice of Cake must be placed in order to activate the buff. It can be mined with a pickaxe or drill and picked up again, even while the buff is active, which will not cancel the buff. Placement is only dependent on an adequate space of 2x2 tiles being available.

Cursed is a debuff which prevents the player from using any items. The player cannot use any item via ⚒ Use / Attack, ⚷ Open / Activate, Quick Heal, Quick Mana, Quick Buff, Grapple, and Quick Mount. Additionally, upon being inflicted with the debuff, all active hooks, mounts, thrown flails, fishing poles, and kites (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) will be dismissed.
A Nazar, Countercurse Mantra, Ankh Charm or Ankh Shield makes the player immune to this debuff.

The Lizard Egg is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Pet Lizard to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Pet Lizard will sprout wings like those of a Flying Snake to catch up with the player. The Lizard Egg has a 1/1000 (0.1%) chance of being dropped by Flying Snakes and Lihzahrds in the Jungle Temple.

The Tactical Skeleton is a rare Hardmode, post- Plantera enemy that spawns in the Dungeon after Plantera is defeated. Once the player is within its line of sight, the Tactical Skeleton remains stationary before firing volleys of four bullets at them that deal immense damage.
It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades.
Tactical Skeletons spawn most often in areas of the Dungeon backed by tiled walls. They can also spawn in other areas, but with a significantly reduced chance.

The Plaguebringer set is a vanity set consisting of the Plaguebringer's Skull, the Plaguebringer's Cloak, and the Plaguebringer's Treads. It is one of the six sets that were added as part of the Journey's End Vanity Contest ; the original concept was submitted by SodaHunter.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Crafting the set requires materials that can only be found in the Crimson. Its Corruption counterpart is the Timeless Traveler's set.

It is possible for the player to create an artificial Crimson biome in a Corrupt world by purchasing Crimson Seeds from the Dryad in a Graveyard during Hardmode to get the materials necessary to make this set.
When the full set is worn, it displays a special set animation of Cursed Flames emitting from it. The color of the flames will change according to the dye applied to the cloak.

The Predictor is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Nebula Pillar during the Lunar Events. Its main attack is firing five Nebula Piercer projectiles at the player, which travel in a straight line in a tight spread.

Use time is a statistic that applies to weapons, tools and other usable items. It determines the time that must pass, after use, before the same item or another item can be used again. In basic terms, this is the "rate of fire", as measured in game ticks. A lower use time means a faster weapon. The shortswords, for example, usually have a use time between 10 and 13, meaning that they can be used in quick succession, as compared to the exceptionally slow Volcano, which has a use time of 40 - a much slower weapon which cannot be used as often.

Use time is particularly useful in comparing the speed of tools and weapons. The in-game tooltips for these items automatically group these values into categories like "Very fast" or "Very slow". They are grouped as following:

The Mrs. Claus set is a vanity set. It is dropped from Presents obtained during the Christmas event, with a chance of 1.08% in pre-Hardmode and 1.001% in Hardmode. It consists of a Mrs. Claus Hat, Mrs. Claus Shirt and Mrs. Claus Heels. These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Mushroom is a crafting material and healing item that spawns randomly on grass or Hallowed grass located on the surface, generally in the Forest. It can be cut with any tool or weapon in order to retrieve the item.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Mushroom inflicts only 30 seconds of Potion Sickness, only half the duration of healing potions. Even so, it can only heal 30 health every minute, compared to Lesser Healing Potion, which heals 50.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) In The Constant worlds, eating a Mushroom also resets Hunger to 5 minutes of Peckish, if the player is hungry.
The Pirate Corsair is a Hardmode enemy that spawns commonly during the Pirate Invasion. It acts similarly to the Pirate Deckhand, but has slightly higher stats.

The Sandcastle Bucket is a tool that places a decorative sandcastle and consumes one Sand Block upon use. It can be used on all variants of Sand Blocks and platforms, in any biome. Sandcastles are background furniture objects, but they cannot be picked up; using a pickaxe or drill on them destroys them immediately.
The Sandcastle Bucket can be found randomly in Water Chests, Ocean Crates, and Seaside Crates.

When the cursor is moved over a valid block, one out of four sandcastle styles will be selected randomly. Moving the cursor over a different block will produce a different sandcastle preview, so players can choose the particular sandcastle variant they wish to place by moving their cursor back and forth.

The Flying Dragon is a Hardmode, post- Golem sword that fires bright red, crescent-shaped Hearty Slash projectiles once per swing, which travel through solid blocks and produce light. The Hearty Slash projectiles travel for one second and can pierce up to four enemies, dissipating after hitting a fifth one or when it travels in a 60 tile square radius. The Flying Dragon has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by Betsy during Tier 3 of the Old One's Army event.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Writhing Remains is a pet-summoning item that summons a pet Eater of Worms to follow the player around. The Writhing Remains has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by the Eater of Worlds in Master Mode.

The Pumpking is a Hardmode, post- Plantera mini-boss that spawns during the Pumpkin Moon event. He is the event's final enemy and can move freely through blocks. He is the equivalent to the Ice Queen from the Frost Moon, being the Pumpkin Moon's most powerful enemy, coming in at the last waves of the event, and being the event's only flying boss.
Defeating the Pumpking during the Pumpkin Moon event will add 150 / 300 / 375 points to the final score, giving the most number of points for any enemy in the event.

Like the Mourning Wood, the later the Pumpkin Moon wave in which the Pumpking is killed in, the more likely he is to drop items. A Pumpking defeated during wave 15 has a guaranteed chance to drop at least one item from his standard drop table.

The Iron Axe is an early game Axe, stronger than the starting Copper Axe and weaker than the Silver or Tungsten Axe. Like all axes, it is used to cut down trees, cacti and giant glowing mushrooms. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Lead Axe.
It is also obtained upon the creation of a Journey Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) character, as it replaces the Copper Axe.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Worm is a critter that spawns in the Underground layer, or on the surface while it is raining. Worms also have a chance to spawn when the player breaks grass or stone or dirt piles, which causes them to fly out. Breaking larger rocks in the background has a high possibility of releasing worms. Worms can also be easily obtained by opening a Can Of Worms. The Worm has only 5 health and no defense, and can be damaged by other enemies and players.

The Worm can be caught with any Bug Net to be carried around in the inventory and released later, or crafted into animated decorative furniture (Worm Cage). Once crafted, the Worm cannot be released again, unless the furniture item is de-crafted via Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
The Worm can be used as bait for fishing, with 25% bait power.
The Worm can be spawned by the Worm Statue, however statue-spawned critters cannot be caught with any Bug Net, and will disappear in a puff of smoke when the player attempts to do so.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, there is a 1/400 (0.25%) chance for a Gold Worm to spawn in place of an ordinary one.

The Radio Thing is a vanity accessory that activates a sepia screen shader effect identical to that of The Constant world seed in normal worlds. In The Constant seed, it will instead cancel out the screen effect, granting the player normal visuals. The accessory functions in both the ordinary inventory slots and vanity accessory slots. The Radio Thing has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of being dropped by Deerclops.

Ghouls are Hardmode Underground Desert enemies who follow the Fighter AI (behaving similarly to Zombies). Ordinary Ghouls spawn inside the normal Underground Desert, the Vile Ghoul inside Corrupt parts of the Underground Desert, the Tainted Ghoul inside Crimson parts of the Underground Desert, and the Dreamer Ghoul inside Hallowed parts of the Underground Desert.

Coin Piles are background objects created when the player places a Copper, Silver, Gold, or Platinum Coin on the ground. They are for decorative purposes only. Only one coin is needed to create a pile (which occupies 1 tile,), but additional coins can be added to increase the pile size. Coin Piles can, like other furniture, be destroyed with a pickaxe or a drill. This allows a player to pick up the coins again.
Coin piles are capable of rarely generating underground, specifically in the Campsite and Mosaic micro-biomes.
Ancient Obsidian Brick is a type of brick obtained by throwing Obsidian Brick into Shimmer. Its appearance is based on the sprite of Obsidian Brick prior to 1.2.
Settings are a set of gameplay options available from the game's main menu, the pause menu, or the inventory screen.

The Parrot Cracker is a Hardmode pet-summoning item that summons a pet Parrot which follows the player around. If the player stays still for long enough, it will perch on a nearby solid block, staying still until the player moves away from it. The Parrot Cracker can be purchased from the Pirate for 3 PC 75 GC if he is spoken to in an Ocean biome.

The Chain Knife is a pre-Hardmode flail that throws a knife-like projectile attached to a chain. It only extends a short distance of 12 tiles, though its quick use time and velocity may make it a good early to mid-game weapon. It has a 1/250 (0.4%) chance of being dropped by a Cave Bat.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

Traps are placed items that cause harm to players and enemies. Most are mechanisms that are naturally generated underground and below. When found initially, they are wired to triggers, such as Pressure Plates, intended to harm players who inadvertently activate them. Traps can be collected by players and utilized in arenas, and are usually essential to battling events like the Pumpkin Moon and Frost Moon.

The Spike and Wooden Spike are exceptions, as they are not mechanisms, but static placed items that simply cause damage on contact. The Land Mine is a trap-like item, though never generates naturally, and is instead purchasable during Hardmode.

All traps, including their triggers, are illuminated by the Dangersense buff, allowing the player to avoid and collect them. Their wiring can also be seen if the player holds a mechanism -related item in their hand, for instance a pressure plate. The player can also see wires even in darkness if they have a Mechanical Lens (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or Grand Design (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) in their inventory.
All damaging traps (except the Land Mine) can only deal 50% base damage to enemies from the Old One's Army (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) event.

Corrupt Seeds are seeds which can be planted on Dirt Blocks to create Corrupt grass, which will then spread The Corruption in all directions. They drop from the Eye of Cthulhu and can be purchased from the Dryad for 5 SC each during a Blood Moon in a world with Corruption. In a world with Crimson, Corrupt Seeds can be purchased from the Dryad if she is spoken to in a Hardmode Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

Corrupt Seeds can be used to farm Vile Mushrooms and may be used to spread Corruption in Crimson worlds. In the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, Corrupt Seeds cannot be obtained within Crimson worlds and must instead be brought over from a Corrupt world.
On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Corrupt Seeds can also be planted on Mud Blocks to create Corrupt Jungle grass.

The Midnight Confetti Block is an animated block type showing falling confetti. It is one of the few items that uses the Crystal Ball as a crafting station. It is a dark, non-transparent version of the Confetti Block.
Cryocore Brick is a type of decorative brick obtained by throwing Luminite Brick into Shimmer during a First Quarter.

When a player is within the range of a boss or mini-boss, a red health bar will appear on their screen that represents the boss' total remaining health. On the Desktop version and Console version, the bar is displayed at the bottom of the player's screen, while on the Mobile version, it is displayed below the minimap. When there are multiple bosses in the player's range, only the most recent boss that had been damaged or the closest one in proximity to the player will be shown.

The boss health bar also has a togglable option that enables a numeric display for boss health called "Boss Health Bar Numbers" in the settings. The maximum and remaining health of the boss will be shown on the bar when the option is on.
The Frozen Turtle Shell is a Hardmode accessory that grants the Ice Barrier buff when equipped, with the effects varying between versions:

(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Gives 25% damage reduction as long as their health remains at or below 50%. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) Gives the player 30 defense when below 25% health.

While not normally visible, it displays as a small blue circle spinning around the character that emits light when active. The Frozen Turtle Shell has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/50 (2%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/100 (1%) chance of being dropped by Ice Tortoises in the Ice biome.

The Evolution Beast is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Nebula Pillar during the Lunar Events. It attacks by shooting a slow, homing Nebula Sphere and attempting to ram the player.

Waterleaf Seeds are a type of seed that can be obtained from harvesting Waterleaves while they are blooming or using the Staff of Regrowth on naturally grown Waterleaves while they are fully grown. On the Desktop version, Console version, Old-gen console version, and Mobile version, a Waterleaf plant only blooms during Rain, whereas on the Nintendo 3DS version, it only blooms when submerged in water. Each plant drops 1-3 Waterleaf Seeds when harvested while blooming.

Waterleaf Seeds can be placed on Sand and Pearlsand Blocks, empty Clay Pots, or any types of Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), even inside water or honey, and will grow into harvestable Waterleaves. They will grow anywhere, not just in the Desert, but will only yield seeds when blooming.

Specular Fish are a type of fish that are commonly found by fishing in a Forest, Jungle or Snow biome in the Underground, Cavern, and Underworld layers. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners, Recall Potions, and Wormhole Potions.

The Ichor Arrow is a Hardmode arrow that inflicts the Ichor debuff for 10 seconds (except in PvP). It can be considered the Crimson counterpart to Cursed Arrows, which inflict the Cursed Inferno debuff. Ichor Arrows are destroyed when fired and therefore are never recoverable.

Moonglow is a type of herb which appears as a bent stalk with a drooping blue-white flower. It grows naturally on regular Jungle grass. Moonglow can be harvested with virtually any weapon or tool, and can be planted manually using Moonglow Seeds in Clay Pots and Planter Boxes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), or on suitable soil tiles.

Moonglow blooms during nighttime (7:30 PM to 4:29 AM). Its blooming is indicated by the blue flower and blue-white light particles emitted. Harvesting blooming Moonglow yields 1 Moonglow item and 1-3 Moonglow Seeds. Harvesting mature or blooming Moonglow with the Staff of Regrowth or Axe of Regrowth (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) yields 1-2 Moonglows and 1-5 Moonglow Seeds instead. Note that these tools can only directly harvest mature stage herbs planted on soil ; see Herbs § Growth for details.
Both Moonglow and Moonglow Seeds have a chance to be obtained from the Herb Bag (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).

The Rich Mahogany Chest is a chest found only in Underground Cabins within the Jungle and Underground Jungle biomes. Like Granite Chests and Marble Chests, Rich Mahogany Chests have exactly the same loot as Gold Chests.
The Worm Scarf is a pre-Hardmode accessory that reduces incoming damage by 17%. This damage reduction from this item is calculated after defense is applied:
Damage taken = (Raw damage - (Defense * (0.5 or 0.75 or 1 for Classic/Expert/Master Mode, respectively))) * (1 -.17)
The Worm Scarf is always dropped from the Eater of Worlds ' Treasure Bag in Expert Mode.

Ninja armor or Ninja set is an armor / vanity set made up of the Ninja Hood, Ninja Shirt and Ninja Pants. King Slime drops each piece separately (1 per kill with a 1/3 (33.33%) chance each), or two pieces from the Treasure Bag it drops in Expert Mode. On the Nintendo 3DS version, pieces of the Ninja set can also be acquired from Lepus, but with only a 3% chance.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it provides very little defense, but increases crit chance and movement speed. On the Nintendo 3DS version, it provides no defense, but does have throwing weapon bonuses listed in its stats. However, it does not provide the bonuses listed, and throwing damage is not a separate damage type in these versions. On the Old-gen console version, it is merely a vanity item and will provide no bonuses or defense.
In all versions though, having the full set equipped grants an after-image movement effect, similar to Shadow, Necro, and Cobalt armors.

The Turtle Shell is a Hardmode crafting material that has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/12 (8.33%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/17 (5.88%) chance of being dropped by Giant Tortoises in the Jungle and Underground Jungle.

Turtle Shells are used solely to craft Turtle armor, which can in turn be used to craft Beetle armor. Crafting all pieces of Turtle armor or Beetle armor requires a total of 3 Turtle Shells. Crafting a set of Beetle armor with both chest variants requires 4 Turtle Shells.

The Pirate Crossbower is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Pirate Invasion event. She fires Flaming Arrows every few seconds, which deal high damage and have a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of inflicting the On Fire! debuff for 7 / 14 / 17.5 seconds.
The Bedazzled Nectar is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Glittery Butterfly pet to follow the player around. The Bedazzled Nectar has a chance of being sold by the Traveling Merchant for 1 PC.

The Keybrand is a Hardmode, post- Plantera sword. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it deals increased damage against previously injured enemies. Upon hitting enemies that have less than 10% health remaining, the Keybrand deals a maximum of 150% additional damage for a total of 250%, as well as causing a sparkling visual effect upon damaging an enemy. The Keybrand also has a 20% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%. The Keybrand has a 1/200 (0.5%) / 399/40000 (1%) chance of being dropped by Blue Armored Bones, Hell Armored Bones, and Rusty Armored Bones in the post-Plantera Dungeon.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Groom is a rare pre-Hardmode enemy and a Zombie variant that spawns during a Blood Moon or very rarely at any time in a Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) biome. He acts the same as normal Zombies, slowly walking towards the player to deal contact damage, while attempting to navigate around obstacles and opening doors if they are in the way. He has greater health than most other Zombies, and is dressed in a tuxedo and top hat.
He does not have any variants, nor does he have an Armed variation in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). The Bride (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is his marriage counterpart.

He is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades. The Groom requires 10 kills to be awarded completion of his Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Announcement Box is a special sign that, when powered, will announce (in the chat) what was written on the sign. They support the usage of tags, allowing (for example) the display of messages in different colors.

The Mini Nuke I is a type of rocket ammunition. Unlike the Mini Nuke II, it does not destroy tiles. It is a direct upgrade to the Rocket III, dealing more damage over a larger blast radius, but with lower knockback.
The Ice Brick is a brick type made from Ice Blocks. It does not have the sliding properties of ice, nor does it cause snow to fall like Snow Bricks.

Feral Claws are an accessory that increases melee attack speed by 12%, and stacks with all other attack speed boosts. Feral Claws can be found in Jungle Crates, Bramble Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Ivy Chests located in Jungle Shrines and at the base of a Living Mahogany Tree in the Underground Jungle.
(Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) In addition to increasing melee attack speed, Feral Claws give autoswing to all melee weapons and Whips.
The Marble Chest is a chest storage item found only in Underground Cabins within Marble Caves. Like Granite Chests and Rich Mahogany Chests, Marble Chests have exactly the same loot as Gold Chests.

Liquid bombs are explosive items which either place or remove liquids instead of solid blocks when exploding. There are four different types of liquid bombs: Dry Bomb, Wet Bomb, Lava Bomb, and Honey Bomb.

When a liquid bomb is used, it will be tossed onto the ground and explode after a 3-second fuse, applying its special effect (see below). If, however, the bomb touches any liquid, it will immediately explode and apply its effects. All liquid bombs deal damage to nearby players, enemies, and critters.

Wet Bombs are obtainable by opening Obsidian or Hellstone Crates found by fishing in lava. If the player is carrying a Wet Bomb, the Demolitionist will sell Wet Bombs for 25 SC each. Purchasing more Wet Bombs will allow the player to craft the other variants (see below). The Demolitionist will also sell the three other types of bombs for the same price while the player is carrying them.

The Shine Potion is a buff potion which grants the Shine buff when consumed. The buff makes the player glow brightly, which is useful for exploring caves or while exploring underwater. This lasts for 10 minutes (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) / 5 minutes (Old-gen console and 3DS versions), but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff,  by selecting the icon and canceling it in the equipment menu,  by double-tapping the buff icon, or  by canceling the buff from the buffs screen.

Sapphire is a gem found within the Underground and Cavern layers of a world. They are obtained by breaking special blocks that have noticeable blue gemstones embedded in it. They can also be extracted from Silt, Slush, or Desert Fossil by putting them in an Extractinator. Rarely, Sapphire can be found in bulk in its own Gemstone Cave mini biome, or in one that contains all of the other gems as well (besides Amber).

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, they can be crafted back into their Stone Block forms at a Heavy Work Bench in a Graveyard biome, and can be obtained by cutting down a Sapphire Gem Tree. They also have a 2/7 (28.57%) chance to be dropped by Geodes.
Like all other gems, Sapphire can be placed on blocks.

The Nettle Burst is a Hardmode, post- Plantera magic weapon that casts a 24-tile-long snaking vine projection that lingers for several seconds, passes through solid blocks, and pierces an unlimited number of enemies. The Nettle Burst scores a rapid succession of up to nine hits to damaged enemies (compared to the Vilethorn 's seven hits), and each hit delivers the weapon's full damage while inflicting a knockback value of 1 (Extremely weak), locking them in place and dealing over 250 total damage to any target that remains in the thorn's affected area for the vine's entire duration. On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Nettle Burst also has 10 armor penetration, similar to that of the Crystal Vile Shard. The Nettle Burst has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/7 (14.29%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being dropped by Plantera.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
Dark Celestial Brick Wall is a type of background wall crafted from Dark Celestial Bricks.
The Tungsten Pickaxe is an early-game pickaxe. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Silver Pickaxe.

The Tungsten Pickaxe can mine blocks and ores weaker than Demonite and Crimtane Ore (which requires a pickaxe with at least 55% pickaxe power, e.g. a Gold Pickaxe). Most notably, it can mine Meteorite.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Optic Staff is a Hardmode summon weapon that summons a miniature version of The Twins in their second form as minions, which follow the player and attack enemies. The summoned pair of minions, named Spazmamini and Retanimini, deal damage with a ramming attack and ranged laser attack, respectively. Like other minions, the summoned Twins are invincible and follow the player for an unlimited amount of time, unless the player dies, summons a replacement minion, cancels the buff, or leaves the world.

Its best modifiers are Mythical, Furious, or Godly. Rounding reveals that these modifiers provide the same increase to damage as the Ruthless modifier, increasing it from 24 to 28 on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version and from 30 to 35 on the Old-gen console version.

The Stalker's Quiver is a Hardmode accessory that combines the effects of the Magic Quiver and the aggro -reducing effect of the Putrid Scent. Unlike the general ranged damage bonuses, it only boosts the damage of the weapons and does not affect damage of the ammo.

Like other accessories crafted with the Putrid Scent, it does not inherit the Putrid Scent's bonus to damage and critical strike chance. It could be seen as the corruption-equivalent to the Berserker's Glove.
For the worthy is a secret world seed with features that aim to increase the game's difficulty drastically.
The following seeds can be used to generate a For the worthy world (case-insensitive):

The Chum Bucket is a consumable item that increases fishing power when thrown into a liquid. Chum Buckets have a 1/2 (50%) chance of being dropped from Blood Moon enemies : Wandering Eye Fish and Zombie Mermen drop it in stacks of 4-6, and Hemogoblin Sharks, Blood Eels, and Dreadnautiluses in stacks of 7-10. All of these enemies have a chance to spawn while fishing during a Blood Moon.

The fishing power bonus depends on how many Chum Buckets are present on the liquid's surface. A single bucket used will increase fishing power by 11, two for a total of 17, and finally three for a total bonus of 20. This bonus is added after all other fishing factors and so is not influenced by time factors like other fishing gear are. See the relevant section on Fishing for details.
Each bucket lasts up to 10 times reeling in the line, even if nothing is on the line or if the line breaks.

The breath meter appears when a player's head is under either water or honey, representing the time the player has until they begin drowning. The breath meter consists of 10 (5) air bubbles (one shown on the right) which fade and disappear gradually as long as the character's head is submerged. When the breath meter is depleted, the player begins to drown and health is lost. The breath meter will start refilling as soon as the player emerges from liquid. It refills at a fixed speed, taking 1.11 seconds to refill from empty to full.

For breathing purposes, the player is considered "in liquid" when the pixel right above their eye is under liquid surface. This roughly correlates to just a pixel above where the liquid will be if the player stands in two full tiles of liquid with a tile of air in the third tile they occupy. In older versions and the Old-gen console version, this was actually the very top pixel of the head. It was changed to prevent players from drowning when their head bumped liquid-filled blocks.
Cog Walls are a type of background wall made from Cogs. The wall is animated similar to placed cogs.

The Paladin's Shield is a Hardmode, post- Plantera shield accessory that functions primarily in multiplayer. While equipped, and when the wearer's health is above 25%, it grants all nearby players on their team the Paladin's Shield buff, which causes 25% of any damage inflicted on them to transfer to the wearer of the shield instead. In both singleplayer and multiplayer, the Paladin's Shield also provides the wearer immunity to knockback (like the Cobalt Shield and its variants), and provides an additional 6 defense.
The Paladin's Shield has a 1/10 (10%) / 19/100 (19%) chance of being dropped by Paladins in the post-Plantera Dungeon.

The Oasis is a naturally spawning mini-biome that can be found on the Surface layer of the Desert biome. It consists of a sizable body of water surrounded by multiple palm trees and shrubbery such as mini cacti, ferns, and flowers. Cattail plants grow in the lake and there are often multiple Dragonflies flying around and above the surface of the water.
The water of the Oasis is a turquoise color, just like that of regular surface Desert water. An Oasis Water Fountain can be purchased in order to replicate this water color at a location of choice.

As a mini-biome, the Oasis is not considered to be a separate biome from the Desert: the Oasis counts as a Desert in terms of an NPC 's preferred biome, the Oasis will spawn Desert-exclusive critters and enemies, and fishing in an Oasis will yield the same results as fishing in a Desert. Thus, it is possible to create an artificial Oasis by placing water in the surface layer of a Desert biome.

The Dead Man's Chest is a naturally-generated Gold Chest rigged with a large variety of traps in order to kill the player upon opening it. This setup usually includes 3-5 Boulder traps, 2-6 Dart Traps, and 0-3 Explosives, with a possibility of 1-2 Geysers if generated at depths in which lava can spawn naturally. The Boulder traps are set up above the chest, the Dart Traps are set up horizontally, and the Explosives are hidden underneath.
Dead Man's Chests will always generate alone, and never in an Underground Cabin.
The Dead Man's Chest will contain standard Gold Chest loot based on where it is found, as well as having a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to contain the Dead Man's Sweater.

The Granite Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Granite Caves, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed. It can also be generated as part of an Underground Cabin in a Granite Cave, considered safe. It is also considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

Critter Shampoo is a vanity accessory equipped in a social accessory slot that changes the color of summoned minions when paired with a dye in the corresponding dye slot. It is purchased from the Zoologist for 10 GC after completing at least 30% (162 entries) of the Bestiary.
The Critter Shampoo cannot be reforged, and therefore cannot have modifiers.

Meteorite Brick Wall is a wall made from crafting Meteorite Bricks at a Work Bench. This mainly serves as decoration, but can be used for NPC houses. Like Meteorite Brick, Meteorite Brick Wall emits a small amount of light when placed.

Mighty Wind is a debuff exclusively inflicted on players during a Sandstorm. It slowly pushes affected players in the direction of the wind, hindering (or increasing) their movement. The debuff will still take effect if the player has a knockback -negating accessory, such as the Cobalt Shield, but it does not affect players standing in front of background walls or while held in place with a grappling hook.
The debuff is only inflicted on players, but enemies in a Sandstorm will also act as if under its effects.

Weapons are essential items used for combat against enemies, bosses, critters, and even other players during PvP games. Some weapons can be crafted at a Work Bench or a Pre-Hardmode / Hardmode Anvil, while others can only be found in Chests, as enemy drops, or purchased from NPCs. Terraria has a wide variety of weapons and weapon classes, each suited to particular play styles or specific tasks.

Most tools can also be used as weapons, despite it not being their primary purpose. Traps, certain mounts, self-defending NPCs (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and even lava, although not primarily weapons, can be considered a weapon if somehow used in combat.

Gladiator armor is an armor set consisting of the Gladiator Helmet, the Gladiator Breastplate, and the Gladiator Leggings. Hoplites have a 1/7 (14.29%) chance to drop a single random piece of the set.
A full set of Gladiator armor provides the following benefits:
+16 defense Immunity to knockback

The Cobalt Repeater is a Hardmode repeater crafted solely using Cobalt Bars. It is one of the first repeaters that can be obtained once entering Hardmode. It is also the weakest of all repeaters, which is not to say that it cannot be effective.Its alternate ore counterpart is the Palladium Repeater.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Raven is a pre-Hardmode flying enemy that appears in Graveyards (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and can be found in the Forest at night during the Halloween seasonal event.
Similarly to Vultures, Ravens will first be encountered roosting and will take flight when approached or attacked. It will hover over the player, waiting a few moments before swooping down to attack.

Biome Keys are Hardmode items used to open the Biome Chests in the Dungeon. Opening a Chest consumes the key. Though unusable until Plantera is defeated, they can be dropped at any time during Hardmode. Each key has a 1/2500 (0.04%) chance of dropping from an enemy in the key's respective biome.

Any enemy in the biome that drops coins when killed has a chance of dropping a key, not just biome-exclusive enemies. Additionally, enemies in hybrid biomes have a chance to drop any key from their composite biomes. The type of key is determined by which biome the player currently is in, not the enemy killed.

Any Biome Key dropped prior to defeating Plantera will display the tooltip " It has been cursed by a powerful Jungle creature " and will be unable to open its respective chest until Plantera is defeated, although they are usable in other worlds that have Plantera defeated already.

The Raven Staff is a Hardmode, post- Plantera summon weapon that spawns a Raven minion that swiftly charges through enemies while dealing contact damage.
