Like other minions, the summoned Raven is invincible and follows the player for an unlimited amount of time, unless the player dies, summons a replacement minion, cancels the buff, or leaves the world. The Raven Staff is dropped by the Pumpking during the Pumpkin Moon event with a 2.5-12.5% (6.25-12.5%) chance depending on the current wave.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Raven Staff has over a Ruthless one is knockback.
The Yellow Slime is a pre-Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns in the Underground layer, alongside Red Slimes. They are slightly larger and stronger than Purple Slimes.
Like most other slimes, the Yellow Slime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.
On Desktop, Console, Mobile, and 3DS, they can rarely be found carrying bonus drops, which the player receives upon the slime's death.

The Rainbow Piece was a crafting material used solely to craft the Pot o' Gold, a pet -summoning item. This required 5 Rainbow Pieces. Rainbow Pieces used to fall from the sky, much like Fallen Stars, except that they fell during the day, disappeared at night, and only fell during the St. Patrick's Day season. They were slightly transparent.

The Cherry is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Boreal tree.
Like all other food items, the Cherry can be placed on a Plate :
Luminite Brick is a type of Brick and an aesthetic building material. Despite being made of Luminite, the highest tier of ore, it has no sell value. It can be used to craft Luminite Brick Walls.
The Teapot is a crafting station used to make Teacups. It can be placed anywhere.

Pylons are placeable furniture items that appear as a large stone or crystal hovering and rotating above a biome -themed stand. They allow a player to teleport to any other pylon by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button on them, which will open the fullscreen map, and selecting the other pylon there. Pylons are only practical if there are two or more placed in the world. The system they form is referred to as the Pylon Network.
The following restrictions apply to the biome pylons (all pylons excluding the Universal Pylon):

Pylons can only be used when there are 2 or more living, housed NPCs (including the Old Man and town pets) within a 169-tile wide by 124-tile high rectangle centered on each pylon. At least a portion of the NPCs' housing tiles must be within this range, but the pylons will still work if the NPCs themselves walk out of this range. Pylons will not work if an NPC is not near their home. Pylons only function when in their respective biome.
The following restrictions apply to all pylons (including the Universal Pylon):

Only one of each type of pylon may be placed in a world. Pylons cannot be used during boss battles or when invasions are announced or in progress. Pylons can only function when the Map is enabled in the Settings. Furthermore, pylons are functional on the overlay map, but they cannot be used to travel long distances without opening the full-screen map. Players must be within the use range of a pylon (60 tiles) to use the pylon to teleport.

The Tome of Infinite Wisdom is a Hardmode magic weapon that possesses two different modes of attack. When pressing the ⚒ Use / Attack button, the Tome of Infinite Wisdom fires bursts of four high-velocity pages that dissipate upon contact with enemies or solid tiles. When pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button, it summons a large, high-velocity tornado that deals 175% of the weapon's base damage (63 damage), pierces an unlimited number of enemies, travels along blocks and through one-block low roofs, and dissipates after a duration of four seconds or upon being stopped by a wall of solid tiles. The Tome of Infinite Wisdom is dropped by Ogres during the Old One's Army event, with a 1/10 (10%) / 1/5 (20%) chance during Tier 2, and a 1/20 (5%) chance during Tier 3.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
The Bewitching Table is a furniture item found naturally placed in the Dungeon. In Hardmode, it is also sold by the Witch Doctor for 10 GC if the Wizard is present.

Placing and pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on the Bewitching Table grants the Bewitched buff, which increases the player's minion capacity by 1. This lasts until the player dies or leaves the world, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.

Unlike equipment buff items, the Bewitching Table must be placed in order to activate the buff. It can be mined with a pickaxe or drill and picked up again, even while the buff is active, which will not cancel the buff. Placement is only dependent on an adequate space of 3x3 tiles being available.

The Monster Meat is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Pig Man pet to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, the Pig Man flies while carrying an Umbrella from Don't Starve in order to catch up. The Monster Meat can be dropped from most Corruption or Crimson enemies with a 1/1500 (0.07%) chance. On The Constant seed, the drop rate is increased to a 1/500 (0.2%) chance.

The Xeno Staff is a Hardmode, post- Golem summon weapon that spawns a UFO minion that instantly teleports above the nearest enemy before rapidly firing thin blue lasers at its target. The UFO's lasers are fired instantaneously at a rate of once every 0.4 seconds on average. If the UFO minion is more than 75 tiles away from the player, it ceases to attack enemies and returns to the player. The Xeno Staff has a 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being dropped by the Martian Saucer during the Martian Madness event.

Its best modifier is Ruthless. The Mythical modifier provides the widest array of stat bonuses, but these primarily affect the initial summon rather than the resulting minion. Additionally, minions cannot deal critical hits. The only lasting advantage a Mythical Xeno Staff has over a Ruthless one is knockback.

Steampunk furniture is made from Cogs, which can be purchased from the Steampunker after Hardmode is activated. There are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 19 / (Old-gen console version) 8 / 4 different Steampunk furniture items.

Mythril armor is an armor which requires Mythril Bars and must be crafted at a Mythril Anvil. Like all Hardmode ore armors, Mythril armor has three different headgear/helmet options, allowing players to focus on magical, melee or ranged combat, and each changing the set bonus. The alternative to Mythril Armor is Orichalcum Armor. Crafting a one-helmet set requires 45 Mythril Bars, or 180 Mythril Ore. Crafting all five pieces requires 65 Mythril Bars, or 260 Mythril Ore.
Damselfish are a type of fish which are found uncommonly by fishing in pure Space layer. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners and Calming Potions.

The Recon Scope is a Hardmode, post- Golem accessory that combines the effects of the Sniper Scope and the aggro -reducing effect of the Putrid Scent. Like other accessories crafted with the Putrid Scent, it does not inherit the Putrid Scent's bonus to damage and critical strike chance.

The Fire Imp is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns in the The Underworld. It fires Burning Spheres, which travel through blocks and have a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to inflict the On Fire! debuff for 7 / 14 / 17.5 seconds. The Burning Spheres can easily be destroyed by hitting them with any weapon, minion, or damage-dealing tool or pet.
Like all casters, the Fire Imp will follow the pattern of firing three times, pausing for several seconds, and teleporting to another location on the screen.
The Bundle of Horseshoe Balloons is an accessory which combines the functionalities of the Bundle of Balloons and the Lucky Horseshoe.

When equipped, it allows the wearer to perform a quadruple jump, as well as increasing the player's jump duration by 33%, jump speed by 30%, and luck by 0.05. Each of the jumps has an effect from the different combined items: sandstorm jump, then blizzard jump, then cloud jump. Having it equipped also prevents the player from taking fall damage.

The Revolver is a pre-Hardmode gun. Statistically, it is a direct upgrade to The Undertaker. It can also be considered an indirect upgrade to the Red Ryder, though the Red Ryder does have autoswing while the Revolver does not. The Revolver can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 10 GC after a Shadow Orb or Crimson Heart has been smashed.
The Revolver has a base 9% critical strike chance as opposed to the usual 4%.
In the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Traveling Merchant uses it to defend himself, but will switch to a Pulse Bow once the world is in Hardmode.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

Tungsten Brick Wall is a background wall crafted from Tungsten Bricks. Like most walls, the Tungsten Brick Wall stops enemies from spawning on the tile where it is placed and can be used to make houses for NPCs.
The Truffle is a Hardmode NPC vendor who sells various mushroom -themed items. He will move in once the following criteria are met:

There is an available vacant house. The vacant house that the Truffle will move in to is located in (or near) a surface Glowing Mushroom biome (i.e. one that is above 0 elevation). Surface Glowing Mushroom biomes do not generate naturally and therefore must be manually created. 100 tiles of Mushroom grass and Glowing Mushroom plants are required to create a Glowing Mushroom biome.

Once the Truffle has moved in, he can be reassigned to a house at any elevation, as long as it is in a Glowing Mushroom biome. If he dies, he can only respawn if a house in a surface Glowing Mushroom biome is available again.

When threatened by enemies on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Truffle will release Mushroom Spores, which hover in midair and explode into spore clouds upon contact with enemies.

The Giant Shelly is a pre-Hardmode enemy found in the Cavern layer, and has two color variants that share identical stats and behavior. The Giant Shelly walks around slowly and occasionally curls into its shell. It then starts spinning and hurls itself at the player, gaining increased defense and dealing high contact damage. Giant Shellies attack very quickly and deal high damage compared to other enemies for the stage in the game where they are found.

Giant Shellies are unique in that their ability to spawn is connected to two other enemies: the Crawdad and the Salamander. Of these three enemies, a world will choose two types that it can spawn, leaving the third inaccessible. Giant Shellies will never spawn in a world that features both Crawdads and Salamanders together. This is taken into account by the Bestiary progression logic (the missing enemy will register as unlocked when the other two exclusive creatures are unlocked) and the banner acquisition (any two of the trio's banners can be used to craft the banner of the missing member of the trio).
Granite furniture are furniture items crafted from Smooth Granite Blocks, which in turn are crafted from Granite Blocks at a Work Bench. There are 20 different Granite furniture items.
Tuna are a type of fish which are found commonly by fishing in the Ocean in the Sky or Surface layers. They are used to craft Cooked Fish and Sashimi.

The Teacup is a food item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
Like all other food items, the Teacup can be placed on a Plate :

The Pirate Deadeye is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Pirate Invasion event. It appears similar to the Pirate Deckhand but comes armed with a blunderbuss that can fire bullets at the player, an eye patch, and slightly modified stats.

The Mechanical Eye is a Hardmode boss-summoning item used to summon The Twins, the Hardmode version of the Eye of Cthulhu. It can only be used at night ; attempting to use this item during the day will not spawn the Twins nor consume the item. The Mechanical Eye is also unusable while the Twins are already alive. If the Twins have not been defeated yet in a Hardmode world, all enemies have a 1/2500 (0.04%) chance of dropping a Mechanical Eye, with the exception of statue -spawned enemies, Meteor Heads, and Old One's Army enemies.

The Book of Skulls is a pre-Hardmode, post- Skeletron magic weapon that fires slow flaming skull projectiles. Each skull can pierce enemies twice, dissipating upon the third impact. The skulls do not ricochet, and disappear upon colliding with objects, but they have a fairly strong homing ability on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version. They also emit a fair amount of light. The Book of Skulls has a 36/343 (10.5%) / 1/3 (33.33%) chance to drop from Skeletron.
A Shadowflame variant of the Book of Skulls is used by the Clothier to protect himself on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Mythril Pickaxe is a Hardmode pickaxe and is the pickaxe alternative to the Mythril Drill, having a slower mining speed but longer range and benefiting from mining speed bonuses. Its alternate ore version, the Orichalcum Pickaxe, is slightly stronger than the Mythril Pickaxe.
It can mine any block except Chlorophyte Ore and Lihzahrd Bricks.
It requires 15 Mythril Bars to craft (60 Mythril Ore)
Its best modifier is Legendary. However, due to rounding, Legendary, Light, Deadly, Agile, Quick, and Nasty provide equal boosts to mining speed for this tool.

The Leprechaun set is a vanity set. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to be obtained by opening a Goodie Bag from the Halloween event. It consists of a Leprechaun Hat, Leprechaun Shirt and Leprechaun Pants.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.
Extra jumps allow the player to perform one or more extra mid-air jumps and are granted by five different accessories and four different mounts.

Each extra jump has a certain type, dictated by the accessory or mount. Jumps of the same type will not stack with each other but will stack with other types, allowing for more than two consecutive jumps. For example, equipping a Cloud in a Bottle and a Tsunami in a Bottle will grant two additional jumps, while combining a Cloud in a Bottle with a Cloud in a Balloon will only grant one extra jump. Each type displays a unique particle effect when used, which always occur in the same order: Summoned mount's jump first, followed by Sandstorm, Blizzard, Fart, Tsunami, and Cloud.

An extra jump uses the same jump speed as the base jump but with a different jump duration. For example, with default jump speed, a sustained jump from a Sandstorm in a Bottle lasts 3 times longer than a base jump, reaching a maximum height of 21.18 tiles, which is an increase of 237.8% compared to the base jump reach of 6.27 tiles.
The Bell is a Hardmode crafting material purchased from the Wizard for 1 GC. It is used to the craft the Fairy Bell, a light pet -summoning item.
When used, the Bell creates a sound that changes in pitch depending on the distance between the player and the point clicked.

The Bat Bat is a pre-Hardmode sword that restores 1 health to the user upon hitting an enemy. The Bat Bat has a 1/250 (0.4%) chance of being dropped by any type of bat. On The Constant seed, the drop chance is increased to a 1/100 (1%) chance.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Nurse is an NPC who will move in once the following criteria have been met:
There is an available vacant house. The player's maximum health is greater than 100. The Merchant is present.
The Nurse will heal the player's health and cure them of any active debuffs at the cost of coins (there are exceptions, see Notes and History).

On the Nintendo 3DS version, healing costs can range from a few Copper to several Silver Coins, depending on how much health the player is missing. She charges Copper equal to 75% of the health restored (e.g. 75 CC for restoring 100 health), plus an additional 7 SC 50 CC for every active debuff on the player.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, healing costs are 1 CC per health restored, plus an additional 1 SC per active debuff on the player, all multiplied by the Nurse's current Happiness price adjustment, and then doubled if playing on Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). Also, the Nurse charges increasing amounts of money for healing as the game progresses; these specific increases are listed below. Thus, at the start of the game, the cost of restoring 100 health can range from 75 CC / 1 SC 50 CC (with maximum happiness) to 1 SC 50 CC / 3 SC (with maximum unhappiness), while by endgame it can range from 1 GC 50 SC / 3 GC up to 3 GC / 6 GC.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, she will fight enemies by throwing syringes that will deal 8 / 12 / 14 damage (affected by various stat boosts), and poison enemies for 3-5 seconds. She can also use healing syringes to heal herself and other nearby NPCs for 20 health. These healing syringes can home in on targets.

The Apple Pie is a Hardmode food item that grants the Exquisitely Stuffed buff when consumed. This lasts for 16 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The Apple Pie has a 1/150 (0.67%) chance of being dropped by Illuminant Bats, Illuminant Slimes, and Chaos Elementals.
Like all other food items, the Apple Pie can be placed on a Plate :
Badger's Hat is a Hardmode vanity item dropped by the Eye of Cthulhu or the Wall of Flesh when they are both defeated on the same day (from 7:30 PM to 7:30 PM the next day).

The Blood Eel is a flying Hardmode enemy that can be spawned by fishing in water during a Blood Moon. When the bobber dips and the player attempts to reel in a fish, a Blood Eel or another enemy has a chance to spawn within a few tiles of the bobber in place of a fish. Its behavior is rather similar to that of the Wyvern, though it moves considerably faster.

It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades. The Blood Eel requires 25 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Resonance Scepter is a Hardmode, post- Plantera magic weapon that creates a glowing pink circular projectile at the cursor's location, which expands and then collapses into sparkles over the course of 1 second. There must be a clear, unobstructed line of sight between the player and the cursor's location for the projectile to be summoned right on the cursor, otherwise, the projectile will be summoned upon reaching the first solid block. The Resonance Scepter has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped by the Princess, but only during Hardmode.

Enemies within the projectiles will be rapidly damaged and knocked back away from the player. There is no limit on how many times a projectile can strike enemies, but the damage of the projectile will be reduced by 2% after each strike. The Resonance Scepter is held in the player's hand and also sparkles while it is used, emitting pink light.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Sickle is a tool that produces Hay blocks when used to cut tall grass. The collected Hay can be used for building purposes and crafted into Target Dummies and Hay Walls. Due to its comparably potent damage-dealing capabilities (only slightly inferior to the Tin Broadsword) and its ability to autoswing, it can also be used as a melee weapon in the very early game.
The Sickle is purchased from the Merchant for 60 SC. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, it is only available during the Halloween season.
Its best modifier is Light for harvesting purposes and Legendary for combat purposes.

The Ice Elemental is a Hardmode enemy that appears in the Snow biome at night and in the Ice biome at any time. The Ice Elemental slowly hovers towards the player and shoots Frost Blasts which, on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, have a 1/3 (33.33%) chance to inflict the Frostburn debuff for 6 / 12 / 15 seconds.

The Bast Statue is a furniture item that grants The Bast Defense buff to players in its vicinity, increasing their defense by 5. The buff effect can be toggled via wire. The Bast Statue can be found in Sandstone Chests in the lower 3/7ths of the Underground Desert and in Oasis Crates and Mirage Crates obtained from fishing in the Oasis. It can also be found as a furniture in Underground Desert Cabins.
The buff is applied to any players standing within a rectangular area of 170x125 tiles centered on the Bast Statue, similar to Heart Lanterns and Campfires.

The Blood Orange is a food and fruit item that grants the Well Fed buff when consumed. This lasts for 5 minutes, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon.
It has a small chance of dropping when shaking a Shadewood or Shadewood Palm tree.
Like all other food items, the Blood Orange can be placed on a Plate :
The Fertilizer is a consumable item which immediately grows a sapling or gemcorn into the corresponding tree.

Each use causes the player character to throw out Fertilizer in a small area in front of them. If a sapling meeting the required growing conditions is present in the area of effect, it will immediately sprout into a tree of the corresponding biome.
Saplings that fail to fulfill the growing requirements will not sprout into trees even if the Fertilizer is used on them, essentially wasting the item.

Vile Spit is a projectile NPC fired by Corruptors, which are only encountered in Hardmode Corruption biomes. It also fired by the Eater of Worlds in Expert Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions). It moves steadily in a straight line at 36 mph and breaks if it comes in contact with any block. Upon striking a target, Vile Spit has a small chance to inflict the Weak debuff. It can be easily destroyed by hitting it with any weapon or tool capable of dealing damage.

The Robot set is a vanity set consisting of the Robot Mask, Robot Shirt, and Robot Pants. Its male and female variants are identical. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to be obtained by opening a Goodie Bag from the Halloween event. When the Robot Shirt is equipped, the player will appear to have their arms facing forward when walking.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Stardust armor is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord armor set that provides summon weapon boosts. It is currently the final summoner set available on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version. Crafting the full set requires a total of 36 Luminite Bars (144 Luminite) and 45 Stardust Fragments.
The set consists of the Stardust Helmet, Stardust Plate, and Stardust Leggings.
A full set of Stardust armor provides the following bonuses:
+38 defense +66% summon damage +5 minion capacity +1 sentry capacity +30% whip range

Equipping the full set additionally summons a Stardust Guardian minion that will follow the wearer, and does not count against the player's minion capacity. It is passive until an enemy is within a 30-tile radius of the player. It will quickly charge through blocks towards the enemy, which it then strikes rapidly with a flurry of punches that each deal ~30 summon damage. Once there are no more hostile entities within range, the Stardust Guardian will return to following behind the player passively.
The Code 1 is a pre-Hardmode yoyo that can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 5 GC once the Eye of Cthulhu has been defeated.
It has a spin duration of 9 seconds and can reach up to 13.5 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

A title message is a mock slogan displayed as Terraria 's window title at the top of the game window. These messages often reference popular culture or other video games. A title message is chosen at random from the list below each time the game is started, and remains unchanged until either the game is exited completely and restarted, or a language button in the language selection menu is clicked, at which point a new message is randomly chosen.

A title message can only be displayed if Terraria's current settings allow a title bar to be present on Terraria's game window. When the game is set to full-screen, or "Borderless Window" mode is enabled (Settings → Video → Resolution), no title will be displayed normally. The title message will always be visible as part of the process collection in the Windows "Task Switcher" Alt + ↹ Tab.
The current title message appears in the top-left corner of the game window on Windows 7 and Windows 10. It appears in the top-middle of the game window on Windows 8 and 8.1, macOS, and Ubuntu.
There are 68 different title messages.
St. Patrick's Day was a Mobile -exclusive seasonal event that lasted from March 5th through March 31st. This referenced the real Saint Patrick's Day.

The Daedalus Stormbow is a Hardmode bow which rains arrows down from the sky, instead of firing them from the bow itself. Each shot fires three arrows with an additional 1/3 (33.33%) chance to spawn one extra arrow (one less arrow while using Holy, Unholy, Hellfire, or Jester's Arrows), while only consuming a single arrow from the player's inventory. The arrows fall in a wide spread towards the area where the cursor was pointed. The Daedalus Stormbow has a 1/4 (25%) chance of being dropped by Hallowed Mimics.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
The Imbuing Station is a crafting station used to craft flasks. It is purchased from the Witch Doctor for 7 GC.

The Malaise is a pre-Hardmode yoyo that can be crafted with Demonite Bars, which only come from worlds generated with Corruption. It has slightly higher knockback and duration than its Crimson counterpart, the Artery, but slightly lower damage and range.
It has a spin duration of 7 seconds and can reach up to 12 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.
Ocram's Razor is a Hardmode boss-summoning item used to summon Mechdusa. It can only be crafted and used in a Get fixed boi world with the Mechanical Eye, Mechanical Worm, and Mechanical Skull.
This item has no function when brought to other worlds, and its tooltip will display 'It has no effect in this world' instead.
The Christmas Tree Sword is a Hardmode, post- Plantera sword that fires ornament projectiles when swung that vary significantly depending on the version.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Christmas Tree Sword hurls a star ornament projectile in a straight line in the direction of the cursor which releases an ornament once every 10 ticks (0.167 seconds), releasing a maximum of four ornaments and one star ornament per every swing. The star lingers in midair for 100 ticks (1.67 seconds), and pierces one enemy before dissipating, while its secondary ornament projectiles travel for 50 ticks (0.83 seconds) before dropping directly downwards. The first and third ornaments will be released to the right (in the direction of flight) and the second and fourth to the left. Since each consecutive ornament has slightly less range, the five projectiles usually align in a roughly triangular shape. Ornament projectiles break upon contact with enemies and solid blocks and deal 100% of the weapon's base damage (86 damage). While the primary star ornament inflicts the weapon's base knockback, colored ornaments only inflict a quarter of its knockback (1.75 (Very weak)). On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, swinging the Christmas Tree Sword launches a single ornament in the direction of the cursor which is affected by gravity. It deals 100% of the sword's damage and breaks upon contact with enemies or blocks. Unlike most other late-game swords, the Christmas Tree Sword is not capable of autoswing in these versions.
The Christmas Tree Sword is dropped by the Everscream during the Frost Moon event with a 3.46%-10.37% (6.22%-31.11%) chance depending on the current wave.
Its best modifier is Legendary.
The Ice Feather is a Hardmode crafting material used solely to craft Frozen Wings. The Ice Feather has a 1/3 (33.33%) chance of being dropped by Ice Golems during a Blizzard in the Snow biome.

The Lihzahrd Power Cell is a boss-summoning item used at the Lihzahrd Altar, located in the final chamber of the Jungle Temple, in order to summon Golem. One Lihzahrd Power Cell is guaranteed to be found within each Lihzahrd Chest, and they additionally have a (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) 1/50 (2%) / (3DS version) 1/200 (0.5%) chance of dropping from Lihzahrds and Flying Snakes, both of which spawn exclusively within the Jungle Temple.

Lihzahrd Power Cells are utilized by using the ⚷ Open / Activate button on a Lihzahrd Altar, which automatically consumes one Lihzahrd Power Cell from the player's inventory and spawns Golem immediately. Golem may only be summoned in worlds where Plantera has been defeated; otherwise, the summoning will fail, and a Lihzahrd Power Cell will not be consumed.
Martian Conduit Wall is a background wall type crafted from Martian Conduit Plating.
Tooltips are bits of "hover text" displayed when hovering over items or selecting them in the inventory.
The complete text shown for an item usually contains the item's statistics.

An added bit of text also appears on many items, which is what is referred to on this wiki as the item's "tooltip" (they are referred to this way in Terraria 's game code as well). They usually describe the item further, often in fun or humorous ways.
The statistics portion of the hover text may contain any of the following:

Type Damage Critical strike chance Use time Knockback Mana usage Pickaxe power, axe power, hammer power, fishing power, bait power Health healed Defense Set bonus (when a full armor set is worn) Modifier effects Bonus effects
Modifier effects, if applicable, always appear at the bottom of the tooltip, colored green (for good effects) or red (for negative effects).

The Katana is a pre-Hardmode sword that can be purchased from the Traveling Merchant for (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 10 GC / (Old-gen console version) 2 GC 50 SC. It has a base 19% critical strike chance, as opposed to the usual 4%, and has autoswing, which makes it extremely useful as an early-game sword.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Coin Stashes (or Caches) are extremely rare background items that drop moderate to large sums of coins when destroyed. There are two types of coin stashes: small 2x1 pouches, which are often generated in Pyramids but can also generate in underground and cavern, and large 3x2 sacks (that appear to be spilled over rocks), which can only generate in underground and cavern.

Each stash contains a single coin type, though the amount can surpass 99 coins. For example, a Copper Coin stash may contain 200 coins, effectively providing 2 Silver Coins. See Notes section for exact chance and amount of coins.
Their rarity rises according to the coin values, with Gold Coins being the rarest. There are no Platinum Coin stashes.
Unlike several other naturally generated objects, coin stashes cannot be crafted with the help of Ecto Mist (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), but can be placed with the Rubblemaker using coins.

The Seaside Crate is a Hardmode crate that can only be fished in the Ocean. Seaside Crates contain items found in standard crates, and always contain one item normally found in Water Chests. Its pre-Hardmode counterpart is the Ocean Crate.
The Yoyo Bag is a Hardmode accessory which allows the holder to use two yoyos, throw two counterweights, and also increases the yoyo's range.

The Rock Golem is a powerful Hardmode enemy that spawns in the Cavern layer. It throws rocks at players that are within its line of sight but out of its contact range. When being attacked, it continues to attack, making stun-lock options unusable.
In For the worthy and Get fixed boi worlds, Rock Golems release a Boulder projectile on death.

The Vicious Bunny is a pre-Hardmode enemy that results from a Bunny that has been corrupted, either by the player using Vicious Powder on it or when a Bunny spawns during a Blood Moon in a Crimson world.

The Star Anise is a consumable ranged weapon, similar to Shurikens although slightly stronger. It can pierce up to 5 targets, hitting a total of 6 targets. 20-40 can drop from Presents obtained during the Christmas event, with a 6.301% chance in pre-Hardmode and a 5.881% chance in Hardmode.
The Spell Tome is a Hardmode crafting material used to create Crystal Storm, Cursed Flames, and Golden Shower. It is purchased from the Wizard for 5 GC.

The Jungle Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in the Underground Jungle, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained by purchasing it from the Dryad for 10 CC each, in Hardmode. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.
Frankenstein is a Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event. Frankensteins are as common as Zombies are at night, but have increased stats.
This is a list of potions which restore health, mana, or both.

Sailfish Boots are an accessory that allows the user to sprint. This item is obtained from Wooden Crates and Iron Crates. When equipped, they allow the player to gain a speed boost after running for a certain distance continuously. By running in one direction, the player's movement speed increases up to 40%. (See Sprinting accessories for more information on the sprint effect.)

The Sailfish Boots, Hermes Boots, and the Flurry Boots have identical functionality, with their only differences being aesthetic. In the case of the Sailfish Boots, the user will generate water particles coming out of their backs while running.
All three listed boots are interchangeable when crafting Spectre Boots.
The Slime Block Wall is a type of Wall made from a Slime Block.

The Pumpkin set is a vanity set which consists of the Pumpkin Mask, Pumpkin Shirt, and Pumpkin Pants. Its male and female variants look identical. It has a 2/57 (3.51%) chance to drop from Goodie Bags during Halloween. Unlike Pumpkin armor, the Pumpkin set cannot be crafted.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Mothron is a rare, powerful Hardmode, post- Plantera flying enemy that spawns during the Solar Eclipse event. Mothron can pass through all blocks and attacks by chasing after the player or aligning itself horizontally with them before lunging towards them at varying speeds, inflicting heavy contact damage depending on its velocity. Occasionally, it lands on blocks to lay several Mothron Eggs that spawn Baby Mothrons if they are not destroyed in time, much like Lepus (3DS version).

It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer or its upgrades. Mothron requires 25 kills to be awarded completion of its Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Stardust Brick is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist brick that is crafted from Stardust Fragments. It is one of the four Fragment Bricks, bricks which are crafted with Lunar Fragments. It can be used to craft Stardust furniture.

The Sandstorm in a Balloon is an accessory that combines the functions of the Sandstorm in a Bottle and the Shiny Red Balloon. It boosts jump height by 33% and jump speed by 30%, increasing the player's first jump's height to 10.5 tiles, and provides a double jump that can reach a height of 26.5 tiles, for a total height of 37 tiles. Unlike most other double-jump balloons, the Sandstorm Balloon jump will put the player at risk of taking fall damage if they do not cancel it mid-jump or have fall damage immunity (e.g. a Lucky Horseshoe).

Oddly, the total jump height of the Sandstorm in a Balloon is reduced when underwater compared to the Sandstorm in a Bottle, reducing the player's total underwater jump height from 27 tiles to 22 tiles.
Pearlstone Brick is a brick made from Pearlstone. It does not spread The Hallow when placed, therefore making it a safer construction material than its raw ingredients.

The Werewolf is a Hardmode enemy that only spawns at night while a full moon is active, during which it is as common as a Zombie. Werewolves can open doors and have a 1/8 (12.5%) chance to inflict the Bleeding debuff for 45 / 90 / 112.5 seconds. At close range, Werewolves attack the player by leaping or lunging, closing distances quickly to catch unwary players off-guard.
The Werewolf can drop the Moon Charm, which allows the player to transform into a Werewolf at night.

The Platinum Bow is a bow crafted solely using Platinum Bars, and is the strongest type of ore bow one is able to obtain before Demonite or Crimtane.  Its sole purpose is to fire arrows from a distance to hit enemies and deal damage to them. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Gold Bow.

Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.

Stoned is a Hardmode debuff which inflicts 20 / 40 / 60 damage to the player and causes them to turn into stone, rendering them immobile and unable to use items. Additionally, fall damage is greatly increased and the distance required before fall damage can occur is reduced (see Fall damage for details). If the player is in reversed gravity, the gravity direction will return normal. It also disables mounts, hooks, and ignores any accessories that grant immunity to fall damage, including the Lucky Horseshoe and all types of wings. However, the effects of the debuff can be negated by the Featherfall Potion, Djinn's Curse, and the Pocket Mirror (which grants immunity to it).

The debuff can only be inflicted by Medusa when the player is in her line of sight and looking at her during her attack state. The debuff lasts 1-4 seconds, depending on how long Medusa has been in the attack state before the player faced her. Medusa cannot petrify any player not facing her direction or otherwise not being within line of sight.

The Flipper is an accessory that allows a player to swim in liquid. With the Flipper equipped in an accessory slot, the player can swim upwards in Water, Lava, or Honey, by holding or pressing ↷ Jump repeatedly — essentially allowing unlimited multi-jumps while within liquid. It can be found in Water Chests and Ocean / Seaside Crates.
Living Rainbow Dye is a Hardmode dye acquired by giving a Strange Plant to the Dye Trader. It is only obtainable after defeating a mechanical boss.

The Forest is a pure biome that comprises the majority of the surface world and is typically where the player initially spawns. The global landscape of a Forest includes lots of grass, plenty of trees, lakes of various sizes, and occasional hills that can reveal cave entrances. Forests often contain one or more Living Trees that sometimes have an underground treasure room.

The Forest changes noticeably in the outer sixths of the world. Goblin Scouts, which are fairly uncommon and drop Tattered Cloth, begin to spawn. The King Slime boss also has a very low chance to spawn and can easily surprise and overwhelm an unsuspecting player. Enchanted Sword Shrines (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) are only found in the outer thirds of the world in the Forest as well.

The Gi is an armor item that can be equipped in the shirt slot. It provides 4 defense along with a 5% damage and critical strike chance boost to weapons. It also provides a 10% melee and movement speed increase. It is purchased from the Traveling Merchant for 2 GC. The Gi will visually cover up what is equipped in the pants slot.

Torches are furniture items that produce light when placed, held, or dropped (via the Throw key), and are crucial at all stages of gameplay as primary light sources. Torches provide light permanently, and are never extinguished. Regular torches can be found randomly in chests and Pots, as a bonus drop (Desktop, Console, Mobile and 3DS versions) from slimes, or purchased from the Merchant or Skeleton Merchant (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) for 50 CC each.

Torches can be placed on the sides or tops of most blocks, on background walls, and on the sides of trees and Wooden Beams. They can also be placed on any type of platform. A placed torch can be retrieved by pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate key on it or by freeing it with a pickaxe or drill. When the block a torch is attached to is broken, the torch will attach itself to any other block or wall directly adjacent to it. If all adjacent blocks surrounding a torch are removed (left, right, and bottom), and no wall exists behind it, it drops like any other item.
Torches are also mechanisms that can be toggled on and off via Wire.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, placing at least 101 torches in close proximity below the surface layer in any biome will start the Torch God mini-event. Completing the event will grant the Torch God's Favor, which will allow the player to automatically convert ordinary torches to one of the biome types.
Red Brick s are bricks crafted from Clay Block.

The Crimson Crust Wall, Crimson Scab Wall, Crimson Teeth Wall, and Crimson Blister Wall are types of background walls which can be found naturally generated in the Underground Crimson, considered unsafe. They do not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, via crafting. They are considered safe walls when placed by the player.
Blue Starry Wall is a decorative wall crafted from Blue Starry Blocks. It is one of only a few animated background walls.

The Fart in a Balloon is an accessory that combines the effects of the Fart in a Jar and the Shiny Red Balloon. It boosts jump height by 33% and jump speed by 30%, increasing the player's first jump's height to ~10.5 blocks (~75% increase), and provides a double jump that goes to 18.5 blocks, for a total of 29 blocks. Unlike most other double-jump balloons, the Fart in a Balloon's full jump is high enough for the player to take minor fall damage, unless the player has fall damage immunity accessories like the Lucky Horseshoe. The double jump also makes a fart sound.

The Vampire Frog Staff is a pre-Hardmode summon weapon that spawns a Vampire Frog minion that follows the player and attacks enemies by hopping towards them to deal contact damage, as well by using its tongue. Like other minions, the summoned Vampire Frog is invincible and follows the player until they die, summon a replacement minion, cancel the buff, or leave the world. The Vampire Frog Staff has a 1/8 (12.5%) chance of being dropped by Wandering Eye Fish and Zombie Mermen.
Its best modifiers are Ruthless, Mythical, Masterful, Godly, Demonic, or Furious, which all raise its base damage by the same amount due to rounding.

The Wooden Yoyo is an early-game, pre-Hardmode yoyo, and generally the first one available to the player. It is the weakest of all yoyos. It remains deployed for about three seconds before returning automatically to the player.
It has a spin duration of 3 seconds and can reach up to 8 tiles.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Antlion Swarmer is a pre-Hardmode flying enemy found in the Underground Desert or on surface Deserts during Sandstorms. It is a large dragonfly-like creature that looks similar to the Antlion and Antlion Charger. It should be treated with caution by newer players because of its health and knockback resistance.

The Anomura Fungus is an enemy found in aboveground Glowing Mushroom biomes at any point in the game, including pre-Hardmode. During Hardmode, they can also spawn in underground Glowing Mushroom biomes.
Lava Moss Brick Wall is a brick background wall with a high visibility in dark areas and lights up any foreground blocks in front, similar to Gemspark Walls with reduced brightness.

The S.D.M.G. (Space Dolphin Machine Gun) is a Hardmode, post- Moon Lord gun. It can be considered an endgame upgrade of the Megashark, with a slightly faster firing rate, a 66% chance not to consume ammunition, and a noticeably higher damage output. Its abilities are also similar to those of the Chain Gun, but it is more precise and deals significantly more damage, though with a slightly slower rate of fire. The S.D.M.G. also has a base 14% critical strike chance, as opposed to the usual 4%. The S.D.M.G. has a 2/9 (22.22%) chance of being dropped by the Moon Lord.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
Mushroom Chests are chests that can be found inside Underground Cabins in Glowing Mushroom biomes.

The Snow biome, also known as the Tundra, is a Surface biome that takes on an arctic appearance with its constant snowfall, its ground made of Snow and Ice Blocks, and its Boreal trees. It can be of moderate difficulty in the early game, becoming relatively easy with some basic equipment. The biome is always found in the direction of the Dungeon, opposite the Underground Desert and Jungle. It extends Underground and transitions to the Ice biome in the Cavern layer.

Specific features of the Snow biome include a different water color and a snowscape background. Boreal Trees and Shiverthorn (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) frequently grow in the snow. Penguins wander the surface, and typical enemies include Ice Slimes, Frozen Zombies, and Demon Eyes. When the player touches water or Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) in the Snow biome in Expert (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or Master Mode (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), it inflicts the player with the Chilled debuff until 5 seconds after they leave the liquid. During rain, the biome undergoes a Blizzard, decreasing visibility.
The trees in the biome can appear to be pines, snowy evergreens, or leafless trees, but they always yield Boreal Wood when cut down. Acorns placed on Snow Blocks always grow into Boreal Trees.

A Snow biome is made of at least (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1500 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 300 Snow or Ice Blocks nearby, causing the water color and the background to change, but Snow plants and enemies can spawn on even a single block of Snow or Ice.
The Corruption, Crimson, and Hallow can spread to this biome through its Ice Blocks, either upon world generation or via improved biome spread in Hardmode.
During a Blood Moon, Penguins become Corrupt or Vicious.

In Hardmode, the Snow biome gets a bit of a boost. Ice Elementals and Wolves begin to spawn at night, and Blizzards can spawn the rare Ice Golem, a recurring lumbering giant with a frost beam attack that chills and even freezes players. Also, any enemy killed in the Snow biome in Hardmode has a 1/300 (0.33%) chance of dropping the Amarok (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), a powerful yoyo that inflicts the Frostburn debuff on enemies.

The Dungeon holds a single Ice Chest, which is unlocked with a Frozen Key, obtainable from the Snow biome during Hardmode, but is only usable after Plantera is defeated. Enemies killed in the Snow biome have a 1/2500 (0.04%) chance of dropping the Frozen Key (on Desktop, Console, and Mobile) or the Frozen Key Mold (on Old-gen console and 3DS). The Ice Chest holds the Staff of the Frost Hydra, a sentry summon weapon.

Fishing in the Snow biome has a chance of yielding Atlantic Cod, Frost Daggerfish (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), and Frost Minnow. Atlantic Cod is used to craft Cooked Fish and Frost Minnow is used to craft Warmth Potions. Frost Daggerfish are consumable ranged weapons and can be useful at the beginning of the game. Frozen Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Boreal Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) can also be caught in the Snow biome in pre-Hardmode and Hardmode, respectively, and always include one unique item from Frozen Chests (alongside other loot).
The Life Crystal Boulder is a furniture item. It spawns naturally in the Celebrationmk10, No traps, and the Get fixed boi secret world seeds.

It appears to be an ordinary Life Crystal and is generated in a similar manner upon world creation, but acts identically to a Boulder if hit with a pickaxe or drill, or otherwise unsupported by solid blocks. The Life Crystal Boulder falls directly downwards until it collides with a solid block, at which point it begins rolling, accelerating and dealing damage to the player, enemies, critters, and NPCs. Life Crystal Boulders pierce through an unlimited number of entities and accelerate to a top speed of 36 mph over the course of 2.17 seconds.

Life Crystal Boulders roll across flat surfaces and down slopes but break and disappear upon colliding with an obstacle, such as a wall of solid tiles. They deal 140 / 280 / 420 to players (70 damage to NPCs, enemies, and critters) and inflict a knockback value of 10 (Extremely strong) on contact. However, when the Life Crystal Boulder breaks after colliding with solid blocks or after rolling for one minute (like all other projectiles), it drops a Life Crystal item.

The Life Fruit is a Hardmode plant and permanent booster item that grows exclusively on Jungle grass in any area within the Underground layer or below. Once harvested and used, a Life Fruit permanently increases the player's health capacity by 5 and restores the player's health by 5, turning one of the hearts in the player's health meter golden. Life Fruit can only be used once a player has reached the 400 health cap from consuming Life Crystals.

On the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, Life Fruit will only grow after one mechanical boss has been defeated. They will also grow 25% faster on average in Expert Mode. On the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version, Life Fruit can be found prior to defeating a mechanical boss, just in much smaller numbers; defeating a mechanical boss increases the amount that can grow. Verify

A total of 20 Life Fruit are required to reach the maximum 500 health capacity, at which point all of the player's hearts will be golden. Once this is reached, the player's health cannot be manually increased beyond 500, with the exception of the effects of the Lifeforce buff.

The Brain Scrambler is a Hardmode, post- Golem mount-summoning item that summons a rideable Scutlix Mount. The Brain Scrambler has a 1/30 (3.33%) chance to drop from Scutlix Gunners during the Martian Madness event.

The Scutlix Mount offers increased acceleration and land speed (41 mph top speed), increased jump height (20 tiles/40 feet), and its eyes automatically rapid-fire accurate damaging red lasers at nearby enemies. It also reduces fall damage to 1.

The laser projectiles deal 150 base damage, cannot be boosted by any damage bonuses, and cannot critically strike. The Scutlix can only target enemies in its field of vision, which is a roughly 120° cone in front of it, and cannot target enemies behind itself unless the player manually turns it around to face them, which also occurs when the player attacks in that direction.
Bloodbath Dye is a dye purchased from the Dye Trader during a Blood Moon for 7 GC 50 SC. When applied, it gives the item an appearance similar to dripping blood.

Meteor armor is an armor set that consists of the Meteor Helmet, Meteor Suit, and Meteor Leggings. Equipping the full set reduces the mana cost of the Space Gun to 0. In the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, the Gray Zapinator and Orange Zapinator are also affected by this change. Each piece of the armor worn increases magic damage by (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 9% / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 7%. If the full set is visible, the player leaves a trail of flames as they move.

Crafting a full set requires a total of (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 45 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 60 Meteorite Bars ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 135 / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 180 Meteorite ore).

The Corite is a Hardmode, post- Lunatic Cultist enemy that spawns in the area of the Solar Pillar during the Lunar Events. It is a flying enemy that shrouds itself in fire before charging toward the player at high speeds, all while traveling through blocks.

The Undertaker is a pre-Hardmode gun. It will always drop from the first Crimson Heart destroyed in a Crimson world (along with 100 Musket Balls) and has a 1/5 (20%) chance of dropping from destroyed Crimson Hearts afterward. It also has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being obtained from Crimson (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) and Hematic Crates (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) fished in the Crimson.
Its Corruption counterpart is the Musket. Compared to the Musket, The Undertaker fires much more quickly at the cost of decreased damage per shot.
Its best modifier is Unreal.
Jungle armor is a pre-Hardmode armor set consisting of the Jungle Shirt, the Jungle Hat and Jungle Pants. It is crafted from items found in the Underground Jungle.
A full set of Jungle armor provides the following bonuses:

+ (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 17/ (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 15 defense + (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 80/ (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 60 maximum mana + (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 12%/ (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 9% magic critical strike chance + (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 6% magic damage +16% mana cost reduction
Jungle armor pieces are interchangeable with pieces from the Ancient Cobalt armor set, while still providing the same 16% reduced mana usage set bonus, but not the grass particle effect.
The total material cost of making a full set is:
10 ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) / 12 ((Old-gen console and 3DS versions)) Stingers 2 Vines 32 Jungle Spores

The Spider Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in Spider Nests, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed and can only be obtained on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, via crafting. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

The Infested Spider Wall (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) is an item that places an unsafe Spider Wall. It is visually identical and is obtained by throwing a Spider Wall into Shimmer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions).
Unsafe Spider Walls will create Cobwebs in front of them over time, serving as a renewable source for the item. These Cobwebs only have a 1/4 (25%) chance to yield a Cobweb item when destroyed.

The Iron Bow is a low tier bow crafted using Iron Bars. It is slightly stronger than the Copper Bow and Tin Bow. Its sole purpose is to fire arrows from a distance to deal damage to enemies. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Lead Bow.

Its best modifier is Demonic, as it does not have any knockback and thus cannot get modifiers that affect it. (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) It can also get the Deadly modifier, which, while the Demonic modifier may provide the greatest damage per hit, grants a higher increase to the overall DPS.

The Wedding set is a vanity set which consists of the Wedding Veil and the Wedding Dress. They are guaranteed to be dropped by The Bride, a rare enemy that spawns during a Blood Moon and in the Graveyard mini biome.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The Decorative Mana Potion is a furniture item. By pressing the ⚷ Open / Activate button or mining it, it drops a Lesser Mana Potion. This item generates naturally in the Dungeon. It can be placed on a flat furniture item, where it functions as a Placed Bottle crafting station.

The Wisp in a Bottle is a Hardmode, post- Plantera light pet-summoning item that spawns a light-providing Wisp that follows the player around. While active, it is similar to the Flickerwick. The Wisp emits cyan light and is brighter and keeps better pace with the player than other light pets, except the Suspicious Looking Tentacle and Jewel of Light (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) which have the same light radius. It moves in accordance with the direction keys the player is pressing, although it is oriented above the player's head by default. The Wisp's movement range appears to be about 7 tiles to the left, right, and below the player's hitbox and 7 tiles above the Wisp's normal starting position. The Wisp in a Bottle has a 1/400 (0.25%) / 799/160000 (0.5%) chance of being dropped by Blue Armored Bones, Rusty Armored Bones, and Hell Armored Bones.
Vitamins are a Hardmode immunity accessory that grants the player immunity to the Weak debuff. It has a 1/100 (1%) / 1/50 (2%) chance to drop from Corruptors and Floaty Grosses.
Vitamins are one of the ingredients required to make the Armor Bracing, which is a crafting material required to make the Ankh Charm, an accessory further required to make the Ankh Shield.
Trout are a type of fish which are found plentifully by fishing in the Ocean in the Sky or Surface layers. They are used to craft Cooked Fish and Sashimi.

The Crimson Grass Wall is a type of background wall which can be found naturally generated in The Crimson, considered unsafe. It does not drop as an item when destroyed, and can only be obtained on Desktop, Console, and Mobile, by purchasing it from the Dryad during a Blood Moon for 2 SC 50 CC each. It is considered a safe wall when placed by the player.

The Clentaminator / Terraformer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) (using Red Solution) and Blood Water convert Grass Walls, Flower Walls, and Jungle Walls (both safe and unsafe) to unsafe Crimson Grass Walls.
Crimson Grass Walls can spread The Crimson to nearby pure walls. See Biome spread for further information.
The Clown set is a vanity set which consists of the Clown Hat, the Clown Shirt, and the Clown Pants. It is purchased from the Clothier for 4 GC (set), once a Clown has been defeated.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

Grown blocks are blocks which are obtained from naturally-grown objects (such as Grass and Trees) and can be walked in front of before they are obtained, but afterwards, are placed down as solid blocks. Examples include all types of wood, Bamboo (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions), Cacti, Glowing Mushrooms from Giant Glowing Mushrooms, Hay, and Pumpkins.

The Shark Tooth Necklace is an accessory which has a 1/150 (0.67%) / 1/75 (1.33%) chance to drop from Blood Zombies and Dripplers found during a Blood Moon. It increases the player's armor penetration by 5 when equipped.

The Flower Pow is a Hardmode, post- Plantera flail which, in addition to the usual flail mechanics, has the unique ability to rapidly fire pink flower petals at nearby enemies. Petal projectiles deal 66.67% of the weapon's base damage (86 damage) and inflict half of its knockback (base knockback of 3.25 (Weak)). While the ⚒ Use / Attack button is held, the Flower Pow's head launches petals at a steady rate at nearby enemies within its line of sight. The fire rate increases drastically when the flail's head is released and remains at rest on solid blocks. The Flower Pow has a (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) 1/7 (14.29%) / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) 1/6 (16.67%) chance of being dropped by Plantera.

Its best modifier is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase the average damage output by the same amount. However, Ruthless might be preferred if the player already has very high critical strike chance.

The Solar Tablet is a Hardmode event-summoning item used to summon a Solar Eclipse. It may only be used during the day (from 4:30 AM to 7:29 PM), causing the eclipse to begin immediately, regardless of the time. The eclipse lasts until 7:30 PM of the current day.

Solar Tablets have a 1/5 (20%) chance to be found in Lihzahrd Chests in the Jungle Temple. Additionally, Lihzahrds and Flying Snakes have a 1/7 (14.29%) chance of dropping 1-2 Solar Tablet Fragments, which can be used to craft a Solar Tablet.

Demonite Bars are a pre-Hardmode type of bars. They are crafted from Demonite Ore at a Furnace, and are The Corruption equivalent of The Crimson 's Crimtane Bars, representing the second-highest metal tier before Hardmode.

Crafting all Demonite equipment requires 130 Demonite Bars (390 Demonite Ore) on the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version and 118 Demonite Bars (472 Demonite Ore) on the Old-gen console version and Nintendo 3DS version.
The Wall Anchor is a wall decoration acquired by completing Angler NPC quests.

The Tax Collector's set is a Hardmode vanity set consisting of the Tax Collector's Hat, the Tax Collector's Suit and the Tax Collector's Pants. It is purchased from the Clothier for 9 GC (set) when the Tax Collector is present in the world.
These items are to be equipped in the Social Slots as they only provide a visual appearance.

The TV Head set is a vanity set consisting of the Video Visage, the Lazer Blazer, and the Pinstripe Pants. It is one of the six sets that were added as part of the Journey's End Vanity Contest ; the original concept was submitted by Dr.Zootsuit.
The Video Visage has the unique ability to change colors depending on where the player is and what they are doing.

The Crimslime is a Hardmode enemy and a slime variant that spawns in The Crimson. It spawns with either 85%, 100%, or 115% of its usual size, with the stats altered accordingly. In the Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it has a chance to inflict the Darkness debuff on contact.
Like most other slimes, the Crimslime will be passive towards any player with the Royal Gel (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) accessory equipped.

Plants are found all across a Terraria world, and may grow from certain block types given various conditions. Most can be harvested for use, and may additionally drop seeds for replanting, such as Jungle grass and Jungle grass seeds. Different biomes generally have distinct plant life.
Plants randomly grow overtime. They also have different growth speed in different layers. See below for details.

An alternative crafting ingredient is an item that can be used in place of another item in a crafting recipe. On this wiki, in the recipe section, substitutes are listed as " Any <groupname> ", or after an " or ", where it will list alternate item(s) that can be used. Below is a list of all potential alternative crafting ingredients. Note that while these items can be substituted in many recipes in which they appear, they may not be able to be substituted in all of them. See an item's page for details on which recipes an item can be substituted in.

A Jungle Sanctum was a structure that occasionally appeared in the Jungle. A Jungle Sanctum was a larger version of a Jungle Shrine, having the usual Ivy Chest containing Jungle-themed items, along with Coin Stashes and various placed furniture.

The Thunder Zapper is a pre-Hardmode magic weapon that launches a fast-moving, non-piercing projectile that is unaffected by gravity and will disappear with a visual explosion that does no damage after traveling for about one second or when hitting a solid block. The projectile moves up and down in a randomized zig-zag pattern horizontally, but not vertically (traveling straight when shooting directly up or down). The Thunder Zapper can be found in Sandstone Chests in the lower 3/7ths of the Underground Desert and in Oasis Crates and Mirage Crates obtained from fishing in the Oasis.
Its best modifier is Mythical.
The Etherian Wyvern is a flying enemy that spawns during the Old One's Army event. It spawns during Tier 1 during waves 4-5, Tier 2 during waves 3-7, and Tier 3 during waves 3-4.

The Etherian Wyvern passes through all solid blocks and flies about three tiles above the player or the Eternia Crystal before diving towards its closest target. This causes it to dip below the surface of blocks, making it somewhat difficult to hit without weapons that can attack through blocks. The Etherian Wyvern can attack approximately once every 1.5 seconds, and periodically lets out a screech as it is diving at a target. Additionally, Betsy can also summon a maximum of nine Tier 3 Etherian Wyverns during her roar attack.
The Etherian Wyvern requires 200 kills to be awarded completion of its corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Goblin Sorcerer is a pre-Hardmode enemy that spawns during the Goblin Army event. Approximately one out of every nine goblins will be a Sorcerer (11.11% chance to spawn). The Goblin Sorcerer fires three Chaos Balls in succession that travel through blocks before it teleports. The Sorcerer cannot fire and will not teleport when taking damage.
Mythril Brick is a mythril tier brick. Unlike Mythril Ore, Mythril Bricks are not immune to explosives.

Defense is a statistic that determines the decrease in damage taken per hit. The player's defense can be increased by wearing armor and accessories, and temporarily boosted/decreased by various buffs / debuffs. Enemies also have a defense statistic.

Defense cannot be reduced to below 0. Furthermore, the damage dealt to an entity will always be at least 1, regardless of defense (with the exception of a player whose multiplayer ally is wearing a Paladin's Shield).

Some forms of damage are impossible to reduce through defense, e.g. damage from damage over time debuffs like Cursed Inferno or from drowning in water. Damage taken from lava, however, can be reduced through defense.
Some items have the ability of armor penetration, which, in most cases, allows them to ignore some or all of the target's defense when calculating damage.

Living Fire Blocks are Hardmode animated background furniture blocks that, when placed, resemble small animated flames and emit faint orange light. They deal no damage on contact and can be freed with any pickaxe or drill. Living Fire Blocks have a 1/50 (2%) chance of being dropped by any enemy killed in the Underworld during Hardmode, including the Wall of Flesh, and drop in stacks of 20-50 at a time.

While Living Fire Blocks can be placed in a manner similar to traditional, foreground blocks, they are actually in the background, similar to furniture, allowing the player to walk directly through them. They can attach to each other horizontally as well as vertically, but other traditional, foreground block types will not attach to them.
There are five color variations of the base Living Fire Block, all of which are crafted from it. They are functionally identical.

A Phasesaber is a (Desktop, Console, Old-gen console and Mobile versions) Hardmode / (3DS version) pre-Hardmode broadsword which is a direct upgrade to the pre-Hardmode Phaseblade. It is very similar to its predecessor, except dealing about twice as much damage, being capable of autoswing, and having slightly modified visuals. As with Phaseblades, there are (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) seven / (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) six different color variations with identical statistics, with the color determined by the color of the Phaseblade used to craft it. All Phasesabers emit a small amount of light when swung.

Because Arch Demons (Old-gen console and 3DS versions) drop Crystal Shards on the Nintendo 3DS version and only a pre-Hardmode Anvil is required for crafting it, the Phasesaber is available pre-Hardmode on this version.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Guide to Peaceful Coexistence is a pre-Hardmode tool that combines the effects of the Guide to Critter Companionship and the Guide to Environmental Preservation, preventing player attacks from harming critters and breaking plants when placed within the inventory.

Pressing ⚷ Open / Activate on the Guide to Peaceful Coexistence in the player's inventory or hotbar will toggle it between the Guide to Peaceful Coexistence and the Guide to Peaceful Coexistence (Inactive), disabling its functions.

The Magnet Flower is an accessory that reduces mana usage by 8%, automatically uses Mana Potions when needed, and increases pickup range for Stars by 18.75 tiles. It will use the first available Mana Potion in the player's inventory when out of mana (from left to right and top to bottom).
The Magnet Flower has the exact same functional effects of both its component items.

Spears are a type of melee weapon that attack in a stabbing motion ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) like shortswords, but much slower and with much greater range) rather than a swinging motion. They are able to hit burrowing entities inside walls, including enemies and bosses such as the Wraith and the Eater of Worlds. Due to their slow animation, they can also hit more than once and penetrate enemies, making them quite powerful against large or clustered enemies. Because of this property, they are very effective against segmented worm -like enemies.
Spears are not capable of autoswing, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) unless the Feral Claws or any of their upgrades are equipped.
The best modifier for all spears is Godly or Demonic. Both modifiers increase their average damage output by the same amount.

Lightning Boots are an accessory that have essentially the same functionality as Spectre Boots, but with enhanced running speed. Its visual effects do not differ from the Spectre Boots.
They have an 8% movement speed bonus compared to the Spectre Boots.

The Sunflower is a large, tall plant which can be found growing naturally on grass, and can be broken with a pickaxe or drill, or by coming into contact with water. It cannot be grown from seeds like most other plants, but is instead placed fully-grown, either naturally upon world generation or by the player. It can also be purchased from the Dryad for 50 SC each, while a Blood Moon is not occurring.

Sunflowers can only be placed on regular, Hallowed, (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Jungle, or (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) Ash grass, at any height. They cannot be placed on Corrupt grass, Crimson grass, Mushroom grass, bare Dirt Blocks, nor in Clay Pots or Planter Boxes.

Sunflowers grant the Happy! buff to players in their vicinity, increasing their movement speed and reducing enemy spawns. Furthermore, they serve as a small barrier against the spread of the Corruption / Crimson and Hallow, negate some of the effects of the evil biomes, and help preventing Graveyard (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) biomes from forming.

The Shiny Stone is an Hardmode, post- Golem accessory that increases the rate of health regeneration slowly over time when the player is not moving or using any tools or weapons. The Shiny Stone is always dropped from Golem 's Treasure Bag in Expert Mode.

The health regeneration slowly increases from roughly 10 health gained per second to roughly 40 health gained per second (for players with enough health capacity to recover for that long). A yellow particle effect over the player signifies that the boost is engaged, which also emits a good deal of light from the player onto the surrounding area.

Web Covered Chests can be found in Spider Nests, though they are rare. They always contain a Web Slinger, in addition to common or uncommon items (also found in Gold Chests) depending on the height they were found: Underground or Caverns.

The Medusa Head is a Hardmode magic weapon that continuously fires close-range yellow beams up to four times per second, hitting up to three enemies per attack within a short radius of the player. 15 mana is consumed per each attack, regardless of the number of enemies struck. No mana is consumed if the Medusa Head is used while no enemies are within range. The Medusa Head has a 1/25 (4%) chance of being dropped by Medusas.
Its best modifier is Mythical.

The Basilisk is a Hardmode enemy found in the Underground Desert biome. The Basilisk attacks by charging quickly towards the player while being highly resistant to knockback. It drops 1 to 3 Sturdy Fossils and has a rare chance to drop the Ancient Horn, which summons a mount version of the Basilisk.
The Lamp Post is a piece of furniture that emits light. It can be placed underwater and can be toggled with wires.
On Desktop version, Console version, and Mobile version, it counts as a light source for housing while on Old-gen console and 3DS versions, it does not.

The Rune Wizard is a rare Hardmode caster enemy that is found in the lower Cavern layer. Upon spawning, he will proceed to fire magical Rune Blast projectiles at the player that penetrate terrain, similar to the Fire Imp 's Burning Spheres. However, unlike Burning Spheres, the Rune Wizard's projectiles cannot be destroyed in any way. He will teleport to a new location after firing six projectiles, and will always drop the Rune Hat and Rune Robe upon death.

It is one of the few entities that can be detected by the Lifeform Analyzer (Desktop, Console and Mobile versions) or its upgrades. The Rune Wizard requires 10 kills to be awarded completion of his Bestiary entry and corresponding banner, as opposed to the usual 50 kills.

The Damage Booster is one of the three power-ups occasionally dropped when striking enemies while wearing a full set of Nebula armor. When picked up, it grants the Damage Nebula buff which immediately provides the player with a 15% damage boost for 8 seconds. When a Damage Booster is picked up while the Damage Nebula buff is already in effect, it stacks with the previous Damage Nebula, for up to 3 stacked boosts. Every 8 seconds, one stacked Damage Booster expires, and the Damage Nebula buff decreases by one level.
Damage Boosters, like all Nebula boosters, float in the air and have a pickup range of 8.875 tiles. They cannot legitimately appear in a player's inventory.

Teleportation allows the player to get to a certain location on the map without moving. Teleporting is useful to save traveling time, and may be used to quickly get to a home or safety bunker. For example, if the player has defeated the last of the Celestial Pillars, and the Moon Lord is about to spawn, they can quickly teleport back to their arena.

The general trend is that players need to teleport to a more-or-less prepared or fixed place, especially their spawn point (Magic Mirror/Cell Phone/Shellphone, Recall Potion/Potion of Return).  Other "world" destinations include the two Oceans and perhaps the center-point of the Underworld (via the Magic and Demon Conch). Later, Pylons and Teleporters provide two separate ways for players to make a network of chosen destinations. The Rod of Discord and Harmony allow short-range teleportation to anywhere on the screen, and in the endgame the Portal Gun adds its own idiosyncratic short-range options.

The Mushi Ladybug is an enemy that spawns in Glowing Mushroom biomes, both on the surface and below-ground in Hardmode, but only on the surface in pre-Hardmode. The Mushi Ladybug's high health and damage, quick movement, and ability to fly short distances place them among the more dangerous enemies that can spawn before Hardmode.
The Flymeal is a pre-Hardmode sword with the unique ability to damage friendly NPCs. It also inflicts the Stinky debuff for 5 seconds, although this effect is purely cosmetic.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

The Hook is a crafting material used solely to craft the Grappling Hook. It has a 1/25 (4%) chance to drop from Skeletons, Undead Miners, Hoplites, and Undead Vikings in the Marble Caves, Ice biome, and Cavern layer. It also has a 1/30 (3.33%) chance to drop from Piranhas in the Jungle, Underground Jungle, Cavern, and Underground layer.

The Dart Pistol is a Hardmode ranged weapon that autofires darts as ammunition, and is the Crimson counterpart to the Corruption 's Dart Rifle, with a higher rate of fire but lower damage. It has a 1/5 (20%) chance of being dropped by Crimson Mimics.
Its best modifier is Unreal.

The Glow Tulip is a pet-summoning item that spawns a Caveling Gardener to follow the player around. When the player is far enough away or in midair, it flies through solid tiles while holding onto a Snare Plant in order to catch up to them. The Glow Tulip can be found rarely near the left and right edges of the world below the Surface as a plant. Depending on world size, a set amount of Glow Tulips will spawn during world generation: 2 in small worlds, 4 in medium worlds, and 6 in large worlds. Half of them are usually generated on the left side and the other half on the right side of the world.
It can also be detected by the Metal Detector.
The Palladium Column is a building material crafted from Stone Blocks and Palladium Ore. It is essentially the Palladium Ore's equivalent of a brick.
The Tin Broadsword is an early game metal broadsword. Its alternate ore counterpart is the Copper Broadsword.
As with all broadswords, this sword swings in an arc, which is more useful for killing flying and jumping enemies than shortswords.
Its best modifier is Legendary.

Ballista Panic! is a buff that increases the fire rate of Ballista sentries. This lasts for 5 seconds, but can be canceled at any time  by right-clicking the icon,  by selecting the icon using Cycle Next/Previous Buff and then pressing Remove Buff, or  by double-tapping the buff icon. The buff is granted whenever the player takes damage and has Squire armor or Valhalla Knight armor equipped.
The sentries' attack cooldown is reduced from 3 seconds to 1 second. If the player is wearing the Valhalla Knight armor, it is reduced from 1.67 seconds to 0.5 seconds.

Flarefin Koi are a type of pre-Hardmode ((Desktop, Console and Mobile versions)) / Hardmode ((Old-gen console and 3DS versions)) fish which are found very rarely by fishing in any biome in any layer, but only in lava. They are used to craft Seafood Dinners and Inferno Potions.

Giant Glowing Mushrooms are similar to Trees, but grow randomly in Glowing Mushroom biomes when enough space exists. They can be chopped down with an axe, which yields Glowing Mushrooms and, less often, Mushroom Grass Seeds. Giant glowing mushrooms also give off light, similar to Mushroom Grass and Glowing Mushrooms.

Giant Glowing Mushrooms grown in surface and underground biomes each have distinct graphics: Underground versions grow with plain, straight stalks, while Surface versions can display more complex branch formations.
They have similar requirements as trees:
